release accused called l scipio father pompey putteth mo ning vv lawe pompey like iudgement corruption wherefore pompey putting garment condemned sort many iudges like memmius contempt pompey taketh selovve state gaue ouer accusation pompey hauing made direction belonged monarchi toke scipio selowe rest yeare hym though others receiued office neuerthelesse ouerloked ruled rome goodsenate estemeth pompey wil senate much enclined despite caesar consulship seeking priuate pleasure seemed make none accompt pompey quickly recouered sicke comon wealth without molesting h dring man furder office banished menban flye caesar fledde still caesar bad beware pompey law corruption made caesar comforte yet sayde well pompey laboured tribune make lawe might lawfull caesar aske seconde consulship hys absence pompey beyng yet office resistyng graunted yet vnderstandyng senate worke fearyng enemy would make pryuate man deuised keepe strength still till declared consul requested senate little longer tyme hys office fraunce least parte marcellus marcellus consull pompey agaynst whiche tolde caesar layde hys hande vpon hilte sworde say answeared thus shall gyue ansvvere caesar he buylded newe como night vnto alpes priuiledges italie whiche many officer yeere shall cittizens rome whiche greate prerogatiue italie one newe como thus borne office thereby thought free rome marcellus despight caesar diddispight marcellus beate roddes whiche romaine doe suffer formo cause rage bewraying harte bad take token hospitalitie goe shewe caesar spight vsed marcellus perswaded sende successours prouincesmarcellus time expyred pompey agaynst vnder shewe conueniencie beneuolence pompey pretendeth regarde caesar meete noble man many wayes profitable hys countrey shoulde thus maligned shorte tyme decreed tyme caesar shoulde gyue ouer hys rule caesar chiefe enimies chosen consul aemilius paulus calidius marcellus cousin paulus c vvon money former marcellus curio greate enimie caesar elected tribune well beloued people great speaker caesar coulde winne claudius money paulus made hys friende hundered fiftye talentes shoulde neyther doe wyth hym hym coste win curio bycause muche debt wyth money paulus builded publique place called paulus palaice one fayre workes rome curio shoulde discouered change sodaine required office making pauing many long high wayes ouerseer fiue yeares togither knowing obtaine none trusting pompey friend would speake haue pretence popey thing coming passe indeed thought occasio offece claudius propounded send successours caesar prouinces time hand paulus said nothing curio seeming calidius question caesar propouded disset fro praised claudius opinion agreeing said meete pompey shoulde giue ouer prouince armye well caesar state citie bee cleare feare bothe side many right bicause pompey time yet expired curio shewed himselfe plainely sharply reason sende successours caesar vnlesse pompey giue ouer suspitious one citie shoulde neuer haue sure peace vnlesse men priuate thus spake bicause knewe pompey would leaue power bycause saw offended hys iudgementes corruption thys opinion beyng honest people praysed curio thethe people prayseth curio man common weale cared neyther displeasure brought home casting floures vpon champion great difficult cause tyme nothyng seemed daungerous dissent pompey senate passing italy somewhat sickely subtitlye sente vnto senate praysing caesar actes rehearsing owne fro beginning thirde consulshippe giuen hym prouinces army accordingly seeke called beyng thought meete redresse common wealth quoth receiued vnwillingly doe willingly giue ouer haue time prefixed manner writing wrought good lyking pompey misliking caesar woulde giue ouer time ended pompey come citie spake muche effect promised giue ouer friend welwiller caesar toke hand hee also would leaue glad mind yeares hauing taken greate paine army againste fierce nation wonne great honor countrey would seeke rest office sacrifice citie thus spake successours might straight sent caesar standing vpon promise curio correcting sutteltie sayd curio againste pompey ynough promise giue ouer deede caesar shoulde put armye priuate state neyther shoulde commodious mainteyne priuate e mitie neyther romaine suche power shoulde one rather eyther woulde hurt citie shoulde haue resist nowe holding longer openly reprooued pompey seeker tyrannie nowe gaue ouer hys army feare caesar would giue ouer therfore thought good disobeyed declared enimies army gathered talke couered corrupted caesar pompey greeued pompey departeth angry threatning went angerly away suburbes senate suspected thought pompey tractable caesar misliked bycause suspition hissenate better liketh pompey consulship therefore thinke safe dissolue pompey power vnlesse caesar resigne abroade aspiring mind curio expedient pompey caesar also giue ouer could obteyne brake vp counsell leauyng allthe authoritie tribune vnperfite might tribune wherfore pompey repented restored tribuneship auntient power sylla made sleder decreed departure caesar pompey shoulde sente siria e countrey bycause cross misfortune pompey v policie required legion againe lente caesar r lo se c tta hys captaynes gaue euery man two hundred drammes sent sente another hys owne beeyng vnderstanded danger syria went winter capua sente pompey caesar tolde many hard tale againste caesar made pompey beleeue caesar army wasted weer nesse long payne desirous come home come thys syde alpes would reuolte pompey thus talked eyther ignorance corrupted euery man surethe souldyers casar caesar promptnesse painefulnesse continuance seruice gaynes grewe victory warre greate liberalitie caesar himselfe hee gaue freely serue would haue knowing likewise abide pompey giuing credite tale neyther gathered armye prouided greate businesse senate requyre euery man opinion claudius crastely propounded dyd aske disioyntly whether woulde sende successor caesar whether would pompey power shoulde taken tation caesar pompey many made denyall caesar decreed successor curio asking agayne would haue leaue power x denyed ccclxx leauyng contention commoditie enclined curio sentence claudius dismisse counsell cry vvinne haue caesar lord rumor raysed caesar suddaynely past al commyng citie greate seare te sydes claudius commaunded armye copu se te againste caesar enimy curio reproued lye claudius sayde may followe ce common decree selfe consull doo sayde thus ranne senate house suburbes fellow offered sworde pompey euen quoth man commaunded thee goe caesar thy countrey giue thee eyther army nowe capua italie thou mayest gather togither thou wil obeyed commaunded consul onely adding vnlesse somewhat e better dissembling euen pretending shewe ho nie curio authoritie ouer citie lawfull tribune goe walles yet hee complayned people doings required consul proclayme man obey pompey gathering men preuayling time tribune shyppe drawing ende afrayde himselfe doubting able help caesar diligence went vnto nowe sayled oceane sea britiayne passed caesar deuided france germany old diu sion italy vvas r b con thereaboute french neere floud rhene mountaines alpes fiue thousande footemen three hundred horseme came rauenna cofine italy end prouince receiuing curio great curtesie thanking trauayles consulted present state curio thought good sende army march rome caesar thought better yet treate reconciliation willed friend compound giuing ouerrequest caesar prouinces army might onely reteyne two legion ill ria france within alpes till declared consull pompey thought sufficient bycause co suls resist wrote senate curio running three dayes three thousande three hundred furlong gaueafter accompt three hundred myles caesar letter senate letter newe consul entryng senate house fyrste daye newe yeare dyd conteyne solemne rehearsall caesar doyngs begynnyng protestation leaue hys armye pompey dyd lyke beeyng yet authoritie pompey woulde gyue vppe woulde forthwith come reuenge hys countrey wyth speede seeke hymselfe whyche euer e man cryed lucius domitius shoulde bee hys successourl domitius warre proclaymed domitius went foure lately gathered antonius cassius tribune curio determination caesar antonitus ca tribune liking well determination senate earnestly affirme army pompey theyr safetie caesar destruction marcellus lentulus consul commaunded antony cassius go assemblie least vsing office tribune mighte happily haue displeasure antonie cryed aloude ranne fro seate rage lameted yt deface office sacred antenie lamenteth sanctuary reiect despighte gyuen counsell common weale hauing committed offence crime man sayde lept man inspiration forespeaking warres murder attendures antonie prophecieth banishment spoyles mischiefe come vppon protesting greate execration cause curio cassius went parte pompey army seene come besette senate house secretely night putting seruants apparell went caesar hired wagon caesar shewed soone caesar shevveth tribun army come vnto army apparell stirre said men well made enimies person suche degree speaking somewhat thus villanously banished nowe warre open side proclaymed euidently senate thinking caesar would suddainely come army fro fre h woulde enterprise great feate fewe appointed pompey gather great number thessalian oldpreparation pompey againste caesar thessalia vvas countrey gre practised souldiers warre take vp new nigh nation fitte serue common treasure decreed warre offering also priuate substance neede ready seruice sent city moe great hast vehemencie leauing nothing vndone might speedy consideration caesar sendingspeedlinesse caesar owne army putting confidence amazing enimies suddaine approche terror boldnesse mighty preparation fiue thousande began greate caesar manner warre sent take comodious place italy certayne captaynes accompanyed boldest sorte peaceable manner willed goe arimeno suddaine surprise citie whiche firste italy france euening though bin well wentethen france extended mino vvhich novve part italy called rom g one colony ayded romaine annihall rubicon deuideth italy ouer vvhich passed armes vvas rebell caesar stayd riuer rubicon saying caesar caesar entreth italy caesar taketh arimeno feare caesar table leauing friendes sitting still takyng coach ranne arimeno horseman following certaine distace posting thus farre floud rubicon deuideth italie stayed course behelde riuer deepely waying mind mischiefe might followe passed water armes turned friend sayde refrayning passage shall beginnyng trouble selfe going shall vexe world thus said man rapte furie hee flong ouer speaking common word die cast hasted arimeno tooke earely morning wet forward leauing garrison conuenient place way wanne eyther violence gentlenesse eeing renning away euery place muche feare remouing without reason lamente yet knowing truth supposing caesar come inuade might power consulsthe consul suffer pompey take right course vvarre heard suffering pompey take stayed way warre according skilfulnesse forced go italie make men citie haue bin taken senatoures hearing caesar suddaine approche beyonde opinion afraide bycause yet prepared griefe repented accepted caesar offer thoughte reasonable many monster token heauen afray god sente downetokens rayne bloud image sweate lightning fell vpon manye temple bule broughte forthe many fearefull token foreshew ouerthrow mutation common state supplication commaunded common calamity people remembring time si la marius cr ed cut caesar pompey giue ouer power way ceasse warre cice sent caesar reconciliation consul againste euery thing fauonius iested pompey word spake call woulde strike earthe foote fetche forthe army shall haue quoth wyll followe thinke griefe leaue rome rome italie neede place house strength libertie men wheresoeuer beare haue reuenged youre selues shall haue house ynough spake pompey threatning would tarry sticke leaue forsaketh land leue countrey streyght hee wente senate house citie tooke hys iourney capua armye consul followed tarried wyth greate doubte kepte nyghte togyther senate house daye come parte went followed pompey r io novv caesar followed domitius corfinio sent su essoure hauyng aboue foure thousande beseeged citie perceyuing domitius woulde flee away kepte gate tooke hym broughte caesas curteously receyued army yeeldyng vnto hym myghte bee encouraged suffered domitius vntouched caesar taketh eth h ie goe vvhere wyth hys money substance goe would thynkyng gentlenesse woulde haue tarryed wyth hym againste hym goe pompey thyngs beeyng thus done suddayne pompey wente capua brunduse passe ionian sea epirus novv al ia make hys prouision warre wrote nation lieutenant prince kyngs city euerye one speede coulde contribute thys warre dispatched speede pompey owne army spaine beeyng ready march occasion shoulde call legion pompey himselfe deliuered consul leade brunduse epirus streyght sayled ita safe dirrachium whiche towne men ignorance thynketh epid nu barbarian kyng called epidamnus buylded citie sea hi selfe called epidamnus hys nephewe hys daughter supposed bee nept e sonne buylded porte citie called dirr chium breethren dirrach made warre vpon h hercules commyng ile erithea ioyned parte lande wherevppon durachians coper one theyr countrey accompte hym founder denying dirrachos desirous hercules bycause god saye thys fyghte ionius sonne dirrachos slayne hercules chance hercules buryed hys body threwe sea myghte beare ioni phrg asia e name processe time certaine phrigians gote citie countrey people illiria called ta lantines whome another people illiria called liburnians lantines na wyth swift shyppes dyd spoyle theyr neerest neighboures thys thought romaine call theyr swift ship liburnius wherewyth gyue fyrste onset fighte sea driuen dirrachio liburnians cor yri e co gote helpe co cireanes valiante men sea expulsed liburnians corcirianes makyng mixt inhabitance taken greeke porte changyng name vnlucky called epid mu name old citie thucidides doth name yet name hath preuayled itt dides called dirrachium consul company came thys citie pompey abode brunduse gathered togither theconsuls ed rizzo rest army tarried shippes carried consul made towne strong keepe caesar walles euening tyde sayled hys company leauyng bo est souldyers defende towne whyche also nyghte sayled ouer wyth g winde thus pompey armye lefte italy sayled piro casar stoode doubt whyche way turne begyn warre seeyng well force euery syde flowed pompey feared army pompey spaine great expert least while followed fleeing enimie beset backehalfe therefore thoughte best trye fielde first iberia deuided power fyue partes lefte brunduse hidrunto tarento run luse hydrunto novve r tarentum sardinia pollio cato guieth place asinius pollio garrison italy sente quintus valerius get sardinia ile plentiful corne gote asinius pollio sente cicelie cato lieutenant asked hym whether authoritie senate people enter violently another man prouince aunswered lord italy sente cato aunswered agayne bycause would spare inhabitance woulde deferre reuenge till another time sayled corcyra pompey caesar came rome comforted people hope caesar rome promise stricken feare memorie sylla marius euill time said woulde vse curtesie enimies taken lucius domitius let go money vnhurt brake locke common treasure threatned death metellus tribune would caesar taketh treasure haue resisted tooke away money man dur touch layd vp inuasions france publike execratio stirre remoue vnlesse warre celtica caesar sayd haue ouercome frenche cel e haue deliuered citie execration hee made emilius lepidus gouernoure citie marcus antonius antonius tribune italy confederate army abroade hee sent sicilie curio succeede cato quintus sardinia cneus antonius illiria france within alpes appoynted licinius crassus commaunded two legion yong souldyers ready speede lye coastes tuscane venetian sea whome captaines sea hee sent hortensius dolabella hortensius dolabella caesar spain afranius petreius herda citie aragon floud ycor caesar hauing thus made italy strong pompey enter went spayne firste encountring afranius petreius lieutenantes pompey seemed weake ioyned togyther hande aboute citie erda caesar lay barraine rockey place fayne fetch hys caesar distresse victual passage riuer sypris sodayne floud came bare away bridge whereby great number lest straytes slayne petreyus caesar himselfe hys army much molested harde place hunger sharpe season enimies little better besieged til sommer came afranius petreyus went furder parte spaine gather another armye caesar preuented stopping passage compelled retyre whence came thys compassed parte army came take vp grounde theira token yelding campe helde shieldes heades token yelding caesar neyther toke hurt suffered caesar gentlenesse vntouched goe afranius meane wanne enimyes hart place hereof manye conuenticles among souldiers talke reconciliation whole multitude wherevppon seemed good afranius leaue spaine caesar depart safe pompey petreius agaynste ranne among souldiours killed made petreius furious metings caesar come killed one hys owne captaines also would haue stayed furye wherfore mindes inclined caesar gentle offended petreius passionate caesar kept water petreius necessitie came afranius parlee caesar army beholdyng agreede leaue spayne caesar shoulde conuey safe floud varus thence suffer goe pompey caesar come floude called romaine italian souldiours thus spake vnto enemyes vsing name shall better declare minde neyther dyd dyspatche sente gette ground campe yelded selues neyther dyd hurt parte army helde water although petreius distray myne toke floud sic rie haue thankes shewe al serue pompey campe thus sayd sent freely away appointed caesar hath spayne quintus cassius gouernement iberia thus caesar began lybia actius varus lieuetenant pompey iuba actius varus iuba taketh pompey parte king mauritania assist curio sayled sicelie two whole legion twelue galleyes many shippes burden landing vtica skyrmished wyth certayne numidian horseman put flight would needes called generall captaine army beyng yet imperator vvas terme latine generall entring armes honor giuen captaines name commeth souldiours witnesies worthy general thys honour captaines olde tyme obtained many great aftayres heare limitation thys title ouerthrowe tenne thousande men while curio comming shippe sicelie lybia thinking glorye name would encampe place called scipio tentes scipio tent e vvater poysoned one emulatio renoune poysoned water deceyued hope curio lodged army sicke drunk fight daseled cloude heuynesse sleepe head many curio armie infected vomites theyr meate shrincking ouer body wherefore curio remoued vtica selfe leading army feeble sickenesse great strong marish grounde heard caesar victory spaine toke courage agayne placed themselues nigh sea steyght waye foughte fiercely curio loosing one man var sixe hudred many moe wounded king iuba coming forth false rumour raysed floude bagrada farre returned backe bycause hys kyngdome inuaded hys neyghbours leauing hys licuetenaunt saburra wyth fewe floude curio gyuing credite thys tal seruente heate thirde houre day led vest parte armye saburras sandy deserte drye place winter brooke dryedthe distresse curio vp heate sunne floud kept saburra king himselfe yet still present curio ranne vp hill toppes choked thirst heate enimies sawe euill bestadde passed riuer boldely readinesse fyght curio vnwisely vnskilfully wyth weake army compassed numidian horseme came downe time gyuing place broughte menne within little compasse beyng ouercharged hee fledde agayne hyll toppes asinius pollio beginnyng thys businesse fewe fledde campe vtica least varrus shoulde attempte thyng noyse euill fortune curio made desperate fighte killed curio killed one left goe pollio vtica ende fighte floudde bagrada curio head cutte brought iuba mischaunce knowne army vtica flamma admirall fledde hys nauie hee receyued flamma lieth man lande asinius tooke boate wente merchauntes porte prayed receyue hys armie conuey away nighte came warde thys purpose souldiours wente suche number botes drowned vppon sea money merchauntes threwe couetousnessecouetise merchant thereof happe vppon sea whiche littell better lande lefte nyght mornyng yeelded var iuba came sette wall shotte death remnaunt romaine souldiours shotte death hys victorie nothyng regarding though varo prayde hym contrarie thus romaine loste twoo legion sayled curio libia horse minister venturer campe iuba returned home makyng boaste hee done greate feate hys friende pompey thys tyme antonius illyria ouercome octauius dalabella pompeyus lieuetenant another armye caesar placentia reuolte againste captaines cry holden long war payed fiue poundes caesar promised brunduse caesar hearing came poste massilia thus spake souldiours yet mutenie speede vse euery thing witnesse wyth warre holden long v enymies flyeth v fraunce mine autoritye haue gayned wel haue bounde selues al seditious souldiours warre parte nowe myddest matter forsake doe doe disobey captaines goe commaunde whome ought receyue commau dement wherfore sufficiente witnesse selfe former affection vnto nowe vse petreius law nineth legion whence tumulte chieflye arose wil put death tenth man greate lamentation made throughout whole legion wherefore captaines knee prayed hym pardon hardly length grauted came anye moste busie shoulde bee taken lotte twelue captaines bandes put death one twelue whiche presente medler thys mutenye caused hys accuser suffer hym sorte sedition placentia appeased caesar went rome people feare chose hym dictator neyther senate allowing none officer pronoucing hee refusing dignitye eyther odious superfluous ruling onely eleuen dayes say appointed consul reste tyme hymselfe seruilius isauricus president prouinces eyther appoynted altered hys pleasure marcus lepidus spayne aulus albinus sicelie sardania sextus peduceus newe france decimus brutus people opprest famine gaue victualls requeste pardoned al fugitiues except milo people desiring also cutting debte bycause thynges bare price reason war sedition denyed appointed purueyors victualls whiche steede debte shoulde take order betwene creditours ye debtore done sente hys army brunduse caesar maketh vvinter vvarre deade winter himselfe went forth december tarying election newe officer tyll newe yeare hand people followed prayed hym one pompey euident ouercame woulde ruler alone went lefte nothing done power speede pompey al tyme made ship still gathered greater army money tooke fortie caesar shippes ionian sea wayted coming exercised people ryding running among euery labor beyond olde yeares whereby got much loue euery man came see pompey exercise spectacle caesar tenne legion footemen ten thousand french caesar army horseman pompey hadde fiue legion hee alled oute pompey army italy many horseman appointed two parthia remnant serued crassus another part gabinius inuaded egipt italian eleuen legion seauen thousande horseman confederate ionia macedonia poloponeso boeotia wyth archer creta slinger thracia vse artillerie aboute pontus horseman weaste french east sirians sent antiochus cilicians capadocians armenia lesse pamphilia pisida al sight garrison munition seruices ye italian army thus thoughte good vse none italian shoulde drawne daye battell army land sea hee hadde syxe hundred gallies surnished ful whereof one hundred romaine conduct whyche hee appoynted leade many hulkes ship burden wyth dyuers admiralls whereof marcus bibulus chiefe al thyngs prepared assembled many senatours romaine gentleman present pompey os army place might harde thus said vnto athenienses also friend dydde leaue citiethe atheniens e citie pe sio fighte libertye agaynste spoyled thinkyng house men citie doyng whyche recouered againe shortly made mor glorious progenitor likewise frenche cel inuaded forsooke cittie cami u comming ardea ardea restore agayne wyse men thynke countrey liberty whyche wee consideryng haue sayled hither leauyng oure countrey preparyng mn lye defend againste doeth violently inuade corruption taketh italy desolated haue declared enimy sends president prouinces appoynteth gouernors citie som countrey thys insolencie hee hathe taken people authoritie doth yet contrition feare one god helpe shal bee punished crueltie violence thinke ye wyll hee leaue vndone thus vseth country get victorye take parte mony gathered fraunce belongeth chose rather bee slaue liue free v refuse fight offer selfe souldior captaine wyl vse mee haue experience war felicitie vnspotted hitherto pray god graunte mee al present defender vnto country danger haue bin aduancing wee oughte putte oure trust god cause hath honest iust desire war common wealth countrey abundance prouision sea land whiche already haue shal haue take thing hand al nation man may say fro east ruxine sea al grecias barbarian v al king friend romains haue sente army weapon vittails al necessary therfore go cheerefully thing worthy countrey selues mind ul g sar dispitefulnesse speede fulfil shal appointed said al army many senator gentleman greate goodly c one voice praise hym praied hym leade thought good set ship keepe sea sente army winter macedonia thinking caesar woulde deser p dece c sayling ouer till winter tyme harde sea rough haue remayned rome bycause consull settle hys rule far amisse coniecture come caesar sayd midst winter go brunduse supposing amaze enimies commyng sodayn therfore neither hauing victuall prouision army called present assembly thus said vnto hys sould neither hardenesse tyme friend ioyne wyth mee moste noble enterprise neyther delay others want conuenient preparation doe wythdrawexpedition purpose surely thinke expedition best way firste go first matter seruants carriage baggage thinke beste leaue behynde v shippes bee nowe may receiue v passenger deceiue oure ennimies sette good fortune againste euil tyme bold courage agaynste smal number ennimies plenty penury shall oure power wee thinke nothing shall winne force let v go therfore againste slaues prouision victualles while house feare winter weather lette v goe while pompey trust spende winter shewes sacrifice consull knowe take chiefesteattempts day point w rres attempt sodayne honourable preuent first opinion f thyngs come foresee receyt folow v next haue thoughte thys time meeter hast stay pompey think yet rome aboute consulship may see hys cam thoughe wel assured youre good willes yet tarry answere army cryed great vehemencie hee leade forth came hys seate sea fiue legion footemen sixe hundred horse men chosen lying anker bycause roughe sea winter sunne lowest winde kepte ved vveather hym backe agaynste hys euill content tarryed brunduse till first day newe yeare came hym two legion whome conueyed ouer winter hulkes hadde fewe gallies lefte custody sicelie sardinia tempest driuen mount cer uno whence sent hys nauy backe fe reste hys army night went citie ori ori hard straighte rocky way compelled diuide army many partes sharpenesse countrey myghte serue hys commyng beene knowne hee might easily haue bin kept backe aboute breake day muche ad gathered army togither people citie saide vnto gouernor hath citie ches lawfull keepe oute romaine consull came therfore gouernour delyuered keyes caesar continued wyth hym place honor lucretius minu ius side orico wyth eighteen gal guarde victuall came shippe pompey drowned ship caesar shoulde take fled greeke durazzo orier caesar went appolonia receyued citizen stamerius gouernour left citie caesar calling hys souldiors togyther putte membraunce done good fortune harde durazzo hathe long turkes lately vvas gotten winter lord sea without shippes hadde wonne orico valona without fight gotten enimies thing pompey yet ignorant nowe sayeth wee catch durazzo whiche baron pompey prouision al handes haue bin labouring whole sommer sayd thus ledde wyth speede durazzo long way resting neyther day ne nyg te pompey hearyng came great hast macedonia cutting h th downe tree went stoppe way caesar hee pulled downe bridge burnt prouision way thynking deede good deuice haue onely preparation mighte serue himselfe dust fyre smoke seene eyther farre thinking bin contrary part stroue shoulde runne fastest sparing time neyther meate sleepe hast speede cry vpon ledde torchelightes whereof grew disorder feare en mies b n heeles weerinesse threw downe burthen withdrew themselues aside corner thinking better lefte behinde present rest goe withoute feare enimie side taking paynes pompey came firste durazzo encamped walles pompey durazzo caesar getteth agayne ori alore floude nauie gote orico agayne gaue better guard sea caesar lay ouer pompey floud alore slowing betweene diuers skirmish passed floud neuer broughte forthe whole power pompey trayne yong souldyers caesar looked rest brunduse thoughte came forthe spring greate shippes could escape galley pompey scowred sea wayted come forthe winter enimie must many tymes take ilands harborough might escape winde waighte mighte passe vpon sente great hast bycause came looked purposed himselfe goe woulde soone come kepte determination secrete sente three seruants floud twelue furlong hire swifte vessell good proofe one dispatched caesar rose table well c st ad friend sitte still put tuate gar el co ch came ship f ca rest eth seruantes call beingcaes wrapt night altogither vnknowen wind rough seruaunts exhorted maister make hast might escape enimies hand maister passed u speedily strength oares whe came mouth floud waues ye sea beating boisterous billowes though enim folowed labouring ye vtter nothing preuailed gaue quite ouer caesar b wraid said alowd bold himselfe stand storme thou caryest caesar caesar fortune marriners amazed ye voyce receiued courage againe force gote ship floudes mouth rage ye sea billowes bigge ship driuen ye shore day drawing neere marriners afrayd spyed enimies caesar cursed enuious fortune bade shipmaister turne home againe quickly done wind seruing floud blamed caesar bolddesse accused taking thing scarcely fitte asor blamed caesar sendeth men souldiour much lesse generall nowe perceiuing could vnknowen sent posthumus sayle place bid gabinius bring army sea refused come antonio caleno fayled heeantonio letter rest folow posthumus take land could g care ship neede men ship thus caesar trust fortune contrary reason pompey inteding take ye aduantage broughtone caesar killeth tvvo pompey forth people fight two souldiers passing ye floud lowest one caesar came againste kylled wherfore pompey retired liking lucke feyning pompey retireth al lose good oportunitie posthumus sayled safe brunduse gabinius obeying ye comandement would needes gabinius loseth men slauonia leade many followed slauonia withoute anye rest almost slayne rians caesar suffered necessitie time antonius shippe brought toward valona good full winde midday caesar shippes n nesse winde waxing c twenty pompey ship scoured sea e yed came vpon calme great feare least ste ne gadyes bore drowne vsing best way made ready dart sings keepe suddainely greater wind first arose whiche tooke mame sayle passed beyond hope tossed ye storme w g raging sea scattered driuen rocky caesar taken falling vpon ye flat b ought rest place called nymphey caesar al pompey encamped one agaynst vpon ppes ing fort mountes assault skirmish one seking one skirmish caesar worse h souldier caesar vv nteth receyued hys prickes vvounds n bodye thys tyme another ce vvhen headpeece vvas broken e h rt rac thigh hys shielde st icken dovvne hys svvord broken lept sea armed vvas ca e safe caesar cry parce imperator bycause vvas fault bee vnarmed plutarch telleth another vvhe caesar vvas englande hee nameth one cil u nothing sayde nuti alian tr addeth e te caesar ca captayne notable valianttie se stru n eye dar done lept rank making toke though would haue saide somewhat called captaine pompey esteemed noble sayd vnto one lyke thee saue thy friende send may leade away bycause hurt two men came running fugitiue whome one killed right cut shoulder hee doubt himselfe fort ashamed faulte came againe lustely recouered fort great valiantnesse also nuti trench keeper help much target say foud cxx dart wounded vj place beside losse one eye also th caesar honor great gif appert ining n souldiers thought haue treason night gate fewe temple diana thys winter pompey father law bring another army syria whome caius cal itius encouter losing legion eyght hundred caesar nothing sea kepte pompey naues wherefore h armye great want eate bread made grasse weedes certayne fugitiues shewed pompey good token hee vv ioyed nothing sayde beastes doe e sigh caesar driuen necessitie broughte forthe ar force pompey fighte though many ca refuseth ight thereby abandoned yet would stirre whe maruellously greeued tooke hand enterprise difficult strange enuiron pompey ca sea sea great thing ke notthe enterprise caesar place yet carrie fame glory noble enterprise thousande two hundred furlong yet ight furlong waketh myle tooke hand pompey made contreworkes walles thus busied themselues defeate last great fight betweene pompey hisa fight valiantly euerthrow caesar souldioures followed fleeyng campe tooke many ensignes eagle chiefe standerd romaine much ado saued bearer regarde throwne caesar repulsed trench fleeyng notorious caesar came another company whiche lesse afrayde though pompey good way yet could abide sighte stayfeare caesar n though hard camp neyther goe order obey caesar commaundements euery one fledde whether hee could neuer looking backe without shame without commaundemente reason caesar ranne rebuke shewe pompey farre beheld threw downe ensignes fledde muche adoe stoode still men amazed looking ground shame confusion fall vpon one turned ensigne thrust poynt againste generall killed caesar gard yt went camp returne place left forsaken trenche vnkepte thoughte pompey come forth power made end warre ye one feate lauinius god working persuaded rather pursue fledde pompey victory follovved somewhat slow himselfe peraduenture distrustyng traynes hadde bin layde campe bycause condemned though warre nowe ended set vpon yet abroade whereof kylled many daye two sightes tooke eyght twenty banner leaning occasion mighte haue made ende caesar could denye day ended warre enimies could haue vsed victory pompey victory sente letter king city ughte caesar souldioures would haue reuolted vnto essed famine ouerthrowe fighte captaynes feare offence god entan e lamented faulte wh gently gaue pardon themselues mutation beyond countrey manner takerepentance caesar souldyers kill euery tenth man caesar w hat greeued con insured cryed punished though shoulde haue ders turned caesar would grant punished fewe fashion whereby caesar mildnesse punishmente great ge moderation entred de red woulde forthwith set vpon enimies earnestly exhorted encouraged promising amend fault notable victory resorted togyther heapes sware caesar syghte neuer returne fielde vnlesse gette fyghte friendes wyshed hym vse thys repentance promptnesse armye hee sayde vnto multitude woulde better oportunitie leade againste enimies badde remember thys forwardnesse hys friend sayde dyd must take theyr heartes feare late losse tarrie tyll fiercenesse enimie abated dyd confesse erred placing campe dirrachio pompey preparation behoued hym seeke caesar remoueth place draw pompey myghte haue lyke wante sayd wente straighte ona thence th s secretely night g e little e g phie giuen spoyle firste city th ssily going fro piro woulde receyue tooke rage g ue souldyers spoyle souldyers bin long filled themselues thing excessiuely r e germanes caesar time drunke people measure especiallyth germanes ted atfor dr nesse againe thought pompey g e haue come done notable fea e negligence iterly om te stirre till caesar marched seaue ay camped pharsalia gomphie say seene notable caesar encapeth pharsalia pompey arriueth razzo vvilling death diuers gomphie chance dead bodyes noble old men e openly hr an shoppe cuppes hand without wound number twenty though hadde bin mu ed king lying vpon ground one g chayre phisition gaue po execration pompey made counsell concerning caesar ing nius nius opinion na great sent caesar lord sea ghte thing hym want wandring iourney pompey hymselfe leade army lande italy whiche yet enclyned vnto voy e enimyes lorde france spaine mighte deale caesar home principall parte neglecting sdiuersitie ion bin best haue bin done followed said caesar army would forsake famine long lyke hold victory wonne urazzo whereas trarywise great shame leaue caesar fleeyng ouercome seme flee hough ouercome giuing place reason regarde nation east depended vpon hym fearing least luci scipio receyue harme cedoni hauing mind vse army couragious fight remoued set camp caesar caesar pompey encamp pharsalo pharsalo foure mile asunder pompey victual brought fro euery place war porte storehouse open vnto land lacked nothing sea whatsoeuer winde blewe seruedabundance vvith pompey turne caesar adde onely suche foode ulde get dayly forcevvant vvith caesar courage caesar ldiours yet n di forsake diuine instinct required g te gyue tell thinking themselues farre better th yo g souldyoures bycause serue w e u e yeares togither spende tyme making mountes treaches cariage victuallthe request caesar souldioures weaker bycause theyr age therefore better trye la oure idlenesse punishe famine pompey vnderstoode thought daungerous deal wyth suche experse men cared themselues aduenture one worke againste caesar ob e fortune thought ii sur r lesse dagerous co sume wtth wante hauyng power releeued land vse sea shyppe conuey themselues pompey confideration good follovved away neede thus hee determined good reason delay warre drawe famine famine greater number senatoures calle gentleman honored kyngs prince lacke experience foolishe hardynesse theyr victory durazzo bycause greater number bycause woulde r ther haue short conclusion honorable ende bycause weery warre exhorted fyghte shewyng caesar dyd alwayes prouoke hym inuite hym dyd vse reason themselues caesar necessary doe delay til occasion muche better neede droue caesar doe hee dyd beeyng styll incensed armye waxed proude victorye durazzo best sorte obiected ambition vnto hym therefore purpose slowe hee myghte beare rule ouer many good pompey called agamemnon hymselfe therevppon called kyng agamemnon bycause hee commaunded kynges warre hee left hys owne consideration gaue place theires god striking rest warre grew pompey alteration sickly slowe contrary nature thing vnwillingly prepared fighte owne destruction gaue hym counsell caesar nyghte hadde sente three legion gette victual thanking pompey delay thynking would haue changed hys minde also sente aboute foode hearde pompey prepared battell knewe dyd necessitie dryuen force armye hee called hys armye forth wyth dyd prepare lykewyse midnight made sacrifice mar venus hys auncessors iulius petigree caesar venus sonne shoulde seeme name house iuli came vowed dedicate temple vnto hir rome fauoured hym broughte hym victorie lightning came heauen wente caesar cam lightning pompey extinct pompey syde thoughte notable thyng shoulde come enimies caesar dyd expounde shoulde quenche pompey glorye nyghte pompey sacrifice host fledde away coulde found swarme bee lightedtokens vpon aulter whyche little stinging flye daye came straunge feare campe th whyche pompey came searche fell deepe sleept beeyng awaked friendes hee tolde dream dedicate temple rome venus victorice pompey dreame knowyng caesar hadde vowed friendes host put trust thinges glad vsed thinges muche contempte fiercenesse wente thys battayle though bin theyr owne many dyd decke tentes bayes token victorie seruauntes prepared good cheere dyd contende caesar officethe securitie pompey army hygh priest pompey man experte warre dyd mislike though troubled yet dissemble helde peace doubt feare nowe dyd rule commaunded bycause force againste hys wyll al thing great discouragement noble man til day alwayes prosperous hap seemed sodaine fall vppon hym eyther followed hee gaue good counsell pompey l tion driuen put liues many hazarde owne glory kepte till day vnspotted diuination euil wyth feare hande day shoulde fall great lordship onelye hys friend thus sayde whosoeuer victorye day shoulde cause great calamitie romains euer set order battell hys wordes hee spake feare many dyd gather wonne day would haue gyuen ouer rule number whereof manye speake vncertainely caesar number followe romaine authours write pompey nuber reasonably italian whome chiefe truste regardyng speakyng much confederate little affiaunce caesar two twentye thousande aboute thousand horse pompey double many seauen thousand horse speake likely say thys battel lxx italian write lesse threescore thousand make moste foure hundred thousande whereof saye pompey three part three part two thus doubtfully haue left matter many soeuer chiefe trust italian straungers caesar french horseman also french men beyond alpes grecian dolopians acarnians aetolians helpes caesar pompey al nation easte heap horseconfederates pompey footemen grecian hadde lacedomonians distributed vnder owne kyngs reste peloponesians boetians athenienses also came thys warre althoughe side proclaymed shoulde hurte sacred men lawe maker drawn thither glory battayle wherein fyghte empire romaine greek fewe sea towarde east inhabitours came pompey thracian hellespontians bithinians phrygian jonians lydian pamphilians pysidianes paphlagonians cilicians syrian pheniteans nation hebrewes arabian also mgh vnto cyprian rhodians stinger creta ilanders kyngs prince also came ayde hym de ota u tetrarche ariarathes easte galatian ariarathes king capadocia armenian wythin euphrates taxiles leade armenian beyonde euphrates magabates lieutenaunte artapa kyng inferiour lordes resorted thys trauayle beside threescore shippes egipt sente prince cleopatra hir brother yet childe notcleopatra vsed warres anye shippes laye ydely corcyra wherein seemeth pompey euill neglect great nauy wherewyth hee myghte haue feated hys enimies al thynges trusted vpon hys armye land woulde trye wyth theyr continuaunce wyth long experience full courage sauage people greedy fight beware mishap god workyng durazzo seemeth bee impediment caesar fitteste opportunitie pompey army waxed insolent made little accompte capitayne tooke hande thys matter verye vnskilfully god hadde appoynted shoulde come suche state nowe ouer eyther assemblyng theyr armyes exhorted firste pompey said thus fellow souldioures commaunde captaynes obey souldiours wheras would haue consumed caesar wyl needes call vpon fyghte therfore appoynters battayle vse may lesse vanquisher contemne vanquished yong despise olde lusty may feeble haue youre syde power preparation conscience cause trauaile libertye country law good opinion men bee senatours gentleman agaynste one man woulde vsurpe gouernment go therfore becommeth good hope haue sight fleeing away made durazzo howe many ensignes tooke day saide pompey caesar hys men spake thus hardest friend haue ouercome steade caesar oratic hunger wante fight wyth men day determineth remember promise durazzo sware one another presence woulde returne victor souldioures whome wee haue followed pillers hercules bee fledde v italy oure tenne yeares seruice many enimies victory harde bee tolde wonne v spayne fraunce britaine broughte v oure countrey well nighe fourtye realmes doth oppresse v without rewarde triumphe recempence whome coulde perswade desiring ryghte wel thought well knowe whome delyuered vnhurte hoping might haue iustice handes togither reuengers thys day euen knowe carefulnesse faithfulnesse free liberalitie harde matter yong souldiours vnexperte ouercome paine haue past well bin tried proofe se youthfull contempte dy ayne armye agaynste capitayne distruste hymselfe whome certainlye knowe goe thys feate vnwilling minde ful feare fallyng hys condition giuen case slouthfulnesse nowe ruler ouerruled thus much thinke haue spoken vnto italian cofeder t care make accempte offer anye earneste fyghte slaues syria phrygia lydia euer ready run away kept vnder certayn ye knowe shall euidently see pompey wyll vse ordered place osbatta le ye haue italian confederate ru e vppon like r ggs downe spare youre men vse confederats afray al thing remember maye see persourme haue promised maye choose eyther victorye eathe pull downe youre campe trench wee may haue nothing vnlesse wee wynne lette oure enimies see without campe necessitie wee muste encampe theyrs thus saide hee sente oute two thousande verye olde souldiors charge campe wit forthe digged downe trenche wyth deepe silence filled ditch pompey sawe thoughte made way flee perceyued bolde determination syghe pompey sigheth sayde vnto hymselfe thys fyght wild beast oppressed famin fit medicine dallying thing come swordes pointe therefore set aboute foure thousande keepe campe pla ed reste betweene towne pharsalo floude pharsalo tovvne vvhere battel thesisaiy italian h c c strength side enipeo caesar also arayd hymselfe ouer agaynste hym eyther placed italian diuided three partes distaunt little sunder sette horseman sydes portios archer slinger intermedled thus italian ordered whome eche chiefe confidence confederats v rather shew pompey greate number dyuerse language placed macedonian peloponesians boetians athenienses nexte italian battayle bycause theyr good order silence euen caesar coniectured commaunded euerye rder natio selfe warder ray battel compasse enimie fight began pursue much hurte coulde put caesar campe spoyle whiche voyde defence scip pompe father lawescipi aphranius pompey leade maine batayle middest dom lefte wing lentulus right aphranius pompey kept cape leader caesar h ste sylla antonius decimus caesar wonte ledde tenth legion whiche caesar order sylla antonius decimu caesar enimies seyng brought agaynst beste horseman beyng number shoulde might encompasse caesar perceyued layd three thousand boldest footemen abushment whome willed sawe enimie goyng aboute enclose shoulde leape forth pike driue harde could face knew yong vnexpert would abyde peril face thus denise bothe side went euery place gyuen order exhorted good hart gaue wordes knowledge caesar venus conqueresse pompey hercules vnconquered ready stoode good whyle great silece stirred looked one vpo amazed men shoulde beginne fight multitude hytherto compassion pitied greate armie italian hazarded vertue shoulde bee tried vpon themselues chiefe hurte italian astonishment bothe army aga nst italian pynche mischiefe hande desire glory sed blinded quenched conuerted feare reason dyd throughly way affection fame measured also daunger present sawe cause consisted contentio two men whose superioritie liues ventured whither euercome coulde safe furdest place great multitude noble men theyr sake remembred auncient friendship affinitie howe many thing done owne honour aduancement weare weapos theselues brought serue like mischiefe one nation citizen kin cmen ally yea brother hapned warre among many thousand togither one nation diuerse straunge effectesthe strange abashment side must happe whiche eyther nowe considering striken presently great repentaunce though day eyther first last vpon earth loth beginne doubtful deede fell weeping side standing thus beholding one another daye passed italian standing due order silence continued pompey perceyuing straungers troubled stay doubting least confusion might follow therof beginning first gaue token battayle caesar like trumpet stroke sounde battayle required number beside sundry part herald captaines hand giue encouragement marched stately astonishment silence men ben many like pastime hand first charge wasthe nset giue giuen archer artillery soden onset horseman enclose footemen fro til pompey horseman hauing better enuiron tenth legion caesar giuing token lay wayte stepped forth horseman theyr pykes put vp lay face could abyde boldnesse blowes made theyr mouthes eye confusedly fled away caesar horseman enclose footemen naked whiche feared haue bene enclosed themselues whe pompey percepued thys commaunded footemen moue stirre battaile throw light weapon stand distante forefront pykes han e resist enemy comming prayse pollicie best compassing caesar epistle doth disprayse bycause stroke giuen mouing vehemence mightier men forcing foreward bolder ye remayne stil ware fearefull easie bitte standing markes shotte proued deed tenth legion fiercely folowing beat body pompeis leaft battayle voyde horseman standing still till put order force made turne beginning ye victorie multitude although diuerse sundrye wayes slaughter hurting yet voyce hearde suche maine battayle sighes grones fell valiauntlye theyr place appointed confederate though come see fight pryse maruel goedly order harte wondering neyther enter caesar campe kept fewe olde men thing stande gaze lefte wing pompeis host retire little little yet fighting stil pompey consederates flec confederate foully fled away cryed ouercome ranne vpon owne tentes campes thoughe bene others whiche spoyled went way fast could italian army perceyuing worse gaue backe first order defending themselues might enemye still comming vpon hauing victorie also turned fle caesar vsed great policie gather togither caesar poli e labor might make end one fight al war sent trupets battels comaunding refrayn fro killing countreymen continue agaynst stranger go among vvord stay stay vvithout feare wer ouercome byd stay wtout feare declaratio crier lerned fro one another warning word popeis host stay wtout fear passing italia one laguage order beat stranger able resist ther gret slaughter made popey saw pompey ama ed speachlesse ax telamonius fell astonishment iudgement giue alteratio astonyed went softly cape come tent sat speechlesse say aiax telamonius grief suffered losse amog enimies battayle troy came cape caesar herald made stay wtout feare ouerpassed enemy might disperse selues day almost ende caesar roade aboute maruelous payne praying woulde take yet exhorting make nd little labour til gotten pompeis campe shewyng emmy returned winner one day got campe warre shoulde ended cuer held vp handes first ranne towarde stirre mindes weary body see generall go victorie thing past hope gette campe al stic againe men hope felicitie feele lesse labour extremitie went great courage beate away warder whiche pompey sawe onely brake thys pompey fleeth speache hys long silence oures tentes hee thus spoken chaunged hys garment leapt horse feure freendes neuer lefte runnyng till breake day came larissa caesar threatened giuing ar s place onset lodge pompeis pauilion supped prouision rest hys army lyke slayne battell bothe partes italian stranger bicause multitude contempt numbred caesar arraye thirtie captaynes bandesthe losse cc souldiours say two thousand ij hudred pompey tenne senatours whiche lucius domitius pompey lo e p x death xxv taking e r ite appoynted caesar successour fraunce called gentleman fourtie beste rest army make moste say xxv asinius pol fight caesar wryteth onely fire thousande pompey slayne battayle ende great fight ha sa euery man cusessed caesar deserued firste seconde honour enth legion crastinius leader bande thought worthy thi de goyng fight asked caesar thought vered couragiou shall winne caesar shalte finde yther aliue r ea going band bande like man furie much might sought found amog dead pompey taketh ea mi ilena esb novv metelin caesar bury ornament due vnto erected tumbe nygh comon sepulchre popey fro larissa wyth lyke speede went sea side toke little boate chaunce met shippe floate sayled mitilena receyued wife cornelia passed foure gallyes pompey determination recouery rodians tirians brought refused sayle corcyra libya great army mighty nauy sea made course parthia thinking recouer al againe keping purpose close fro friend tyll came much ado ciluia prayed hym cornelia pompeis vvife crassus daughter beware parthian whiche lately ouercome crassus whereby insolent fit bring cornelia fayre woman among vntemperate people especially crassus daughter deuised whither go egipt iuba king barbarie thought good iuba therfore counselled go egipt nation nygh great dominion fertyl aboundant grayne money nauye whose king though child yet friend father sake cause sayled egipt time cleopatra eiected kingdome hir brother wt shoulde ioyntly haue raigned prepared army syria againste ptolomeus cleopatra brother crassus hil end nilus ptolomeus cleopatra place egipt called cassium lye campe resist sister force fortune wold pompey driue thither perceiued army aland stayed ship thought deede king hee sent vnto shewe amity betweene hys father king thirteene yeare olde one achillas gouerne army photinus cnuch treasurer beganne consulte beste done wythachille photinus theodo u pompey also theodotus samos drator scholema ster king dyd perswade wicked acte deceyue ky pompey gratifye caesar counsel preuayled sent simple boate though roughnesse sea would suffer greater king seruauntes wente beate semprouius romayne serued vnder pompey nowe wyth kyng offered hande king name pompey wylled hym come son friende done army set order drewe neare sea honoure pompey king set midst purple vesture seene pompey suspected ordering army meanes vessel chiefly bycause king came toward sent noble men spake verse soph cles vvho tiranne goesa verse ophocles slaue though free rose entred yt boate euery man silent passage rather suspected chiefly sempronius eyther bycause knew romaine hauing serued vnder hym bycause coniecture seeing stading according souldiours discipline doe set chiefe turned sayd surely know thee souldier nodded hym agayn turned first stroke wife friend seeing farre cried held vp handes god sempronius romaine first stryketh pompey reuengers friendshippe broken sayled away streyght enimies lande photino cut pompeis heade kept caesar great gratification pompey cruelly killed worthily reuenged wicked deed vpon rest body buryed sea bancke silly sepulchre made one wrote epitaph lo lyeth simple graueepitaph popey temple deservde haue processe tyme graue couered sand certaine image brasse inhabitant afterwarde set vp pompey vnder hil cassius taken away layde vppe secrete place temple tyme adrianus romaine emperour hys iourney way adrianus emperour rest reth graue pompey cause sought found made graue amended euery man might see erected image dedicated pompey end pompey many great battayles bene fought romaine empire increased pompey great surname great neuer ouercome youth still inuincible happy fro three twenty eight fiftie yeares ruled like king opinion supposed gouerne like populare man emulation caesar lucius scipio pompeis father lawe noble men escape battayle fledde cato corcyra corcyra iland io ian sea care pompey friend generall another army three hundred gallies left prudent counsellour noblest pompeis friendes deuided nauye cassius sayled pontus pharnaces stirre caesar scipio cato wente libya trusting vppon varus army iuba king numidia confederate pompey pompeis eldest sonne labienus pompey sonne labienus scapula wyth scapula hauing part wente spaine make caesar got another army iberian celtiberians slaues haue preparation greater mighty power pompeis army yet left infelicitie abandon fled away cato chosen general lybia refuseth lybia chose cato general captaine presence suche men bene consul others bene lieuetenaunts pretor rome refused l scipio made general great army gathered trayned chiefest preparation libya iberia gathered caesar victorie caesar aboade two dayes pharsalo sacrificing thessalian made free caesar vvho serued recreatyng hys wearye armye made thessalian free serued pardoned athenian sute vsing wordes howe often hath glorie auncestours saued whe haue deserued destruction third day remoued towarde east following fame pompeis flighte wante gallies sayled ouer hellespont little boates novve europe covvarde cassius number gallies met going pharnaces although might gallies haue aduantage little boates yet feare caesar felicitie valiantnesse amazed suspecting caesar come purpose finde helde vp handes came gallies boates aske hym pardo deliuer gallies much force glorye caesar felicitie see none reason iudge meane great difficultie time haue fortune afray cassius valiaunt man comming vppon scauent e gallies vtterly vnprouided durste medle cowardly yeeld vnto vpo sea cruelly kyl whe lord rome wherefore euident ouerborne feare felicitie caesar thus saued hope past hellespont pardoned ionian ore aetolians nation inhabite greate cherroneso one name called asia lower forgaue caesar say e h egipt sent embassadours craue understanding pompey gone egipt went rhodes would tarry reste armye comming part gallies cassius rhodes men presently hadde toke shippe night sayled forth shewing whether commaunding captaines night follow light shippe day flag maister whereof commaunded sayled good way set course toward alexandria three day vpon sea came thither thys place wel receiued king officer king yet mount gassius caesar comming pretended haue nothing ado bycause fewe men went citie beholde beauty therof stood heard philosopher disputation wherby wanne muche loue good fauour alexand among one hauing nothing army come hee layde handes vppon photinus put death wickednesse done pompey therdotus fled asia whome cassius founde caused hanged alexandrian offended herewith sette vppon king army made many fight hym king palaice sea banke caesar driuen take sea swimme good way alexandrian tooke hys cloake bare vp token victory last battell wyth kyng hymselfe floude nilus ouercame restored kingdome caesar ouercommeth kyng aegipt booke extant caesar vve vvhen see pompey heade cleopatra bin nine moneths sayled vppon nilus foure hundred shippes company cleopatra whose pleasure many thing whiche particularly tolde booke egiptian matter could abide behold pompey heade brought vnto commanded buryed also builded little temple citie called temple reuengementtemple reuengement traiane tyme traiane emperoure make warre jewes pulled downe serue turne warre caesar done thing alexandria wente wyth hys army thoroughe syrta againste pharnace bin caesar againste pharnace domitius ouer throvvne yr amysso citie confines paphlagoma capadocia busy taken diuerse romaine prouinces gotten one victory domitius lieutenante caesar growing stoute tooke amyso citie pontus allied romaine people whereof solde slaues made child enuchs caesar came fled farre coulde sent caesar peace hys ambassador brought crowne golde offered foolishlye kyngs daughter marryage hym perceyuing presentes message wente wyth army entertayning king ambassador ordinary talke till came nighe encamped said shall murtherer father bee yet killed leaped horse first charge pharnace fled awaye caesar ouerthrewe moste parte thousand horseman firste keepe chase hym thys caesar saide loude voice happy pompey haddest war mithridates man father therby thought called great fight hee vid vici sp part kingdome p sent thus rome came sawe conquered pharnace content go kingdome bosphorus caesar appoynted caesar spent time trifle many battels yet remayning behinde went asia waye gathered money city troubled wyth tooke paymentes tribute haue shewed booke asia word brought hym sedition raysed rome editio rome antony lieutenat keep common place wyth army therefore setting thinges aside hee made haste rome whither come ciuill discorde ceassedsedition caesar army another began among souldiours bycause yet neyther receiued promise made theyr seruice pharsalo reaso shoulde still kept war therfore cried euery man go home promised reward pharsalo rewardes war libya drac p e coyne vvaying muche sterl ng groat eight groates ovvnce salustius danger ended therfore sent thousand drammes apeece promise bad promise pay al hand lacked little killed crispus salustius shifted away caesar hearde commanded legion antony guarde citie keepe aboute house entry citie fearing spoile hee verye boldly men fearing diswading rage souldiors went among mutinie field mar caesar among seditious souldioures perceyued set high seate confusedly tumulte came running vnarmed maner salute generall commeth firste among commaunded thing say touching gift shoulde speake face while hee present durste speake word feare taking caesar vvs n ting sould meane way cryed released war hoping bycause e neede men finish rest war would haue saide somewhat giftes contrarie opinion without stay answered discharge ast med hereat standing great silence saide againe wil giue haue promised shall triumphe rest word vnlooked appearing curteous strike suche consideratio emulation thoughte shame forsake capitaine middes enimies others shoulde triumph place theysouldioures repent remembred losse haue leauing warre libya thought enimies aswell caesar hys aduersaries doubt remained silent feare hoping yet caesar woulde haue giuen rewarde forgyuen faulte hys present neede sate silent therefore hys friend wished say somwhat vnto leaue oft serued hym shorte seuere speech began speake call citizen stead souldiers token discharged war become former priuate case could suffer cryed repent prayed mighte taken war caesar refused came seate made greater instaunce beseeching hym hadde done amisse punishe stayed neither going forward backewarde seeming doubt yet hee returned sayde hee woulde punishe none grieued tenth legion whiche alwaies loued honored shoulde giue cause suche tumulte onely thys saide release seruice yet wyll gyue haue promised come libya giue lande warres shall ended sylla dydde spoyling hadde causing taker loser liue togither maintayne perpetuall enmitye wyll diuide bothe common mine lacke wyl buy mony showte reioyce made sauing tenthe legion whiche caesar seemed inexorable thereforethe tenth legio desireth bee punished desired hym might bee punished death lotte shoulde fall hauing neede furye perceyuing throughlye penitent forgaue reggio f rthe tovvne italy tovvardes fore ande caesar sayleth cittye e carthage senate lybia three dred romaine adrumeto city affrica farie carthage labienus petreius putteth caesar backe petreius folovveth vnstorye streyght went war barbarie passing narrowe sea reggio hee wente messina l lybee vnderstoode cato kept part army bothe sea lande v ca wyth three hundred whiche lyke chiefe counsellers greatest doer war called senate generall lucius scipio best laye adrumeto therfore sayled scipio gone uba gaue order fight campe taking oportunity againste hys enimyes without generall labienus petreius chief vnder scipio refuse fyght far better caesar putting flight fiercely contept followyng hym til labienus horse thrus e throughe belly killed saued guarde hys person petreius taken sufficient triall army might winne woulde lefte thing vnfinished saying leaft take victory scipio generall caesar fortune also another token caesar fortune enimies apparaunce hauing victory woulde sodainly breake fight day say caesar fighte fa ne stande againste men take egle fro bare chiefe standerd goe formostthe ger caesar stay fro flying till petreius retired caesar time depart leysure end first fight made barbarie long scipio came forth legion xx h sme wherof part affricanes many target rrr elephant uba kyng footemen rrr numidia horsme almost xx many darter threescore elephant caesar army dismayed troubled among themselues well former losse fame aduersaries number vertue specially numidian horseman beside terror make straunge fighte occhus king moore chiefe citie iuba vpon newes owne losse returned home armye leauing onely thirty elephant scipio caesar army tooke courage fifth legion desired fight elephats whome hauing noble victory geue elephante ensigne day battell long difficulte euerye side full vncertainetie aboute euening caesar hardly gote victory ouerthrew scipio camp leauing victory night till brought passe enimies sinal part could fled scipio afranio leauing fledde sea twelue ship vnarmed thus armye fourescore thousante souldyers well trayned warre encamped former victory seconde fight vtterly vanquished caesar glory felicitie comp ed vnconquerable ouercome woulde attribute nothing manhoode excuse theyr caesar felicitie faultes felicitie seemeth warre vnfortunate end vnskilfulnesse captaynes endure till caesar mighte haue bin put shiftes norvnskilfulnesse bring first victory perfection woulde needes leaue middest told v ica thethe nobleman rome flee thyrde day caesar comming forward euery man beganne flee whome cat stayed none gaue shippes noble men desired yet himselfe tarryed like constant man v ica promised woulde make intercession caesar themselues cato smiled aunswered cato v icenses needed reconciliation betweene caesar hym caesar knew well ynough sealed vp al treasure assurance writing euery man deliuered magistrate v ica euening vsing bath supper sitting meate wonte since death pompey nothing changing wonted inner neyther ahing lesse talked familiarly present sayled wind good farre might passe morning caesar came wente bedde hee change nothing vsage embraced sonne straightly wont bicause found sword place bed wont stande cryed hee betrayed enimies owne folke vse quoth set vpon night desired would content worke nothing himselfe rest without sworde might quoth woulde cheke selfe cloke crush head wal fall breake necke stoppe breath kill selfe heard speake sort broughte sword called plat booke immortalitie soule cato strike soule whe redde thinking kept dores rest stroke himselfe sworde vnder brest bowel fell whiche noyse without came phisitions put bowel againe vnperished came againe himselfe sory giue deeper wound thaking saued life made beleeue would rest tooke away sworde shut dore might sleepe seeming asleepe tare asunder hand like wilde beast sowing vp hysthe death cato wound rente belly asunder flong entrayles store dyed fiftie yeares age co firmed opinion held men twenty dayes passing long way greate army suche feare fell among broughte neuer bycause multitude experience desperation enimies wherefore caesar came flowlyer forth bycause vsed foresight pompey came lustily vpon vpbrayded fearefulnes rebuke caesar could suffer made order battell corduba worde venus pompey pietie shoulde goe fearefeare caesar army vvrighte fight vvas giuen monda vvhich novv mundesara place farre asunder name one dreadfull slouthfulnesse tooke caesar army wherefore besought goddes held vp hand heauen might lose noble actes one battell therefore went army exhorted bold pulled headpeece head might see face receyue good heart could put awaye feare till caesar tooke target one captaynes thus sayde shall ende mee life seruice ranne army farre asdanger caesar tenne foote wreath white riband marullus sesetius tribune apprehended threwe p son thinking haue pleased caesar one abhorred name king hee suffered patiently others called king went gate people sighed aunswered couertly king caesar though bin deceyued caesar accepteth name king name marullus caused apprehended fyrste beganne matter w lled hym broughte aunswere hys courte caesar coulde longer suffer accused marullus hys fellowes senate one craftily wroughte agaynste hym caesar angrye vvith tribune causeth sp kingdome calumniation tyrannie whereas deserued eathe yet thoughte sufficiente lose theyr office putte senate thys dyd confirme coueted thys litle bente pra ise ende vtterly become tyrante good authoritie punish named man king tribune office holy inuiolate lawe auntient oth made anger sha per woulde tarrie time office whiche vnderstoode hee ent first perceyued harde thing deale rigorously peace withoute authoritie warre hys friend gaue counsel beware giuen great caesar vvarred occasion vpto caesar seate set crowne head sight reioicing lamenting caesar threw antony set againe caesar reiected people stoode silent looking end woulde haue saw caesar vtterly refuse reioyced highly commended therefore eyther bycause despayred vayne attempted woulde auoyde practise od ous thing woulde leaue citie bycause enimies regard health troubled falling sicknesse rest many time came vp caesar hath falling sicknesse determined greate voyage againste getes parthianes getes bycause insolente people quarrelling uer troubling romaine state againste ete ithi europa voyag parthie parthianes bycause would nge crassus deathe whome slayne contrary oth promise hauing armye sixteene legion tenne thousand horse sent afore passe ionian sea sybils bookes olde saying parthian shoulde ouercome till kyngprophecie went wherefore bold saye expedient romaine call dictator imperator anye name stead king nation subiect romaine empire call hym king hee refused also made hast iourney bycause sawe enuyed citie whereas tarried till appoynted time enimies killed foure dayes senate house eyther enuie commonly accompanyethenuie felicitie auctoritie said loue cou trey libertie knew well thoughe hee ouercome nation without doubte woulde king cause thinke tooke enterprise agaynste vnder pretence name thoughe hee dictator degree much kyng deede thereconspiratours rutus ca cassius brutus two chiefe conspiracy marcus brutus cepio sonne brutus killed sylla whiche fled caesar calamitie pharsalo field caius cassius delyuered hys galleis caesar hand hellespont two afore pompey part much honoured caesar decimus brutus albinus alwayes thoughte worthy caesar vsed honor credite great affaire committed war lybia trusted wyth army made gouernours prouinces decimus france beyond alpes brutus thys side alpes brutus cassius beeyng pretor contended superioritiecloaked contention place eyther indeede shoulde higher else pretence shoulde seeme friendes caesar setting order betwixte said hys friendes cassius desireth right brutus muste pleased great loue honour caesar vse hym compted hys son bicause loued wel seruilia catos sister brutus mother therfore got victory pharsalo hee gaue greate caesar care brutus charge hys captayns wise saue brutus brutus either ingrate man ignorant mother faulte distrustfull ashamed desirous coutrys libertie preferring thing descended auntient brutus droue king incensed rebuked people manye thing written vppon image olde brutus inbrutus courte hall brutus secretly set vp brutus thou takest rewardes brutus thou arte dead brutus woulde thou aliue nowe brutus vnworthy posterity hast thou brutus thou arte come hym many lyke inflame yong man mind take worke hande progenitor making king still encrease woulde counsell little cassius tooke brutus hand sayd brutus shall counsell shall casars slatterers agree make hym kyng brutus answered would counsell cassius cheared wordes said call v officer shall good brutus wyll quoth defend countrey euen death cassius embraced hym saying wil e thou take best opinion doest thou thinke artificer light people set writing vpon thy judgemet place rather tha best citizen rome pretor looke shews pastunes horse wilde beast thee require liberty worke worthy thine auncestors thus firste opened long kept mind dealte plamely eche themmore cospira e proued friend caesar whome knewe meete bolde enterprise got friendes two brother cecilius buc l u r brius riga q l ga iw marcus spurius seruilius galba sextius naso u aquila trusty friend caesar familiar decimus whome spake caius casca caesar muste goe away fourth daye hys armyes shoulde straighte haue guarde souldioures aboute hym place appointed senate house thinking though senatoures priuie yet sawe eede woulde helpe saye brutus cassius beyng togither talke one senator publius laenas sayde hee wished well mindes exhorted dispatch much amazed helde peace anguishe caesar came forth one hys familiar vnderstanding ition dis ing conspiracie vsing tel hee hearte wente calphurnia saide onelye thys bycause matter touched caesar much would tarry til came senate knew al wrought one artemidorus hoste guido ranne vnto counsell house found hym newe slaine anothera booke conspiracie booke conspiracie deliuered made haste senate whiche founde againe hys hande hee dead came litter laen wished wel cassius came vnto hym talked verye earnestlye wyth sight wherof trouble length thefeare co spiratoures talke made winke one another dispatche themselues taken perceyuing manner laena liker speake himselfe make supplication bewray stayed ende saw hym giue humble thankes encouraged againe custome ruler citie shoulde sacrificesacrifices went senate agayne caesar firste sacrifice harte say heade entrailes whe diuinor said signe death caesar contem neth sacrifi e il luck hee smiled sayde spaine ouerthrewe pompey diuinor aunswering perill indeede nowe token manifest caesar bad hym sacrifice againe nothing appearing better ashamed made senate tarry hym hastned enmies though bin fri d dispight enimies went must needes come determined left trebonius entertaine antony without dores caesar hys seate stoode aboute hys friend weapon hid first attilius cymber stoodt u made sute hys brother returne banished caesar vtterly denying hee tooke hym purple robe would haue made sute rufdedthe garment pulled ouer necke cry staye frieds casca came ouer head first thrust dagger throat missing hit breast caesar twitching gown fro cimbro catching casca hand flung fro seate great violece layd hold vpon casca while wrestling another stroke caesar giue ouer vvhe brutus ken vvrite sayd vvhat thou sonne side laye open cassius hurte face brutus thyghe bucolinus betweene shoulder yet caesar rage reare like wilde beaste stepped euery brutus hurt thoughe hee dispaired wrapte gowne fell comely picture pompey downe vsed despite gaue three twentie woundes many hastie hurte one another act done murderer sacred place vpon sacred
