many wente sicelie ile nigh italie pompey receyued pompey noblenesse yong pompey gladly shewed notable care afflicted sorte sending cryers abroade call sortes coulde saue whyther free bonde propounded reward double muche killer boates shippes burthen meete sayled galley beeyng full euery shore shewed token went amisse saued mette receyuing came gaue raymente liuing forthwyth worthy sorte vsed hys army nauie three men shoulde make truce woulde neuer graunte tyll come hym shoulde comprised moste profitable hys afflicted countrey wanne greate glory hymselfe inferioure hee hadde hys father others beeyng otherwise edde hydden tyll truce fieldes graues citie lyued sharpe paynes loues incredible shewed woman theyr husbandes due chyldren towarde theyr father seruauntes againste nature maisters notable declare paulus brother lepidus captaynes hauyng reuerence vnto hym brother prince theyr leaue sayled citie brutus mi eto whiche place peace yet beeyng made hee obteyned returne called home woulde lucius uncle antonie antonyes mother kepte hym lucius hydde beeyng hyr brother captaynes parte honouryng hyr mother chiefe ruler vsing violence came forthe common place anda good sister antony sa e wyth prince sayde confesse prince haue receyued lucius haue hym yet keepe hym till thou kill v togyther lyke payne appoynted receyuers reproued hir good sister vnkynde mother antony vvords mother shee ought saue lucius shoulde haue stopped hym iudged hyr sonne enimie neuerthelesse caused plancus consull decree hys reuocation messal noble yong man fledde brutus three men fearingmess la wisedome wrote thus since friendes messala dothe affyrme vnto v heea letter three men medler caius caesar kylled put hym proscribed number dyd accepte pardon brutus cassius kylled aboute thrace armye whyche remayned greate hauing shyppes money good hope woulde haue hadde massala bee theyr captaynemassala refused persuaded gyue place aduerse fortune ioyne wyth antony wherefore hee greate credite antonie agreed wyth hym tyll hee reproued hym hys wanton dealing wyth cleopa ra wente caesar made hym consull antonyes place hee agayne declared enimie hee dydde fyghte agaynste antonie battell sea acti ad ep ru acti caesar sente hym agaynste frenche reuolted caesar sent graunted hym triumph victorie bibulus also accepted antony messalae wasbibul admirall antony wente agaynste caesar warred togyther beyng presidente syria vnder antony dyed acilius fledde citie secretely beeyng betrayed acilius good vvife hys seruaunte souldyoures hee persuaded hope muche money sende wyfe wyth token whyche tooke broughte vnto hyr store saying dyd delyuer vnto though woulde performe theyr promise yet shee knewe whether woulde deceyued thys good liking hyred shippe acilius sente siceli lentulus beeyng desired hys wyfe flee wyth hym lentulus good vvife diligentlye attendyng hym hee woulde putte hyr daunger fledde secretely sicelie eeyng made lieutenaunte pompey hee sente hyr worde howe hee scaped office hearyng hyr husbande secretely lefte hyr mother good eye vpon hir wyth two seruauntes wyth greate payne wante slaue went till came messina reggi aboute nyghte easilie learning lieutenantes tente founde lentulus lieutenant poore b dde layde vppon grounde simple dyet desire hir apuleius wife threatned woulde bewray hym fledde good vvi e alone wherefore againste tooke hir happe fleeing suspect going openly wife men maides antius wife wrapped hir husbande couering good vvife meane sent carrier sea whence fledde sicelie reginus wife put hir husband night filthy sincke reginus good vvife souldioures would go day sauoure next night cladde like colyer gaue asse carie cole folowed little litter warder sawe suspecting man litter searched whereof reginus afraide anne backe straunger prayed souldioure good woman angerly answering colier knew notwithstanding hadde serued vnder syria sayde goe boldly captayne becommeth yet call thee scoponius wife obteyned antony beeyng till time good fame heale one euill fortune another geta sonne made fire open parte house geta good sonne burie father seemed dead whome hidde house countrey newe made olde man disguising hymselfe layde parchment hys eye agreement made tooke away parchment foundeeye lost lacke vse eye lacke vse oppius sonne minding tarrie olde feeble father bare oppius good sonne backe till past gate rest way partly leading partly bearing broughte hym safe cicelie man suspecting troubling manner wright aeneas reuerenced enimiesaeneas anchises bare father anchises people rome commendyng young manne caused afterwarde made chamberlayne citie bycause hee coulde beare charge office hys goodes confiscate artificer freely gaue hym supply thekindnesse common people behelde hys shewes euery man caste muche money game place made riche arianus caused grauen sepulchre hys testament arianus good sonne epitaph thus lieth sonne proscribed hide condemned eyng saued life metellus father sonne father captayne metellus father sonne vnder antonie actio taken prysoner vnknowen sonne serued caesar capitaine fielde caesar gyue sentence vppon captiues samo yong man presente olde manne samo e ouer agaynst ho good sonne brought foorth forlorne long heare miserie wante transformed order captiues called crier hys sonne lepte hys seate embraced father whome scarsly knew teares ceased sorowe hee sayde caesar hath bene thine enimie caesar thy friende thou muste punishe rewarde desire thee saue father mee lette die hym euery man takyng pittie caesar commaunded metellus saued though hys enimie afore despysing many gyftes drawne antonie seruauntes marcius good loue fortune marcius good seruaunts tyme proscription dyd keepe hym within hys house till feare set aside marcius came house banishment hirtius wyth hys menne fleeyng cittie wente aboutehirtius italie deliuered prysoners gathered togither fledde tooke townes firste moe number till sufficient armie ouercame parte brut n whence sendyng army sayled al pompey restio thoughte fledde alone seruaunte followed restio good seruaunt hym secretelye beeyng broughte vppe hym aforetyme well vsed euill condition branded restio rested fenne see seruaunte nighe hym afrayde whome seruaunte sayde hee much remember present brandes hee dyd former benefites caused hym repose caue prouided meate hym well hee coulde cane suspected souldyours drewe nighe restio hee seruaunte perceyuyng matter followed killed olde man passed cutte hys heade souldiours beyng angrye commyng aboute take killer hee sayde haue kylled mayster restio gaue mee brandes tooke heade haue rewarde caryed vayne citie seruaunt comforted bye mayster sayled hym sicelie appion restyng stable souldiours sought hym appion good seruant seruaunt put garment lay vppon bedde willingly receyued death hys mayster sittyng forme seruaunt memmius house soughte souldiours one whose seruauntes wente litter hys fellowes bearyng good seruaunt hym hadde bene theyr maister beeyng taken contente die maister fledde sicelie iunius hadde free made manne philemon hadde good seruaunt fayre house hee kepte hys mayster vaughte whiche woonte laye harnesse money wrytinges fedde hym nyghte tyll peace made free made man keepyng sepulchre hys master also preserue maisters sonne graue togither father lucretius wanderyng twoo faythfull seruauntes forlucretius lacke meate returned hys wyfe beyng borne litter hys seruauntes citie sicke man happened one seruaunts broken hys legge hee wente tyll hee came gate hys father afore beyng proscrybed sylla taken souldiours commyng aboute hym hee muche afrayde lucke place wherefore hee fledde seruaunte hydde hym graue chaunsing robber sepulcher dyd searche graues seruaunt offered hymselfe bee spoyled robber whyles maister fledde gate tarried tyll hys seruaunt came hym whose garmentes hee put wente hys wyfe vnder whose care beyng kepte hee hidde betwene twoo beames till hee pardoned meanes made three menne peace made office consull sergius hydde antonie hymselfe tyll hee haddesergius perswaded plancus consull proclayme hys reuocation agayne dissention caesar antonie antonie declared enimye senate hee onely openly gaue voyce hys acquitall thus saued pomponius decked hymselfe lyke pretor hys seruantspomponius lyke sergeaunts went thorough citties wyth mace officer rounde aboute hym hee bee knowne gate hee tooke publyque coach wente thorough italie euery manne receyuyng hym sendyng hym pretor appoynted three menne make truce wyth pompey whome also hee came publike galley apuleius aruntius counterfaiting themselues capitaynesapuleius aruntius seruauntes souldiours ranne gate capitaynes pursued others way deliuered prysoners receyued suche came eyther sufficient bande ensignes armour e army chancing diuerse wayes went toward sea bothe camped one hil great feare lookyng one another mornyng hauyng cleere sight thinkyng eyther bene sente destroy fought fiercely tyll knewe truthe repenting deede threw away weapos wayled fortune shoulde contrarie tooke shippe one saylyng brutus pompey went pompey vnder brutus president bythinia brutus dead deliuered antonie saued seruaunt ventidius firste condemned put ventidius good seruauntes fetter though woulde haue deliuered hym killer night perswaded hys felowes cladde lyke souldiours mayster lyke capitaine wente lyke bande appoynted brought mayster citie passing italy sicelie many tymes meeting capitaynes sought ventidius another hidde hys mayster sepulchre hee coulde abyde fearfulnesse fansie sepulchre hee hidde homely house nyghe whiche souldiour dwellyng coulde abyde feare neyther wherefore turnyng feare extreeme boldenesse shaued hys head played schoolemayster rome till truce volutius aedile condemned hauyng friendship volutius priestes isi vvere clad vvith garment dog head caleni campania sittius priest isi borowed stole vesture downe foote put dogges heade maner furious seruice passed safe pompey calenians dyd keepe sittius citizen liberally spent substance vpon weapon warded rebuking seruants keeping soldiours fro walles till furye beeyng paste sent three men obtayned sittius excluded rest italy remainea banished man countrey countrey sittius firste onelye man straunger outlawe owne countrey varr philosopher writer history hauing doonevarr good seruice warres place lieutenaunt therefore peraduenture ennimie monarchie condemned friend beeyng desirous receiue andit saide antony pardoned varro vvith vvords viuat varro vndoctissimus contending hym calenus obtay ned hym kept vineyarde whither antony came sometyme walke yet neuer one within bewraye varro neyther hys owne seruaunts calenus virginius eloquentman taughte seruauntes ifvirginius kylled little money danger shoulde get hate length great feare saued win sure glory good hope hereafter money muche abundant certaine wherefore fled fellowe seruaunte way beeing knowne fought souldiours taken tolde also woulde kill hym anye malice onelye hope money shoulde haue iustlye plentifullye would go hym sea quoth wife hathe shippe mony persuaded brought hym sea wife shee appointed came sea bycause hir husbande tarryed thinking bin gone pompey went hir way leauing seruat shore whim whe virginius come seruant ranne vnto shewed shippe sayled maistresse said money left behinde tell souldiours perceiuing al true virginius desired staye til might call wife backe goe hir mony tooke boate great labour rowed sicelie receyuing promise woulde goe tarryed till ende certaine marrinet receyued rebulus shippe goerebulus sicelie required mony would accuse didde themistocles fledde thatthemistocles threatned would accuse receyuing mony wherefore mariner afrayde broughte vnto pompey murcus lieutenante vnder brutus condemnedmarcus brutus ouercome taken made himselfe seruant whome barbula bought perceyuing himbarbuli apte made chiefe fellowes gaue money bestowe sawe still wise diligent common nature seruantes put hope one proscribed men woulde saue woulde confesse denying earnestly declaring stocke name former maysters caried rome thinking bene condemned man woulde haue refused goe followed cheerefully gate consul house friend barbulas saw murcus eruile maner wayting vpon secretly tell eare agrippa obteined caesar murcus pardoned remained friende caesar long happened captaine warre againste antonie actio barbula capitayne antony fortune camebarbula bothe alike antonie ouerthrowen taken counterfeyted seruant whome murcus bought ignorant shewing caesar obteyned hysequall fortune pardon requited former benefit fortune like side continued officer togither one dignitie rome balbinus fleeing retourning pompey made balbinus lepidus deposed consull hapned lepidus great prince made priuate man caesar came necessitie maecenas accuse lepidus sonne conspiracie caesar also accused mother consenting hir sonne lepidus himselfe weake man despised sonne sent caesar actio mother bicause woman aryed required suretie putte consull man would hir suretie lepidus wayted many time balbinus dores comming sate judgemente ofte repulsed officer length much ado spake thus accuser confesse mine innocencie affirming lepidus sute vvife neyther consenting wife sonne didde proscribe thee one proscribers haue respect vnto chaunces worlde attende vpon thee giue grace eyther wife may goe caesar vpon suretie bounde goe hyr while lepidus spake balbinus considering mutation cicero son deliuered wife hir bonde yong cicero sent father grecia foreseing would come greece went brutus brutus death pompey honoured place lieutenaunt caesar cleere cicero iniuriethe bishop old rome vvere magistrate iudges religion made straight bishop long consul president syria whe caesar ouercame antony actio yet consul caesar wrote letter readde people rome sate seate justice father head put appius diuided substance among seruants sayledappius sicelie watching mony storm rysing put boate might sayle safetie chaunced boate saued beyonde hope drowned theyr shippe publius treasurer brutus familie anteny publius requested forsake brutus bicause would proscribed yet returned friende caesar caesar came woulde shewe brutus picture praysed caesar thing beyonde hope happening proscribed men daunger safetie many moe omitted thought chiefe declared matter thus passed rome place trouble ful enimies great warres fell libya cornificius sextius syria cassius dolobella sicilia pompey great affliction among citties captiuitie ouerpasse lesse greatest appeared worthie rest loadicea tharsus rhodes patareans xantheans euery beginning order haue gathered write romaine call parte yet olde libya wanne carthaginenses whiche king iuba helde andolde libya gotten caesar call newe libya may bee numidia sextius president new libya vnder caesar commaundednevve libya sextius cornificius cornificius giue place olde thoughe libya caesar lot three men made diuision sayd knew suche diuision made three men among themselues woulde deliuer prouince receiued senate onelye againe cause made war one another cornificius armye well appointed great number sextius lighte harnessed fewer whiche comming abroade hee caused men reuolte cornificius gaue repulse ventidius captaine cornificius comming vpon lustily besieged laelius captayne cornificius went abrode wan cirta place sextius al sent arabion cirta cittie numidia vvhere ugurth kylled adherbal arabion sittius king called sittians take part warre called thys cause sittius rome abiding sentence quarrell fled gathering army came fro italy spaine libya tooke part among libyan king warred togither ioyned gotte victorie called sittian bycause army valiantlysittians caius caesar persecute pompey friend fyghte libya ouerthrewe sabura iubas lieutenant famous man whiche cause sittius rewarded caesar manassa manasses king manasses land al best part manasses arabions father confederate iuba lande caesar gaue sittius bocchus king marusians one part whereof sittius diuided people vnder arabion fledde iberia pompeis child caius caesar killed retourned againe libya euer sending libyan yonger pompey iberia receyuing expert souldiours thence tooke hys lande bocchus dispatched sittius craft still friend pompeyans perceyuing fortune full infelicitie without hope agreede sittius soone hym reconciled caesar sittians also father beneuolence wyth caesar ioyned wyth hym sestius nowe emboldned came siege fight ventidius slayne army fledde without guyde whome chased killed tooke many laelius hearing leuied siege cirta wente cornificius sestius hauty feat went cornificius vtica encamped hauing much people cornificius sending laelius horsmen take view sestius sent arabion horse laelius face horse better appointed came vpon side disordred hym laelius thoughe inferior yet fearing retire shoulde haue bene shutte tooke hill betweene arabion hee directed kylled manye compassed reste cornificius seeing came foorthe wyth hys whole power helpe laelius sestius sette vpon back sodayne charge whome cornificius endeuoured repell great trauaile arabion meane time creeping stony place came secretly ouer mountaines vpon cornificius campe roscius keeper campe distressed offered roscius kylled hys throate cutte page cornificius wearie fyght went laelius mountaine cornificius killed knowing doone campe arabion horseman came vpon killed laelius seeing al ielius kylleth kyniselfe vpon hill kylled himselfe captaines deade army fled seuerally suche proscribed men cornificius fledde sicelie whither could sestius rewarded arabion sit ians goodly gift citties pardoned obey caesar ende warre libya betwixte cornificius laelius shorte man consider feates doone wyth great speede brutus cassius comparison little wasbrutus cassius done caius caesar killed murderer tooke capitoll obi uion al thinges decreed came people funerall caesar moued wyth pittie ranne aboute seeke quellers driuing backe toppes house went prouinces caesar appointed cassius brutus beyng yet pretor citie assigned also caesar prouinces cassius siria brutus macedonia bycause coulde goe prouinces time abide hate citiebrutus cassius wente away yet office senate consideration appointed purueioures prouision meane time shoulde thought flee away beyng gone syria macedonia apointed decree antony dolobella consul senate beeing muche grieued gaue steade thereof creta cirene whiche regarding shorte tyme gathered much money men entred syria macedonia thus wroughte dolobella hadde kylled trebonius asia antonie hadde ouercome decimus celtica senate offended decree antonie dolobella enimies restored brutus cassius former prouinces added brutus illyria commaunding al ruler romaine illyria added brutus dominion well prouinces army obey brutus cassius cassius preuented dolobella entring syria vsed token office gathered twelue legion moste parte hadde serued bin trained vnder casus caesar one whiche caesar hadde lefte syria goe thepassus sextus iulius war parthian charge secilius bassus dignitie sextus iulius hadde yong man caesar kinsman lasciuious suffering legion fall riot bassus reproued wherefore fell bassus called hym rascall waxing disobedient bassus commaunded hym broughte sergeant whereof tumulte growing bassus beyng daunger killed armye abiding disorder killed iulius whiche repenting fearing caesar displeasure agreed togither vnlesse forgiuenesse woulde fyght til death compelled bassus getting legion trained valiatly ouercame sextius murcus sente againste three legion caesar murcus came aide minutius crispus bythinia murcus three legion besieged bassus sixe legion cassius comming reliefe bassus receiued hys armye freely minutius murcus deliuering tominutius hym legion goodwill obeyed thinges senate comauded albinus sent dolobella brought oute aegipt foure legion remnaunt pompeius crassus discomfiture caesar left wt cleopatra cassius set vpon palestina knowing nothing chaunces sodainely compelled deliuer armye afraide foure legion fyght againste eight thus cassius beyond al expectation lord twelue legion manye parthian archer horsebacke came serue cassius hee known among officer crassus campe dolobella remained ionia dispatching trebonius trebonius putting tribute vpon city lucius figulus figulus hyring nauies rhodes lycian pamphagonians celicians whe ready determined go syria himselfe land two legion figulus sea hearing cassius army tourned hys iorney laodicea cittie friendly hym ioyning cherronesus fitte al surniture ore well passage sea defence lande place mighte prouide thinges plentifullye se would without feare saile lande cassius seeing fearing dolobella escape hauing gotten place called isthmus almoste iland na rovve land betvveene tvvoo sea two furlong ouer took stone tymber cotages borough sepulchre make peere ship sent phoenitia lycia rhodes reiected donians yet went againste dolobella bothe haning loste number shyps dolobella tooke fiue al men cassius sent againe despised hym cleopatra queene aegipt serapion generall cypre hir tyrians aradians serapion without arad ile aradus one citties ph nitia maketh polis tyrus sido excuse cleopatra telligence cleopatra sent many ship hadde queene made excuse cassius hunger pestilece wherwith aegipt oppressed familiarity former caesar shee fauoured dolobella determination sente hym four legion albinus sufficient company sea bicause winde stayed rhodians lycian said woulde helpe neither brutus cassius ciuill warres giuen ship passage dolobella entred societie warre cassius prepared againe presently encountred dolobella twice firste fought oute like force dolobella weake sea cassius rampire beat walles cittie lyke fade coulde corrupte marsus chiefe watch night wanne marsus loadicea vvon dolobella killed captaines band warded day marsus resting daye gate opened entred diuers part army citie taken dolobella bad one guard cutte heade carrie cassius saue owne whiche killed himselfe marsus also ridde life cassius hauyng gotten citie sware armie dolobella himselfe laodiceans sacred publyke thing spoyled laodicea spo chief citie punished oppressed grieuous payment brought citie extreeme miserie laodicea hee wente towarde aegypt vnderstandyng cleopatra dyd sayle greate nauie caesar antonie thynkyng hee myghte stoppe hir voyage reuenged hyr vnderstandyng aegipt greate distresse famine hauyng greate army straungers souldiours beyng gone albinius beyng hope determination brutus haste aduertised hym caesar antonie dyd passe ionian sea cassius vnwillyngly lefte enterpryse aegipt sente away parthian archer horsebacke wyth rewardes messenger theyr king ayde whiche commyng done ranged syria nighe nation ionia departed cassius lefte hys nephewe syria one legion horsemenne hee sente afore cappadocia suddenly sette vppon ariobarzanes distressed ariobarzanes kyng one meante deceyue cassius brought money rich cassius tharsias beyng debate one parte honoured cassius comyng tharsue diuisi citie cilicia floudde cydno firste dolobella shew city authoritie embracing turne serued either side chageable citie vsed oth extreemely cassius ouercome dolobella commaunded paye thousand fiue hundred talentes knowingthe calamitie tharsus doe beyng despight requyred souldiours therevnto compelled sell pryuate iewels holy thing common whiche triumphes sacrifice whiche suffising magistrate solde free people firste virgines men child woman olde men pityfully theyr youngmen whereof many killed themselues case cassius came syria stayed pitties cassius shevveth souie pittie sake released rest tribute thus tharsus laodicea punished cassius brutus consultyng togither seemed best brutus remoue armie thencecounsell ene brutus cassius macedonia greater consideration bycause sayde theyr enimies fourty legion eyght past ionian sea cassius thought multitude enimie passed bycause tyme number shoulde destruction wante therefore shoulde sette vpon rodians licians friend enimies hauing nauies least come vpon backes agreed deuided army brutus went licians cassius agaynst rodians hee brought vp learned greeke tongue bicause novve capo crio strong vpon sea prepared exercised hys owne ship guido wise men rodes afrayd come fight romanes people lusty recounting formerthe rhodes iland sea called carpathio vvhich greatnesse next iesa u cyprus feat maner men shippes also gathered beste whiche xxxiij done sente mindo cassius requesting woulde reiect rhodes citie euer reuenge contemned couentions betwene rhodians romanes one shoulde beare armes alleage thyng societie warre woulde vnderstande senate rome commaunding sayde would thus much sayde answeared rest warre must iudge steede wordes league comaunded leauie armes one another rhodians conspire dolobella ayded cassius comaundeth one help another cassius requireth vse shifte romane senate scatered present destroyed tyrannes citie punished rhodians taking partes onlesse commaunded thus sayde cassius whe knowne rhodes auncient men afrayd people persuaded one alexader manasses remebring vnto mithridates came wt many moe ship demetrius therfore made alexander chief officer called prytan manasses admiral pryta eu vvas athens chiefe citie autonie neuerthelesse sent archelaus embassadour cassius schoolemaster greeke intreate familiarly taken hande spake hys acquayntance thou art louer greeke language disturbe archeleus scholenaster cassius greeke citie rhodes louer libertie deface dorian dignitie neuer yet blemished since firste began forget goodly historie thou diddest learne rhodes rome rhodes howe muche citizen haue euer stoode defence nation king thought inuincible demetrius mithridates libertie whiche thou sayst thou trauaylest rome haue done wel antiochus great pillers set vp monumets v thus much may sayd romanes natio worthinesse state neuer yet seruitude societie choyse thee cassius certaine great reuerece say remayneth toward citie thy nurse thy scole thy phisitian house wher thou didst dwell scole self thing wherein toke paynes well requite al vpo countrie forced make warre thee nourished brought vp put v necessitie one two thing either rhodians shal destroyed cassius ouercome aduise thee beside haue prayed thee hast tak hand feate ye comon welth rome thou always make god guydes great cause romanes call god witnesse caius caesar ye made solene league wt v othe cofirmed gaue v right hand enimies performe shal frieds felowes refraine god cause glory among men seing nothing barbarous breach league make offendours seeme vnfaithfull friend foe whe old man thus sayd let cassius hand go wept wiped eye manner might moue cassius reuerece abashed wt passio sayd thus thou diddest persuade rodians doe iniurie thy selfe hast done thou diddest exhort aduise ca e helous couldest persuade reuenge thee haue bene iniured euidently firste bycause asking helpe nourished taught contemned despised bycause preferred dolobella whome neyther taught brought vp haynous onely brutus noble men whome knowe well fledde tirannie ready fight libertie countrie rodianes louers libertie preferred dolobella v seekyng take v whome ought fauour pretend deale ciuill warre ciuill couet vnlawfull power ope warre made people rule tirannes state haue popular gouernment forsake labour lawes beare good romanes condemned death without iudgement prescribed confiscate haue pitie answeare vnderstand senate minde destroyed helpe self ye knew senate decreed brutus al inhabitant betweene ionia east obey comaundements thou makest rehearsal haue done v wats good haue receyued reward againe forget denie help v suffer iniurie sauing liberty ought bene friendship betwirt v would haue begon haue ayded comon cause rome beyng dorean libertie bring foorth also league lacking matter caius casar first author tirannie make say romanes rodians help one necessity helpe nowe romanes greatest cause moste perill cassius romane borne president romanes dothe chalenge league accordyng decree senate whiche commaunde dweller beyonde ionia shoulde obey v brutus dothe require pompey keepyng sea senate safetie decree wee ioyne prayer fledde senate brutus pompey people publike decree rhodianes shoulde help romanes euery one haue neede neyther officer romanes take v fugitiues straungers condemned name v haue proscribed v haue nothing v romanes rhodianes league may make warre stranger free confederacie excepte obey v require thus cassius dallying archelaus sent away alexander manasses captaynes rhodianes three thirtie shippes sayled cassius myndo preuent sea hauing hope lightly ouercome bycause made voyage guido agaynste mithridates happy ende warre vsing rowing shew sayled first day guido next guido citie like ilande caria set vppon cassianes whereat maruelling encounter shewing noble strength sydes rhodian shippes light gaue suddayne onset enimiesbattayle sea betvveene romanes rhodianes retired againe fetched course woulde romaine heauie abode ioyned ouerlayde like fight foote cassius multitude shippes beset enimie could compasse retire pleasure onely aforehande giue charge retire againe commoditie taken away streightnesse place commyng vpon romanes great shippes sharpe stemmes dyd good bicause romanes stoode vnmouable light vessel ende three rhodianes men taken two broken sonke rest sore beaten fledde rhodes romaine resorted myndo repaired vessel myndus sea coast tovvne caria brused ende fight sea betweene romanes rhodianes cassius behelde mountayne repayred nauye sayled lorenn castell ame rhodians footemen committed phanius lentulus bee transported greate shippes sayled fourescore vessel whyche terrible sighte rhodians arriued rhodes stirred neyther hys nauye hys fotemen thinking woulde haue yeelded came fiercely forthe fyghte hauing lost two shyppes shutte themselues within porte citie toke armoure resisted fotemen phanius hadde sette shore also cassius approched walles next sea vnfitte fight foreseeyng broughte turret set vp assayled citie sea land vnprouided suddayne matter must needes eyther force famine ouerthrowen wise men citie auoide daunger hadde talke phanius lentulus meane time cassius goterhodes taken citie choyce army vsing force hys entrie whiche thought pityed famishing citie cassius hauing citie captiuitie sate downe judgemente seate pitched speare token thrall badde feare commaunded armye vppon payne death make spoyle called rhodians bythe hard dealing cassius vvith rhodians name whome punished death fiue twenty would appeare banished toke money golde siluer holy publike appoynted daye euery man bring priuate substance proclaymed deathe hidde thing accuser proclaimed third part bonde libertie manye beginning hidde thing hoping spoyle woulde haue suche ende sawe men bewrayed brought forth feare hidden ground filthy pittes graues brought first thys captiuitie rhodes rule whichspoyle rhodes lucius varus left cassius encouraged speedy taking citie abundance money commaunded nation asia pay tenne yeares tribute whiche accordingly reported cleopatra great preparation ofcleopatra army nauye would sayle octauian antony friendship former caesar feare cassius sente murcus best legionarie men archer morta tanarum promontorie iaconica vvhere hercules tooke vvay hell brutus iycia countrey little asia betvveene pamphilia carta loca region ende greece illyria great region europe novve called lanonia fourescore armed shippes pelloponesus staying tenaro meant preuention get spoyle pell pon thing brutus licia great thus beganne army apuleius gathered tribute asia sixeteene thousand talentes sayled b ecia receyue decree senate shoulde vse gouerne macedonia whyche beeyng knowen tooke hym three legion illyria whyche vatinius lieutenante illyria delyuered vnto hym another legion antonyes brother macedonia whyche ioyning foure lorde eyghte legion greater parte whyche hadde serued vnder caius caesar hee hadde also greate number horseman archer shotte macedonian hee armed italian manner gatheryng thus hys army treasure good lucke thracia polemocratia prince wife slayne foe came totreasure prince childe deliuered brutus brutus care hyr sonne committed hym brutus handes whth hyr husbandes treasure deliuered chylde trayned citizenians tyll shoulde sette father ciricus ile propon vvith citie name kingdome founde treasure greate massies golde syluer whyche caused coyned make money cassius come vnto brutus consulted vpponthe seege zanthus citle iycia vvhiche shevved greate manlinesse agaynste h rpagus lieutenant cyrus theyr businesse determined beginne warre vppon licians xanthians beginne zanthians citie cutte sub be brutus vse haue comodity thing compassed citie ditche vpon made defence ditche fiftie foote deepe breadth proportionate accordingly upon stoode threw dartes arrowes vpo romanes diuided floud impassable brutus gote many pioners couered leather ouerthrow ditche parted army night dayes labour neuer ceassing matter great speede vsed souldioures cotend fastest though beginning seemed went tedious frutelesse worke yet end brought passe quickly contrary zanthians opinion whiche thoughte woulde haue bin many monethes done nowe shutte vp driuen within gate greate change gaue dayly assaultes gate euer changing brutus beateth dovvne trench men resisted put freshe sounde men place weery wounded long fortes helde beaten downe broken brutus thinking woulde follow commaunded souldioures retire gate zanthians thinking bee done negligence issued nighte lightes burne romanes engine encountred romanes laye themthe zanthianes killed theyr gate retired gate keeper whereof fearing enimie enter also shutte whereof followe greate slaughter gate long romanes goyng backe againe citizen came fired engine bycause former losse gate opened whose goyng two thousand romanes thrust followed entrie gate fell downe eyther suddaynely purpose matter failing held themthe romanes danger vp romanes eyther killed shut gate could opened without engine remoued zanthians threw vpon streetes aboue hauing neyther bowe arrowes gote straight place called sarpedono vtterly besette aboute romanes withoute carefull within brutus ranne among see help mighte assayed gate barred yron could get scale tower burned wherefore made scalyng ladder presently wente vp vppon timber vpon ladder tyed forkes rope threwe fasten wall climbed vp coardes nandians theyr oenandia citie al ra little region spand neyghboures enimies confederate brutus gate vp ouer rocky place whiche romanes saw followed great laboure whereby many fell gote ouer went ope gate layd timber thicke mighte come ouer whiche many brake gate strog within without helping souldioures entred verye boldly broken gate ouer wall vpon way made timber thrusting euery side zanthians greate shoutes set vpon romanes werethe romaine saued serpedono holy place closed citie sarpedono romanes gate carefull within without vsed violence make way caried furie bare downe afore making suche bast noyse mighte know within god working change setting sunne citie thus taken zanthians wente theyr house burned precious thing wilfully offered throtes cutte lamentation greate brutus fearing spoyle called souldiours backe athe taking zanth trumpet knewe done pitied state liberty sake sent truce vnto repelling brought bringing stackes hadde made house set fire burned themselues therewith brutus saued sacred thing tooke seruants xanthians hundred fifty woman free wythout husband thus three time zanthians perished theirthe oft sacking zanthus libertie beseeged arpalus lieutenant cyrus great killed themselues rather tha would slaues citie lefte graue say suffered like alexander philip sonne coulde abyde obey alexander though lord many landes brutus wente xantho patarea citie affayres citie vvhere gaue ansvver sixth monethes vvinter sea like vnto bringing army citie commaunded obediente vnlesse woulde suffer xanthians done xanthians come vnto bewayling theyr misfortune counselling see better themselues patareanes aunswering nothing xanthians spent rest day consultation daye beeyng come brutus approchyng cryed fro walles woulde obey hym anye thyng would opened patarea yeelded theyr gate entred neyther killing spoyling man theyr golde siluer city gathered togyther commaundyng euery bryng hys priuate goodes vpon paynes cassius sette vpon rhodians dyd seruaunt dyd accuse hys maister hydyng money shewed capitayne sente golde beeyng carryed away maister held peace hys mother wylling saue hyr sonne cryed hadde hydde money seruaunte required speake affirmed sayde true hadde hidde whereat brutus pitying yong man silence mother passioniustice sente away vnhurte money brought hanged seruante woulde haue betrayed hys maister lentulus time sent andriaca notable porte andriaca name tovvne diuers region cia citie lycia nauies myreans brake cheyne port went citie obeyed hys commaundementes deliuered money whych carryed brutus lycian sente brutus woulde obey hym ayde hym theyr power putte tribute vpon gaue ylas asia free men xanthians citie commaunded nauie lycia sayle wyth rest ab whence led footemen abo e cassius coming fro ionia goe togither seftus sestus pa diuided narrovv called hellesp murcus saylyng aboute peloponeso vnderstoode cleopatra wracke tempest aboute libya hir scattered nauye blowen laconica sicke laconia region peloponesus sometime called city vvere conteyned vnneth coulde gette home agayne shoulde seeme bryng greate companye vayne sayled towarde brunduse tooke ile nexte port kepte rest enimies army theyr victual macedonia antonie came agaynste hym fewe long shippes hadde nygh place annoyed hym wyth antony murcus tower hadde made sente hys armye partes greate shyppes obseruyng wynde lande shoulde bee intercepte murcus beeyng doubte called caesar coast sicelie matche sextus pompey whyche matter wente sorte pompey yonger sonne pompey greate beeing pompey yonger accompted caesar hys youth like archieue matter remayned spayne companye wyth fewe theeues roued sea knowen pompey sonne number roners increasing hauing good bande confessed pompey chylde wherefore remnant hys father brother armye resorted familiar captayne arabion beeyng dispeopled libya came vnto hym wee arabion ioyneth vvith pompey haue sayde hee hauyng thys multitude hys actes esteemed greater pyrate pompey name sounded ouer spayne full people officer caesar durst meddle wyth hym whyche caesar hearde sente carina wyth greater armye ouerthrowe pompey beeyng armed lyghte attemptes suddaynely sette vppon hym troubled hym tooke city small greate whyche cause caesar sente abnius pollio succeede carina warre pompey whyche time caesar killed trie power pompey reuoked senate went massilia heare done chosen admirall father gathered shippes could get togither kept sea would come rome three men power began sayled sicelie beseeged captayne bythinicus woulde receyue till hirtius fannius condemned proscription fledde rome caused place giuen pompey thus pompey lord sicelie hauing nauie iland nigh italy great army also fledde rome bond free city italie sent giuen pray souldioures detest theyr heart conquest three men much could secretly wrote many might get countrey nowe countrey fledde pompey hande accepted romaine time came also seaman libya iberia skylfull water muche pompey full captaynes shippes souldioures money whyche caesar vnderstoode sente saluidienus nauy thinking itsaluidienus easie matter put pompey sea passed italy help saluidienus reggio pasteth helpe saluidienus tovvne end calabra scylla pompey came againste saluidienus greate nauie making fyghte hard shallowes ile aboute scyleion pompey shippes lighter exceeded promptnesse experience skilfull seaman romanes heauyer greater vnfitte manner shallow sea whirle aboute thatthe fight sea betvveene saluidienus pompey billowes breake eyther side water pompey lesse troubled custome surgies saluidienus shippes could neyther stand firme lacke experience able vse are hauing fitte sterne turne sore troubled wherfore towarde sunne sette saluidienus first withdrew pompey also like losse shippes equall brused broken saluidienus repayred lying port narow sea balaron balaron caesar came gaue greate fayth reggians ipponeans reggio surdest citie italy nexte sicelie ippona vvas citie somtime called vibona vi falentia novve little tovvne called bona exempt gyuen victorie feared bycause nigh narow cut antony sente hym haste sayled brunduse hauyng lefte hand sicelie entendyng matche pompey murcus caesar came hee shoulde inclosed antony wente little brunduse waytyng way great shippes carried armie macedonia whiche wayted galley winde great euen coulde wish sayled away cheerefully without neede galley whereat murcus grieued wayted returne empty bothe caried ouer army full sayle tillthe army passeth army caesar antony passed murcus thus hindred fortune thought taried passage preparation new souldiours italy hinder much coulde prouisions army lefte domitius oenobarbus one cassius capitaynes came seruice great moment fifty shippes one legion archer caesar army hable victualed otherwise sufficiently italie might thought stopped thence thus one hundreth twentie galley shippes burden great army scoure sea ceditius norbanus whome caesar antony sente withantony caesar viij legion macedonia thence thracia went aboue hilles hundred xl myles tyll came beyonde philip tooke streyghts torpido salapian beginnyng philippi first called dathes torpido salapia straight thracia rascopolinus lande onely knowen way betwene europe asia let cassius army goyng castius abydus rascopolis rascus brother bloud thracian rascopolis rascus brother diuided king prince one region differed opinion raseos fauoryng antony rascopolis cassius eyther hauyng three thousand horse cassius capitaynes askyng way pol sayde shorte playne way goeth hence maronaea leadeth streights salamina beyng citie salamina ouer agaynst possessed ye enimie passed another way thrice muche aboute harde passe enimie goe lacke victuall whence might goe thracia macedonia hearde thys wente aeno maronaea lysimachia cardia receyue aeno vvhere vvas buried ci citie cost strayght cherronesus twoo gate nexte day came gulfe mellana mustered men ninetene legion armed brutus tenne cassius nine none full twoo thousande moste bee filled fourescore thousande horseman brutus foure thousand celtians lucitanians twoo thousandelucitamins parthenians thessalian thracian irians cassius iberian celtians twoo thousande arabian median parthian archer horsebacke foure thousande king prince galatian asia confederatesthe muster cassius army folowed greate hoste footemen horseman aboue fiue thousande great armie brutus cassius set order gulfe melane whiche proceeded warre appoyntyng menne necessity purged army sacrifice accordyng manner fulfilled promise made money giuyng libecally liberalitie ca winne mennes harte might well hauyng suche plenty richesse bycause many serued vnder caius casar none shoulde make stirre sight name newe caesar thought meete speake army greate seate sate none senatours pretor rest wel romanes straungers oode glad see one another stronger supposed boldnesse great hope grew sight army whiche thing increaseth good wil souldiours captaine hope comon getteth beneuolence noyse hereof made cease trumpet crier cassius bicause elder tha brutus came little foorth thus sayde army contention souldiour felowes rommon ation ca v therfore causeth v trust one conuenient performe haue promised whiche greatest trust wee fulfill whatsoeuer promise hereafter hope consisteth vertue souldiours v see aboute seate many great men senate also plentyfull furniture thyngs whiche see victuall armure money shippes confederate nation kyngs necessitie reason muste bee ready willyng agree whome prouision common cause hath ioyned togyther whereof twoo men enimies calumniate v know throughly serue v willyngly therefore nowe fitte declare cause whiche shall chiefly shew wee haue beste moste iuste pretence warre haue made caesar great folowyng hym leading warres continue hys friendes ende shall appeare entrapte v enimity mater peace blamed v friendes haue bene honored lawes order common wealth whereof law rule best people power remayneth father framed expelled king othe confirmed neuer receyue othe posteritie minde consenting puttyng execration thereof could longer endure see one man though friende beneficiall conuert himselse publique treasure army election officer fro people gouernments nation senate yet law steede lawes lord steede people prince respectes steade senate whiche peraduenture doe perfitely know consider valiantnesse warre may easily learne ye thing touched selues people warre obey generalles lord condition receyue v agayne peace senate prouidyng deceyued selues judge lawmaker accordyng company society creatyng consulles tribune pretor voyces iudging ye greatest thing punishing preferring thought worthie punishment preferment retribution citizen hath brought authoritie tothe authority people highe felicitie haue preferred worthy preferred haue rendred like thanke worthinesse made scipio consull testified scipio made consull time matter libya made whome woulde tribune euery age selues fitte cause neede rehearse many thing already knowe fince caesar bare rule coulde create neyther consull pretor tribune officer coulde testifie man vertue receyue mutuall testification selues speake chief man gaue thankes office authoritie iustice correction moste lamented could helpe tribune villanie done shoulde retayne power continual make sure inuiolable selfe see ought haue bene vntouched authoritie inuiolate ornament sacred co demned without iudgement commaundement one onely bycause seemed grieued woulde haue declared kyng whiche senate tooke moste grieuously sake tribuneship senate yet yee could plainly accuse man bring iudgement bycause hys mightie army whiche belonging publique state chalenged hys priuate pleasure whiche entendyng reuenged reste tyrannie coniured agaynst body sentence necessarily proceede beste seate done fewe soone done senate decreed common agreement openly rewardes killyng tirannes might put vre antony staying vnder pretence tumulte thinkyng selues worthy rewarde citie rather helpe countrey stayed bycause would contumely shewed caesar releasement tyrannie euery man decreeyng getfulnesse thing moste suretie matter shoulde bee made murder antony litle litle withdrawing people v senate gaue v great office prouinces army commaunding lande betweene ionia syria obey v whether punishing offendours honoring solemne purple ma sergeant whiche reason called pompey banishment beyng yong man acquaynted thing onely bicause sonne pompey great trauayled people rule bycause secretely spaine auoyde tyrannie restored value father goodes common treasure made ruler sea mighte haue authoritie beyng people faction acte token senate yee require done sentence onlesse inough confesse worde say togither saying rewarde great gift bicause whe say performe know men hadled proscribed without iudgement goodes publicate killed without sentence house theyr porch temple souldiours seruants enimies drawen priuie house pursued euery place ye law permitteth man flee common place neuer enimies head brought armour shippe stem heds consul pretor tribune questors gentleman brought rewarde appointed euill insurrection cruell euer sortes sodaine slaughter men straunge hate woman child freemade men seruaunts farre suche change citie turned author mischiefe three men whiche afore haue proscribed brother vncles answearyng one citie menne say taken wilde barbarous yet celtes cut head vsed villany wt toke prohibited man hyde flee yt warre neither euer vse citie haue take force neither haue persuaded yt priuate citie chief al doth suffer affirme reforme direct common wealth like thing tarquinius ye iniurie done one woman proceeding loue king banished act could neuer abide kingdome while three citizen thus terme v seditious say wil reuege caesar proscribe yt present whe killed many see codened rich house fauoring ye people gouernmet ye reason popey also proscribed wt v beyng far iberia ye deede bicause desceded father yt loued people state yt called home ye senate made admirall ye sea three men co dened death wome conspire caesar whome haue condened paymet people haue codemned pay vpo payne accusation proscribed onlesse whereof ought free yt al haue done canot yet performe theyr promise souldiours haue done wrong haue performed promise reserue time serue thus god hath shewed helpe v iustly god haue consider men see citizen haue seene pretor cosuls many time prayse see fleyng well doer louers people taking part wishing wel rest yt shal take hand iust reward propounded v ye preseruers yt would destroy care v killed c caesar yt would haue ruled alone others v remain despite tiranie take rule theselues leaue ye people according country lawes war take like cause make power tirannie whiche haue shewed proclamatio make matter yt cou trey set free may liue priuatly vnder lawes order al good men goddes chiefly iudge cause best hope maketh warre iust cause let trouble v though haue serued vnder caesar serued vnder vnder coutrie gift giuen caesar coutries publique neither armie b tus cassiw romanes felow soldiours romane captaynes whiche yt make warre v would vnderstad euery might safely lay downe armure reder army citie make choyse might profitable desire seing wil chose wicked tyranie haue shewed let v warre felows go sure hope serue free romane senate people libertie euery cried let v go let v go desire marche hande cassius glad forwardnesse caused silece made againe thus sayd god lord warre requite war felows faith proptnesse vnderstand prouisto captaines haue made men fauoured god farre exceede enimies number goodnesse haue armed legion equall haue fortified place good garde wel horsmen nauies passe aliance king prince nation asia surmount come vpo v face go vpon backe also haue pompey sicelie murcus ionia norbanus also lieth wt great nauie two legion stoppe passage sea place behinde v voyde enimies bymoney strength vvarre land sea mony whiche call strength warre want neither performe promise old soldiours exact much condened men supposed bycause none frends willing buy place haue put sale otherwise get nothing italy wasted sedition tribute condenations great care haue got present plety wherewith may gratifie agayne muche collected nation behynde v bee broughte vnto v victuall greatest wante mighty army haue none onely macedonia mountaine countrie thessalia straight region whiche great toyle muste conuey lande thyng brought parte iapigia ap affrica lucania iapigia pompeius murcus domitius shall shutte vp bothe haue shall haue sea ilandes place continent euery day without difficultie betweene thracia floudde euphrates without daunger enimy beyng backe wherefore power doe feate wyth speede doe leysure consume enimies hunger thys haue felow souldiours man prouision reste shall answeare order thorough god haue gyuen former matter promysed requityng fayth multitude gyfts greater labour wee worthily recompence accordyng determination goddes nowe shall cheerefully goe feate thys assembly exhortatios sake wil giue euen thys seate souldiour thousande fiue hundreth drammes italie capitayne bande fiue tymes muche tribune accordyng proportion hee sayde thus encamped army worke worde gyftes hee dismissed multitude remayned praysing br tus hym muche promysed doe shoulde bee conuenient gaue gyftes hande beside beste sorte many ployne thracia vvhich number greate army toke tvvo egles consideration receyued sente foorth bandes dorisco folowed long thys tyme twoo eagle sate vpon twoo siluer egles standerde beatyng say coueryng tarried still fedde publique prouision appoynted generalles night day battell flewe away two dayes comyng gulfe melana went oeno oeno dorisco place mounte serrio hyll ta serrio stretchyng sea kepte stil lande commaunded tullius cymbrus nauie one legion andtullius cymbros certayne archer goe chast bin deserte although land good thracian neyther vsing sea feare receyuing came contrary coast grecian calcidonians keeping sho e vsing sea flourished merchaundise tyllage thracian agreeyng receypt mountaynes till philip amyntas sonne ouercome chaldean others nothing seene passenger onely little chappell desert place tullius quickly passed ouer brutus company espyed fitte place measured campe keeping course shippes much norbanus lefte streight saporians vnprofitable bee saporia tle floud nestus kept thing happened desired sighte shippes norbanus troubled saporia called ceditius turpilio come hym hast theturpilio streightes turpilio left brutus men wente deceyte appearing norbanus ceditius toke sapeio manfully brutus people could passe wherfore afrayde least theysapeio must goe aboute shoulde haue done begynning passe euery place besette hauing time conuenient bycause mountaines season yeare standing stay rascopolis sayde vnto roscopolis sapei people floude nestu way compasse mountayne sapeorans three dayes iourney neuer gone men sharp rockes want water thicknesse wodde therefore woulde goe must carrie water passe streight way yet passable iourney solitarinesse birdes couldsolitary vvay discouer fourth day haue floud arpesso arpe h bru flouds thracia running floud ermo whence one day going philip mighte sette enimies suddayne whome might ouercome byca se none shift souldioures taughte thys way lacke hope take enimies aduantage part sente lucius bibulus appoynting rascopolis guide waye greate payne laboure wente made yet courage good hearte rather bycause sent afore returned sayde sawe floude farre fourth daye tyred wyth sharpenesse iourney troubled wyth thyrst water beeing spente whiche braughte three ayes bycause sayde therethe h rd passage ro water beganne feare least deceyued dyd beleeue sayde sawe floude bycause thoughte ledde wrong way therefore beganne exclayme crye rascopol came encourage reuiled threwthe dacourage age stone hym bibulus humbly besought woulde paciently abyde rest iourney little nyghte floude seene formost streyght eskrie made reason greate gladnesse whyche beeyng receyued followed came hyndermost brutus cassius vnderstandyng ledde rest armie thys harde way crie greate hearde enimies whereby coulde preuente rascus brother rascopolu hearyng crie suspected wasa oyfull crye di couereth enimie enimie maruelled greate armye coulde passe harde iourney voyde water whyche scarcely passable wylde beastes hyghnesse woodes hee amphipoli c tie h vvcen streyghte tolde n banus fledde streyghtes amphipoli thus thracian breethren holpe theyr armyes one leadyng vnknowen way descrying call dionisio mynes golde called vntouchable dionisio nonlatin alphabet place holy inu olable place campes epidamnum du zzo casar sicke goyng philippi myle two hylles standing two mile philippi asunder dyd encampe cassius towarde south brutus towarde north myndyng followe norbanus bycause hearde antony hand caesar remaining epidamnum sicknesse fielde knowen bee fayre battayle hylles campe aboute one syde fennes water strymo side streightes desertes vnpassed pathes middest hylles myle ouer way betweene asia europe gate thys place fortifyed trenche trench leauing gate middest seemed one pe floude nygh whyche call ganga gangites behynde gangites thasus ile nigh thracia nea ilande citie vvhere say philoctetus vvas bitten serpent dyed sea whyche hadde theyr prouiston passage entrie made thasus orehouse proui ion ij wyth gallyes passage nea citie xe myle ioyning place tray theyr armyantony antony came great hast insending get amphibol stay warre finding possessed n r anus glad lefte furniture warre wyth one legion p arius ledde wente boldly camped fielde myle enimies streighte seene want abundance army one aboue frutefull ground beneath bottome anto e camp wodde mountaynes fenne water riuer pooles pittes digged time hadde victual thaso fewe furlong amphipole aboue thaso ile citie oueragainst floud n ssus antony camp fiftie myles seemed antony driuen thus bycause good grounde playne beeing hollowe whych reason ouerflowyng floud sometime found water sweete sufficiente making welles pittes thys boldnesse although proceeded necessitie yet astonished enimies nygh soone encamped suche contempte wherefore made manye trench fortifyed euery place walles rampyers cassius seeyng antonyes furie greate entrenched left fenne omitted streightenesse parte vndefenced syde brutus whyche hyllie cassius hadde fenne sea rest beeyng taken trench ditch gate thus placed onely wyth horseman sometime skirmished thing prouided caesar yet able fighte came litter hys armye hys captaynes sette themselues order fyghte brutus dyd lyke higher place easie seene yet intended come downe waste theyr enimie wyth wante either nineteene legion armed footemen butthe number b uies brutus selver number caesar thracia hors caesar ant nie aboue thirtene thousand brutus cassius twenty thousand multitude men boldenesse vertue captaines armoure furniture souldioures goodly shew side yet nothing many day bycause biutus woulde strike battell consume stopping victuall enimies hadde al asia serue nighe place bring thing sea enimie hadde little neither susficient certain aegipt couldvv campe receiue nothing bicause dearth wasted cou trey fro spaine affrica bycause pompey fro italy bycause murcus domitius macedonia thessalia could great deale supplie want whiche place onely succor cause brutus refused battaile antonie fearing determined wise giue battel possible make fen passable might come vpon backe enimy take victuall came thase therfore tyme bringing men foorth order battaile antony polliey pa nefulnesse banner displayde appointed parte armye bothe night daye make straighte pathe cutting downe reedes laying tymber stone eyther side shoulde shrinke foundation wherof pyled made strong maruellous silence thicknssee reed tooke away sight worke antony maketh vvay fenne wrought tenne dayes sent certaine bandes direct way space lefte betweene tooke made many tower cassius maruelling deuise pollicie intending defeate castells made antony entrenched residue fenne beginning campe sea pauing making bridge ditch vpon sure ground taking also waye antony hadde made neyther could go abroad helpe though woulde antony perceyuing midde day rage furie brought whole army otherwise appointedb vvhat occa patte beg nne turned vppon ification cassius campe fenne bringing engins scale though woulde charge vppon campe betweene army great boldnesse brutus souldioures grieued thinking shame let escape wythoute comm ement sauing one capitaine sette vppon theyr fla ke brutus menne hauyng thus begonne matter gaue charge vppon caesar army readinesse putte place tooke campe whiche common caesar antony caesar hymselfe absent shifting day dreame hadde hee writeth booke remembraunces antony seeing fight begunne gladde brought enimie c sar absent dreame yet thoughte good turne playne leaste hee shoulde disturbe battaile therefore doe rest wyth fier enesse beganne running manner marched mounted vp resistaun e made verythe rie antony vehement force beat backe battaile cassius keepyng order appointed astonished thys feate done beyonde reason antony hadde thus broken brake ouerthwart trench vtolence filling ditche stinging downe rampires rest gate di ressed warder entred weapon throwne vppon passed ouer broken walles ouer dead bodyes al fight doone ftercelye sodainelye came oute fenne helpe driue backe againe gotte wall wyth lyke vehemencie antony entred cassius campe stil fighting without campe thought strog therefore fewe kept whiche cause easily taken soldtors cassius thus put taketh campe worse knowing campe taken fled verye co fusedly matter equal sids erutus ouercame caesar battell lodged campe antony ouerthrew cassius take maruellous bol enesse spoyled campe slaughter confused greatnesse playne raysing duste one knewe another till sometimes asked called due place retourned loaden gere like cariers rather soldiors threw away tooke reioycing one another bicause wel knowne much confusion cassius side numbring siaues al sort slaine viij caesar twice many cassius put campe could get wente hill phillippi behelde doone hee neyther coulde well see heare duste noyse onelye hee sawe hys owne campe spoyled wherfore hee commaunded ca co ded pindarus kyll hym pindarus hys page kyl hym owne sworde pindarus stayde matter meane tyme messenger came tolde brutus ouercome caesar possessed campe whiche cassius saide tell ouerthrowne victorye turned pindare sayde doste thou ridde thys dishonor offering hys throate pindarus cutte thus saye cassius died tel sort asome thinke c kylled himselfe vvyr dagger th killed caesar bande brutus horseman came bring good newes thought bene enemy sente titinius knowe truth horseman receiuing great ioy srend made loude noyse cassius fearing fallen enimies hand said thus haue suffered see friend taken oure enimies wet pindarus neuer seen thinke pindarus ende cassius kylled byrth day cassius life chaunfing day foughten battel daye birth titinius killed selfe long tariance brutus bewayling death cassius rare romaine brutus teth death ca one like founde vertue valiantnesse called happye hee ridde care trouble whych would bring like ende committed body secretly buryed army shoulde discouraged sighte withoute meate sleepe remayned night setting cassius men frame day come ennimies order againe fight seeme haue worsse brutus perceyued intente sayde lette v arme also make shewe likewise wee inferiour done enemie retired sayde pleasantly friendes seemed prouoke v weaker wil putte matter tryall day field fought philippi ye vvas light great seate done onio domitius caluinus lcade gret ship legios caesar name martial called honor valiantnesse led also bad guarde two thousande men foure troupe horse number gathered together fewe galicyes murcus otnobarbus mette one hundred thirtie long shippes fewe former hulkes fledde good sayling sodayne ceassing winde sea calme still caught fortune giuen enimies without feare bo ged brake hauing helpe fewe galleyes compassed many greate diuers trauaile perill linking themselues togither cable weapon courage putting themselues order enimie vse though ouercame murcus threw dart ofnre quickly burne byndings ship se uered asunder auoid fyre galley ready hinder euery way wherewith souldiours beyng grieued especially martialls beyng better valiantnesse ea c shoulde p r lacke fyghting kylled themselues fire leapte enimies galley kylled killed themselues shyppes halfe burned wet way carying men consumed fyre wat thirst cable planck carried rockes desert shoars saued beyond al reason continuing flue dayes eating pitche osf cable sayles helde till briuen lande byllows thece many gaue themselues enimies ouercome calamitie vij galleyes yeelded whose souldiers murcus tooke caluinus general came fiue dayes biund se one shippe thoughte tocaluinus haue bene lost happe onio day fielde philippi whether wil call shipwrack shipfight euils cocurring together known caused greater feare brutus called army together sayd thus nothing fellowe souldiers yesterdayes fight butoration tus maketh superiour enimies gaue charge cheerfully warning giuen fourth legion renoumed whome battaile confidence ouerthrew vtterly army droue campe campe first toke spoyled much haue farre ouercome losse last batail might haue made ende trauayle chose rather fall spoyle followe enimies ouercome many running set vppon spoile one haue oure campes haue recompenceof losse double hauing aduantage fight much wise exceede may learne captiues want victual striuing difficult bringing euident getting little sicelie sardinia libya iberia haue none pompeius murcus oenobarbus keping sea two hundreth three score shippes macedonia haue consumed haue thessalia long serue therefore see offer fight thinke chiefely forced hunger doc choose death rather handes let v contrarywise foresee hunger may fight v may take feebler consumed shal fit let v carried affection due tyme thinke flownesse quicknesse experience haue oure eie vppon sea backewarde ministreth v suche foode seruice see victorie without daunger abide distruste thoughe come forth prouoke v stronger worke yesterday shewed auoyding feare courage desire keepe may shew forth shal require perfect reward victorie god shall haue giuen sentence v perfect deed giue vnto yesterdayes vertue giue euery souldiour thousand drammes capitaines proportion requireth thus said straight diuided gifte euery legion say promised giue macedonia thessalia spoile caesar antony seeing brutus would vnwillingly come fight called people antony said thus yesterday worke men perceiue enimies word diuide antones oration chased v spoiled campe indeede confesse al affirme vnto neither next day yet willingly wil come fight certain surety yesterday fear losse maner contention force weaker go place dydde gather greate armye mighte inhabite deserte thracia making walles made defence fearo comming vppon minding keepe yesterday ouerthrow elder expert captaines desperation kylled himselfe whiche greatest declaration miserie therefore shall prouoke aunswere come hilles truste holdes steede handes romaine men enforce againe ye forced yesterday thinking shame giue place fearfull prouoked refraine holden worse men keeping come hither liue playne tarryed woulde suffise v speedy attemptes bee giuen warre wise may longer continue peace tymes trauaile muste foresee cannot complayne yesterdayes assaulte attempte required shewe vertue capitaines grieued yesterdayes spoile rich haue got conquest lost yesterday remaineth safe enimie must yeeld v ouercome wil go forth get must set forth sight yesterday tooke sufficietly happily susficient owne haue brought togither haue violence spoiled oute asia comming countrey haue lefte home moste precious thing onelye broughte necessary hadde anye thyng estimation compted generalls whyche ready giue thys victorye recompence losse sake giue reward victorie euerye souldioure fyue thousand dram capitaine bande fyue tymes muche tribune double muche captaine antony thus sayde sette order fight ennimie woulde come forwarde antony grieued stil set battaile ray brutus hadde army good order needed come fyght taken al wayes prouision thing needefull hill nighe cassius campe harde enimie take bycause nighnesse made danger archer cassius entrenched man place giue bold attempt vnlooked abandoned casars men take hill brutus caesar soldiors night wt iiii legion tooke carying many hurdle hide resist ye shot whe hil led x legion halfe myle towarde sea firste foure added two legion take deuise thing euen sea way beside sea fennes mean might distresse take victual enimie brutus made deuises setting vp fort camp casars souldiors also set vp new worke nowe yt famme euidet increased euery day greatnesse fear campe casar could longer haue sufficient brought sto thessali fro yt sea hope ye enimies lord yt ship late losse ionto beyng tolde bothe afraide winter hande lying fenny plaine deliberation thing sent legion armed achia prouide necessarye victualls north p lopo sende speede able auoide present perill make deuice reste campe doe anye offend enimie came foorth showts called brutus fight scoffing rayling antonie prouoketh fight doubting whither refraining fight like man besieged rather man beraught wit knowne beginning beleeued rather bycause want losse ionto perceyuing enimies one mischiefe another determined man besieged way auoide battell rather come hand men driuen hunger desperation thing hauing onely hope hand army lacke consideration thinke grieued woman within shut vp ydlenesse feare captain also content blamed brutus opinion thinking courage souldiors sooner ouerthrowe ennimie cause hereof proceeded brutus courteous milde al esie hin vnlyke cassius seuere imperious al thrnges commaundements kept without resistance souldiours asking question reasoning woulde haue done brutus woulde doe nothing withoute opinion captaines thorowe gentle nature length hys armye company rowtes beganne openly aske meaneth oure general wherein haue offended late ouercome tha distressed enimies tooke campe brutus suffered purpose dyd call ye assemblie least shoulde forced vnseemely rude multitude beareth purpose chiefly hyred sorte whose manner euer lyke vnto vnstable seruauntes hope change maisters set safetie contrary faction captaynes also angrie wishing doubt armye beeing forwardnesse would notable feate thing hapt amisse fighte myghte returne theyr campe defende themselues theyr wall brutus muche greeued wyth captaynes fearyng woulde putte hym daunger lyghte dealyng wyth army whereas wythoute doubte sharpe fortune sure victorie daungerous consented hys al destruction thus reproouing like pompey greate forced fyghte commaunding ut one r led like pompey captayne rather obeying souldyoure thynke spake hyde feared least armye sometyme serued caesar woulde take occasion reuolte whyche beginning cassius feared gaue none occasion offence brutus brought vnwillingly sette hys men order trenche wylling marche farre byll myghte haue theyr retyre neede nigh bee surer easie marche agaynste enimies agayne side greate preparation thinges greate desire feate boldnesse necessitie one feare hunger iust reuerence compellyng captayne come forthe shoulde worse theyr promise weaker theyr wordes bee thoughte rather gilty payne theyr rashnesse worthye prayse theyr good counsell brutus goyng among horsebacke shewed seuere countenance exhorted fewe wordes tyme woulde serue would needes fight would needes force otherwisethe hauyng victory deceyue neyther selues thys hope haue hyll fyghte youre backe youres youre enimies doubtfuli case beyng betweene famine hauyng sayde thus rode aboute encouraged bandes wyth crye receyuing hym hys greate prayse caesar antony goyng aboute theyre offered theyr ryghte handes nexte seuerally exhorted dyd hyde theyr hunger myghte stirre presente boldnesse haue founde men enimies haue caesar antony wee desired theyr trenche lette none afrayd gyue charge gyue place sette vpon lette hym rather chose famine dolorous destruction bee auoyded oure ennimies death bodyes whyche youre boldnesse weapon trauayle easily gyue presente case requireth speedinesse maye deferre nothyng tyll morrowe thys daye must determine thynges eyther wyth per te victorie valiant deathe haue victory shall winne one daye victuall money shyppes campes rewardes victory v thys wee must remember gyue charge vpon wee doe fyrste purpose myddest theyr force forwardnesse shutte theyr campe dryue playne hylles warre bee begunne agayne oure enimies dryue v idlenesse agayne whyche theyr faynienesse haue hope fighte put theyr trust retrayning battell caesar antonius thys sorte exhorted theyr souldyoures euery man hadde respect appeare worthye souldyoures suche captaynes styrred auoyde wante suddayne losse ionian sea rather wyth payne hope neede abyde vttermost consumed wyth euill cannot bee auoyded matter standyng thus euery one moued agaynste hym next anger side encreased much filled boldnesse incessable nowe dyd remember citizen togyther enimies nature bloude threatned one another sonature countrey forgotten suddaynely hadde rage furie quenched nature reason prophecyed alyhe sydes daye feate iudge romaine cause iudgemente gyuen deede day beeyng spente preparationtvvo eagle token fight tyll ninth houre two eagle falling betweene campes soughte togyther great silence eagle flying toward brutus whereat shrill crye made enimies broughte forthe theyr standardes marche fierce vehement little needed arrowes stone dartes manner warre vsed none comming order battell wherein broughte vp buckled wyth naked swordesthe veheme souldioures layde eyther syde put one another theyr ray one theyr safetie rather victorie victory comforte theyr captayne whome prouoked fighte slaughter fightes great bodyes beene away put theyr place serue former rankes captaynes riding aboute beholding euery encouraged valiante comforted ke paynes continue still laboure shrunke changed boldnesse fronte myght bee continued length souldyoures caesar eyther feare famine caesar fe citie brutus men blamed ouercame battell enimies putte backe heape heauie masse yet turned agayne theyr place slowly wyth order ray broken went away faster second third bande turned wyth disorderedly thrusting one vpon another broken themselues theyr enimies withoute stay pursued tyll ledde euidently caesar ould youres remembryng theyr promise chiefly fiercely followyng gaue assaulte vppon theyr campe daungerously euery de sette vppon compelled slee whereof wente towarde sea hylles floude zygat thys alteration beeyng made g nerall diuided rest caesar keepe fledde theyr campe holde campe hymselfe antony followe fleer ouerthrowe remainers assaulte campes wyth dent violence putte ruyne fearing captaynes myghte escape hym gather another armye sente hys horseman wayes issue filde stoppe ed e wente hyll hyll rascus captayne beeyng theyr g yde bycause hys experience way passed trench rocky place chacing fledde keeping fleeyng followed brutus hymselfe lucinus sawe fast running hym stayde though bin brutus prayed myghte ledde antonie lucinus acte saue brutus caesar whiche rather thoughte brutus auoydyng hys vnplacable enimie antony vnderstandyng hee broughte hym wente towarde hym good order considering fortune woorthynesse vertue man howe myght vse hym beeyng hande l cinus meetyng wyth hym verye boldly sayde brutus taken neyther shall vertue euer takenboldnesse vi e deceyuing men thus thee whiche worde horseman beeyng ashamed antony comfort sayde haue hunted none game better thynke muche friende better enimie committed lucinus wayte vpon one friend vsed hym hys assured brutus fledde mountaynes conuenient multitude night might returne hys campe take hys way sea hearde passage kepte hee continued people armes say hee looked vp starres saying iupiter thou knowest cause euils meaning brutus vvordes meanyng antonie vvhom sayde punished antony repentance trenche dead body antonie say antonie priuate peril confesse saying might haue ruled brutus cassius slaue octauio night antonie continued armes might haue brutus makyng trench dead body baggage brought togither caesar labouring till midnight withdrew himselfe sicknesse committyng charge army norbanus brutus perceiuing wayte enimies made hauing foure legious wel warded desired chiefe host whiche ashamed repented act sende see might make way passe traynes recouer owne kept abadoned tentes vnwilling considering brutus men gyueth ouer god agaynst tolde generall giuen euill counsell hauing tried fortune oft woulde put hope matter brutus sayde friendes longer profitable countrey hee called one moste rat brutus eyng persuaded flee sayde yea vvith hand vvith death brutus vvherin vv le n vertue vvas ouercome fortune saying overtue vnhappy vvordes ely vvi e c one onely fault brutus ca trusty friendes named rato epir wylled hym kyll hym ou hande entreatyng hym take better aduice called one hys seruauntes sayde brutus thy laste commaundement thou shalte wante neyther thy friende thy seruaunt hauyng thus sayde hee thruste hys orde brutus side neyther r sistyng helpyng thus cassius brutus died moste nobl worthy romanes one fa te uer folowed vertue whome ca caesar enimies takyng pompeyus part made reendes friendes vsed chyldren senate euer greate regarde pitted chaunce twoo sake decr acte obliuion thyngs vvorth u l ca l de sente prouinces shoulde seeme flee omittyng yet honour caesar forgettyng hys feates whose vertue fortune maruelled beyng aliue hee dead buryed publique expence proclaymed hys workes bee immortal apoynted office prouinces part assignement findyng thyng better caesar determined care regard men brought suspitionthe estimation ut ca brought calum false accusation honored al men best banyshed men thought honorable though pompey hande whose cause vnpardonable farre voyde reconciliation needyng many thing scarsly hauing two legion gathered twentie legion many thousand horseman twoo hundred long shippes sufficient furniture money moste plentifull willyng vnwillyng nation city ouercame enimiesthe povver tu ca contrary faction hadde rule realmes macedonia euphrates whome soeuer ouercame brought societie hadde moste trusty vsed king prince parthian although enimies matter small accompt came greate thyngs coulde abide bycause woulde accustome barbarous hostile nation among romanes moste maruell thatthe souldiours ed vnder caesar vvere sty u army beyng moste parte caius caesar desirous felicitie good affection coulde turne contrary parte killer wente agaynst caesar sonne faythfull antony fellow rule enterpryse cta ian forthe souldiours tu ca antony none lefte brutus cassius ouercome antonie brunduse forsoke triall pretence paynes bothe vnder pompey nowe themselues name people gouernment ouer glorious commodious bothe sawe coulde bee longer profitable countrey dispatched themselues alike seuerall considerationsmaners ca u cassius utable combattes neuer g ue ouer onely hauyng regarde daungermaners brutus brutus euery place full affabilitie gentlenesse ignoraunt philosophy yet men acte agaynst caesar done contrary thyng beyng simple worke small matter agaynst freende contrary reason agaynst well doer vnthankfullytheyr faulte agaynst caesar whome h e saued warre agaynst chiefe ruler iniustly senate house agaynst holy man hauyng holy vesture suche officer neuerthe vvorthynesse c god punished death caesar brutus ca u toke cassius lyke profitable menne countrie empire whiche god punishe many time gaue token cassius purgyng hoste sergeant put crow e wrong way hys golden consecrate vesture victory fell grounde many greate byrdes sitting vpon campe made noyse swarmes bee continually aboute brutus say celebratyng hys birthe day amo vpon thetokens brutus sea beyng nothyng mery aboute without occasion caste forth verse cruel destenie l tone sonne doth destroy vvordes patroclus vsed brutus goyng army betweene asia europa watchyng night lighte fayled fearefull shape appearedthe bad angel brutus hym whome hee boldly askyng man god hee vision answeared brutus thyne euill lucke philippi appeare agayne vnto thee say sawe hym laste fight armie wente campe ethiopian mette whome euill token killed thing also diuine worke cassius invvork god ca ius despayreth one victorie yet indifferent gaue ouer hope without cause brutus dryuen hys good determination refrayning fighte fallyng handes forced famine brutus ouerruled hymselfe hauyng plentyfull foode shippes commandement rather ouercome hys iers hys enimies fought many fieldes neuer hurte bothe killer themselues caesar thus cassius brutus punished brutus body beyng founde antonie cladde purple pall hee hadthe body brutus mother vsed fire hee sente relikes hys mother seruilia brutus army hearde hee dead sente messenger caesar antony pardoned diuided army beyng aboute xiiij yeelded also kepte gyuen poyl ortes tentes whiche gyuen caesar antony souldiours spoyled noble men brutus slayne battayle offered themselues freely general purpose continued fighte kylled lucius ca u c sonne cassius brother sonne cassius cato sonne falling many time among enimies forsaken tooke hys headpeece mighte knowne notably kylled bothe labeo knowne wisedome father labeo nowlabeo renou ed knowledge lawes made graue tente bigge inough body takyng order al thing seruaunts signified wife child would haue done tooke letter seruaunts carry taking right hande loued best turnyng romane manner made free beyng turned tooke sworde offred throte hisa tente graue tent graue ra u thracian brought many mountaynes desired reward saue hispolicie brother brother ra polis whereby may perceyued beginning thracian variance bicause two great army debate shoulde passe country diuided cert fortune wanne might saue hym po brutus vvi lo portia wife sister ca yonger heard th read diligently kept seruants tooke fire har swalowed cole noble men fledde thaso sayled awaye gaue themselues rest army s cor s cor ant thy armye lucro ibulo men like aucthoritie mighte take counsell themselues doe rest many gaue themselues antony sayled towarde hase mony armoure plenty victual preparation whiche great thus caesar antony singular boldenesse gotte suche iorney two fight foote none done forthe mightinesse army suche great army romaine euer came handes gathered common citizen beste gentleman ignorant fighting long
