practised th selues straunge barbarous nation one language one arte war one strength exercise hard matched therefore among themselues none euer vsed boldenesse fiercenesse fight token number deade men equall bothe fight fewer ouercome caesar antony souldiours fulfill captaines one day one worke chaunging extreame danger famine feare death victuall abundant safety stable victory notable followed ofthe fight hevved vvhat vvould become rome fight wise romaine prophesie common wealth chieflie iudged feate lyke haue come populare state agayne acte anye suche trouble among themselues variaunce betweene caesar antony whiche laste among romains thing meane tyme done vnder pompey brutus cassius brutus friend fledde hither thither retaining renmaunt great preparation neither done boldnesse force men city captaynes prouinces nobilitie senate glory brutus cassius ende fourth booke ciuill dissentions p fift booke appian alexandria ciuill dissentions romaine deathe brutus cassius octauian went italy antonie aegipt cleopatra meetyng loue th ouercame firste sight loue brought destruction aegipt vtter ruine wherof egipt also shal part volume great giue ye title bicause many ciuill battailes intermedled cassius brutus lyke ciuill dissentions wythoute generall commaunded leading army till sextus pompey seconde son pompey pompey greate lefte faction sette vp depriued brutus friend lepidus nowe putte dignitie al authoritie rested antony octauian whiche thing fell sorte cassius surnamed parma brutus cassius wente parma battaile lefte asia army nauy gather mony cassius deade hauing hope brutus tooke thirtie rhodian ship thought sufficient burned rest holy one excepted rebel shippes departed clodius sent thither brutus thirtene shippes fynding rhodians reuolted brutus also deade tooke away garrison three thousande souldiors sayled cassius orulus ioyne hauing many otherio l shippes mony gathered rhodes reuolted nauy thing power resorted office asia made legion souldiours sea wel could seruants people cou try ilands came cicero son tullius th s iland aenobarbus cicero diuerse noble citizen sled thaso great army sufficiet nauy good captaines taking lepidus also band whiche kept brutus creta force sailed murcus oenobarbus gulfe ionia diuiding themselues part went sicelie sextus pompey part remained oenobarbus priuate faction thus remnant brutus cassius newe armye made octauian antonie sacrificed victorie philippi gaue thankes souldiors performe promise octauian went italy distribute lande souldiors choose health antony wet among octauian goeth italy antony goeth beyond sea nation beyond sea gathered mony hie souldiours diuided betwene land lepidus frace beyonde alpes octauian woulde haue free according determination decree vncle caesar lepidus accused fauour pompey part lepidus accused founde false octauian determined giue hym prouinces licenced old souldiors except eight thousand desiring serue still diuided betweene apointed bandes body added eleuen legion wente brutus xiiij thousande horse fphesus novv f lg cittye ionia vvhere vvas goodly temple buylded amazos antony pardoneth pergama cittie asia far floude ca troy vvas called name laodicea citie asia vvhose citizen eno augustus made king whiche antony tooke hys iorney sixe legion tenne thousande horse octauian foure thousande horse fiue legion antony shoulde receiue antony calenus whiche lefte italy sayled ionian sea whe antony come ephesus made solemne sacrifice god forgaue souldiors cassius sanctuarie asked pardon petronius except many conspired caesar death quintus betrayed dolobella cassius laodicea grecian nation inhabit pergamo asia great assembly ambassador came peace spake wise men grecia kyng attalus testament bequeathed vnto v whome founde beneficiall vnto attalus forgaue tribute payd attalus tyll wee neede tribute bycause troubled peace sette tribute vpon accordyng euery man value myghte exact wythout perill required pay portion yearely wee myghte bee partaker youre yearely fruites feele youre losse harde tune bayliffes requiring ought dyd iniurie c caesar forgaue thirde parte youre tribute forbadde iniurie done heereafter committed gathering tribute youre countrey people good citizen call man tyrant haue giuen much money kyllers man deserued v reuenged hys quarrell forasmuch fortune fauouring iust cause hath decreed woulde ryght continued armes fellowes bin punishable bycause doe easily beleeue compulsion forgiue greater punishment haue neede money land city pay armyes whiche eyghte twenty legion wt appertenaces maketh thousand beside horseman remnant common sort multitude may wel coniecture charge octauian gone italy diuide land city vnto myght say bid italy packing leaue city countrey house temple religion youre auncesters monument onely require money could beare meane part heare thinke wil goe conteted away much gaue enimies two yeares whiche ten yeares tribute much wil require sauing must paid one yeare bycause nenessitie exacteth may acknowledge thakes confesse punished haue deserued thus spake please ye souldiors promised reward meeting modena xl legion many cosumed fully ended tale whe ye grecian sate vpo tribute put vp grecian ony ye ground wt many demonstratios accusing ye crueltie brutus cassius shewing wer rather worthy pardo tha punishment would gladlye giue friend bereft enimies giuen theyr monies fayled iewels ornament coyned themselues length much ado obtayned paye nine yeares tribute two yeares went prouinces lucius brother cassius cassi p doned antony fearing themselues hadde harde mercye shewed ephesus came submitted themselues pardoned except priuie conspiracie inexorable comfort city yt priuileges giue iy xamb exhorted restore cittie ilands giuen rhodian called clade nigh iland g non vvhere child vvel brought vp proued euill asia l people e called call part syria next arabia playne countrey antony partiall cl op excuseth li grieuouslye oppressed gaue priuilegies lycian exhorted xanthians et store citie gaue rodians andrus tenus naxus mindus shortly toke bycause sharpe gouernement graunted tarsentans laodicians libertie made free al citizen tarsus bin taken priuiledge receiued athenienses gently gaue tenus aegi icon c sciathus peparetis going phrygia mysia gallogrecia cappadocia cilicia cael ia pale ituraea prouinces syria put gret tributs vpon toke vp matter controuersie prince cittes euen hee wold wher controuersie cappadocia betweene sifinn ariarathes preserred si na gl phy fayre mother sake syria deliuered townes tirannes cilicia accused cleopatra bycause helpe caesar war much excuse hir selfe boaste sent oure legion dolobella beginning war hauing prepared nauy letted tempestes chaunce dolobella ner ouercome loked notwithstanding cassius twice threatning hyr contemned murcus also riche nauy sayled ionian sea beside loss fel sicke wherfore returned sea victorie antonie caughte minde sight hir hee began loue hir like yong man though fourty yeeres oue age nature seemeth euer pliant thing hadde minde hir captaine horseman alexandria vnder gabinius leauing woonted diligence hee thing cleopatra woulde haue without respecte god mannes lawe much sente souldiours kill arsino hir sister fledde temple diana cry mercy commaunded tyrians deliuer serapion captaine e cleopatra tyrus sometime ande oyued land alexander king aegypt deade neuer founde cypre cleopatra fledde safetie tyrus likewise commaunded arcadian doe fugitiue bicause toke vppon person ptolomeus cleopatra brother ouercome nilus caesar neuer seene also commaunded megabysus pr e diana ephesus bee deliuered bicause receyued arsinoe queene ephesian made sute cleopatra let goe soone changed affection beginning histhe lightnesse antony trouble ende life cleopatra gone home sent horseman spoyle palmirians cittie farre euphrates lighte offence beeing obiected fashion bicause dwelling confines romanes parthian seemed bee doubtful faith merchant brought fetched ware india perside romanes deede enrich horseman palmirians vnderstanding conueyed away good garded archer wherin excelled horseman finding citie voyde went away emptie vnhurtfull thys occasion warres parthia seemed ryse many tyrannes countreye syria resorting countrey till antiochus thethe state syria good sonne vnder king successoures seleucus brought forme prouince scaurus scaurus ius crassus president whome senate sent successours among gabi made warre vpon alexandrian crassus succeeded gabinius slayne parthian death caesar sedition rysing euery city holden vsurper partheans helping nowe hadde entred syria crassus deade one alluring another whence antonie droue away made flee parthian done put tribute vpon people pacifie prouince commotion palmirians diuided armye wintering place went cleopatra egipt whome princely receyued taried winter hir lyke priuate man antony pr man kingdome eyther shewe rule perteyned fitte frequent feastful dayes winter leauing care captaine put greekes robe garment athente s egiptians priestes vse resorted onely temple scoo e assembly philosopher keping company grecian obeyed cleopatra whose cause hee hee sayde made voyage caesar octauian meane time fell sicke iourney octa io sicke rome verie dangerously brundusi sayd deade recouered entred citie deliuered antony letter captaines strayght commaunded calenus deliuer two legion octauian wrote africa sextius deliuer prouince done dyscharging lepidus suspition committed africa diuision italy souldiors gouernement solde good condemned men yet bought going place souldiors dwelling diuide landes founde greate trouble soldiors required euery best citie italie chosen warre contrary city required italy might contributarie diuision place dwelling might apointed lot soldiors also required valewe land bycause co mon pay olde yong woman child assembled togither temple publique place lamenting complayning natiue italy putte theyr house landes prisoner warre people wepte misery moste remembred done common wealth priuate lust fewe whiche ouerthrowne common weale gaue soldiours rewardes gifte ready serue turnes stil k epe italy downe common state caesar appeased city shewed cause necessitie sufficient hee sayth truth neyghbours oppressed soldioursi tiablenesse soldiours goyng beyond boundes catching giuen taking euer best neyther frayed caesar rebuke cotented new gift litle force prince neede helpe hold vp ambition ende fiue yeares approched euery one neede seuerall helpe maintayne lordship soldiours neede keepe stil giuen neede souldiours fauour confirme rule caesar also comforted needy soldiours gift borowyng money temple wherby wonne harteso excl po beyng thankefull whome receyued landes goodes spoyled cry vpon whiche suffred soldiours sake lucius brother antonie beyng consull wife fuluia manius ouersight thing absence benefite might seene onely octauian haue thanke generall defrauded fauour soldiours vsed subtill meanes placyng inhabitauntes might deferred till antony commyng whiche seemed vnpossible haste souldiours desired octauian mighte place antony souldiours although agreement graunted caesar antony souldiers placed friendes octauian antonie whiche denied true therefore bryngyng f luia antony litle child campe besought instantly suffer antonie defrauded antonie renounced thankes renowne gotten antony name glorious among soldiours others victory philippi attributed antonie onely bycause caesar sicknesse though octauian sawe couenaunt broken yette antony sake hee content gyue place antony legion placed wyth much licence shoulde seeme bee inferiour benefite caesar city neare whose land deuided souldiours whiche suffered many iniuries theoppression city souldiours citizen cry octauian diuision landes nowe cruell proscription lyfe enimies punished innocentes plagued caesar well perceyue iniurie coulde remedie neyther hee money wherewith pay possessours lande neyther could rewardes victory deferred warres myght ensue pompey beyng lorde sea pompey aenobarbus murcus lordes sea caused famine cittie victuall beyng kepte away aenobarbus murcus hauyng army gatheryng nauie souldiours vnwillyng excepte haue promyse kepte space fiue yeares almoste come muste haue neede souldioursinsolencie souldiours therefore bare insolencie muche theatre common souldiour wantyng proper seatetheatre place vvhere beholde pastyme wente satte place gentleman people noted caesar raysed hym souldiours angry caesar came passe tyme compassed requyred felow souldiour whome thought destroyed hee came sayde came prysoninsolencie souldiours whiche bycause hee denied sayde hee hyred say traytour hys company rudenesse vsed theatre beyng called diuision campe mar comming night angry caesar tarried long nonius capitayne rebuked tolde dutie put cause vpon caesar sickenesse called nonius kylled soldiours flatterer threwe stone vppon droue take water whiche tooke hym vp dead layde hym waye caesar shoulde passe monished hys freendes truste theyr rage hee oyde furder inconuenience hys absence wente heevprore soldiours sawe dead body nonius went aside fault layde vpon fewe hee willed hereafter one spare another gaue giftes distribution land andsufferance liberalitie rewarded beyonde owne expectation constancie hym lyked requyred kyllers nonius myghte bee punyshed hee sayde hee knewe well inough satisfied wyth confession conscience reste hee forgaue whyche mercy liberalitie beyng prouoked made greate shoutes hys felicitie twoo contempt souldiours among many may suffice shewed cause thys without lawfull authoritiecause disorder among soldiours happeth ciuill warres takyng vppon bee capitaynes led souldiours serue countrey themselues agaynst enimies agaynst citizen destroyed discipline romanes warre souldiour rather desirous serue pryuate affection capytaynes abuse priuate commoditie onely souldiour whole army bee bought money offence fauour good prayse aduaunce euill lighte cause whole army would go good lawfull leader lewde vsurpyng captayne lyke agreeyng lyke souldiours tooke enimies neuer honest capitaynes hated capitaynes haue souldiours hande suffred committe thing abhominable without al reuerence lawe iustice nowe discipline beyng corrupted werediscipline corrupted compted best could rayse moste sedition citie meane time great penurie prouision corne beyng stopped pompey italie tillage beyngpe ie trouble rome almost le te continuaunce warre consumed soldiours citie theeues murderer night vnpunished soeuer done imputed souldiour common shutte vp theyr shoppes withoute officer whiche woulde serue thefte suffred lucius beyng well affected common wealth lucius taketh parte vvith old husbandemen greeued power three prince continuyng longer time appoynted contended caesar onely promised helpe olde possessioners making supplication officer promised seruice wherby bothe antony soldiours caesar accused enimy fuluia also stirrer warre time manius counsel deuise manius preuayled persuaded fuluia italie quiet antony woulde remayne cleopatra aegipt warres styrred hee woulde come quickly fuluia antony vvise stirreth vvarre fuluia womannishe passion incensed lucius caesar wente place newe inhabitancy antony chyldren lucius wente caesar shoulde haue whole thankes goyng alone caesar horsemenne scoured coaste towarde sicelie pompey shoulde spoyle lucius begynnyng suspition eyther afrayde deede fayning bee afrayde horseman sente agaynst antony child wente haste inhabitauncies antonie gette garde accusing caesar vnfaithfull antony answered kept faith friendship antonie lucius sought moue warre offended rule three newe inhabitant might take full possession horseman yet coast duty whe teano citie fia appia apulia condition betvvene caesar antony soldiours antony soldiours vnderstoode made meeting theano reconciled condition shuld deuide lad serued philippi money condemned men landes equally diuided among antony souldiours hereafter one alone leuy men two legios antony serue caesar popey alpes towarde spaine shoulde open caesar sent shutte asinius lucius put away garde exercise office quietnesse couenants whereof onely two last kepte saluidienus passed alpes spyte kepte preneste novve pilestrena citie latio rest defeated wherfore lucius went preneste affirmyng afrayde caesar hauyng garde aboute none fuluia also went lepidus saying afrayde fuluia fleeth lepidus hir child trusted better caesar bothe wrote antonie certaine freendes carying letter might certifie thyngs copy whereof haue long sought finde chiefe army agreed take vp thys matter affirmed woulde compell hym vnwillyng sente lucius friendes come whiche denying doe caesar accused well chiefe army officer city great resorte made lucius citiegreat resorte lucius beseechyng haue compassion afflicted italie take man eyther capitaynes might make ende matter lucius regarde spake also thyngs spoken manius manius ansvver sharpe answeared sharpely antonie onely gathered money strange nation caesar gette men loue preuention army fitte place italy fraude gotten fraunce antony prouince xviij city giuen soldiours ransacked almoste italy also gaue money foure thirty legion onely eight twentie fought hys quarrell spoyled temple pretence warre agaynst pompey whiche yet begon greate dearth citie deede winne fauour souldiours agaynst antonie muche goodes attaynted solde giuen seeketh peace good fayth must make accomptof thing hath done hereafter nothing consent bothe bolde answeare manius neyther caesar shoulde doe thing alone couenaunts betweene antonie remayne firme either haue full authoritie prouinces confirme others actes caesar seeyng soughte warre prepared hymselfe two legios wer placed ancona firstsouldioures ancona labour peace serued father antony loue bare sente ambassador rome pray haue respect peace caesar aunswered swerued antony lucius wyth hym embassador conferring officer antonyes souldyoures sente common embassage lucius requiring hym contente committe hys difference wyth caesar arbitrement affirmyng woulde take vppon excepte woulde condiscende hauing obteyned request gabij appoynted place gabij people destroyed tarquinius superbus meeting gabij fight chance meeting midde way betweene rome preneste prepared seate judge two chayres shewe cause caesar came firste sente horseman way lucius shoulde come eyther see lucius dyd whether traynes layde lyghted vpon antonyes horseman whyche came forerunner lucius see cleere fell fight kylled wherefore lucius wente backe feare treason sayde beeingthe daye frustrate called chiefe army promising hym conducte safe refused thus pacifyers beeyng deceyued warre threatned wyth bitter wordes betweene lucius haddethe vvarre breaketh lucius povver sixe legion leuie whiche toke created consull besyde eleuen antonyes vnder captayne caleno italy caesar hadde foure legion capua certayne bandes caesar povver antium vvas citie latio good vpon sea lannuuium novv indo treasure house holy money tibure novve tiuoli nemore arre aritia pompey increaseth person saluidienus broughte syxe legion spayne lucius money prouinces antony pacyfyed caesar hadde came vnto hym lotte excepte sardinia whyche warre gote much temple promising render interest capitoli antio lanuuio nemore tibure whyche city treasure day holy money italy thing quiet pompey resorte condemned citizen auntient possessioners greatly increased mighte estimation feared life spoyled goodes lyked present state fledde hym disagreemente lucius augmented hys credite beside repayre yong men desirous gayne seruice caring vnder whome went bycause romanes sought vnto among hys cause seemed iust waxed riche booty sea hadde good store shyppes furniture murcus also brought two legion fiue hundred archer much money fourescore shippes another army cephalenia wherefore thynke inuaded sea pompey loseth honor pompey sextius italy might easily haue gotte afflicted famine discord loked pompey ignorance rather desend owne inuade others till ouercome also affrica sextius lieutenant antony beeyng lately commaunded deliuer charge fagion caesar lieutenant sent againe take fagio would deliuerfagio made warre hauing bande discharged souldyoures number africanes helpe prince fagio ouercome wing battell also lost campe thinking come treason fagio killeth carina killed himselfe sextius onto agayne lord prouinces affrica bocchus king mauritian persuasion lucius made warre vpon carina gouernour spayne caesar aenobarbus lxx shippes two legion band archer venturer scouring sea ionia destroyed region accepted rule three men come brunduse e partly tooke gallyes caesar partly burned driuing brundusians within wall spoiled land caesar sent legion thither willed saluidienus come spayne throughout italy men mustered hast well caesa captaynes antonyes lucius dyuers troubled ouer fightes betweene iust battell ambushmentes fauoure italy enclined lucius bycause fought new inhabitant onely city giuen pray also italy stirred fearing lyke calamitie reiecting caesar souldioures borowed holy money partly kylling gaue aide lucius keeping city contrarywise new inhabitant stucke caesar though eyther laboured owne state caesar called senatoures oct senate gentleman thus spake vnto know contemned lucius faction coward afrayde myne owne weakenesse contempt increased assembly haue valiant army iniureth hyndering possession also aforetime haue serued vnder banner rest sure except one meaning delighte ciuill warres necessary thinke abuse citizen left destroy one another chiefly thys ciuill motion miserie whereof shall tolde macedonia thracia shall seene italy fielde warre incommodities shall suffer cause yrketh beginne first protest neyther quarrell antony anye thing quarrell part selues reprooue lucius abettor whome praye reconcile vnto continue obstinacie shall make knowen slowe feare consideration shall witness onely also antony driuen necessitie insolencie lucius caesar thus said returned hast preneste lucius answered matter would come tryall side shortly caesar dissembled sente legion brunduse stoppe antonyes passage italy manius also shewed antonyes epistle false true tell whycha letter shevved willed estimatio mainteyned though warre embassador senate demaunde blemish estimation coplaine judge manius vsed many threatnings againe till wetno conclusio peace away without conclusio yet embassador dyd shew answere caesar either bycause knew particularly bycause wer abashed cause present war appered lepidus gouernoure citie caesar made prouisio left lepidus gouernor yt citie wt garrison two legion many noble men rome resorted lucius declaryng authoritie three men displease lucius tvvo legion thus thys warre followed thys sort two legion lucius alba made tumulte droue away captaynes readye reuolte caesar lucius made hast lucius came fyrste wyth many fayre wordes promise stayde furnius broughte hym another army caesar cutte tayle droue furnius hyll nyght following wente sentia citie hysfurnius besege sentia betvveene campania lucius entreth citie faction whome cesar would follow feare traynes next day beseeged citie lucius went rome wyth al hast sent three bandes night followyng armye receyued nonius gard gate tooke hys souldyoures serue lepidus escaped wente lepidus fleeth lucius people rome caesar lucius assembled people put good hope caesar lepidus shoulde punished misgouernement hys brother woulde willingly giue ouer vnlawfull authoritie take consulship office instituted theyr auntient father sayd thus muche people beeyng glad thinking three men authoritie soone ceasse saluted hym generall done went caesar gathering way another host place antonyes inhabitance settled beeing well affected antony barbatius bin treasourerberbatius warre sente hym displeasure tolde people antony angry styrred caesar common authoritie people beeyng thus abused forsooke lucius wet caesar lucius marched againstpeople forsaketh lucius saluidienus brought great power france caesar andsaluidienus asinius agrippa asinius ventidius antonyes captaynes followed tayle coulde goe forward agrippa man trusty caesar fearing least saluidienus copassed tooke lombardy place thought lucius could spare woulde leaue saluidienus come mighte saluidienus follow taile agrippa deceiued whe lucius saw deceiued purpose repaired asinius vetidius whereby saluidienus agrippa free take adua tage could whiche lucius perceyued durste fight went perugia citie wel defensed oeth perugia encamped loking ventidius caesar agrippa saluidienus comming vpo ged three army perugia least lucius might escape hads sent caesar force deteine asinius ventidius although made great hast approued warre noroccasion hinderaunce lucius sure antony minde beside emulation betweene eyther seeking leader lucius thus besieged neyther durste giue battel lucius distresse inferiour number also goodnesse soldiors departe thence manye readye molest therfore sent ventidius asinius manius perswade come helpe hym besieged sent also titinius four thousande horse spoyle caesar landes thereby myght call siege haue perugia siege perugia free winter neede til ventidius companye myghte come caesar hauing al power togither compassed caesar encloteth lucius place eight mile aboute bycause hill made long trenche tiber nothing shoulde bee tiberis springeth aboute goeth thorough turs rome novv tenure plancus brought thence perugia luc n lyke sorte trenched rootes hilles fuluia commaunded ventidius asinius ateius calenus make haste helpe besieged gathered newe hoste sente plancus lucius thys plancus waye cutte legion caesar andplancus whereas asinius ventidius went slowly vncertaine antony wil yet fuluia manius sake came forwarde caesar agrippa went meete leauing sufficient force perugia disseuered themselues one lucius povver dieuerereth selues pa enna fi deth gulfe n ce arimeno se rauenna arimeno plancus spoleto caesar leauing agaynst eche power keepe ioyning againe togither retourned perugia added rampires ditch making ditch large thirtie foote breadth deepnesse made also trench stronger ioyned tower woodde lx foote asunder serued bothe turnes well resiste came citie keepe woulde come whych tymes manye sally made city caesar men better far shot lucius bolde hand stroks whe work finyshed famine tooke city encresed daily neither cicizes lucius made prouision victual caesar e peru len e rie daye neth firste moneth yetre sayleth campe vnderstood kept straighter night calends ianuary lucius thinking feastful time would haue wrought negligece among enimies gaue assaulte camp thinking might haue put companion whiche many diuerse place one legion quickly called watch caesar comming band sharp fight lucius repulsed time rome corn kepttumulte rome corne v nt u vse soldiors people tumult contention ran priuate house tooke corne could tidius soldiors thinking shame helpe lucius marched foorth ouerthrew caesar garisons euery place agrippa saluidienus come turned fulginio castle far fro perugia besiegedfulginie agrippa signified night lucio wt many fiers thought best try fight plancus thought best stay hazard thiselues betwene connsel caesar agrippa sentence preuayled besieged perugia saw fiers glad thought impediment came forward fire ceassed thought bin destroyed lucius oppressed famine made issue city first watch vntil break day euery side repulsed euery place retired perusing victual commanded bondman shold haue none yet kept thatextremitie uine shold get shew need enimie ran orchard garden eate grasse leaues theymisery sla e could find whe pined lucius put diches enimy shold perteiue burial citty infected fauors end hunger death soldiors weary desired lucius sally would break conteary trench whole feruentnesse lu que ius saw said late fighte valiauntly f might haue done therfore yeelde sight death euerye man consented therfore night shoulde giue none occasion cowardnesse desired might go daye lucius led forth breake day many scale engins yron fill ditch climbe theassaulte trenche trench wyth kind weapon throw thus issued great violence filled ditch withoute stoppe casting engins wall beate downe trenche set vp scale assaulted toures without respect death fought notwithstanding great resistaunce made shotte contrary parte fight diuers place defeucethe er enelle fyght weaker fight fierce vpon bridge passed also scaled rampire like haue done desperate feate except valiat caesar host like courage come resistace euer relieued fresh men length tyred thrown trench engins broke yet stucke without shrinking though strength voice fayled yet able resist ashamed giue place abode lucius repulsed til lucius blow retreat caesar souldiours make great token gladnesse lucius men stroken shame tooke scale approched wal able good lucius againe cal backe shoulde caste away liues vaine heauye hart wils retired end sharpe assaulte caesar appointed souldioures warde frenche token leape vppe wall whyche dydde thoughe hadde none casion exercising themselues discouraging foe lucius souldioures remained sadde ward negligentlye kepte diuers fledde campe onely common sorte also capitaynes lucius inclined peace pitying multitude perished one thing hindred caesar en y afraid themselues en loned whe heard vsed fugitiues getly desirous man death luius thought expedient without anye respect seeke peace least people woulde deliuer hym thoughte would proue lucius ieged mindes thus saide desire intent souldiour fellowes haue reduced common wealth state ancestor left bycause sawe office thres men tourned tirannye amended death brutus cassius whome made pretence warre lepidus remoued collegeship antony occupyed far part man alone dothe listeth lawes bee onely pretence shade seeking remedye incommodities minding haue restored commo wealth required souldiors hauing due rewardes power one might haue bin abolished bicause coulde wente aboute doe force power thys man accused army one pitied antiet inhabitance accusation ignorant beleeuing hearde bycause sure receyued landes diuision yet many beleeued false accusation ioyned make warre v one day shal find done themselues witnesse following better part haue labored aboue strength yet ouercome eunimye hunger forsaken captain haue become haue abiden vttermost country therby ende haue prayse good wil whose safetie preferre glory therfore wyll send ambassador victour require punish let go would giue forgiuenesse aske selfe citizen sometime souldiours nowe offending hauing iuste cause war ouercome fight famine thus said sent three offiters chiefe rest multitude lamented eyther case generalls meant wel seemed friende common wealth fayneambassadors caesar giue place extreame necessitye ambassadoures sent caesar remembred common country common souldiourfare passed friendship noble men sids custome ancestor abhorring caesar ansvvere suche deadly oissentions thing thys purpose caesar knowing enimies hoste consisted olde young souldiors vsed arte saide pardoned antony souldiors required submitte discretion thus hepriuate talke spake opely secretly furnio signified would pardon al except priuate enimies priuate talk furni suspition saide war made displeasure common cause required lucius either haue general peace martial war lucius hauing pitie noble men equall dignitie praised saide woulde sende ambassador lucius goeth caesar bycause thought none fit hymselfe woulde go alone without heraulte tolde caesar lucius comming hym went straight meete bothe came sight accompanied friend habite general lucius sending aside hys friend wente two sergeant signifying meant caesar following caesar meeteth vvith lucius beneuolence shewed lyke token modestie saw lucius come within trenche might shew himselfe power firste wente oute trenche lucius might free saue hymselfe thys lucius caesar dyd outwardly token courtesy come ditche saluted eche lucius thus bega made warre straungers would haue bin ashamed caesar haue bin ouercome ashamed yeelde myselfe whiche ignominie woulde easilye haue deliuered life bicause haue dealt citizen lyke authoritie country thinke shame cause ouercome manne speake refuse suffer thyng thou writ put vpon mee beyng come campe wythout herauld aske pardon iuste commedious thyne estate whych thou mayste vnderstande playnly wyll separate theyr cause mine thou shalt vnderstand onelye cause thou mayste exercise thine anger vppon thinke inuey againste thee licentiously oute tyme wyll onelye tell truth cannot dissemble tooke thys warre agaynste thee woulde bee prince hadde dispatched thee myghte haue broughte common wealth rule senate whyche nowe taken awaye power three thou thy selfe canste denye begunne confessyng vnlawfull sayde necessarye tyme cassius brutus beyng alyue coulde reconciled vnto taken awaye reste rest afraide takyng armes agaynste common wealth youre tyme beeyng ended requyred oppressed senate myghte restored regardyng brother countrey hoped haue perswaded retourne made haste doe tyme myne offyce thou wouldest haue doone thou shouldest haue hadde glorye alone bycause could perswade thee wente cittye thought gette strength force senatoure consull onelye cause warre brother manius fuluia landes diuided souldyoures wanne fielde philippi pitie olde possessioners cast landes myne authoritie appoynted landes brother legion olde owner spoyled thys calumniation thou dyddest deuise thou myghtest putte faulte warre thy selfe newe inhabiters thys arte wynnyng heartes olde souldyoures thou hast wanne also victory persuaded woulde putte violence deuices vsed thou madest warre agaynste nowe beeyng conqueroure thou bee ennimie thy countrey make mee enimie also coulde remedie beeyng lette famyne thys speake freelie gyuing selfe sayde thy handes shewyng thought thee nowe also beeyng thee alone thus much selfe concernyng friendes whole army thou wilte beleeue wyll gyue thee profitable councell doe vse hardly cause matter seeyng thou arte man subiect vnstable fortune make thy friendes flower venture thee shall see example gyuen thee nothyng hoped conqueroures thou reiect councell thyne enimie maye bee ashamed craue pardon thee thou wouldest exacte punishmente friendes faulte missefortune rather turne vppon mee whyche cause trouble haue lefte behynde purpose least shoulde speake thing theyr hearyng shoulde seeme seeke myne owne cause thys caesar aunswered sawe thee come mee withoute heraulde came apace campe thou myghtest freelie doe myghte bee thy good seeyng thee acknowledgyng thy faulte thou commyttest thy selfe power neede confute thyngs whyche thou hast obiected againste firmely falsely hurting mee thou thou haddest come make confederation thou shouldest haue come angrye conqueroure without cause seeing without condition thou giuest thy selfe thy friend army v al anger taken awaye al necessitie truce cutte nowe muste consider much haue deserued seemly mee doe whyche hadde rather doe eyther god cause cause thy sake lucie neither deceiue caesar pardoneth expectation thou haste broughte thee thus much find dayly note chronicle time matter caesar maruelled noble stoutthe maruell generalis courage lucius ioyned prudence lucius maruelled clemencie quicke briefenesse caesar gathered comecture talke countenaunce bothe lucius sent chiefe captaynes shoulde receiue lucius rendereth watche worde caesar brought booke number manner captainea booke number soldioures lucius soldiours receiue vvatche vvord caesar asketh watche word offereth prince booke hys number euery day receyuing watch worde leaue wented watch caesar commaunded keepe watche seuerally nexte day caesar sacrificed lucius sent hoste caesar carying harnesse going common apparel farre saluted caesar generall stayde legion legion caesar hadde appointed deuided olde legion young hadde sacrificed sate general seate commanded euery one lay armour beeing done hee commaunded old souldiors drawe nighe mighte reproue vnkindnesse make afraide yet meaning knowne well ynough whither purpose affection caesar souldioures came ute theyr placessouldiours embracing embraced lucius souldiors wept sued caesar woulde leaue stil cryed vppon caesar muche mourning caesar chaunging hys minde appeasing multitude said thus fellowe souldyers haue alwayes well serued caesar pardoneth yong souldyoures deny anything yong souldyers whiche thinke haue serued iustly vnder lucius standerd remitte haue heeretofore bin ioyned wyth warre saued meane woulde aske miurie haue done grace denyed shoulde serue another beare armoure selues suffered paynes diuision landes ofsouldyers crie pardon partaker whose l udenesse nowe sufferme punish denying cotinually calling pardon graunt quoth demaundepardon let goe free heereafter agree whyche beyng promised partes thanks cryed caesar contente shoulde lodged house common sorte wylled lye theyr campe fyrste placed tyll sente wintering sitting hygh seate called lucius chiefe perugia among whome many senatoures gentleman hea ie remanes appeared vvere vvell vsed time shape beeyng towne garrison entred come caesar tooke lucius hym committed hys friendes officer beeyng warned keepe honest secrete custody perugians cry pardon ouer wall commaunded come without senate perugians pardoned whyche beeyng done pardoned senatoures putte prison kylled except lucius aaemilius rome killer caesar cryed thoughte good shoulde punished thecaptaynes perugia killed citie purged mynded haue gyuen citie spoyle souldyoures one sextius madde fellowe surnamed macedonian bycause hadde serued macedonia sette hys sextius setteth citie fire perugia set fire owne house fyre threwe himselfe wynde beeyng great blew fyre ouer citie burned temple vulcene excepted thys ende perugia auntient goodly citie say one theantiquitle perugia vvas first called vi ia coloni vibius captayne acheanes first came thither criaginens armenia build griffou vvhich bare standerd called language perugio called citie perugia caesar repayred citie vvas called perugia augusto vvith scription augusto sacro perugia restitut twelue city hetrurians buylded firste comming italy wherefore tuscane fashion honor iuno followed chose vulcane stead iuno patrone next day caesar made truce armyes yet tumultes continued betweene til canutius flauius clodius bithinicus diuers slayne deadly enimies caesar ende seege perugia warre lucius made certaynely daungerous like haue continued long asinius plancus ventidius crassus attieus others faction hadde army diuided thirteene partes sixe thousande horseman aboue scattered brundusio rauenna tarento cius ar scattered wente murco aenobarbo antony himselfe caesar bandes chaced land agrippa gote two legion plancus left camerina fuluia cameria lat fuluia eeth putzol campania hir child fledde putzolo thence brundusio three thousand horse captaynes appoynted hir conduit brunduse tooke shippe fiue gallyes sente macedonia plancus went hir cowardise forsaken rest army whiche serued plancus covvard ventidius asinius entised aenobarbus antonyes side whereof wrote letter vnto prepared agaynste comming italy bandes antonyes vnder alpes wherof calenus captayne caesar intended winne bycause antony suspition friend would keepe proued enimie would serue himselfe whylest soughte good occasion calenus dyed caesar tooke aduantage army fusius calenus sonne deliuered feare thus caesar taketh antonyes band lomberdy caesar without businesse gote eleuen legion ample prouinces whiche remoued old officer placed owne went rome antony kepte messenger sent inhabitancy eyther bycause winter antony deteyneth messenger bycause would haue report doings beginning spring wente alexandria came tirus thence cipres rhodes asia heard seege perugia whiche blamed antony findeth vvife brother wife manius founde hys wife athens fledde brunduse mother iulia pompey sendeth iulia antonyes mother honourably pompey sente sicelie whither fledde company libone father law saturninus others best sorte assayed allure antony pompey parte pompey friend assayed antony antonyes aunsvvere caesar antony thanked pompey sending hys mother would requite time conueniente hee make warre againste caesar woulde vse societie caesar continued agreement woulde reconcile c sar antonyes aunswere caesar beeyng come rome vnderstoode gone athens answere antony could tell soughte caesar discrediteth antony rome discredite antony souldyoures would ioyne pompey put possession manye fledde pompey coulde winne souldyoures antony greate glory hadglorie antony great gote philippi caesar thought himselfe good ynough antony pompey lao aboue legion ship woulde beset coast italy might soone oppresse famine therfore many maydens offered marriage thought make best match wrote maecenas shuld cotract scribonia sister libo father law pompey mightmariage caesar serue turne haue pretence agree pompey neede done remoued diuers antenyes friend authoritie sent lepidus affrica sixe legion antonyes hee called lucius praised kind brother caesar luciu woulde take faulte vppon himselfe coulde thinke vnkindnesse great benefite shewed would playnely tell brother conspiracie thys lucius aunswered knewe sister lawes ambitiouslucius caesar desire rule tooke commoditie brother armye take rule brother woulde come nowe abolishe youre monarchie woulde take hys parte alwayes agaynste thee countreys sake although priuately beholden vnto thee hee seeke companion hys tyrannie take thy parte thou wilte destroy monarchie affection countrey shall alwayes preuayle fauoureconstancie lucius kindred caesar maruelling constancie lucius saide woulde caesar ucius vse hym hys brother though would followe yet woulde committe prouince spayne appoynt lucius honored caesar vvith regard peduceus luceius lieutenantes thus shewe honor sente away lucius yet secretely commaunded priuily watched antony leauing wife sicke scicyone tooke sea wyth sicyone farre corinth great army nauie two hundred shippes whyche made asia whe vnderstoode aenobarbus came meete aenobarbus goeth antony great army suspected trusted worde one condemned men conspiracie againste caesar battel philippi fought caesar antony yet went toward fiue good shippes myghte seeme trust willing rest followe aenobarbus whe sight came forward al nauie plancus afrayde wished stay firste trye plancus afrayde meante bycause doubted antony aunswered rather dye deceyued trust thoughte antony plancus flee feare come neere admiral knowen flagges sayled one herald antony standing forepart eyther ignorante sure friend boldnesse minde inferioure stoupe superioure commaunded strike saile whiche drewe side antonyes shippe saluted embraced one another armye aenobarbus receyued antony theyr generall yet plancus scarsly assured antonie tooke aenobarbus owne ship sayled poloenta aenobarbus hadpoloenta footemen aenobarbus gaue place antonie general tent thence sayled brunduse fiue bandes casars garrison brundusians shut gate aenobarbus antony aenobarbus bruduse antony kepte brunduse auncient enimie antonie one brought en nie antonie tooke pretence done caesar commaundement therefore fortified narrow parte earth antony besieged runduse brunduse vvas builded m ter inhabited cr tense laste made inhabitaunce rome hath name forme harte head vvith horres vvhich sapians call brudusium shape hath porte vvhich one beste vvorld antony vseth p helpe pompey sendeth nauy vvith menodorus besiegeth cossensa thuris space tiber beneuento vvas called onia vvhich name also italie vvas called caesar troubled consentia yet citie buylded vpo seue hilles thereof gyueth seuen hilles armes souldiours practise peace sio novve canossa ap tlia antony policy agrippa recouereth besieged place ioyned citie ditche trenche citie almoste iland porte lyke crescent whiche lande could come vnto cliffe cutte place fortified antonie also beset hauen great ilandes many castels hee made sent also sundry coastes italy take fitte place exhorted pompey also hee inuade italie much coulde gladly sent menodorus great army iiij legion gette corsica caesar tooke two legion beyng amased attonement antonie antony captaynes tooke sigunto citie ausonia pompey befleged thurij cossentia placed horseman fieldes caesar troubled many place sent agrippa releue ausoniae commaunded souldiours placed serue vnderstandyng done antony co sent denied whiche troubled caesar moste yet wente brunduse army fayre wordes made soldiours go whiche practised secrete meanes reconcile caesar antonie antonie woulde woulde sticke caesar sicke canusio greater armie antonie come brunduse sawe antonie cut lande towne hee lay wayted aduersaries dayngs antonie stronger munition meane whereof sente armie macedonie vsed policie put country men nighte shippes bothe galley make shewe great army come macedonia began beate brunduse whereof caesar sory coulde helpe euening tolde agrippa recouered siguntum pompey repulsed thurio cossence still beseeged whereat antony sory hearing seruilius comming caesar one thousande two hu dreth th rio vvas citie builded niei comming athens farre vvhich mama gathered antony vali antnesse ca horse could stay straight fro supper greate rage tooke freendes iiij c horse valiantly gaue onset vpon v c tooke sleepyng vria brought brunduse great fame still victory hee gotte philippi garde person would come caesar campe vpbrayde vnkindnesse hym saued philippi answeared defende themselues obiected one agaynst otherobiections soldiours partes one excluded brundusio armie calenus taken brunduse besieged coast inuaded aliance made aenobarbus killer caesar pompey chief enimie length caesar men opened minde antony felowed caesar forgettyng antonie beyng desirous might reconciled antonie would relent woulde vttermost talke antony campe whyles doyng newes came antony antony vvyfe dead wyfe dead coulde beare hys vnkyndnesse leauyng hir sicke bidding hyr farewell hir death thought comodious fuluis vnquiet woman ielousie cleopatra raysed suche mortall warre yet matter vexed antony bicause upted occasion hir death l cocceius freend sommer cocceius talke antonie sente caesar cecinna antonie asia antonie sente cecinna home kept cocceius still seekyng occasio trie antonie told caesar set desired might departe asked whether hee woulde wryte caesar antonie content hee departe wrytyng sayde hee shoulde wryte tauntes one seyng wee nowe enimies wrote hym cecinna copie whereof shall haue wyll brought letter hym sayde cocceius enimie take hym vsed brother lucius freendes well quoth antonie hee shutteth brunduse hath taken myne armie prouince calenus kepte hee good freendes hee hath made hys benefites mine enimies cocceius mindyng furder stirre angry man departed caesar saw hym marueling caesar cocceius tarried long sayde haue saued brother become mine enimie cal sayd freds enimies take fro army prouinces wherto caesar sayd death calenus great charge ought giuen yong man calenus sonne antonie absent lucius asinius aenobarbus armes placus legion intercepted shoulde go pompey horseman thing tolde otherwise antonie sayde yet beleeued nothing till shutte brunduse knewe sayde caesar neyther commaunde brundusians garrison left could abide hee brought aenobarbus killed caesar proscribed field philippi besee ged brunduse yet troubleth coast italie burned shippes spoyled countrey haue sayd cosented one make alliance ye wil neither haue antonie ioyned manqueller haue regard father aenobarbus man killer neyther decree anger made neither priuie purpose thought vnworthy pardon bicause freend brutus must see whether al case cofederacie made pompey hurte make warre vpon antonie haue societie reconcile hym boyde faulte faulte warre bene made italie durste neuer haue sente embassages antonie caesar replied sayde fuluia lucius manius began warre italy pompey durst neuer inuade coast italy vpon trust antonie trusting vppon antonie sente hym sayde cocceius dissemble shall reste italie voyde nauie make peace caesar caesar vvordes pompey vnwillyng heare diuise stayde whyle pompey shalbe punished whelynow quoth already repulsed fro thuriji cocceius perceyuing controuersie tolde hym fului dead unkindnesse antonie nowe shee gone way vtter one others greefe without caesar talke cocce dissimulation caesar beyng appeased talke receyued cocceius requested wryte somewhat antonie yonger elder denied wryte thing enimie woulde write nothing also thought vnkindnesse antony mother beyng use fledde italie would seeke hym whome might haue obtayned thing hir sonne hir ee content wryte cocceius came foorth many capitaynes declared mindes souldiours except woulde reconciled warre made hee tolde antonie wished coutermaund pompey furder inuasion italie sende aenobarbus away till agreed iulia mother ioyned cocceius prayed hir sonne doe antonie stoode doubte peace take muste antony doubt vvhat doe desire pompeis helpe agayne whiche woulde shame hym mother putting comfort seeming knowe antony gaue place required pompey returne antony consenteth peace sicelie would keepe promise sent aenobarbus authoritie bythinia army heard chose messenger mighte goe eyther generall cutting rehearsall vnkindnesse paste requyre engers linke purpose caesar parte chosen antonie pollio cocceius ioyneda maryage pra free e bothe bycause marcellus dead husband caesar sister required shee might made sure antony whiche beyng done army cried happy continuing reioyce one whole day night caesar antonie agayne deuided whole empire made c dropoli citie slauonia bothe partes bycause stoode ende adria icall sea caesar haue al ilandes westward euen mayne sea antonie shoulde haue lyke eastwarde euen floud euphrates lepidus haue africa still caesar appointed caesar make warre vpo pompey vnlesse order taken antonie shoulde make warre vpon parthian reuenge iniurie done crassus aenobarbus receyued societie condition antonie lawful leuie men italie like number legion peace solemnelie ratified whervpo sent away friend affayres antonie sent ventidius asia represse parthian yong labienus help parthian made new commotios syria far ionia shewed parthian menedorus dryueth helenus sardinia warre pompey capitayne menodorus repulsed helenus casars lieftenant sardinia wherfore caesar would reconciled went rome togither celebrated mariage antonie put manius death bycause hee manius put death antony saluidienus accused stirred fuluia make warre accused saluidienus gouernour caesar armie rh danu hee woulde forsake hys mayster cleaue hym whereof wrote letter hym brunduse lyked men declaryng vnconstant dealing much seeking amitie caesar called saluidienus vnto saluidienus killed caesar matter charge sende againe army came slew reproche deliuered army antonie suspected meane time cytie oppressed famine neyther durst merchauntes bring corne eastfamine rome bicause pompeis sicelie weast c sica sardinia pompeis shippes also lay fro africa nauies conspiratours kepte station distresse alleaged discorde ruler cause therefore required peace might made caesar vvyll agree peace vvith pompey pompey vnto whiche caesar woulde agree antonie thought warre needefull necessitie bycause money wated decree made antony aduise euery maistera payment put v people pay half xxv drammes euery slaue whiche determined bene done war cassius somewhat also shoulde payde euery man heritage people tore decree great furie obiected consumingthe people resist decree caesar antony treasure publike spoylyng prouinces sacking italie priuate displeasure yet woulde serue muste nowe put newe imposition vpon haue nothing left assembled murmured copelled would threatnings spoyle burne theyrthe people resist caesar house gathered people caesar fewe freends garde came excuse themselues threw stone droue away antonie heardvvho buyeth firendship decre shal smart came help comming holy way people nothing bycause willing agree pompey prayde departe would threw stone brought soldiours walles citie diuided market place streates wounded set vpon multitude killed streates came could easily flee ye multitude breake runnyng many hurte killed cry yellyng house antonie hadde muche ado escape caesar caesar e eth antony meanes dead body cast ryuer poy ed euidently preserued got away thus antonie delyuer caesar present perill body common killed caste riuer auoyde griefe sight came passe soldiours fished streame carried tooke apparell antony cousel iance mariage betvveene caesar siser sa vvas named aenaria e novv isch strength vvas inhabitance marquesse whiche grieued beholder thus euill ended enuie prince yet remedie lacke thing whereat people grutched suffered antonie wished libo hys freendes call sicelie congratulate alliance made would procure greater matter saue harmelesse wrote letter libo pompey content goe come ile called pithecusa aenaria people assembled praied caesar send letter safecodu come treat peace although wil people also copelled mutia mother pompey go vnto threatning el burne hir help make peace libo perceyued enimies inclined desired speake captaines baia vvas citie farre naples vvhere old romanes great delight menodorus counsel might togither agree couenants people co pelled much antonie caesar went baia persuaded pompey earnestly peace menodorus wrote fro sardinia make open warre dryue whyles dearth continued hee might make peace better coditions take heede murcus mouer peace one sought authoritie wherefore murcus put pompey pompey put away murcus vsed counsell whome hee honoured worthinesse wisedome whereat murcus tooke displeasure wente siracuse suche siracuse novv sarag sa goodly citie sicelie sent keepe spake openly agaynst pompey wherewith beyng angrie killed diuerse beste aboute murcus sent kill say slaues done murcus bythinius killed pompey whiche beyng done hanged certayne murcus slaues though done whiche craft hid wickednesse bythinius noble man valiant warriour constant beginnyng friende spaine whence came willingly serue sicelie dead men tooke hand persuade peace accused menodorus desicous office sea much caring master owne power popey folowyng cousell sayled aenaria wt many chosen shipsnovv ischiae gorgious galley sixe ore sea e passe dicearchia proudly towarde euening enimies dicearchia novv puzzole puteoli old ruined citie nearer naples baia beyng three myles asunder lande vvh ch calig made bridge sea meeting caesar antony pompey loking vpon next morning stake set sea bridge made one ioyning lad caesar came antonie pompey libo entred bridge distance one could heare vnlesse spake alowd pompey required societie rule place lepidus onely grauted return countrie al dashed till ofte message wer set offring diuerse coditios side pompey required condemned men caesar death might safe exile men honour proscribed might restored countrey goodes dearth continuing people vrgyng peace graunted recouer fourth part goodes redeeming new possessioners wrote codemned men thinkyng would accept tooke offer beyng afrayde pompey wickednesse committed agaynst murcus went moued agree tore pompey age cloke betrayed defended oft called menodorus one expert matter slate onely constant faith length exhortatio murcia mother iulia wife three met agayne vpon old peere sea beyng wel garded cocluded coditions peace shoulde bothe sea lande merchantesthe condition peace betvveene antony caesar pompey haue free course pompey take garrison italie receiue fugitiues keepe nauies italie rule cicelie cersica might returne home except condemned publique iudgement caesar death fled feare restored goodes codemned fourth parte slaues serued vnder pompey shoulde free free men shoulde haue stipendes old soldiours antonie caesar condition peace whiche beyng written sent rome kept holy virgin desired one banquet lotte pompey banqueteth c antony fell first pompey receiued greate gally ioyned peere next day caesar antony feasted hym tentes pitched peere euery man might eate shore peraduenture safetie shippes hand gard order guestes weapon menedorus councell vnder clokes sayd menodorus banqueted pompey shippe sente one pompey put remembrance nowe time reuenge father brother death would see none scape shippeansvvere pompey aunswered became person place menodorus might haue done without agreeth menodorus periured false may pompey supper pompey daughter wife libo espoused marcellus antonyes nephew sonne caesar sister next day consul appoynted foure yearesconsuls appoynted first antony libo antony mighte make substitute next caesar pompey aenobarbus sosius lastly caesar antony thrice consul hoped restore people gouernement common wealth thing concluded departed pompey shippes sicelie land rome newes peace citie italy made great ioy ciuill warre continuall muster insolencie garrison running away slaues wasting countreys decay tillage aboue greate famine taken away therefore sacrifice made way princesreioyce peace preseruers countrey citie receyued goodly triumph hadde entred nighte bycause would charge citizen onely partaker common ioy possession banished men goodes returne league heauie enimies banished men fewe except went againe pompey banished men returne tooke leaue puzzolo wente citie new ioy de returne many noble men caesar went ifye france antonie make war parthian senate hauing approued actes wel past antonyes actes allovved senate antony maketh king come sent captaynes abroade would appoynted also certaine king pay tribute pontus darius pharnaces sonne mithridates nephew idumeans samaritanes herode pisidias amyntaes part idumei people betvveene iudea arabia samtria regio pal sta besides e pa cilicia polomon others natios sente army haue wintered parthiena natio illyria nigh epidamn yt sometime entierly loued brutus might acquaint gayne exceccise another army set dardanes people illyria also wot make rodes macedonia comaunded abide epirus might novv g nera al haue intending winter athens sent furnius frica leade vj legion sextius parthian yet heard lepidus taken sextius thing done wintered athens octauia alexandria cleopatra looked antonyes behauiour athens letter came fro army leauing habite generall vsed garmets priuate without garde wet copany two frieds heare lector disputation philosopher dyet grecia maner hauing octauia euer copany one fond vpo wome winterchange antony ended changed maner gouernement officer captaines attending gate thing done make feare embassagies differred heard audience giue ship prepared full businesse whilest antony thus occupyed league betweene caesar pompey broken secrete cause caesar breaketh vvith pompey pretence breach open matter antony comitted morea pompeyus vpon condition shoulde pay debtes see paide leaue matter safe tooke prouince wyth coditio haue coutrey wt debt greened peruerse nature caesar said bycause enuye others haue greater army gaue much credit menedorus said peace truce repaired ship gathered gallies made oratio army declaring war must needes follow troubled sea rouers little commoditie came citie accord wherfore spoke openly peace made releeue peril adde fourth nu ber tyrantes encreased caesar tooke pyrats putquareis pompey torture make confesse pompey sent caesar told people signifyed pompey letter pompey excused coplained dealing touching peloponneso noble remained pompey perceiuing always ruled bin bondme killed freemade either theselues please caesar kindle menodorus hys maister thys purpose hate bare menodorus time philadelphus freemade caesar sayled menodorus corne micilio sure fried menodorus wet deale caesar promising rule sardinia corfica three legios many frieds matter practised either philadelphus displeasure pompey caesar would ye first legth accepted thinking peace broke deede called antony fro athens brunduse certayne daye caesar calleth antony athens war sent gallies fro rauenna army fro lombardy lye brudusio putzolo inuade sicelie side antony would agree thervnto antony came day finding caesar tarried either liked war antony cometh rundulio suspition betvveene caesar antony token antonyes campe truce saw caesar make great preparatio ambitious rule feared token one watch tet deuoured wolfe al saue face though shuld knowe whiche done without crie noise brundusians said saw antony caesar wolfe runne fro pauilios breake day notwtstading wrote caesar breake couenant made threatned menodorus claymed antony take menedorus slaue bond pompey ye great whose goodes bought caesar sent officer receiue sardinia corsica menodoro fenced coast italie many fortes subiecte pompey rouing hee commaunded gallyes made rauenna menodorus reuoketh caesar rome sent great army illiria menodorus made freeman guide nauie brought vice admirall vnder caluisius continued leysurely making preparation angry antony would tarrie nauie prepard rauenna badde cornificius go tarento tarentum citie apulia vvhich hath goodly porte tvvelue mile compasse euill token caesar wente tempest rose crushed chiefe shippe wherein caesar goe thought euil token whereas people thought warre made truce caesar auoyde suspition wrote people rome spake army pompey broken league sending pryats sea playne confession menodorus caesar affirmeth peace broke pompey pirats themselues whereof antony wasnot ignorant therefore would let haue peloponesus whe thought himselfe well furnished sayled sicelie tarent caesar sicelie caluisius sabinus menodorus tuscane armye came land reggio great hast thing wer done pompey knowe menodorus fledde till caesar come sayled againste nauies himselfe tarried messina sent menecrates caluisio menodoro menecrates vvith greate company keeping sea greate enimie condition came sight enimie euening withdrew gulfe cuma rested nighte menecrates wente cuma vvas goodly auntient citie farre paie novve nothing left maruellous ru ne menecrates fighteth vvith caesar captaynes aenaria morning caluisius nauie coasted shore cuma forme crescent keepe enimie menecrates came forth made speede againste enimie whome bycause could drawe deepe sea set vppo kept shore defended themselues might take sea would come agayne fiercely change shippes pleasure coulde stirre keepe aduersaries one side rockes side menedorus menecrates saw one another lefte rest nauies came togither rage noyse seemed ouercame shoulde conquerourethe fight betvveene menedorus menecrates nauie shippes great violence crushed one another sterne menodorus shippe broken pump menecrates grapeling shippes togither stoode firme marriners souldyoures fought lesse courage footing hin land shotte darted threw stone dydfight sea cast bridge passe one another bycause menedorus shippe higher dyd harme menedorus hurt lesse payne many killed hurte menedorus stricken arme dart whych streight pulled menecrates hurt thygh forked spanish arrowe whych could pulled beeyng menecrates drovvned able longer fyght exhorted hys company lept sea menedorus tooke hys shyppe drew land could fight longer fight lefte side nauie right caluisius chaced certaine shippesdemochares menecrates demochares freemade pompey also viceadmirall menecrates entred vpon shippes caluisius whereof droue shore made flee set fire caeluisius came chace sawe caluisius shippes distressed hys nauiescattered fired stayde one quenched bycause night withdrew former harborough end first fight sea wherein pompey better demochares greeuously taking deathe menecrates greate losse pompey euer vsed menecrates menedorus seruice sea leauing al thyngs though menecrates body one shippe hadde bin lost whole nauie went streight broyle sicelie caluisius lay still long thought demochares would come saw gone refreshed ship kepte alongst shore side caesar great nauie fro caesar pompey shevve messina tarento army reggio mette pompey messina fortie shippes friendes exhorted take occasion shippes pompey sette vppon rest nauie came caesar would tyll caesar refuseth fight ioyned caluisius affyrming folly hazard without helpe demochares come messina pompey made apollophanes freemade man also chiefe thenevv admiral pompey nauie nauie stead menecrates menedorus caesar heard f losse caluisius crossed sea meete caluisius passed betweene stylida sylla pompey set vpon seylla one notable cockes narrov sea sicelie named say seylla daughter phereu charybdi novve g lof ro another rocke ouer named also vvrite greedy vvoman name stylidae scylla coast sicelie vnder hell segp continent italy caesar refuseth fight sea caesar nauie hurt caesar leapeth sh corn ficius vvant asar host taile nauie prouoked fight meanes caesar refused either bycause would fight streights bycause would first find caluisio comanded draw nigh shore lie anchor stad defence set vpo demochares coming setting two ship vpo one droue togither vpon rockes many crushed perished cowardly like lucke heere fighte cuma caesar lept ship shore holp saue swamme liues cornificius captaines without comandemet hoysed anchor tooke sea thinking better ouercome fighting tha perish foolishly cornificius great boldnes toke ammirall demochares lept another fighte cetmu ng wyth great losse menodorus caluisius seene coming caesar copany trauelled liues pompey people therfore retired neere night would c frechmen weery chanced wel danger nighte many forsooke theyr ship went mountaines made many tok f sea night without meate without rest wanting thing caesar like case went praid hold til morning yet knowe caluisius come neither help fro shipsa good lucke casar al dager drowning another good lucke legion drew nigh mountaines whiche hearing losse resorted fire rocky place found generall weery wanting thing one help another brought caesar old house withoute caesar distresse chamber dispersed nightes tumult whe sente aboute shew safe vnderstoode caluisius come recomforted two ioyful newes tooke rest breake day loked saw ship burned halfe burned floting broken caluisius come caused much help repaire made could rather bycause enimie gone behold vehement southwind blewe made rough sea astempest vpon caesar shippes caesar ship againe crushed cliffes rockes one another pompey port messana menedorus fearing violece storme wet sea many followed exaple thinking storme woulde soone haue ceassed wont spring time kept stil shore sauing theselues labour winde waxing greater went wracke cabels burst ship brake escrie sothe trouble caesar nauie great good aduice could heard difference betweene maister mariner skil rule preuailed alike perished ship slitte drenched coulde swimme broken rockes floud sea came whiche wont great ship new rage tossed hither thither beating one another wind continuing toward night made feare losse bee darkenesse light greate lamentation made calling one another help vayne cast sea cryed help ship loked help land crushed cliffes present death euery place great darkenesse neyther heauen earth coulde seene euery one looked death whiche greeuous death selfe suddainelythe looking deathe grecuous vehement storme winde ceassed sunne appeared storme hauing bin great countrey affirmed neuer seene like destroyed part caesar ship souldyoures afflicted newe caesar agayne afflicted vibo calamity went vibo land vnpatient minde sente captaines euery place mutiny mighte bee made trayne layde appoynted army land keepe coast italie pompey incouraged victorythe great negligence pompey shoulde inuade neyther attempted thing lande made ende sea suffered gather togither could prosperous wind gette vibone either bycause thought afflicted ynough could vse victory sayd slowe inuade contente defend caesar nauie scarcely halfe lefte sore brusede leauing ouersee sorowfull mind went campania neyther shippes hauing caesar vvant neede manye time make dearth beeyng great people cry peace blaming warre made promise neede also hadde money whereof great want people rome moued payment octauius caesar subtile owne commoditie caesar continuance vva e sent mecenas antony instruction call societie warre refused would trasport legios sicelie trie matter lad care knowen antony woulde ioyne warre agrippa victory french aquitanes frieds aquitan call ing u also city promised ship leauing sadnes prepared greater nauie beginning spring antonie came fro athens tarentum iij c ship ioyne antony commeth italy caesar warre according promise changing purpose tarried til nauie furnished told caesar contemneth antony antonyes nauie sufficiente alleaged lettes might appeare quarrell antony despised help trusting owne antony taking greeuously remained yet still required againe hauing much adoe prepare money parthian war nede antony desirous italian souldyoures italian souldioures would haue chaged ship although coposition might take vp italy harder bycause italy another ma prouince wherefore octauia went hir brother moue therevnto octauia hir brother said antony forsaken whereby like haue bin lost sea sicelie aunswered tarento antony saw caesar lept bote alone signifying trusted caesar seing like either made hast get groud contrary side caesar quicker arriued antontes side wente charriot antonie hys sister octauia lodged togither without garde nexte day antonie lyke thus soone debate suspition soone agreed necessitie caesar deferred warreexchaunge fortresse agaynst pompey till next yeare antonie could tarry longer parthian warre made exchange antonie gaue caesar hundreth twenty shippes whiche caesar promysed twentie thousande legion soldiours italian octauia presented hir brother ten shippes bothe serued burden ore caesar gaue octauia one thousande choyse men garde antonie woulde take bycause time three men authoritie expired decree senatecontinuaunce three men authoritie continued fiue yeare owne pretended bin groud thought haue bene true ranne catche comon pray whiche perceyued went away laughed whereat caesar souldiours much agrieued whe shewed seruice could menodorus deliuereth rebilus senator deliuered rebilus senator taken making way fayned vinidius familiar caesar woulde flee away sayling nigh enimy desiredhe maketh deuise vinidius speake vinidus matter concerned graunted meeting alone tolde hym fleeyng agayne pompey despightes caluisius done nowe agrippa admirall hee woulde returne agayne caesar seruice vinidius messala would bryng assuraunce messala agrippa leiftenant promysing recompence faulte singular seruice tyll assuraunce sayde would molest done auoyde suspition dyd messala doubted firste matter honest length hee grauted eyther necessitie time knewe caesar woulde content thus agayne hee fled menedorus reuol eth agayne hee came caesar kneeled asked pardon hee shewed cause former faulte caesar bycause promise content pardon appoynted keeper tauromino lovve sicile taurom io vvas builded casidians colonie rome hauyng name bull minos vvhich beare armes stylida scyl uc novve called capo di squillaccia daungerous place v b hipponao citie vvith gulfe novv called eu n calabris papias lepidus shippes distroyed ti nu strongile novve sho al far fro sicelie pelorus poynt sicelie ouer agaynst scylla e novv zzo ty aride far myle gaue leaue capitaynes taurus goe mount silatio mountaine tauromino whiche hee beyng fitte fight passage army land followed scouted light horseman nauy brigandine foystes caesar came vibone praysed order returned vibo vnder leading apollophanes late bondman hee folowing lxx day agrippa set forth halfe nauie fight agrippa goeth fight papia alone saw apollophanes nauie rest pompeis shippes hee signified caesar pompey myla greater parte nauie kept battel great shippes comaunding al roste keepe course hiera preparation great bothe side shippes turret sterne pompe exhortation giuen beganne fight caesar vpon face othersthe fighte sea difference shippes vpon side fetching compass pompeis shippes lighte litle apte turne returne aboute enimies caesar great beauie therefore slower force offende defende soldiours morethe difference men manly mariner gotte aduantage compassing aboute breaking sterne side enimie violece somtime gaue great blow tooke contrary side caesar ship sterne easily put backe little either crushed pearced fought hande combred shotte hooke helde harde woulde icape sea take vp againe litle botes wayted shippes agrippa gaue onset vpon papia shippe agrippa driueth papia shippe force slitte fought toppe fell downe water entred lower sorte drowned escaped swimmyng papia beyng receyued another papia fighteth agayne shippe fought agayne pompey standyng vpon hyll perceiuing shippes weake weary agrippa continually refreshed rerewarde commaunded pompeis shippe retire retyre order whiche shewe fight agrippa folowed fledde rockes softe ooze brought flouddes agrippa aduertised hys maisters aduenture shalowes caste anchor abroade though would giue new charge neede night beyng admonished folow anger reason ouerlabour weary soldiour watchyng trust muche caulmenesse sea hardely departed pompeis men got porte pompey hath lo se sea loste thirtie shippes enimies fiue drowned many hurt pompey praysed manly resistyng pompey prayseth souldiours greate shippes whiche hee sayde seemed fighte sea assaulte wall rewarded victours puttyng hope narrow sea shippes woulde euer better might hee woulde adde somewhat theyr height ende fighte sea myla betweene agrippa papia caesar meane season chaunce departing one onely page without seruats soldiours family came port abala abala caesar desperatio brought messala founde great feare desperation carying shippe shippe brought legth messala far tooke rest sent caesar signifieth vvell brygantine cornificio shore signifie hee alyue promised would shortly help caesar goeth stilida hee litle rested hee wente night stilida whence messala caried
