kill fledde brutus cassius death gaue himselfe hys nauie antonie romane vertue thought good remember example romane vertue messala hym condemned hys power cast vtter desolation restored state preserued hym cornificius although hee might easily haue kept enimie campe yet bycause hee wanted victuall hee prouoked battayle pompey thought good fighte desperate hopyng subdue famine cornificius marched receyuing batayle vnarmed escaped sea beyng greatly annoyed wt horsmen plaine part affricanes moore fourth day came dry place called ye parchyng plotte thethe drye place fire burned dryed euen sea inhabitantes dare go night great heate cornificius daunger cornificius burst neyther passe way night bycause moone shewe skilfull way coulde abide day heate intollerable thirst could aswaged go fast bicause horseman folowed come issue sawe naked men ranne vponnaked citizes vpon armed romanes claspyng put daunger choking yt yet troubled soldiours desperatio cornificius coforted tolde well atthe romanes grieuously troubled hand put backe rude people till came well found possessed enimies like sort vtterly hope saw army co ming could tell whether freend foe zaronius kept well saw fled fearingzaronius interclosed whereat weary soldiours made great ioy shoutes cryes laronius answered runne heapes wel captaynes forbidding drinkesoldiours perished vvith hasty drinking hastily would folow cousel died presently thus beyonde hope cornificius broughte army safe myla agrippa taken tyndarida furnished wyth agrippa taketh tyndarida vvhiche vvas citie named tindarus father led thing necessary fitte warre sea whither caesar sent footemen horse sicelie one twenty legion twenty thousande horseman aboue fiue thousande light horse pompey held yet garrison mylas nauloco peloro sea coast afrayde agrippa kept peloro one foure hils sicelie tovvarde italy myla floud citie vvith port novv called melazzo dianio citie also spayne vvere ox phaetusa vvhich hir tvvo sister kept myconio caesar peril againe continuall fyres vse ship kept mouthes taurominio myla shutte pathes mountaynes walles also molested caesar beyod tyndarida would yet fight supposing agrippa would arriue went speede peloro leauing streightes myla whiche caesar forthwith take little towne called dianio notable tale goodly ox taken away vlysses slept noyce agrippa comming ceassed pompey heard streightes myla possessed hee called tifieno army caesar going encounter wyth missed way nighte hill myconio lay without tent whereas rayne greate wont autumne stoode night vnder french targetthe hill aetna novv mongibello spouteth fire souldyoures holding ouer horrible fearefull sound hill mongibello heard flashing fire seene sauoure brimstone felt much germanes lept feare thought tale germanes afrayd noyce aetna heard hyll wasted countrey palesteno mette lepidus taking vp corne palesteno messana beseeged layde seege messana many skirmish great battell caesar sente taurus keepe victuall pompey take city remained hym difficultie driuen tryal determined aduenture one fight bycause thoughte himselfe weake land sent herald require fighte sea albeit pompey desireth trie fight equall number shippes caesar good match sea hauing hitherto euill lucke yet thinking dishonorable refuse appoynted day fighte three hundred shippes side furnished weapon defence coulde deuice agrippa inuented graple raster fiue cubites long layd ouer yron hauing cricle ring eyther ende onegraple inueu ion agrippa crooked hooke yron many rope drew hooke gynne cast sling agaynst enimies shyppes day come first onset small vessel withoute escries throwing dartes andthe stoute last fight sea stone shotte fyred well hand engine ship rushed one another side sterne poupe thereby souldyoures shaken vessel broken vsed shotte dartes farre little boates take vp fell water souldyoures marriners contended best exhorting captaynes good engine help graple whiche reached small ship farre lightnesse held fast drawyng rope neyther coulde cutte bycause couered yron rope touched bycause theyrthe profite graple length neyther engine knowen might haue armed weapon yron rowed suddaine thrusting ship sterne get aloose enimies force equal graple came thing selfe ship fought ioyned togither leaping one another scarcely coulde one knowne armour weapos alike shape one priuie token vnderstoodliken esse armour maketh confusion cause muche deceyt confusion distrusted owne feare deceyued know might meane time hurt great sea full well men armoure rumes broken crushed vessel came fyghte hande threw fire armyes footemen stoode vppon shore wyth doubtfull mynde whyther victory woulde encline multitude syxe hundred shyppes coulde discerne beeyng alyke excepte couloure theyr toppes wherein onely differed onely coniectured markes hadde noyses voyces howe matter went agrippa vnderstoode pompey agrippa get victory worse hee exhorted hys souldyoures stande myghte obteyne victory whyche theyr handes dyd wyth suche furie violence enimie fledde ranne themselues ground eyther taken burned whiche kepte sea dyd see yeelded nauie caesar sang song victory whychreioyce victory caesar en footemen shore aunswered lesse gladnesse pompey perceyuing ouerthrowe fledde messina remembring force footemen yeelded pompey army yeldeth caesar caesar shortly horsemenne lyke whyche pompey hearde commaunded put thing seauenteene shyppes lefte leauing habite generall woulde flee antony whose mother hee pompey fainteth prouideth flee hadde saued lyke daunger myghte bee better welcome sente plennius bring eyght legion hee lelisbeo whyche woulde leade wyth hym perceyued friend souldyoures continually yeelde caesar enimie entred narrow sea although strong well furnished citie yet hee would tarrie plennius fledde wyth hys seauenteene pompey fleeth vvith vij ship shippes gone plennius came messina kept citie end last fighte sea whyche three caesar ship sonke seauen twenty pompey remnant defeated agrippa except xvij pompey fledde away caesar remayned naulecho commaunded agrippa beseegenaulechi messina whiche fellowship lepidus plennius sente peace agrippa thoughte good deferre aunswere tyll morning lepidus contente winne plennius souldyoures hym permitted halfe spoyle messina sacked citie hauing obteyned beyonde hope beyng glad haue gone theyr liues night sacked ye citie lepidus souldyoures meanes lepidus wanne plennius legion sware vnto nowe hauing two lepidus diuideth spoyle messana vvith plennius receyuesh army lepidus thinketh lord sicelie quarelling betvveene caesar lepidus twenty legion great nauie little proude thought winne sicelie bycause gotten diuers place sent garrison keepe octauian next day caesar expostulated lepidus friendes saying came confederate resort sicelie get ile himselfe alleadging authoritie taken fro caesar alone could content render africa corfica sicelie caesar angry came vnto charged ingratitude departed stoode doubt keeping warde seuerally shipyes lay anchor suspected lepidus intended haue burned caesar ship army fearing new ciuill warre like estimation lepidus caesar accompted wise diligente remisse negligent bycause suffered enimies partaker spoyle octauian vnderstoode caused friend deale captaines secretly promise liberally many wonne vnto specially pompey band thinking state sure excepte caesar cosented caesar came person many horseman left without trench entred camp vnbeknowing lepidus lacke foresight protesting new lepidus army reuolteth warre moued wherefore souldioures saluted generall pompey parte corrupted asked forgiuenesse said maruelled pompey souldyours yeelde caesar aske forgiuenesse hauing yet done conuenient vnderstanding meaning tooke theyr ensignes brought caesar pulled downe theyr tentes lepidus heard tumulte came armed streight fray began one caesar page caesar stricken killed himselfe stroke brest plate hurte wherefore departed hast horseman garrison iesteda castell beaten dovvne vvhose garrison iested caesar running away whereat angry quiet till beaten downe castell whiche done castels gaue ouer like sort presently nighte following neuer spoken pretendingcastels giuen r caesar occasion beeyng vexed horseman yet abode brunt repulsed lepidus euery sent helper reuolting also rest willing changed mind first againe pompeyans yet remayned sooke little little lepidus caused armed kepe armed intet toke ensignes aid others ioyned theselues caesar lepidus threatened went prayd also tooke standerds sayd woulde neuer deliuer whe souldyour said thou shalt deliuer lepidus vtterly forsaken dead gaue place last sooke horseman sente caesar know shoulde kill hymthe horseman sende caesar knovv vvoulde houe lepidus killed denyed thus lepidus saken men hauing lost army changed habite went caesar many ranne see sight caesar rose came would suffer kneele depriuing authoritie reseruing priestly office apparell came sent lepidus e ri ed speciall liuing reserued mu abiliti fortune rome thus bin many time generall sometime one three ruler making officer condemning many good himsolfe liued priuate life vnder whome attainted caesar would persecute pompey caesar vvon follovv pompey suffer either bycause would meddle another man iurisdiction would behold antonyes doings haue iust occasion fall al aduersaries taken away thought ambition woulde make two quarell bycause pompey none conspirator caesar affirme nowe army caesar mighty armie ld legion xxv horseman souldyoures many gathered togither sixe hundred gallyes many shippes burthen sent owner gaue souldyoures rewarde victory promised time come distributed crownes garland honor fo gaue pompey captaynes thys greate felicitie fortune u ie owne armie fell toenuic follovveth fortune mutinie destring discharged requiring rewardemutinie souldioures promised field philipps aunswered thys warre like notwithstanding woulde reward togyther antonyes souldyers returne concerning discharge put remembrance oth obedience seeyng styll obstinate ceassed hys rebuke least souldyoures lately yeelded follow trade promised antony would discharge conueniente tyme would vse cruell warre help god ended done nowe would leade slauonia barbarous nation shoulde get great booty sayde woulde g vnlesse hee woulde rewarde thoroughly sayd would reward also giue gariano garmentes honor prayse sayde ofilius one tribune garlandes ofilius rudely speaketh caesar purple garmentes bee rewardes child souldyoures neede money landes multitude sayde true caesar greeued came scate stoode nexte tribune praysed rebuked woulde agree wyth sayde sufficiente alone defende iust cause nexte daye seene coulde bee knowen become ofilius scene agayne souldyoures one feare altogither requyred dismissed caesar spake feare coulde theyr captaynes discharged serued philippi modena olde souldyoures commaunded depart ile least corrupt rest thus much sayd discharged thought discharged themsouldyoures dismissed nowe yet woulde reward speaking hee made wytnesse periurie departed discharged leaue theyr generall praysed th promised dismisse shortly repente duetie done nowe woulde giue euery fyue hundred drammes sette vpon sicelie fifteene hundred talentes appoynted lieutenant sicelie barbarie diuided hys army antonyes shippe sent drent rest hys army sent partlie italy partly tooke wyth hym wente ile commyng towarde rome senate receyued hym wyth kynde honor permytting himselfe receyuehonoured offered caesar rome whyche would eyther pleasure mette farre wyth garlandes well senate people whome first brought temple hys house daye following made oration senate people declared hys doyngs order administration caesar declareth actes senate people caesar oration published common wealth hys beginning thys day whiche oration written hymselfe published wyth many example pronounced peace tranquilitie long ciuill warres tribute vnpayd hee forgaue lykewyse gatherer tolles synes office honor senate accepted chariot theatre yearely solemnity dayes hys victoriesmodestic caesar image golde common place wyth thys inscription peace gotten many warres lande sea refused chiefe byshopshippe peopleinscription peace offered hym whyche auntiente custome vsed taken man aliue lepidus woulde haue hadde hym kylled lepidus enimie denyed wrote manye letter armyes wyth commaundemente bee opened daye appoynted doe commaunded whyche restore bondman rome italy maisters heyres freedome giuen request pompey whichebondmen restored maisters returned old state like sicelie vnchalenged put deathe citie whence came seemed end ciuill warre caesar caesar honoured god xxviii yeare age robbery citie eyght twenty yeares age consecrated god citie sicelie troubled much wyth robber rouers boldnesse openly committed lewdenesse correct sabinus sent put manye tosab u sword spent yeare coulde ridde time say band watch appoynted whichvvatches appoynted night citie continue day speedy redresse brought greate estimation caesar exercised manye thing olde manner yearely officer burned letter written time warre promised restore commonthe hope restorement common state caesar vvords wealth soone antony returned knew also woulde giue vp office nowe ciuill warre therefore extolled immortall prayses tribuneship giuen euer meaning thetribune perpetuall taking leaue wrote priuately antony gaue aduice bibulus goyng hym placed lieutenant prouinces intending companion warre slauonia pompey fleeing sicelie came shore lacinie lacinie hill furthest shore italy pompey spoyleth temple iune mitylene citie lesbo novv mitcline vayne hope pompey lalien spoyled rich temple iune thence went mitylene father lefte mother made warre caesar bycause antony gone parthian warre intended yeeld returne reported antony ouercome beleeued hee conceiued hope succeede prouinces least part taking example labienus ranne ouer asia occupyed cogitation heard antony come alexandria prepared himselfe course wrote antony friend fellow meaning pompey vseth double deuice espie doings secretely sente embassadours prince thracia pontus minding passe armenia obteyne purpose wrote also parthian hoping would take hym captayne warre beeyng romane againste antony theyr romane aduersary prepared shyppes souldyoures pretending afrayde caesar prepare antonyes vse antony hearde hys purpose hee sente sent pompey antony titius chiefe captayne agaynste hym receyuing armie nauie syria hee shoulde resiste pompey hys power rather receyue antony truste hee shoulde bryng honorably embassadours pompey made request wee sent thee pompey hee coulde admitted spaine prouince oweth good pompeis embassadours anotonie father sake listed make warre whiche holpe hym younger offereth theyr ayde bycause hee rather enioy peace thee vnder thy banner make warre neede new intent ruled sicilie inuaded italie saued sente thee home thy mother desired thy friendship whiche thou haddest accepted neyther bene driuen sicilie whereto thou diddest lende thy shippes thou bene ouercome parthia caesar sending thee army promised yea thou mightest haue brought italie vnder thy power although refused time desireth thee illuded deceyued many fayre wordes affinitie remembryng pompey also promise contrarie iniustly inuaded caesar spoyled portion whereof parte hath redou ded thee thou onely arte lette hath monarchie hath long thirsted bin war popey bene thou oughtest foresee thing thy selfe good hee beareth thee rather haue amitio playne liberall man subtill crafty fellow pompey angry thou lentest shippes agaynst beyng constrayned thou mightest haue men putteth thee remebrance much army sent thee hinder thee shorte pompey committeth himselfe thee shippes trusty army whiche haue forsaken hym though fledde thou shalt purchase great prayse beyng peace thou wilt preserue sonne pompey great warre broken whiche feared thou mayst haue confederate might estimation antonie hearde sayde antonie pompeis embassadours pompey meaneth good faith haue giuen commission titius bryng meake pompe messenger sente parthian taken antony officer messenger taken brought alexandria whome antonie learned thyngs sente pompeis embassadours shewed exell hym beyng yong man extreeme necessrie fearyng ed dry en soexcuse popey proue moste mortall enimies people rome sure antony mynde hee neede furder suyte eeued playne man nothyng suspitious furnius antonie plaine man furniu beyng president asia receyued pompey gently beyng hable ect hym sure antony minde hee sawe hym trayne soldiours hee gathered pompey trayneth men ob rbus amyntas practise disco red countrey sente capitayne armie amyntas freende assemblyng quickly togither pompey complayned hee vsed enimy sent embassadours antonie loked answere meane practised take curio put death helpe cu ne hys freende practise discouered curio put death pompey kylled hys la e bondman theodorus killed lampsaco taken pompey capsico citie shore hellesponte besiegeth cyzi ade propontide citie name great strength theodorus nely priute counsell doubted furnius tooke citie lampsaco composition many italian dyd inhabite appoynted iulius caes r whome hee allured pay great promyses hee two hundreth horse three region besieged cyzicus sea lande whiche repulsed litle bande antony certen sworde player brought vp furnius absteyning battayle old cuermore encampe nigh kept fro soraging part gr went aboute territorie acheans pompey set vpon fore parte hys campe sente aboute pompey di odgeth furnius like behinde whereby furnius resisting hys campe taken dryuen flee fieldes scamatria litle tovvne porte ili scamandria pompey killed many fielde moyst shoures escaped durst turne againe fielde people mysia propontide pla espeople resorte pompey pore consumed payment came seruice beyng renoun ed hys late victorie wantyng horseman beyng shrewdly hand ed foragyng heard novve sea sayne george mys novve pompey money taken bande italian horseman goyng antonie whiche octauia sente athens sente corrupt golde president countrey tooke brought money distcibuted horse men pompey n cea nic medium gathered muche money greate successe furnius agaynehe gathereth nicea citie diuerse place n comedia novv cuie procon novv mor ile propontide comming fielde encamping nigh came lxx shippes sicelie spryng leste antonie lent caesar titius came syria hundred twentie shippes greate army arriued proconnesco pompey afrayde burned shippes armed mariner hauing trust lande cassius parma nasidius saturninus therinus antistius honorable friendes pompey furnius moste pompey frendes yeelde antonie deere vnto lib father lawe saw pompey alwayes weake yeelded themselues antonie thus forsaken went midland bythinia entending go arm nia furnius tituis folowed secrete departed tent great iourney ouertooke night seuerally encamped aboute hill without ditche trenche beyng late weary pompey assayleth eninues night night pompey set vpon three thousande men sleeping put flee naked shamefully hee assayled whole power folowed pompey loseth occasion broke gotten perfect victory fortune would suffer got nothing thereby went iourney recouering horse folowed kepte victuall beyng dryuen speache hee desired speake furnius tyme freende hys father man greate dignitie st ndyng banke riuer hee sayde hee sente embassadours antonie pompey desireth speach vvith furnius meane season wantyng victualles dyd hee done make warre vpon mee y commaundeme seeth wel receyuing greater warre hang ouer hym vpon owne authoritie pray beseeche would ceasie till embassadours returne carie safely furni committe selfe promise deliuer safe antonie thus much hee sayde hopyng antonie gentle man seekyng passe iourney quietly furnius thus answeared thou wouldest haue co mittedfurnius pompey thy selfe antonie thou shouldest haue done first beyng quiet haue looked answeare yiene makyng warre thou haste brought thy selfe case thou repentest thee blame v antonie hath appoynted titius receyue thee hym therefore committe thy selfe thou mayst require thou requirest mee commaunded thou playest parte enimie kill thee bryng thee honorably vnto pompey offended ti vnthankfull bycause hee pompey hateth ti made warre agaynst hym whome tooke saued hym therefore pompey grieued come handes meane man whose fidelitie suspected eyther behauiour former iniurie hee done pleasure wherefore agayne yeelded furnius desired taken graunted pompey yeldeth furnius vvho vvoulde take suffer amyntas desired amyntas ight take whe furnius sayde bycause wrong commission antonie brake furnius soldiours thought hee woulde haue yeelded nexte day titius night makyng fire founding trompe euery reliefe watche went campe tellyng woulde doe hee meante haue gone sea haue set titius campe fire whiche gone discouered departure whiche may went amyntas folowed hundred horseman drewe nigh people fors ke hym openly pompey forsaken handes secretely sawe forsaken side hee pompey yeldeth amyntas vvithout condition yeelded amyntas without condition refusing ti condition thus yonger great pompey taken losing father yong brother whenthe conn ing vp pompey toward mane estate two taken away lay close great whye vexed spayne wyth priuie robbery tyll hadde good rescet professed hymselfe pompey sonne made open rodes iulius caesar slayne moued playne warre beeyng ayded wyth greate multitude force suddayne gayning shippes publike treasure ppressed italy wyth famine broughte hys enimies condition woulde wicked condemnation executed rome sauedthe good acte pompey manye noble men enioyed theyr countrey benefyte fortune fauouring hym woulde neuernegligence v pompey take aduantage hys enimie neglecting manye occasion would lye still thys bondage titius commaunded hys army sweare antony put titius putteth pompey death mil citie endes ionia caria hym death mileto hadde lyued age fortye yeares eyther remembred late displeasure forgot olde good rurnes commaundemente antony bee saye plancus antony dyd commaundeplancus hym dye whyche heeyng president syria written ten time euery yeare authour appianus alexandrinus hath like lucke al estimation vvas halfe labour lost last part vvhole ciuill tumult fro briefly supplyed otherwise end romanes wo beginning ioy might declared one successiuely folovving vvhich may please honour accept according accustomed goodnesse beseeching liuing lord long preserue honour humble seruaunt h b continuation appian alexandria till ouerthrow antonius vvhiche vvas laste ciuill dissention whiche octauius caesar rule romane empire alone octauius caesar antonius agreed sextus yonger sonne pompey great determined antonius shold make warre vpon parthian reuenge death crassus wherefore presently sent ventidius represse parthian gratifie octauius content marie sister antonie marieth octauia made holy minister iulius caesar dead remayning rome ruling common consent octauius caesar well matter cittie whole empire befalleth betweene prince make pastime play match antonie alwayes worse antony fortune ouercome caesar whiche somewhat moued company aegiptian ye maner soothsayer eyther please cleopatra shew truth tolde antonie hys fortune obseured fortune octauius therefore hee aduised go furder sayth whe thou art abrode thy nature noble coragious thou art deiect afrayde antonie whether motion owne inclination content leaue octauius go towarde olde loue aegipt yet carying new wife graecia pretending earnest desire reuenge iniurie done crassus sorte crassus pompey caesar suters consulship crassus pompey caesar rome agaynst stoode cicero cato crassus pompey chosen continued caesar authoritie france fiue yeares longer desired castyng lotte prouinces spayne fell pompey whereof glad beyng giuen please wife people gladde beyng desirous haue pompey nigh citie syria fell crassus whereof crassus goeth vvarre agaynst order onely gladde sory perceyued hee wholy giuen spoyle countrie parthia whiche comprehended law prouinces wherfore atteius tribune people forbad crassus inuade parthia animated caesar letter fraunce pempeys presence rome wente forwarde notwithstandyng tribune gate citie stande fire sacrifice coniuryng name moste straunge searefull goddes proceede kinde execrationexecration romanes thinke moste horrible bothe doth pronounce pronounced crassus pasion sea lost many shippes sayling due time gotten city accorde wonne one force woulde needes called imperator mocked bicause name notimperator giuen romanes plaine batayle ouerthrowne x spending one winter like rent gatherer without exercise soldiours spoyling temple hierapoli holy citie ful maruelous thing hierapoli entry sonne fell one vpon offred help king armenia would make iourney thorough countrie better way refused went rashly mesopotamia passage ouer bridge made thundred lightned face blew downe parte bridge come ouer campe twice set fyre lightning many token might haue moued went forthtokens till sonne xx romanes slaine x taken al despite done could deuised vpon antonie goeth par an reuege crassus antonie better li tenant himselfe ventidius occasio antonie leade army parthian leiftenat ventidius gaue great ouerthrow while athens wherfore made great feasting among graecians ready go forth ware garland holy oliue fulfill oracle caried vessel water meane time ventidius gaue ouerthrow whiche pacorus king sonne slaine although seemed sufficiet reuenge crassus death yet gaue thirde euerthrow betweene medium mesopotamia ventidius thought good stay least antonie enuie subdued reuolted besieged comagenus antiochus samosatis samosatis citie vvhere lage maruelous nature antonie refuseth good offer promised giue thousand talent obey antony vnto ventidius willed send embassadours bicause hand done would recerue offer shoulde seeme ventidius hath done antonie returneth citie stoode defence would yeelde sorie refused condition content take three hundreth talent go way agayne athens hauing done litle nothing syria rewarded ventidius well sent rome triuph triuph parthian man base bloud auaced antonie cofirmed saying caesar antonie better preuayle lieftenants thanking orodes killed sonne moneses themistocles compared antony liberalitie couternayle king persi themselues orodes king parthia killed sonne phra e fro many fled away amog moneses noble came antonie coparyng miserie themistocles owne felicitie kyngs persia gaue three city eue xerxes gaue lij city themistocles bread drynke meate say twoo lo gyng apparell kyng sent moneses restored antonie content offered hym peace hee would nder ensignes captiues taken losse crassus tooke iourney arabia armenia increased army consederate kyngs wherof greatest king armenia lent horse footeme mustred army romane footeme l spanish french romane horsme x natios horse footeme xxx great power cast terrorvaine lo euen indian vaine loue cleopatra brought none effect desire come againe hir companie made al thing time order lefte laste wife octauia hyr child chyldren heeocta first wyfe fuluia octauius caesar beyng easte partes wholy gyuen wanton desire cleopatra whome hee gaue prouinces cypre caelosyria cleopatra phaenitia parte cilicia iurie wherewith romanes antonie killeth king iurie vanitie antonie muche greeued also crueltie antigonus kyng iurie vanitie chyldren hee cleopatra callyng one alexander sunne cleopatra moone yet cleopatra fayrest woman worlde wittie sull artificiall deuises caste beguyle antonie easie ledde haste hee woulde suffer hys armie reste long iourney haste hee lefte engine behinde whereof one called ramme foure score foote long haste heehaste maketh vvaste lefte medium passyng lefte hande armenia atropatia whiche hee spoyled hee besieged great citie atropatia one part medium phraata hee founde hys errour leauyng hys artillerie behinde therefore cause hys men somewhat made caste vp mountes meane tune king forth mighty army hearing artillerie left behind sent great parte horse men slew tatianus ten thousand left custody enginesthe artillerie romanes taken tooke spilled munitio much discourage soldiours caused kyng armenia soke whose cause made warre parthian bragge vpon romanes wherefore antonie tooke ten legion horseman range countrie thereby prouoke enimie fight whe gone one dayes iourney saw enimies round aboute therefore campe determined fight yet would seeme raysed campe goe away commaundyng foote men hande horsemenne shoulde sette vppon enimie whiche stoode triangle battayle beholde romanes good order shakyng dartes tyme serued horseman gaue fierce onsette vppon tooke away vse theyr shotte notwithstandyng stucke foot men came shoute fearefull shew parthian horseman disordered turned backes antony thinking make ende warre daye gaue chase yet tooke xxx kyl ed lxxx whiche agayne much discourage romanes since lost many small victory cariage wanne little victory next day antony returned camp way first mette enimies afterwards last much molested much adoe got tentes enimie saulted trench diuers feare forsake wherefore antony punished euery tenth man fedde rest wythpunishment fedde vvith barly vvas punishment among souldyoures barley warre greeuous antony could goe foraging without great losse kyng feared men shoulde lye fielde winter would forsake wherefore deuised policie noble men parthian suffered romanes carrie awayecrast parthian prayes great commendation worthinesse king woulde glad peace riding neerer army would rebuke antony keeping strange countrey whiche though parthian theyr friend shoulde harde escape antony hearde caused enquired whether men dyd speake king consent aunswered sente king woulde restore captiues ensignes would depart king sayd would sende would depart quickly therefore antony made vp retired going away speake souldyoures wont doe elaquente way whereat many offended committing matter done antony omitteth generalles part mardus domitius aenobarbus way one mardus well acquainted parthian maners whose faith romanes proued tolde antony best goe hee might haue hilles right hande hazarde hys army laden armour parthian archer horseman playne way antony consulted counsell pretending yet afrayde breache peace accepting counsell compendious antony required suretie mardw bind till came armenia beeyng bound brought two dayes quietly third day antony loked nothing lesse parthian vpon romanes parthian mardus espyed banke riuer bee broken downe water flowing abroade coniectured done enimie hynder passage antony therefore wished antony loke faire antony sette men order parthian came vppon whome receyued shotte muche hurte done side till french horseman brake vpon put day antony taughte hereby went square battel fencing thoroughly shotte horseman commaunded gyue repulse enimie done cha e farre parthian trouble romanes parthian foure dayes receyued much hurt done minded retire bycause winter hand fifth daye fuluius gallus valiant man desired antony fuluius gallus taketh euill enterprise haue greater bande shotte horseman would notable feate receyued put backe enimie returning armie againe pursuing along without feare whiche leader rerewarde see called backe hee would obey whereas titius tooke banner turnetitius backe put forward againe badde hym meddle hys owne matter wente farre compassed hys enimies compelled sende helpe wherein canidius canidius greate credite wyth antony dyd well hee sente fewe soone put backe vtterly hadde bin lost hadde antony come wyth hys legion time abated courage enimie notwithstandyng romanes slayne three thousande romanes slayne fyue thousande hurte gallus wounded foure dartes dyed antony antony vveepeth went weeping comforting desired content well well great lone bare souldyoures vnto compted one best captaynes time enimies encouraged victory wayted camp night thinking romanes would haue bin gone morning number much encreased king sent horseman gard person came fight himselfe nowe fortie thousand horseman antony woulde haue gone among souldyoures blacke gowne friend woulde antony lamenteth suffer went generall like praysed hadde done well rebuked done otherwise prayed pardon punish euery tenth man desired leaue sorrow held hand vp heauen saying anye disdeyne god remained hys antonyes prayer former fortune desired might fall vpon romanes army might saued haue victory next day went warily contrary theyr looking parthian came rolling downe hill thinking haue gotten pray haue founde warre romanes policie romanes tooke archer middest battell causing kneele stouping couered shield vppon parthian arrowes slided parthian thinking romanes stouped weerinesse made shoute came vpon staues whiche time romanes rose encountred parthian repulsed droue away thus troubled dyuers dayes made little way nowe wante campe coulde gettevvant romanes camp corne cattell spente partly losse partlye carrying wounded sicke men barly lofe wasbarly bread hearbes venemous fren ye camp solde waighte siluer eate strange hearbes rootes brought present death kinde madnesse coulde nothing else roll stone campe almost occupyed picking turning stone remedye thys wyne whyche wanted hostvvine therefore hadde vomited melancolie dyed manye thus dying parthian styll commyng vpon antony oftentimes cryed oh tenne thousande meaning tenne thousand greekes vnder leading xenophon passed safe farre longer way despight enimiesthe xenophon nowe parthian perceyued could preuayle againste romanes breake order alwayes put backe began deale gently againe wyth forragiers shewing string bowes vnbente make ende onely fewe median shoulde followe tayle keepe townes spoyling wordes made romanes glad antony minded goe champion way leaue hil e entred way one mithridates antony vvarned cousin monesis fledde antony came vnto required speake one coulde parthian tong whome alexander antioch friende antonyes appoynted tolde monesis good antony sent shew vnder hilles saw nexte vnto playne way ioyne parthian lay secrete beguile againe faire word therfore woulde saue himselfe host shoulde leaue way hilles deede shoulde finde laboure thirst way escape crassus misfortune saide went way antony communicated wyth friendes mardus affirmed lyke truth therefore sayd best go hils though paynefull shoulde lacke water one daye nowe antony toke way commaunded euery man carrie muche water coulde lacke vessel andvvater part carryed sallet parthian spy told whiche way antony went contrary theyr manner came vpon night breake day set vpon rereward weeryed labour watching compelled march resist enimie foreward come floud whiche cleere salt whosalt vvater soeuer dranke full payne mardus gaue warning souldyoures would ruled antony ranne aboute praying refraine passe little floud healthsome water chose way parthian could follow cause souldyoures haue shadow blew retreat pitched tent done parthian going backe wonte mithridates came agayne spake withmithridates alexander telling hym souldyoures rested remoue passe ouer next floud farre enimie would followe antony heard tooke many cuppes gold alexander giue mithridates antonyes giftes many could carrie away antony departed hadde much ado enimies followed hard sacked hys antonyes treasure spoyled carriage tooke table plate golde many hadde anye thyng kylled spoyled whereby thought armye disordered scattered much antony called one chamber hym wylled commaunded hym kyll hym shoulde vppon antony dread hys oth take away head mighte knowen dead antony sorrowe mardus dyd comfort affirming floud hande whiche hee knew coldnesse aire felte antony cold ayre oke vvater bring quiet commaunded campe euen breake daye parthian againe charged vppon tayle defence whome shotte sent battell defended shieldes parthian durst come handstrokes time foreward come floud uer antony sent first hurt sicke souldioures appoynted horseman encounter enimie whiche meane wente ouer might haue leysure drinke parthian sawe floude vnbente theyr bowes sayde romanes myghte nowe drinke leysure deserued theyr vertue romanes beeyng past floud marche order yet trusting parthian sifth daye theyr last fyghte came floude araxes diuideth medium armenia bycause thys araxes diuideth armenia atropatia floud harde passe agayne afrayd theyr enimies ayne awayte passing quietly soone came lande reioyced sea embraced one another weeping ioy followed another inconuenience countrey plentifull souioyoures taking muche fell many disease dyed antony mustered men finding wantedlo twenty thousand foot men foure thousand horseman halfe dyed disease e citie phra ti b comming seauen twenty dayes whiche hadde fought eyghteene time parthian whome coulde haue perfite victory bycause king armenia forsooke whose army hadde bin expert haue dealte parthian wherefore euery man counselled antony reuenged king antony vsing policy shewed courtesy men countrey sent fayre message king came vnto whome co itted carryed alexandri triumphed ouer hym antony taketh king ar fl ght ant yes triu p displeasant romanes thing greeued romanes antony woulde defraude countrey please concubine winter greate lost eyghte thousande coulde come castell called leuce great agonyes till cleopatra come like foolishe yong gaue himselfe wantonnes riot running table sea side euery antonyes ond s day see come came brought muche apparell money gyue soul youres say antony toke hir gyue romanes variance fallen betweene king parthia medium spoyle romanes goodes median king sent antony come agayne woulde ioyne wyth antony c lled med agayne power great antony little glad heereof bycause helpe median mighte bee meane hym conquer parthia intended make new urney rome oct uia de red goe hir husbad antony c sar content muche pleasure sister take occasion c r seeket occasion antony euill handling suspected would followe hir moue iust warre antony come athens receyued letter antony stay bycause antony forbiddeth vvife octauia newe voyage smelling matter wrote vnto know whether send thing whiche brought saye many coates souldyoures great plenty cattell money reward captaines two thousande freshe souldyoures gard person well set hym niger messengerniger cleopatra heard fearing octauia came would put hir conceyt bestirred hir pined hirselfecraft cleopatra wepte wayled woulde needes dye antonyes sake sayd would take iourney hand blamed antony rude hard harted h e would put louing lady great queene danger hir life eyther wiues sake anye cause muche antony made tame foole deferred vnto antony doteth next sommer expedition returned alexandria winter cleopatra octauia returned rome hir brotheroctauia willed hir goe hir owne house went antonyes house kept good order cherishing well child first himselfe redde noted might sayde agaynst called senate c sar obiected agaynst antony testament redde openly whereat many grieued thinkyng reasonable man minde death shoulde bee scanned whylest aliue greatest faulte founde willed wheresoeuer died body caried alexandria sente cleopatra furthermore one caluisius freende caesar obiected agaynst antoni giuen hir librarie p rgamo thelibrarie p rg whiche two hundred thousand bookes would rise table ample vpon hir feete compacte suffered ephesian presence call hir soueraigne h gaue audien e king p ce woulde receyue letter loue hir written table antony freends made meanes people rome sent geminius geminius vnto warne take heede loste power pronounced rebell rome geminius cleopatra tauteth geminius come graecia cleopatra suspected came entreate octauia beyng supper taunted vsed spitefully bare till might haue antonie alone yt would comaunded tell came cue ansvvere geminius supper sayd thing required sober conference one thing knew sober dronke geminius telleth truth blamed well cleopatra went aegypt antonie angry cleopatra sayde thou haste done well geminius tell truth without torture geminius went hys way hand parasite cleopatra dyd cause many flee bycause coulde beare despite contumely romanes fleeth antonie among whome syllanius dellius sayde hee feared destroyed cleopatra glaucus phisitian tolde hym caesar ready thrall woman farre passed good footeme hir pleasure put strength nauie hee vnderstoode captaines nauie found fault lacke good seaman supplied want roges cariers haruest men laborer wasted graecia yet nauie furnished many shippes voyde vnable fight caesar made shippes huge ostentation shew butthe maner caesar shippes light swift well furnished whiche helde tarent bruduse fro thence sent antonie require loose caesar prouoketh antonie time come forth would giue safe rodes porte nauie giue conuenient ground italie lande men surely quietly antonie contrary side bragging antonie chalengeth combat vvith caesar chalenged fight hand hand would doe fighte pharsall fielde caesar fought pompey caesar while antonie lay anchor actio actio whiche nicopoli passed sea get towne epirus whiche called toryne antonie beyng afeard enimietoryne set vpon shippes vnfurnished made shewe great readinesse shippyng oares euery side kept porte wherby caesar deceiued went backe antonie deuised take away water fro scant naught hee dealt gently concerning domitio contrary cleopatra opimo sicke tooke litle boate fled caesar yt although greeued antonie notwithstanding sent goodes seruants bicause openly knowe fled grieued died king amintas deiotaras went caesar also bycause antony nauie sufficient copelled looke trust army land canidius yt general footeme persuaded wisecanidius send cleopatra home go thracia macedonia try ye mater lad dicomes king getes redy help great nubers yt shold shame refuse fight sea bicause caesar practise reaso ye sicilian war great blame vnto vse force lande wherein moste experte suffer antonie heareth good counsell abused sea cleopatra vrged fight sea although despayred victorie secretely prouided meanes antonie danger flee away time antonie daunger certaine narow space grounde betweene nauie ouer whiche maner passe without feare whiche caesar aduertised layde wayte whiche little quicke tooke came antonie hardely escaped ranne away determined fight sea burned vnprofitable vessel kepte gallies best sorte whiche put twentie thousand footemen two thousand archer certayne captayne bene good seruitoura good request old capitayne graunted expert soldiour shewed wounded body antonie cry generall doest thou distrust woundes weapon puttest thy trust brittell vessel let aegyptians like make fight sea giue v land haue bene wonte stande die else conquere antonie answered nothing antonie refuseth al good cousell hande head signifying good cheere passed hope layde aside maisters shippes would haue taken away sayles commaunded carried shippes none enimies shoulde escape preteded day xiij day rough weather deferred fight fifth day weather beyng fayre made fight antonie publicola righte wing caelius left marcus iusteius midde battayle caesar appoynted agrippa right helde lefte canidius hadthe fight antony land soldiours taurus caesar beyng order quiet shore antonie went hys nauie foyste e horting soldiours fight without remeuyng bycause waight shippes commaunded maysters standyng anchor shoulde sturre onset enimie auoyde disaduantage place mouth porte say caesar wente day view hys nauie hee mette man leadyng asse asking namea token sayde name fortunate mine ass name victorie forme place figure man asse sette vp afterwarde table brasse common place rome hee ouerlooked residue nauie betooke himselfe righte battayle behelde enimies quiet straight seemed lien anchor helde shippes backe good beyng twoo mile sixe clocke good gale beganne blowe antony soldiours would tarry longer trustyng greatnesse ship moued lefte battayle caesar sawe hee gladde held still right battaile might get enimies straightes swifte shippes fighte huge heauy vessel enimies nothing well manned onset giuen couragiously encounter antony ship could well stirre giue good assault whiche best done mouyng caesar shippes sitte gyue charge vpon front bycause others sharpe strong beakes durst side breakyng owne beakes greate tymber yron worke mighty vessel therefore like fight onthe diuersitie fight lande rather may say assault wall three foure caesar set vpon one antony fought theyr dartes pykes fyred weapon antony menne flong downe theyr weapon tower casting engine agrippa began stretch foorth compasse rest whiche publicola dyd see forced diuided midde battayle fighte beyng sore bothe side vncertayne whome victorie cleopatra fleeth woulde fall cleopatra hyr threescore shippes whiche placed behinde greate shippes brake thorough greate disorder tooke themselues flight antonie shewe himselfe haue forgotten office antonie folovveth charge verified olde saying minde louer liueth body though bene annexeblouer hyr coulde neyther lyue die without hir soone saw hir shippe vnder sayle forsoke left soldiours slaughter enimie shed bloudes two companion aegypt got brygandine folowyng cleopatra bring hir reprochfull death see commyng sette antony hoysted cleopatra shippe flagge call hym hee beyng hoysted vp hyr looke vppon hyr shee vppon wente satte solitarie foreparte shippe holdyng hedde bothe handes shortly caesar swifte shippes followe hym sight whome antonie put backe sauing one whiche euricles fiersly pursued shakyng speare threatnyng antony pursued woordes antonie standyng still askyng hee foloweth antonie quoth hee lacharis sonne thateuricles good fortune caesar pursue thee father death yet take antony shippe goodlinesse whiche riche furniture cleopatra hee gone antonie satte still one sortesilence antonie one place spake cleopatra eyther anger shame hee come naro womenne naro forelande familiar bothe brought talke borde bedde entendyng sende thence africa choose one queenes riche shippes full golde siluer gaue hys freendes wishyng prouide themselues wepte prayed hym cheere hee desired folowe hys requeste antonie giueth frends leaue shift selues wrote theophilus hys officer corinth gyue quicke dispatch helpe hyde till caesar might bee pacified many shippes burden frendes come fight declaryng nauy loste thought army lande safe wherefore wrote canidius make haste macedonia bryng armie asia case antonie caesar long fighte antony nauie whiche caesar victorie length vehemencie bothe rage sea courage enimie gaue ouer onely fiue thousande beyng slayne three hundreth skippes taken fewe knewe antony fleeyng andmen amazed antony madnesse hearde wondred thyng incredible hauyng ninetene legion footemen twelue thousande horseman woulde forsake runne away though hee knowne vnstablenesse fortune notsoldiours good opinion antonie proued chaunce warre full many tyme souldiours thought still hee woulde come among muche caesar sente messenger reiected continued seuen dayes capitayne canidius antony footemen yeldeth stolne away night left comfortlesse yeelded conquerour sayled vnto athens makyng vnitie gretians distributed corne among afflicted kynde exaction seruitude antonie sent cleopatra aegypt paretonio hee wente paretonio port tovvne affrica twoo freendes one gretian romane lyued solitarily till hee heard hys antonie despayre lieftenauntes hadde forsaken would haue kylled himselfe hys freendes stoppe hee wente againe cleopatra diuising great expensesa deuise cleopatra hy safetie carrie hyr nauie nooke strayghtest place sea thought diuide affrike asia might bee safe inuasion bycause first shippes came euill lucke antonie hoped hys footemenne safe actio hee causod hyr leaue ensed mouthes floudde nilus beyng done antonie antonie folovveth trade timon buylded house sea lanterne ramped aboute separating himselfe company men affirmyng hee woulde folowe trade timon surnamed hater men forsaken freendes deceyued suche menne brought aduauncement hee tooke ingratitude harte hee woulde refuse men societie euen timon dyd citizen athens called house timons tabernacle timons tabernacle firste brought hym newes losse hys footemen actio canidius hymselfe shortly waseuill nevves one tolde hym herode iewe gone caesar certayne legion prynces dyd lyke none thyngs dyd moue beyng well wyllyng leaue bothe hope care contented hymselfe timons tabernacle beyng otherwise perswaded cleopatra came courte alexandria gaue hymselfe feasting banquettyng alexandrian dyd nothyng else antony renueth riot great whyle make good cheere maner felowship vsed among woulde lyue forsooke beganne whiche called woulde die togither whiche inferiour delicaciefeastes dying sorte superfluitie many sworne dye togither made suche feastes order course one cleopatra beside gaue hyr selfe searche moste cleopatra seketh poyson speedy poyson venom caused onely suche growyng thyngs accompted moste effectuous sought also lyuing beastes serpentes made proofe hyr folkes bothe shee antonie request cleopatra requestes antonie sente caesar shee requyred kyngdome aegypt myght entayled hyr chyldren antonie desired hee myght lyue pryuate lyfe athens hee might doe aegypt lacke freendes fayne sende euphronius schoolemayster alexas laodicia euphronius alexas laodicis infidelitie punished deceyued antonie meane herode iewe gaue hymselfe caesar dyd accepte hym put chaynes sent die countrey rewarde hee hys vnfaithfulnesse antonie caesar would heare antonyes request promised cleopatra kinde courtesie woulde reiect antony sente caesar promiseth much cleopatra liberte thyrenus learned man might moue magnificall lady wyth hope lusty yong emperoure vsed long pleasing oration antony suspition therefore toke caused whipped antony vvhippeth messenger caesar wrighting caesar stirred pride insolencie would moue man though miserie ifscornefull message antony quoth doth greeue take liberte hipparchus whippe shall euen nowe cleopatra might wipe away suspition honoured hym maruellously celebrating hir owne birth daye meanely asbirth day hir case required honoured nobly princely many came pore feast w nt rich away time agrippa wrote caesar rome anye caesar goeth rome wise repaire thither case required presence occasion warre againste antony deferred tyll next somme caesar sent force againste captaynes affrike went himselfe asia pelusio part egipt cleopatra suspition taken elusio suspected cleopatra contented seleucus shoulde deliuer purge crime toke wife child punished goodly sepulchre made ioyning temple isi whiche shesepulchre cleopatra placed hir treasure princely thing caesar afrayd driuen desperation woulde set fire put hir great hope alwayes come wyth army citie horseman lay horserace vppon antony came fiercely droue antony issueth alexindria repulseth caesar horseman cleopatra revvardeth valiant souldyoure seconde chalenge antony vpon cleopatra camp returned court tooke cleopatra armes kissed hir recommended vnto hir fought best gaue head peece coate armour golde yet night fledde caesar antony challenged caesar againe fight hande hand caesar aunswered many wayes antony dye seing way honourable dye fight antony determined set vpon caesar sea land supper bad drinke make merry coulde tell antony cheereth men serue lord shuld liue whe wept word sayd would leade fight ye might rather hope glorious death tha sure triumphat victorie midnight wasa noyse citie night svveete musicke heard ouer al ye citie pleasant noyse musicke went vsed yt sacrifice bacchus wet forth citie enimies camp expounded god serued also forsake ye morning brought forth footemen placed vpo hilles citie stood see yt successe nauie comming nigh yt enimie saluted friend like antonyes ship forsake yeelded perceyued antonyes horseme fled caesar also footemen fight ouercomehis horseman forsake done retired ye citie cry betrayd cleopatra whome made war hir sake antony complayneth cleopatra cleopatra sleeth antony message cleopatra afrayd furie got hir hir scpulchre causing bridge drawne kept close shut done sent one tell dead whe heard sayd teptest thou antony wet chaber vnharnessed saying cleopatra tormented without thee wil soone thee antonyes greefe great captayne preueted thee art woma case fortitude hero faithful seruat sworne kill whe commaund saith time thee toke sword turned face killed fell dead hero antonyes man killeth himselfe antonyes feete ah good eros quoth antony thou couldest abide doe thou hast taught selfe thrust sword belly layd downe vppon antony thrusteth svvord himselfe bed stroke great could dispatch hym fore commaunded make end went chamber leauing cry lamenting til diomedes came cleopatra bring antony todiomedes hir hearing aliue commanded caried hir antony caried halfe dead sepulchre armes dore monument cleopatra would open lot downe sheetes line heaue vp whyche hir two woman onely hir pitifull sight see bloudy yeelding ghosta pitifull sight halled vp hardly holding forth hand stretchyng himselfe toward hir well could pore wome hauing stregth ynough till cleopatra hir hads ding downeward much might got vp yt cry vpon hir haue pitie vpo whe layde vpo bed lamenting tearing hir mourning weede wiping bloud fro face called lord husband emperour forgetting hir owne sorow copassion somewhat coforted desired cuppe wine eyther thirst yt might sooner dispatched whe vvords antony death dronke wished hir prouide hir selfe wel could hir honor saued among caesar frieds trust proculeius shuld afflict hirselfe thisproculeius great alteratio rather comfort hirselfe yt dealt yt mighty ful power romane thorough cowardise ouercome romane said yelded antony dyeth ye ghost whe proculeius come fro caesar whe antony stricke himselfe drawe cleopatra derceteus onederceteus gard toke bloudy sword caried caesar telling caesar vveepeth antony stood whe heard went closet wept antonyes chance bin valiat copanion many battels red letter friendes declaring proudely arrogatly answered gentle letter comanded proculeius yt could get cleopatra aliue feared destructio hir treasure thought would smal honor might bring hir triuph wold talke wt proculeius wtin far hardly hir voyce could heard hir request hir kingdome might establishedrequest cleopatra hir child proculeius bad hir good cheere remit al caesar marking ye place sent word caesar sent gallus togallus talke hir purpose prologed comunication till proculcius hauing got scalling ladder two got window antony taken went streight ye place proculeius getteth secret scpulcre cleopatra wher talking wt gallus one ye wome cryed vnhappy cleopatra thou art take aliue would haue stricke hirselfe ware dagger proculeus ranne quickly proculeus stayeth cleopatra om lling hirselfe embraced hir hand saying cleopatra doe iniurie selfe caesar taking acte clemencie casting infamie vnfaithfulnesse tooke dagger hir cut hir garment shoulde haue poyson hir caesar sent freemade man epaphroditus commaundement shoulde epaphroditus care caesar keepe cleopatra aliue anye wise see hir kepte aliue thinges gently curteously entred citie arrius philosopher holding hande citizen mighte caesar honoureth philosopher see honor come common hall citizen lying prostrate feare willed rise saying forgat firste alexander fame caesar mercy alexa ne builded citie beautie thirdly arrius sake body antony caesar contente shoulde burie hir owne hand labour whereof cleopatra buryeth antonyes body princely cleopatra kept killing hir selfe hunger getting agew glad hadde suche cloke refrayne meate kill hirselfe hunger whiche perceyued caesar threatned hir losse hir child contente releeued againe fewe dayes caesar came see hir comforte hir lying homely hir night gowne lept bedde fell downe caesar commeth cleopatra caesar feete trembling voyce heauie cheere hir body deformed hir owne stripe whereof printes seene hir eye sonke hir couloure swart yet dyd hir behauiour declare hir grace extinct whiche dyd appeare forepined wasted corpse caesar willed hir sit sate hir making excuse done al feare antony whiche caesar reproued cleopatra submit caesar gaue hir wholly mercy toke note suche treasure one hir treasurer seleucus corrected hidde somewhat lepte vnto knocked aboute pate whereat caesar smylingshe beateth one hir seruants blaming hir caesar sayd greefe seeing thou doest disdeyne visit wofull estate accused seruants keeping fewe woman thyngs wherewith would winne thy wife liuia thy sister octauia make thee fauourable caesar glad word thinking desire liue granted hir al beyond hope thinking hadde deceyued hir caesar granteth thing cleopatra deceyued cornelius dolabella noble yog caesar camp great desire cleopatra caesar gaue leaue come tell hir would go home lad syria dolabella sent cleopatra hir child sent italy shippe vnderstoode desired caesar mighte firste celebrate antonyes funerall wherwith content came graue hir woman sayde late noble antony burie cleopatra celebrateth antonyes funerall thee free honor thy buriall captiue garded consume wretched body much lamenting thee whiche reserued shewed triumph thee honour hand thou shalt looke ready caried away thee nothing separate v lyuingvvords cleopatra death must parted thou romane must lye heere vnhappy egiptian italy farforth partaker thy countrey god thyng oure god haue deceyued v heere forsake thy wife aliue neyther suffer triumph made thee burie close heere thee infinite greefes none great shorte time haue lyued without thee ended lament put garland kissed graue commaunded bath made readye hir washed wente meate greate cheere chest brought countrie hir man gard asking toke away leaues cleopatra deceyueth caesar shewed figges maruelling forme greatnesse man smiled desired take thethe gard deceyued suspecting nothing bad carrie sent caesar hir writing sealed remoued hir two woman shut dores hir letter come caesar redde founde hir onely request hee cleopatra last request caesar greate petition buryed antony whiche hee saw suspected mynded haue gone streight thither hymselfe yet first sent see done dispatched suddaynely ranne thither founde alteration gard opened dores found hir dead lying bedde gold royally cleopatra foud dead vpon ded gold hit tvvo vvomen ir one hir woman called iris lay dead hir feete whose name charmium ready fall downe dead trimming crowne vpon hir head cryed well done charmium yea weli quoth one descended many progenitours king said thus much fell downe dead bed side say serpente called aspis brought among figges couered wyth aspis brought amog figges sting hir death leaues whiche sting hir death whose nature giue heauinesse sleepe without shrinking marke skinne onely putting forth gentle sweat face ane trance hard wakened saye two little spot hir arme whiche caesar eyther eleeued else would haue beleeued hir image yt brought triumph rome set forth serpent two markes hir arme howsoeuer caesar ory chanced yet highly commend hir noble mind caused hir royally layd antony hir woman nobly buryed also cleopatra xxxix yeares age hadde raigned xxij whereof xiiij antony liued liij yeares age antony cleopatra lvj antonyes image throwen downe cleopatra remoued archibius hir friend obteyned caesar thousand talent antony seauen childre three antonyes child wiues whereof attilus eldest killed caesar rest octauia brought vp hirs attilus betrayed hys scholemaister theoderus tooke goodly iewell hys necke killed required denyed caused hanged cesarione cleopatra first caesar beyng also betrayed scholemaster sent great caesar besto eth cleopatra child treasure india slayne dead hir doughter called cleopatra hir name maried flourishing king iuba promoted antonie sonne fuluia high favour next agrippa liutas child chief sheehe vseth one antony sonnes great fauour marcellus two daughter one sonne named marcellus caesar adopt made sonne law daughter giuen agrippa marcellus dying shortly mariage octauia desired agrippa mighte marrie hyschaunge mariage daughter antonie hyrs hir daughter bestowed vpon domitius aenobarba drusus liuias sonne steppechilde caesar came germanicus claudius germanicus diedemperours antony issue claudius emperoure germanicus came caius emperour also agryppinae e domitio aenobarba marrie claudius emperour adopted domitius calling nero germanicus emperour thus antony race diuerse emperours issued albeit himselfe lamentable end haue hearde cause romane state restored common wealth agayne anthony cause alteration romane estate noble brutus protested died al whose execration came vpon antonie died eyther god woulde plague antony euill life would chaunge state mighty comon wealth whiche worlde suche becke might doe woulde whose outragious dealing wel foreine ciuill murder pleased god punish great alteration else secrete determinatio natiuitie sonne iesus christ lord caesar monarche without competitor yet childe leaue adopted tiberius wiues sonne whome might see emperour thought shee holpe dispatche caesar time title augustus giuen thing neuer done anyaugustus romane onely augmentyng encreasing empire rome also de nation destinie assigned vnto hee shutte gate ianus temple generall peace folowed ianus temple shutte onely tvvice token generall peace world disposed set good order citie made many good lawes preseruation whiche time diuerse toke appeared coming greater prince prince prince king king borne worlde time glory god highestbyrth iesus christ peace earth men good great enuie iulius caesar great rule best sort men c caesar king emperours emperor hee generall army pontus place goe beyond rule nation bee beyonde rene getes bee beyonde hister call dacies boundes land neare coulde gather ilandes sea cyclades sporades h ade echi ade tyrrenides esia whatsoeuer name haue libya ionia aegipt ro sicilie otherwise called sea al subiect romanes excellencie named romanes great ilands cyprus creta hodes lesbus euboi sicelie sardus cyrnas whatsoeuer else passing north ae ile brittaine yt greatnesse maye continent haue ye best parte halfe reste passe parte haue fruitfull great al natios yt greatest labour conquere italy could hardly yeares halfe yt tyme vnder king e p sed king sworne woulde receiue vsed rule best meane hadde yearely chosen twoo hundred yeares v c empire waxed moste greate lordes nite raine power subdued nati o caius caesar getting vpper hand made sure state kept still forme name commo wealth made himselfe monarchie ouer rule hath continued one thys daye whome call king thinke e olde othe name emperoures whiche title rule army tyme purpose bee king emperoures haue continued thys tyme aboute two hundred yeares whiche citty hath bin chiefly tisied reuenue moste encreased thing long sure peace brought perfect felicitie emperoures haue made theyr dominion force haue holden reuolte therefore good skill hadde rather keepe profitable aboute sea encreace extende theyr dominson barbarous nation poore vnprofitable whome haue seene embassadoures come rome yeelde themselues subiect receyued emperoure vnprofitable many nation appoint king bycause empire hadde neede subiectes must kepte shame forsake though pore greate armyes euery place circle keepe greate lande sea one place neuer monarchie great continued long state grecia man begin fro tune darius army flourished vnto time phill amyntas sonne though put togither power athonians grecia darius first king persia cyru daughter vvi lacedemonians thebanes shall appeare mighty thing contended rather ig itie among themselues tha get dominio thought matter noble maineteine libertie againste strange king molested sayled farre sicel hope rule ouerthrowen went asia little returned coclude power grecian thoughthe ath ni n vver ouerthrovven italy otetions rule proceded surely grecia shewed would keepe seruitude vnconquerable muche could philip alexander thynke haue done euil vnworthy theselues horseman three hundred elephant vsed warre two thousande armed chariot muche armoure woulde serue three hundred thousande besides prouision lande two thousande small vessel galley little greate thousande fyue hundreth double furniture eyghte hundred shippes shewe whiche vsed pompe stem sterne golde seauen hundred fortie talent egipt treasure al whiche appeareth prince recordes yet extant seconde king egipt alexander al moste able spende bountifull bestow desirous get lefte behinde prince lagus vvas mightiest alexander muche inferiour mutuall discorde posteritie onely destruction great kingdomes came nothing romane empire passed greatnesse felicitie continuaunce wisedom senate neither wanted theyat lake al canne novve manhoode patience painefulnesse til established power gaue place misfortune loste sometime twenty thousande sometyme fortie fiftye thousand battaile diuerse tymes citie daunger famine pestilence sedition yet woulde abate ambition space seauen hundred yeares stryuing paine perill till brought dominion keeping stil one rade heigth receyue moste ample fruit wisedome happinesse thing many gretians romanes haue put writing historie farre exceeding macedonian haue considered valiauntnesse would see euery nation penne hath carried lybia vberia iberia sicilie macedonie embassages confederacy sundrye nation brought againe forced man sicilie carthage eftsoones carried mee away vnperfect til gathered partes howe tthey sent ambassadours armyes si ily iland til conquered many ambassages many league made ouerthrowes bothe side giuen till carthage ouercome africa made prouince carthage restored againe state nowe haue done like euerye prouince bycause would know romaine euery might see manhoode fayntnesse al natios vertue fortune conquered whatsoeuer matter chaunced thinking woulde acceptable also vnderstand romaine actes thys sorte haue written euery nation selfe leauing write done meane time placyng seuerally set time euery thing thought much moste notable expresse distance time firste romaine one name al afterthe romaine haue diuerse name came another length thirde also added known marke body vertue mind grecian surname ioyned name time wyll put chiefly noble men may betterthe diuision vvorkes knowen name one shal moste fitte three bokes declare romaine doings italie call three romaine actes italian multitude matter thus diuided made amitie french moue agaynste italy filled sea pirate cilicia pillers hercules whiche made trafficke sayling could bee one citie another wrought great famine euery place generally lefte nothing
