romanes number nine fortie order meete make mention matter romanes prusias called hunter marriedprusias cyrigus daughter perseus kyng macedonie romanes perseus making warre long prusias stoode neuter perseus ouercome mette romane captaines wearing romane garmente called toga hauyng shoe afterthe romanes vvere called tog greekes italian manner hys head shauen wyth cappe whyche manner goe made free testamente beeyng euill fauoured man beholde little shorte one meeting wyth spake romane tong freemade man romanes call libertus appearing sightethe behauioure prusias disguised libertus seruant made free laughed sent rome laughed also pardon long vexing attalus king asia pergamo wasted hys lande asia whyche senate rome heard sente prusas hee shoulde molest attalus friend confederate romanes thought muche obey embassadours sharply commaunded obey senate come thousande horseman confynes decide matter willed attalus bee many despising small number wyth attalus thynkyng myghte entrappe hym sente hys embassadoures afore though woulde followe thousandethe craftie prusias horse bringing army went battell attalus embassadours hearde fledde euerye man coulde tooke carriage romanes destroyed towne nicephor burned shippes beseeged attalus pergamo romanes heard thys sente embassadoures commaunded prusias restore attalus loss prusias afrayde obeyed wente hys waye payne put vpon hee shoulde presently gyue hym twentye armed shyppes time fiftie talentes shyppes gaue hande talentes prusias forced recompence attalus payde time hated subiects crueltie sonne nicomedes well beloued bithinians wherefore prusias suspecting sent lyue rome vnderstandyng well beloued wylled hym obteyne prusias practiseth kill sonne nicomedes senate release money ought attalus sent mena deale commaunded mena coulde gette hym discharged money shoulde spare nicomedes coulde kill hee sente thys purpose certayne greate shyppes two thousande souldyoures mena bycause penaltie forgiuen attalus hadde sente andronicus tell payne lesse spoyle neyther durst hyll yong man whome sawe worthy loued honoured goe agayne bythinia yong man knowing tarrying came talke good conspired againste prusias tooke practise embassadour attalus persuade get nicomedes kingdome bythinia met togither bernice little citie epirus nighte wente shippe consulted done secrete nighte day come nicomedes came forth ship cladde nicomedes shevveth himselfe king king robe purple crowne head andronicus meeting saluted king sent forth fiue hundreth souldioures ready mena dissembling though seene nicomedes till ranne two thousand though bin discontented beeyng come talke sayde haue two kinges one home going en souldyoures must needes foresee safetie coniecture well establish securitie well appoynting whych two haue raigne one olde yong bithinians hate olde loue yong chiefe romanes loue yong man andronicus defendoure hath promised attalus friendship hauyng greate kyngdome ioyning bithinia olde enimie prusias sayde thus withall declared crueltie prusias mischiefe done men common hatred bithinians againste perceyued abhored wickednesse prusias ledde strayght nicomedes seconde andronicus called king garded two thousand attalus receyued yong man gladly required prusias giue yong man city dwell landes finde aunswered would shortly giue attalus kingdome whose sake inuaded asia said thus sente rome accuse attalus nicomedes call iudgement attalus wente armie bithinia whome bithinians little little reuolted prusias distrusting men hoping romanes woulde deliuer hym danger obteyned fiue hundred thracian diegelies hys father lawe onely committed body fleeyng castell nicaea pretor rome bringing prusias nicaea vvas first called aftervvard nicaea vvife messenger senate speedily bycause fauoured attalus last brought senate commaunding choose embassador might ende warre chose three men whiche one head stricken stone andembassadors laughed euill fauoured scarre left another feete festered sore thyrde compted ydiot muche cato iesting embassage saide neyther minde feetecato head embassador went bithinia commanded ceasse warre nicomedes attalus dissembling obey senate bithinians set sayde coulde longer beare crueltie prusias especially knowen embassador bycause romanes hadde yet heard matter departed nothing prusias despayring romanes whome trust help comming went nicomedia get thenovv nich saylers comidia citie defend himselfe enimies forsooke shutte gate nicomedes came army certayne nicomedes host sent killed prusias fleeing temple iupiter thus nicomedes prusias killed raigned bithinia prusias time ending life hys sonne nicomedes called philopater succeeded romanes giuing father kingdome decree senate thus romanes made heyres labi testamente wente state bithinia learne nephewe another nicomedes leste romanes hys heire testament ruled cappadocia macedonian well tell whether vnder king owne vnder darius seeme alexander left nation tributarie arisus sayre tovvne confines pa phligon cappadocia ruler went darius semeth amisus citie athenian kind bring people rule according countreys manner sayde page duplicate page duplicate hieronimus subdue city hieronimus vvas historievvriter rhodes coast pamphilia cilitia turne another way againste darius perdiccas succeeded alexander macedonia put death ariarathe ruler cappadocia eyther reuolted woulde haue made macedonian appoynted nation eumenes cardia eumenes destroyed iudged enimie macedonian antipater perdiccas ruled country alexander gotten sente nicanor rule cappadocia macedonian long beeyng ciuill debate antigonus gote syria expuised laomedonta mithridates beeyng hys familiar bloud royall persia antigonus dreamed sowe grounde wyth golde mithridates dyd carrie golde pontus whendreame antigonus reaped wherefore hee tooke hym woulde haue kylled hym fledde wyth syre horse fenced place cappadocia many reuolting hym thys tumulte macedonie little little gotte cappadocia nation confynes pontus greately enlarging hys realme hee lefte hys chyldren raigned one another tyll sirth fyrste mithridates whiche made warre romanes stocke kynges cappadocia pontus conuning thynke bee knowen diuided kingdome reigning cappadocia pontus thys mithridates first friend romanes sente shyppes little helpe agaynste carthaginiens called euergetes whyche ouerranne cappadocia straunger beneficiall mithridates hys succeeded named dionisius eupater romanes commaunded hym gyue place kingdome cappadocia ariobarzanes sought thought himselfe nygher kingdome mithridates else bycause suspected kyngdome mithridates growyng greate vnder hande woulde diuide partes hee suffered agaynste nicomedes nicomedes prusia hys sonne romanes appoynted reigne father kingdome sent socrates brother nicomedes called chrestus armie socrates toke kingdome chrestus good profitable bythinia time mithrias bagoas expuising ariobarzanes romanes set kingdome cappadocia put ariarathes romanes restore bothe nicomedes ariobarzanes proper kyngdomes sendyng certaine embassadours purpose whereof manius acilius chiefe commaunded lucius cassius litle armie pergamo asia helpe also mithridates eupator hee beyng offended romanes cappadocia beyng put phrygia wee haue shewed greeke matter helpe cassius manius armie gatheryng greater galatian phrygian sent nicomedes bithynia ariobarzanes cappadocia persuaded bothe beyng neyghboures mithridates molest hys countrey prouoke hym warre romanes woulde mayntayners bothe alyke affected durst prouoke mithridates fearyng hys mighty power ambassadours rgyng nicomedes promised gyue embassadours muche money hys restitution souldiours yet hee ought beyng debte romanes money lente hym hys matter vnwillyngly hee inuaded mithridates lande spoyled farre citie amastris none amastris ch ese c e ca ed vvoman persia beyng named c n resistyng hym meetyng hym albeit mithridates hys armie ready yet hee refrayned haue iuster cause warre nicomedes returned home great pray mithridates sente pelopida romane capitaynes embassadours ignorant enimies cause inuasion yet dissembled sought manifest cause ofthe embassador mithridates romanes warre come pelopida told phrygia taken fro cappadocia alwaies bene auncestours left father phrygia giuen general rewarde victorie gotten aristonico neuerthelesse redeemed generall great summe money nowe see sayde nicomedes shutteth mouth pontus spoyleth land farre amastris carried away great bootie sel e well know kyng hauing power sufficient reuenge doth suffer may witness sight iniuries bycause know see mithridates desireth friend confederate friende confederate couenants tearme v woulde helpe v nicomedes dothe v wrong forbid v thus sayd pelopida nicomedes embassador making aunswere contraryeemba dors nicomedes sayde mithridates long layd traynes nicomedes sent socrates army kingdome would haue bin quiet iustly suffered elder brother raigne thus mithridates againste nicomedes whome romanes appoynted kyng bithinia whereby manifest thing done againste v like authoritie commaunded king asia meddle europe hath taken much cherronesus e despighte disdeyne disobedience great preparatio great furniture great notable warre well owne armye consederates racia scythia nigh nation hath married king armenia hath sente egypt syria allure king hathe three hundreth armed shippes making hath sent maysters gouernoures shippes phen ia egypt nicomedes r mane done mithridates disderning euer since haue commaunded hym leaue phrygia right possession decepte bought money one youre general greeued also cappadocia giue ari barzanes fearing increase taking occasion v deceyue wisedome tarrie till conf make warre rather looke actes wordes deceyued counterfet na frendship forsake youre true firme friendes deede neyther see iudgemente kingdome despised enimie v thys sayde nicomedes embassadoures pelopidas came agayne romanes audience accusing nicomedes thing done old prayd romanes judge thing done sayde hath done sight mithridates kingdome hathe diminished sea hath shutte spoyles hathe carryed away needeth debating consultation agayne pray eyther correct done help mithridates hath suffered wrong lastly romanes forbidde hym reuenge himselfe let two trye aunswered pelopidas certayne romanes fauoured nicomedes fashion heard controuersies somewhat moued wordes pelopidas bycause mithridates yet league romanes stoode doubt aunswere presently hauing wisedome considered matter aunswered thus neyther haue mithridates romanes aunsvvere suffer thing wrongfully nicomedes neyther suffer warre made vpon nicomedes thinke good romanes nicomedes hurt thus sayde pelopidas woulde haue made aunswere sentence doubtfull wente seate mithridates sawe manifestly iniured romanes sent sonne ariarathes great army reigne cappadocia expelled ariobarzanes kingdome pelopidas commyng agayne romane officer said thus mithridates hath borne hads romanes spoiled phrygia cappadocia haue heard hurt nicomedes hath done see let passe appealing amitie leage though accuser accused aunswere thinke profitable romane state nicomedes shoulde hurte though iniured romanes cause thing done cappadocia againste state rome thorough youre contempt v subtill aunsweres mithridates hathe done thys sendeth embassadoures againste youre senate whome sendeth worde aunswere attempt begin thing kindle warre withoute common consent romanes mithridates hathe father kingdome conteyning length twenty thousande furlong gotten many nation hym colchos warlike nationeight furlong maketh mile greekes dwel pontus barbarian next hath friend ready commaundement scythian taurians basternians sarmatians tanais hister fenne maeotis rbanes armenia maeotis great fenne scyth sonne lawe arsaces parthian hys friende hath nauie shippes whereof bee readye made furniture conueniente poyntes bithinians dyd nowe saye vntruely kynges egypt syria lyke onely take oure parte warre bee made also asia haue lately gotte grecia libya many nation italy beare youre ambition make endlesse warre wyth whych bycause cannot ceasse sette nicomedes ariobarzanes vppon mithridates turne say friend confederate aunswere vse hym enimie nowe go thing past repente yee eyther forbidd nicomedes molest friend doe promise mithridates shall ayd italian breake fayned friendship let v goe iudged rome sayde pelopida bycause seemed presumptuous commaunded mithridates shoulde deale nicomedes cappadocia woulde sette ariobarzanes kingdome agayne pelopidas shoulde depart fro camp returne embassadoure except king woulde stand order thus aunswered sente hym awaye wyth kepers shoulde corrupte none wentethe embassador make vvarre vvithout consent senate sayde tarrying senate wyll warre people consente gathered army bithinia cappadocia paphlagonia galatia asia theyr owne armye lucius cassius asia ready confederate gathered togither whyche diuided intothe romanes force diuers campes cassius middest bithinia galatia manius way bithinia mithridates appius another army hylles cappadocia hau g horse footemen number fortie thousand nauie shippes whyche minutius rufus caius popilius gouerned keeping mouth pontus nicomedes came wyth fiftie thousand footemen sixe thousand horseman greate army ready mithridates owne two hundreth fiftie thousande footemen fortie thousande horseman mithridates force three hundred armed shyppes hundreth gallyes wyth munition accordingly chiefe captaynes neoptolemus archelaus breethren greatest parte ledde himselfe sonne arcadia brought ayd tenne thousand horse armenia lesse laus ledde order mayne footemen craterus broughte hundred thirtie chariot greate prouision side romanes mithridates began warre clxx olimpiade large field floud ammeum mithridates nicomedes floud captaines see one another prepared fighte nicomedes et al order neoptolemus archelaus light harnesed horseman arcathias brought chariot foteme wer yet coming sent take stonyhil playne shoulde copassed bithinians greater nuber whe saw beaten fro hill neoptolemus fearing enclosed came rescue speede calling arcathia nicomedes seeing set vpon great fight slaughter nicomedes fight fiercely following mithridates men fledde till archelaus comming righte side repulse chacers coming vpon gaue place little neoptolemus might returne fro flight whe saw done deede set armed chariot vpon bithinians violence teare two partes acte muche discourage nicomedes host en ut asunder yet breathing torne many peeces violently carried chariot vnpleasantnesse sighte rather losse fight disordered battell feare vpon thus broken came archelaus front neoptolemus arcathias returning flyght vpon backe resisting side defended themselues good whyle many slayne nicomedes fledde rest paphlagonia fotemen mithridates nicomedes fleeth fight camp money many prisoner taken mithridates vsing gently mithridates vseth courtesie gaue conduct money sent home making shew enimies humanitie first feate great warre mithridates affrayd romane captaynes begunne rashly without common consente fewe ouercome many without help place fortune fighte vertue captaynes valiantnesse souldyoures nicomedes camped manius mathridates wente hill scoroba bankes cappadocia pontus hysscoraba scoutes hundreth horseman sauromatanes meetyng eyghte hundreth horse nicomedes tooke diuers whome mithridates agayne suffered goe countreyan courtesie mithridates money way manius going backe neoptolemus nemanes armenian meetyng towne pachius constreyned hym fighte nicomedes gone cassius pachius tovvn proponsid hauing four thousand horseman tenne time many footemen whome killed tenne thousande tooke three hundred prisoner whome mithridates brought let goe winne heartes enimies manius campe takena third curtesie mithridates romanes discontented sangaris othervvise called corallus lentocephale fledde floud sangaris passed ouer night saued himselfe pergamo cassius nicomedes romane legate sette camp leontocephale strong towne part phrigia trayned people newe husbandman artificer ioyned phrigians people vnwilling durst meddle men expert battell therefore licenced departed cassius apamed army nicomedes pergamo manius rhodes kept mouth pontus hearing forsooke key ship nicomedes pontus deliuered mithridates thus one brunt getting nicomedes land went mithridates lieth harborough vvhere great alexander lye set order city going phrigia comming inne alexander rested tooke lucky toke mithridates might lye alexander lodged gote rest phrigia misia asia romanes lately wonne sending place aboute got lycia pamphilia farre ionia laodiceans inhabit floud lycus resisted q oppius romane captainelycus q oppius hauing horseman footemen hyred got citie kept sent trumpet walles commanding hym say king mithridates giue suretie laodiceans would bring oppius hearde proclamation laodiceans betray oppius lette hired souldiours goe freely brought oppius mithridates maceberers scorne mithridates oppius ledde prisoner hurt ledde lose aboute shewing romane generall captiuitie long manius despighted mithridates cruelly handled tooke manius acilius best ye embassador chiefe cause warre ledde set vpon asse telling loked vpon manius till came pergamo wher put molte gold mouth reprouing romanes taking giftes appoynting ruler countrey came magnesia ephesus mitelena euery one receyuing without resistance ephesian throwing away image romanes whiche punished afterward going ionia tooke stratonicaea punished money set garrison citie seeyng mithridates taketh vvife stratonicaea monime made queene fayre mayde made hir one wiues man desirous know hir name monime ye daughter philopaenos magnesians paphlagonias lycian yet resisting hee ouercame captaynes thus mithridates romanes hearing thys first force inuasion asia determined warre hym although troubled ciuill strife incessantly citie italy occupyed great warre home almost euery place consul takyng charge asia fell cornelius sylla warre appoynted roome agaynst mithridates store money enacted sell thing numa pompilius kyng hadvvant treasure rome appoynted sacrifice goddes great want ther great ambition thyngs sold whereof raysed ix thousand pounde waight golde gaue great warre sylla long kept sedition wee haue shewed ciuill dissentions meane time mithridates made many shippes agaynst rhodians mithridates decree murder wrote secretely prince ruler city shoulde thirtie day beyng obserued kyll romanes italian men woman chyldren free killed caste vnburied diuide halfe theyr goodes kyng mithridates halfe themselues appoynted payne buried hidde rewarde bewrayed killed hidde seruantes libertie kill master debtours halfe debte kill creditours mithridates sente secretely daye come diuerse calamity seene asia whereof ephesian dragged fledde temple diana embraced image killed pergamenians shotte death fledde temple aesculapius woulde pulled image adramitte citie coaste mysia cruelty asia agaynst romanes c u novve ro e tovvne caria adramiteans killed swamme sea drowned chyldren cauneans beyng made tributarie rhodians warre antiochus restored romanes litle pulled italian holy common place whether fledde first killed child mother face mother laste father trallians keepe themself infamie murderer hyred theophilus paphlagonia cruell man acte theophilus killed beyng shutte temple peace cut hads imbraced image italian romanes suffred calamity asia men woman child free bonde italian generation wherin euidet asia much feare mithridates romanes hated hate romanes suffred double punishment mithridates shortly vsing cruelly contrary fayth cornelius sylla
