rich workes stone woman aray plenty money pontus time rhodians fortified walles porte c ri yria prepared al defence telmisians lycian con odered italian yt fledde asia came rhodes among l cassius gouernour asia mithridates coming thither pulled downe suburbes ye enimie take profite prepared fight sea front side mithridates coming galies comaunded men extend theselues winges flotethe vvarre muthridates agaynst rhodes swifte rowyng mighte inclose enimies fewer rhodians afraid copassing gaue place litle turned fledde porte shutting barres resisted mithridates walles encamping citie drawing nighe porte attemptyng tarried footemen brought asia shorte continuall skirmishing walles rhodias hauing better litle encouraged ship hande encounter enimy occasion serue great shippe king passed vnder sayle rhodians sent litle galie either side helping diligently great fight began sea mithridates beyng superiour anger minde multitude shippes rhodians arte setting vpo nauy disordering toke one galie men much munition spoyle brought hir hauen ignorat yt great galie taken enimie sent vj swif est recouer hir damagoras admiral wet mithridates sent xxv hym gaue place till night waxing darke king shippes retourned set vpon tooke two chased two lycia returned nighte ende fight betweene mithridates rhodians doone hope rhodians fewnesse mithridates multitude fight king sayling encourage men shippe chia hys nauie crushed king shippe confusion whiche kyng dissemblingthe king shippe crushed chaunce punished captaine maister offended xian thys time king footeme brought great ship pery risyng vpon driuen rhodes rhodians quickly comming vppon yet troubled strome tooke crushed burned tooke four hundred prisoner mithridates preparyng sambuca vvas engine vsed siege city bycause rope vvere stretched string instrument musicke called fight sea againe force towne made certaine engin called sambuca carried two ship fugitiues tolde side hill might scaled temple iupiter tabyrius weake wall put army ship night gaue scaling ladder commaunded goe silence till fire made temple crye loude coulde bee made assaulte towne force porte silence drewe nighe watche rhodians knowing made fire army mithridates thinking bin fire temple deepe silence cried togither well scaler marriners thethe rhodians put kyngs men avvaye rhodians cried fast chearefully came togither wal king men nothing night daye putte backe althoughe sambuke affraid rhodians much casting many dartes arrowes shotte beeing isi goddesse aegipt broughte againste temple isi souldiours many scalyng ladder shippes came forth woulde haue giuen asiaulte rhodians defended themselues manfully till engine brake waight vision isi thought caste greate fire vpon mithridates despairing enterprise sayled rhodes patara siege cut holy woode latone patara cittye lycia make engins till feared vision left woode leauing pelopida continue warre lycia hee sente archilous grecia winne force friendship much possible committing many thing captain trayned furnished army passed time woman stratonicede sate iudgement thought watch make mutinie helpe romaine while hee thus occupied thinges done grecia archelous sayling great nauie well victualled tooke delos reuolted athens place violence power killing twenty thousande men whiche moste italian place appointed athenian whyche meane extolling mithridates greatly praysing hym brought friendship sent holy money delos delos ile aegian sea aristion occasion money plaieth tyra aristion man athens two thousand gard mony aristion vsing purpose played tiranne country athenian killed oute hand fauourers romaine sent mithridates yet scholer epicurus learning alone athens critias beyng professours philosophie critias tyrannes italy pythagoras schoole grecia called seauen wise men rule theyphilosophers tirannes tooke vpon vsed tyranny cruellye vnlearned tyrannes therefore doubt suspition philosopher whether vertue pouertie lacke experience comforted themselues philosophie whiche many priuate poore couering neede sapiece speake bitterly againste rich men prince cotempt rich rule opinion rather enuy caried vnto bee slaundered wisely contempne one maye thinke bee spoken aristion philosopher occasion matter moued acheans lacedemonians relent archelous thespia free tovvne boeotia magnesia ionia demetriada thessalie boeotia except thespia whome beseeged time metrophanes sente mithridates another armye make warre vppon eubea dimetriades magnetia resisted mithridates brittius comming macedonia small nauie fight sea sinking one greate shippe foyste killed metrophanus beholding afrayde fledde hauing good wind brittius could ouertake tooke scyathus receypt barbarian rouers hanged vp scyethu e slaues cutte hand free men turning boeotia thousand horseman footemen comming macedonia cherona foughte three dayes aristion archelous equall indifferent fortune side lacedemonians acheans come ayde aristion archelous brittius thinking himselfe weake match pire novve portolione port athens able hold four hundred shippes went pire till archelous came kept sylla beeyng chosen generall warre againste mithridates tooke iourney italy fyue legion bandes companyes arriued grecia gatheryng money mon victual aetolia thessalia thoughte sufficiente wente attica againste archelous came boeetia sauing reuolted greate citie thebe lightly taking thebe boeotia mithridates parte againste romanes nowe swiftely turning archelous sylla came tryall went attica sending one parte armye againste citie beseege aristion wente pireo archelous within walles heygth whereof fortie cubites beeyng worke pericles made greate stone pireus vvas made p nacles vvalled tvvo myles length megara achaia ele sina attica square athenian made warre pelopenesians bycause putte victory pireo made strong sylla come wall gaue assaulte forthwith muche hurte beeyng done sydes cappadocians manfully defendyng beeyng weery wente eleusina megara made engine pireo mountes rampires artificer stuffe yron sling suche broughte hym thebe cut downe wodde academia made greate engine toke away academia vvas shadovvie place mile athens long side cast stone timber earth vppon rampire two slaues athens pireo fauouring romanes fidelitie slaues romanes foreseeyng theyr safetie anye thing shoulde happe wrote pellet leade euer shoulde done threwe romanes sling thys beeyng often done come knowledge sylla hauyng regarde matter founde thus written morrowe footemen shall come vppon face youre labourer horseman shall sette vppon sydes romanes therefore layde ambush ready enimie thought haue come ou suddayne suddaynelye dyd sette vppon kylled many droue sea thys ende thys attempte nowe many greate tower beeyng sette vpon mounte archelous dyd make lyke side furnished wyth weapon sente power chalcidonia ilandes armed hys mariner woulde hazarde archelous hadde greater armye sylla nowe muche bigger midnighte issued wyth lyghtes burned one greate engine belonged sylla tenne dayes made another sette archelous erected tower agaynst wall another army beyng come vnto hym mithridates whiche dimoxetes ledde brought forth fighte wyth whome mixed hys shotte stoode vnder wall warder myghte throwe vppon enimies stoode gate wyth fyre lokyng token sallie forthe fyghte long tyme equall nowe one another gaue place barbarian beganne flee tyll archelous commyng vppon made turne agayne whyche greately afrayed romaine fledde murienas met themromaines flee returne agayne reproued sorte vvere noted covvardlinesse called v pera returned bande come foragyne reproued seeing fighte hotte gaue couragious onset vpon mithridates menne killed two thousand droue walles archelous woulde haue tourned backe againe fyghte tarrying long bycause earnestnesse shutte oute taken rope sylla released rebuke noted bycause fought valiauntlye rewarded souldioures wyth gyftes accordingly winter come hee placed hys army eleusine andeleusine made ditche highe place sea ennimies horseman shoulde easilye breake vppon whyche hee working euerye daye diuerse skirmish sometime aboute ditche sometyme walles ennimyes commyng vsyng stone dartes pellet sylla wanting shippes sente rhodes rhodes coulde passe bycause mithridates helde sea hee commaunded lucullus diligece lucullus noble manne rome generall thys warre sylla goe priuilye alexandria syria gather armye kynges citties sende rhodians hee fearing sea besette wyth shyppes tooke light vessell chaunging shippe shippe vnknowne came alexandria bewrayers pireo wrote againe pellet nighte following archelous woulde sende athens want corne vpon soldiors backes sylla laying wayte tooke corne carrier daye minutius didde hurte neoptolemus chalcide novve negropon ey chiefe cuttie e boe captaine calcide killed thousand fiue hundred tooke moe prisoner long pireo ye night watch asleep romanes brought seales fro ye next mount got wal killed watch yt next wherfore ye barbarias leapt forsaking wall though al bene take turning force killed ye leader scaled flung downe headlong getting gate hadde neere hande burned one romaine tower scylla come army fought wyth nyght day greate labour saued archelous made tower wall romaine might fight togither vpon tower whiche oft furiously harde tyll scylla caste twentye greate pellet sling killed many beate arthelous tower vnprofitable archelous fayne lie behind wall feare citie pressed hunger slaues signifyed againe pellet victuall shoulde sent nighte cittie archelous suspecting treason bewraying carying victual sente victuall set gate fire runne vppon romaine sylla woulde force victuall happened sylla toke carried corne archelous burned certaine engine time arcathias mithridates sonne inuaded macedonia athias dieth tid army easily ouercame fewe romaine lefte subdued macedonia appointed ruler marched sylla falling yet sicke tid died athens citie great daunger famine sylla made many fort none shoulde flee remaining vexed multitude erecting mout pir hygh planted piece vppon achilous digging vnder mount taking away earth long knowne made mount sincke whiche soone perceiued romanes toke away engine filled vp earth againe vsing like waye vndermining wall met togither fought short weponsa fight night much might darkenes while sylla went wall many engine till parte fel made way burne nexte tower carried many lightes caste vppon commaunded boldest men go assault much beyng done bothe side tower burned sylla cast downe parte wall set garde foundation wall cast downe bound woode ful sulphure pitche flare al sone burned one p e fel ouerthrew yt stoode vpon tumult beyng soden great troubled warder though fallen also whervpo wherfore turning euerywhere hastily doubtful minde feare resisted enimies faintly sylla came vpon stil thus affected cheered histhe assaulte owne euer putting fresh weary went assault giuing courage voyce person threatning vnwilling short labour might make end archelous likewise came forth freshe men yt afrayd exhorting stirring ye onely paine worke weale great courage boldnesse againe either side great slaughter side equall alike till sylla comming forth wery blewe retreate praysed soldiours vertue archelous night repayred breach making vp broke sylla brought whole army thinking might easily beate downe new made soft r againe straight place beaten face side slippery place left getting pireus assault entended winne famine continue siege vnderstoode citie greater want spent beast sodde skinnes hide vsed broth gotten meate eate dead flesh commaunded army copasse citie one escape done went straight assault wall weake men fledde entred citie againe great slaughter murder athens coulde flee fors weakenesse p ti neither child woman sylla comaunding kill euery man mette anger soone without cause reuolted barbarian vvas vvhiche sang daunced hersed verse vvente vp vsed theatre resisted obstinatly much many hearing proclamation cast themselues willingly killed wet great pace castle among aristio place pastime first burned sylla make matter force fort would suffer cirie burned gaue spoile soldiours found man flesh readymans fleshe dressed sustenance libertie giuen posteritie athenian theselues dressed sustenance many house next day sylla sold seruats freeman escaped fro murder night sayd gaue libertie libertie posteritie haue also free election forbad aliue thus citie athens filled ful miserie sylla besieged castle easly tookes aristion yt fled ouercom hunger thirst whiche sylla put death aristion aristion put death serued borne office done anything co trary romanes order since taking pardoned appointed lawes al almost giuen romanes tooke poud waight golde siluer oq done castle litle sylla immediatly citie take belaying take pireo stege braught engine munition many men vndermine wall instrument beate downe many kept wall shooting darting vpon ouerthrew bowing part wall moyst weake new e archelous thinking made many like within sylla might euer haue somewhat finding new one like vsing cotinual assault wt incessable violence going among exhorting mater thing great importace praise al hope done lie themselues redy inough glory great feat win wal wet fearcely archelous astonished vehement motion beyond reason left wall vnto ranne strongest parte pireo compassed sea whiche sylla lacke shippes coulde attempt thermopyle greate hill diuideth grecia streyght vvith ho e vvaters thence archelous sayled thessalia boeotia gathered thermopyle rest owne army brought syndromichate hee called also came macedonia archatias king sonne freshe bande full beside mithridates continually sent hee neuer lefte sendyng done great vehemencie sylla burned pireo whiche greater labour pireo burned cittie sparing na munition preparation went archelous boeot nigh togither pho litle region grecia went thermopyle phocida thracian scythian pontus cappadotians bithynians galatian phrygian al fauored mithridates al cxx euery one chiefe captaines archelous generall ouer sylla hadde italian greekes macedonian reuolted archelous borderer thirde parte enimies number encamped togither archelous setting men order alwayes prouoking battayle sylla delayed considering place multitude ennimies followed archelous went calcide expecting time place sawecherona vnquered cherin hilly place whiche wer ouercome could flee plain nigh men redy prouoke archelous fight wil playne commodious marche forth retire pleasure wheras archelous baset hils coulde vse men would altogither place inequalitie ground turne harde place woulde hinder flight waying matter sylla taketh aduantage place th se difficulty gaue onset knowing great multitude would litle profit archelous think romanes would haue fought therfore kept campe neglygently whe battel begon felte hardenesse place perceyued late sente horseman kepe returning oriuen hils sent l armed chariot see could violence breake cut maine battel romanes theythe armed chariot defeated suffred passe front ende diuiding themselues ouerthrowen shot vnweldy turne though archelous might thus haue kepte campe soone hils defence yet set whole multitude order came vpon sylla sodeyne streight place bycause hand first brought forth horseman grat violence cut asunder romanes battayle easilye compassed small number fighting valiatly kept themselues ring greatest daunger fought vnder galba ortensius whome archelous fought barbarian sight shewed great manhoode till sylla came thyther horseman archelous thinkyng sylla hee came shewe ensignes raysing much duste leauyng hys compassing went hys battayle sylla brought horseman beste twoo newe bandes lay ambushe charged vpon settyng themselues order yet al come compassing due forme fronte brake confounded turued flee whiche followed beginnyng victory thus murena lefte wing furthered thethe ouerthrovv archelaus lustily encouraging men manly folowed chace wing archelous turned midde battayle holde fledde also sylla foreseene fel vpon enimie hauing free place turne playne flee hilles slayne folowed fell hades wiser got campe archelous ignorant feates warre commaunded turne vpon enimies way obeyed readily wating captaines set order knowing proper ensignes beeing fouly disordered wanting place bothe fighte flee beeing driuen straighte chaced killed ease ennimies could kill againe themselues cofusion straight place went againe gate gathered togyther rebukyng shutte rehearsing theyr countrey goddes naturall familiaritie much enimies disdayne destroyed tyll archelous seeyng neede opened gate late receyued running disorder romanes perceyuing callyng one vehemencie swiftenesse gotte cape fled brought victorie end archelous fledde could saued themselues calcide hundred xx many x remayning romanes say died xv two returned end field betwene sylla archelous cheronea tovvne b otia vvhere p rch vvas borne capitain general mithridates cheronea chiefly ye wisedom sylla foolishnesse archelous happe sylla hauing got much armure spoyle taken many prisoner ye vnprofitable thing gathered heape girded romane maner burned god warre resting army went euripus ye light horse archelous eurip streight sea flovveth seuen time day w wadred ilandes without dread romanes hauing ship folow tooke coast townes going zacynthus caped besiege citie certen zacynthus ile ionian sea romanes cape came vpo night departing hast went calcida like rouer tha warriour mithridates heard losse troubled againe afrayde case might gathered army natios hast thinkyng yt many would forsake ouerthrow occasion gathered togither suspitio warre wa e sharper firstcrueltie mithridates galatian killed gouernours galatian frendes yet subiect wife chyldren except three fled layd traynes killed night banquet thinking none woulde keepe fayth sylla came confiscating goodes made eumachus presidet nation ruler escaped gatheryng army tenaunts countrey droue garrison galatia mithridates nothing nation money angry ye chians euersince ship crushed king shippe battaile rhodes came secretely vpon first leased vpo goodes fled sylla sent inquire tooke romanes parte chio zenobus ledde third army though would chio novv io haue hasted gretia came walles chio naked place night tooke setting garde gate proclaymed stranger stirre assembled chians mithridates spite agaynst xi l cause say somwhat king whe come sayde king citie suspition bycause fauoured romanes ease must deliuer armure best child pledge seing theyr citie already taken deliuered zenobus sente erythea commaunding erythea citie asia far io vvhich vvas one sybilla chians tarrie king letter mithridates letter came effect yet frends romanes many citizen enioy fermes haue let pay nothing v mithridates letter ch galley fight rhodes shake crushe shippes fault would put onely vpon guyders ship could recouered loue secretly haue sent chief men sylla haue accused none doyng without comon consent haue punished priuie doyngs whereas might punish death beyng counsayled friend seeker life traytours kingdome punish two thousand talent tenor letter would haue sent embassadours zenobius woulde suffer armure gone chiefe child taken away great army barbarian heauy heart tooke treasure temple wiues jewel might make ij talent whe done zenobius finding fault wayght called al ye theatre setting soldiours ye theatre withthe lamentable destruction chians weapon drawne way downe ye sea side called seuerally put ship men theselues ye wome likewise child theselues barbarously scoffing thus spoyled countrey sent pontus euxinus mithridates sort chians vsed ephesian required zenobius yt come leane army ye gate come went philopaemena father monime mithridates loued madethe ephesian kill zenobius ouer ee ephesian willed ephesian proclamatio come togither assembly lokyng good hads deferred till next day ye night gathering togither exhorting one tooke zenobius killed pryson fenced walles put people order gathered corne kept citie strength trallians papenians mesopolitans afrayed trallis floud ru papen triphylia calamitie chio ephesias done mithridates sent army reuolted vsed cruelly tooke fearyng rest made city greece mithridates releaseth debtes maketh free free proclaymed forgiuenesse debtes fermours made citizen bondman free hoping deede released debt new made citizen freeman would sure vnto hym thinkyng thing could sure vnto mithridates rule meane season mynio philotimus smyrna clisthenes asclepiodotus lesbian ala conspiracte bevvrayed freendes king asclepiodotus sometime captayne straungers make conspiracie mithridates asclepiodotus bewraier credite brought passe kyng vnder bedde hearde mynio sayde cospiracie bewrayed cruelly killed like suspition vpon many moe pergameneans doyng like foure score take city mithridates sending searcher euery place finding enimies killed thousad sixe hundred men accuser log soone punished sylla killed themself fled mithridates pontus mithridates gathered army lxxx dorilus leade grecia archelous x left syllas army orchomenus floud name nigh archelous orchomeno saw great nuber horseman digged many pittes plaine x foote broade army order receyue archelaus romanes fayntly come fight multitude horseme rode exhorted beside threatned whe could bring matter lept horse tooke ensigne ranne enimies garde cryingthe boldnesse sylla man aske romanes betrayed generall sylla say fought orchomeno capitaines ranne fro bandes hym beyng daunger multitude beyng ashamed chaunged feare courage victory began appeare mounted horse agaynethe victory romane rode host praysing euery place exhorting till brought end dyed enimes aboute fifteene thousande whereof part horseman among diogenes archelous son footemen fledde campe sylla fearing least archelous woulde flee againe thalcida hauing shippes night set watch playne day fully furlong fro archelous cast trench comming forth exhorted earnestly army finish rest al battel seing enimies durst come brought trech archelous like mutation among enimies necessitie captaynes running aboute shewing presente daunger rebuking woulde defende theyr camp enimies fewer force crye made eyther side great might shewed part romanes couering themselues shield digge downe corner campe defendours put backe shorte weapon none durst enter till basillus captayne legion firste lept inthe valiantnes basillus killed resisted al army followed flight slaughter made barbarian went driuen lake nigh coulde swimme made prayer barbarian tong killer vnderstoode archelous hidde fenne getting boates sayled chalcida gathered togither rest king army diligencethis garland crovvne vvas called vallaris vvhich vvas giuen first scaled trench sylla nexte daye gaue basillus garland rewarded others giftes accordingly spoyled soeotia euer wauering come thessalia wintered tarried shyppes lucullus hadde bycause could tell lucullus made shippes time cornelius cinna gaius marius enimies rome proclaymed sylla proclaymed rebell rome rebell spoyling house village destroying friend notwithstanding thinges authoritie hauing army valiant obedient cinna chose flaccus hisflaccus fellow consul office sente asia two legion place sylla declared enimie ruler asia make warre mithridates flaccus vnexpert warres man senate good beloued army named fimbria wente saylingfimbria brunduse many shippes lost winter weather nauie sent mithridates burned shippes went espiall army forsooke flaccus malitious couetous cruell man part sente thessaly turned sylla rest fimbria thought better captayne gentle nature flaccus stayed reuolting chancing cotention lodging betweene treasurer flaccus leauing matter vniudged somewhat touching honor fimbria disoeynefull threatned returne rome flaccus appointed successour thing done fimbria wayting went calcida first tooke mace thermo flaccus made officer receyuing charge cosent army following flaccus anger til droue house escaping night fledde first calcide nicomedia shut gate fimbria came vpon killed fimbria killeth flaccus crept pitte consull romanes generall warre priuate wasa rare crueltie romane come friend request cut head threwe sea carcasse cast vnburied making himselfe generall foughte diuers fightes valiantly mithridates sonne droue k himselfe fro pergamo pitane citie lide whither followed pitane beseeged till shippe fledde mitylene fimbria inuading asia punished faction cappadocia spoyled land woulde receyue ilians beseeged fledde sylla vvhere troy vvas promised come willed say fimbria yeelded fimbria heard praysed friendes romanes desired receyue romane also estingly shewing ilians romanes affinitie entred killed mette burned euery thing embassador sente sylla tormented dyuers wayes neyther sparing holy thing fledde temple minerua whome burned templecrueltie romane next day bet downe walles went see thing stoode citie worse vsed hym troy vvorse vsed romane man allied agamemnon time house temple image left image minerua called palladium sent heauen thinke suppose palladium image minerua sente heauen vnbroken couered walles fell excepte diomedes vlisses carried away warre troy thys fimbria iliu ciii olimpiad ending thinke thousand fifty yeares agamemnon mithridates heard losse orchomeno considering multitude hadde sente grecia continuall greate ouerthrowes sent archelous make truce good manner could come parley sayde sylla mithridates auntient friend sylla hath made warre couetousnesse generalles archelous sylla content leaue warre thy vertues sake thou wilt commaund shall iust sylla wante ship money none sent bycause enimies iudged rebell hauing gathered money pythians olimpians epidaureans giuen reason holy thing halfe theban land oft rebelled hauing army valiant experte leade agaynste rebellion hys enimies bent peace sayd mithridates bin iniured haue sent embassadoures doyng iniurie hath inuaded many land men hathe slayne many common holy thyngs city proper goodes hathe spoyled beeyng like vnfaythfull friendes v whome hathe killed many slayne prince banquet night wiues child hath shewed v rather crueltie nature necessitie warre vsed italian asia kindes euils destroying murthering men woman child slaues nation italy great hate againste italy alleadgeth auntient amitie fashion hathe lost hundreth threescore thousand men maketh mention wherefore reason would take vnfaithfull yet thy sake vndertake get forgiuenesse romanes repente doyngs dissemblethtalke peace also loke thou wel archeloe consider present state well thy selfe consider howe hee hath vsed friend haue vsed eumenes massinissa hee speaking thus archelous disdeynefull brake tale spoken proue sayde woulde neuer betray army committed yet hope peace thy hand thou makest reasonable coditions sylla ceassing sayd archeloe mithridates doe deliuer vnto nauie thou hast deliuer captaines embassadours prisoner fugitiues slaues fledde fro v let go chians beside forth hath made captiues pontus take garrison euery place except breaking peace defray charge warre whereof hathe bin cause conteyne himselfe within limit father dominion trust persuade romanes remember hathe done thus said archelous tooke garrison euery place rest sent king sylla somewhat vacation spoyled enetanes dardaneans eiutians nation eople paphlagonia nigh macedonian alwayes molesting macedonia exercised souldyoures gotte money likewise embassadoures nowe come mithridates agreed thing hauing excepted paphlagonie saying mithridates mighte haue would make peace generall fimbria sylla angry said would punishe fimbria well ynough whe come asia would see whether mithridates hadde neede warre peace said thus went cypsela thracia sent lucullus afore abydus whether come daunger rouers many time brought nauie shyps cyprus phoenitia fro rhodus pamphilia spoyling many coastes enimies skirmishing king shyppes sylla cypselos mithridates pergamo mette agayne talke commyng playne fewe mithridates recorded father e confederacie accused romane embassadoures lieuteuantes whiche hadde vsed vniustly setting ariobarzanes cappadocia taking phrygia hym winking nicomedes dyd hym open iniurie quoth money taken well thyngtalke peace betvvene sylla mithridates romanes blamed bycause corrupt money warre broken youre generalles soeuer haue done defence hathe bin rather necessitie mithridates sayde thus hee ceassed sylla thus aunswered although thy comming peace yet doest renue matter refuse speake briefely lieutenant cilicia sette ariobarzanes cappadocia decree romanes thou diddest obey thou shouldest haue spoken wrangled afterwarde swarued order manius manius actes reproued gaue thee phrygia money iniustice indifferente thou doest confesse thou gottest vnlawfully giuing money manius thing done money reproued v senate dissolued done reason whereof woulde make phrygia tributarie vnto beeyng gyuen vniustly thee lefte free reason doest thou vsurpe thing haue taken warre wyll yet haue thee rule nicomedes accuseth thee alexander woundyng hys bodye sendyng socrates chrestus kyngdome reuenge inuaded thy realme dyd thee wrong thou shouldest haue sente embassadoures haue tarried aunswere thou dyddest make speedy reuengeance nicomedes dyddest thou inuade ariobarzanes hadde done thee wrong thou hadst begunne romanes compelled couenantes restore hym beeyng restored defend thou madest warre beeyng thus persuaded hope thou didst ouercome romanes thou shouldest reigne ouer making pretence thy purpose whyche haue thys coniecture warre thou madest league wyth thracian scythian sauromatians sendest king thy neyboures thou madest shippes gatheredst maisters mate time doth bewray thyne intente thou hardest italy reuolted fro v wayting trouble thou didst inuade ariobarzanes nicomedes galatian paphlagonia thou dydst inuade asia lande thou hadst got didst thou city ouer thou madest slaues fellowes debt ruler giuing libertie releassing debt agaynst grecian small occasion thou didst kill sixeteene hundreth prince galatia whome feast thee thou didst murther italian nation one daye thou didst kill drowne wiues childre sparing fledde holy place howe greate crueltie great impietie extremitie hate didst thou show agaynste v gathering euery man mony thou didst sayle europe greate armyes forbiddyng kyngs asia enter europe thou wert come thou didst ouercome macedonia oure prouince thou tokest grecian theyr freedome neyther didst thou repente thee make archelous meane thee tyll hadde recouered macedonia delyuered grecia thy violence slayne hundreth sixtie thousand thyne army taken thy campes theyr munition therfore maruell thou doest iustifye thy selfe thyngs thou desirest forgyuen archelous whyche farre thou didst graunte nigh thou doest call question whose tyme past thou making warre resisting mightily resist thee ende sylla speaking anger king afrayde graunted confyrmed condition made archelous deliueryng shyppes thing went pontus father kingdome onely thus firste warre betweene romanes mithridates ceassed sylla encamping two surlongs fimbria commaundedvvarre betvveene sylla hym deliuer army whiche helde agaynst lawes taunted rule lawfully beseeged sylla many openly forsaking called rest counsell exhorted tarrie sayde fimbria forsaken woulde fyght countreymen tore garmente besoughte refused also many still went went tentes captaines winning money called agayne counsell commaunded sweare enetans cryed must call sweare name called bin benefited hym first nonius nonius refuseth svveare priuie doings refused sweare drewe hys sworde threatned kill hym tyll crye made ceassed feare hyred slaue hope libertie money goe fugitiue kyll sylla beeyng thyng troubled beyng thereby suspected taken confessed syllas army rage disdeyne standing aboute fimbria hys trenche dyd reuile hym call atheniona fewe dayes king ouerathenion seruantes sicelie rebelled fimbria despayring came wall desyred speake wyth sylla vvill speake vvith fimbria sylla sente rutilius place chiefly greeued fimbria would speake denyed enimies desired pardon hadde offended yet yong man rutilius sayd sylla would let goe quietly sea would giue place asia sylla lieutenant sayde would find better way went pergamo temple aesculapius kylled hymselfe wounde beeyng sufficiente badde hys p ge dispatche fimbria killeth himselfe kylled hys maister fyrste himselfe thus ended fimbria muche mischiefe asia mithridates whome sylla gaue freemade bury sayinghi b ly given b rye othervvise marius vsed rome woulde follow cinna marius rome kylled many men woulde suffer buried receyuing fimbria armye came vnto hym sette hys owne commaunded curio restore nicomedes ariobarzanes cappadocia wrote senate thyngs seemyng declared rebell setling prouince recompenced ilians chians lycian rhodians magnesians others confederate good suffered whiche cause heethe revvardes faithfull people dismissed free registred friendes romanes rest sent army proclaymed seruantes hadde freedome mithridates shoulde restored theyr maisters whereof manye disobeying city rebellingthe punishment reuolting people followed great slaughter free bond diuers occasion walles many pulled downe made seruile people many cappadocians faction men city sharply punished chiefly ephesian impudently reuile romanes comandemets proclamation made chiefe euery citie come sylla ephesus come common hall thus sayd vnto first came asia army antiochu king sylla ephesi syria ouerrunne driuing away makyng aly taurus limit kingdome toke holy floud running taurus made lefte free excepte gaue eumenes rhodes confederate tributary tenant proofe whereof toke licians rhodians making complaynt thus wee help aristonicus four yeares v attalus philometer left kingdome v testament till aristonicus taken many came againe necessitie feare thus doyng foure twenty yeares comming great rich substance well publike priuate thorough peace abundance wrangle agayne wayting trouble italie brought mithridates receyued came moste cruell men one day killed italian chyldren mother spare fledde temple goddes whiche punishment haue mithridates beyng vnfaythfull llyng murder banishment makyng diuisions landes releasing debtes libertie slaues putting tyrannes causing many robbery sea land experience may know comparison gouernour haue receyued reiected beginner thing haue bene partly punished v payne must publique haue done lyke may correspondent haue done romanes vse wicked murder sudden confiscation rising seruants barbarous thing minde abhorreth regarde shalbe nation name greece glorie asia freendes romanes honour sake wee put vpon tribute fiue yeares onely brought presently expences warre haue bestowed rest take order make diuision accordyng city declare frendship shall keepe order appoynt punishment enimies sylla sayde thus diuided payne embassadours sente mony city beyng poore oppressed debte let ferme theatre creditours common house wals porte thing publique without despite souldiours gathered money brought sylla asia inough euils full manifest robbery rather like army tha pirate mithridates long set sea wasted al thing long keepe beyng moste aboundant onelyinconueniences asia iassus ile ca troubling men sea spoyling porte townes city euidentlye iassus samos clazomene samothracia sylla taken temple samothracia robbed value thousand talent eyther willingly leauing punishe offendoures bycause sedition rome wente grecia thence italy army haue writte bookes ciuil dissentio second warre mithridates beganne occasionthe seconde vvarre vvith mithridates colchis next pontus murena l e sylla two legion fimbria shewed certayne formes warre desire triumph mithridates gone pontus made warre vpon colchians bosphoria colchians desired sonne mithridates might giuen king whome receyued obeyed mithridates killeth sonne forthwith king hauing sonne suspitio coueted whole kingdome sent held cheynes gold killed done muche good seruice asia fimbria bosphorians hee gathered gret army made great nauie mightinesse whiche preparation raysed opinion bosphorians romanes restored cappadocia ariobarzanes kepte parte styll archelous fleeth fro mithridates comana citie dedicate bellona murena cauilleth archelous suspition granted grecia needed sylla making peace archelous perceyuing fearing fledde murena whome incensed persuaded againste mithridates murena entered cappadocia comana greatest citie vnder mithridates hauing holy temple treasure killed certaine horseme mithridates embassador alleaged leage answered none sylla wright confirmed word left whe murena sard thys hee fell spoyle refrayning holy money wintered cappadocia mithridates sent rome senate sylla coplayne murenas doings time passed floud aly great deepe bicause raine calidius commeth rome vvith counter e commaundement spoiled mithridates townes king yet meeting loking embassador rome hauing got great bootie went phrigia cappadocia whither calidius came rome touching mithridates complayntes brought decree onely sayde vnto midst hearer senate comanded spare king confederate hadde said thus seene speake alone murenas ceassed inuasion still molested land king euidently perceyuing vsed enimie romanes bad gordius take nigh townes gathered many beastes cariage munition priuate men souldyours camped floud ouer agaynst murena neither began fight til mithridates came great army mighty fight floud mithridates murenas fleeth violence passed floud otherwise good murena fled king force strong hill hauyng lost many departed mountaynes withoute anye way phrigia followed oppressed victory euident quickly gotten soone spred abroade turned many mithridates putting murenas garrison euery place wt great speede make sacrifice iupiter warriour maner coutrey top hil wher make great pile wood king bring first stick theythe manner sacrifice king asia made mithridates victory make another lesse circle vpon higher put hony milke wine oyle kind perfume giue bread meate best present make pile fashio persian king sacrifice rarsardis greatnes euidently sene many thousand furlong one ca come nigh place many day aire hote sacrifice make custome hys countrey sylla cotent yt mithridates league haue war made vpo sent aulus gabinius comand murena molest mithridates agree mithridates refuseth mithridates gold ariobarzanes mithridates meeting making sure sonne ariobarzanes iiij yeares age meane holding still cappadocia getting feasted put gold cup meate iesters singer al vse gabinius touched none thus second war mithridates end thirde yeare quiet subdued bosphorus apointed son macharis king inuaded acheans aboue colchos seme fledde troy lost theyr way losing twoo partes hys armie fighte colde deceiptes returned sente rome haue league ratified ariobarzanes sente also eyther hymselfe stirred others hee receyued cappadocia mithridates kepte yet better parte hym sylla commaunded mithridates gyue place cappadocia hee sente embassadours cochieus came troy haue condition peace registred sylla dead senate assembled bycause vacation sent tigranes sonne law inuade cappadocia tigranes persuasio mithridates inuadeth cappadocia cautele vnknowen romanes armenian compassing cappadies neste ledde away three hundreth thousande men armenia made dwell place first toke crowne armenia hys name called tigranocertos whiche citie tigranes doyngs asia sertorius captayne spayne dyd stirre place romanes made senate counterfeyte romanes two faction mithridates sendeth sertorius lucius manius l fanius persuaded mithridates ioyne sertorius putting hope greate parte asia nation persuaded sent sertorius ledde embassadoures senate made glorious tale renoume spredde farre p ntus beseeged romanes west east couenanted giue mithridates asia bithinia paphlagonit cappadocia gallogrecia sent captayne marcius varius lucius manius l fanius counsel dyd mithridates begin thrid last war romanes lost al kingdome sertorius dead spayne general sent rome first lucullus admiral syllas nauie pompey vnder whome mithridates hadthe thirde vvarre vvith mithridates nigh floud euphrates pretence violence war mithridates fall romanes mithridates hauing proued oft romanes medimnus vvas measure contayned six modij modius contayned syxe sextures vvhych commonlye called bushell calybes people poute dig yron naked heniochi people ponius liuing theft thermodon thinking war made without cause sodaine would appeased made al preparation hee coulde try whole rest somer al winter made shippes armoure brought sea ij c medimnes grayne got confederate beside hys former power chalibyans armenian scythian taurians achuians heniochans leucosyrians inhabite floud thermodon called land amazones gotte asia going europe sarmatians basileans iazugeans coralleans al nation thracian inhabite aboute hister rodope aemos basternans valiaunt people hadde mithridates europa hadde gathered hundreth fortie thousande footemen sixteene thousande horseman another great number venturer piouers victualer spring come viewed nauy sacrificed mithridates souldiours iupiter warriour vsuall sacrifice neptunus cast sea chariot white horse wente paphlagonia taxilus eumocrates generalls come made solempne oration armye setting forth progenitor himselfe verye highly enlarged kingdome little great neuer ouercome romanes presente whome accused ambition vnsatiablenesse whiche said haue made italy countrey seruile repeated last condition whiche woulde subscribe seekyng tyme inuade againe making cause warre hee extolled power prouisio shewed romanes trouble molested spayne sertorius home italie ciuil warre therefore saide thorough negligence sea hathe long tyme beene full pyrates confederate haue none willingly auye wil vnder see noble men sayde hee shewing varius lucians enimies country friend v said thus stirred armye hee wente bythinia nicomedes beyng dead without chylde leauyng nicomedes leaueth kingdome romenes cotta fleeth kingdome romanes cotta presidet man litle skill warre fledde calchida power bithynia agayne vnder mithridates romanes fleeing cotta calchide mithridates comming thither cotta nudue commeth chalcide vvhere port coloyse lette dovvne many romanes stayne lacke experience came foorth nudus admirall part army tooke stronger parte fielde whiche beyng driuen hee fled gate chalcide many hedge great paine gate great thrust would get darte caste vayne folowed wherefore keeper beyng afrayde gate let barres fall tower tooke vp nudus capitaynes rope perishe betweene freendes enimies holdyng vp hads mithridates vsing course good fortune brought shippes day porte breakyng barre yron burned foure enimies shippes tooke three score neyther cotta nudus resistyng keepyng theelues within walles three thousand slayne romanes lucius manlius senatour mithridates loste twentie basternians first wente porte l lucullus beyng consull chosen generall warre lucullus generall brought one legion rome two fimbria beside two hauing thirtie thousand footemen sixtene hundred horseman encamped agaynst mithridates cyzico vnderstandyng fugitiues king three thousande men victual brought forager sea sayde aboute would take enimies without payne bad remember lucullus espieth aduauntage espied hill fitte campe might get forage keepe enimie entended get winne victorie without daunger beyng one way straight mithridates kepte strength taxiles capitaynes aduise lucius manius came fro sertorius made league mithridates sertorius dead reuolted secretly lucullus sayth beyng receyued perswaded mithridates lette romanes mithridates abused go campe would two legion fimbria would straight reuolt come kyng neede vse force slaughter might ouercome without fight mithridates consenting vnwisely vncircumspectly suffered romanes passe streight without feare encampe hyll hauyng whiche might haue victual behinde brought without feare mithridates beyng shut fennes hilles floudes could haue none lande litle neyther hauyng way easily force compell lucullus hardenesse passage whiche power hee neglected winter beyng hande commyng sea woulde fayle lucullus perteyued hee put freendes remembraunceerrours mithridates promise hee spake bee performed mithridates mighte peraduenture haue passed thorough middes hys enimies hys multitude hee lette passe also gaue himselfe onely gettyng cyzico thynkyng remedy bothe wante harde cyzico iland citie propontide great renovvne way hauyng plentie souldiours wente aboute meanes possible nauie hee enclosed double wall entrenched rest citie set vp many rampiers engine vpon tower rammes couered one called helepolis hundred cubites vpon helepolis engine beate vvall tower set casting arrowes stone diuerse weapon porte two gallies ioyned togither bare tower bridge caste engine nigh wall ready hee sente three prysoners cyzicus shippes citie holding vp hand praying spare people daunger till lisistratus lisistratus captaune came walles trumpette exhorted beare patiently mischaunce mithridites deceyued purpose hee brought engine shippes threwe sodenly bridge vpon wall foure men ranne vpon whiche cyzians amased straungers gaue place commyng forth tooke courage againe killed foure without threwe fire pitch vpon shippes made tourne theyr engine enterprise sea cyzians better day third time brought al engine lande within labouring putting backe violence rammes bet stone put collats brake dint peltes wooll thethe valiantnes cyzians fierie dartes quenched vineger water clothes cast sayles wrapped togither stopped throwe lefte nothing vndone menne might doe although suffered labour resisted euill yet night parte wall burned fell manne durste enter heate cyzianes made vp night long great storme wind breake reste king engine reade cittie dowrie iupiter proserpine cyziens honour hir god feast day came sacrifice blacke cowe hauing one made one paaste blacke cowe came sea whyche going vnder barre hauen ranne cittie camea sacrifice proserpina temple stoode aulter cyzians sacrificed good hope mithridates friendes counselled go cittie holy would went dindimus high hill made trench cittie set tower mine digged wall sente hys horse leane lacke meate lame labour bythinia lucullus mette wente rindacus killed toke many prisoner men fifteene horse sixe thousand many beast burden time eumachus captaine mithridates ranne ouer eumachus killeth romanes sau people asia lesse phrygia slewe romanes woman child inuaded pisidus isaur cilicia till one prince galatia deiotar u stopped course killed manye done phrygia winter come mithridates without victual wont come sea wherefore hys armye famyshed many dyed eate dead men barbarously eate hearbes sicke casting dead bodyes vnburyed broughte pestilence hunger mithridates continued hoping get citie engine dindymus ciziceans dindymus hill idea defeated purpose burned engine made many salyes vpon enimies feble hunger mithridates intended flee night shippes par armye wente land lampsaco came floud aesepus whiche growen high lucullus aesepus floud lesse nisia flovving hill ida set vpo passing killed many thus ciziceans escape greate preparation king owne manhoode helpe lucullus oppressed famine whiche cause make playes day whiche call lucullus playes mithridates conueyed lucullus playes away army come lampsa beseeged lucullus lampsatians also shippes sente committed tenne thousande best guided varius sente sertorius alexander paphlagonian dionisio eunuch sayled nicomedia winter weather destroyed many whe lucullus wrought feate lad famine gathered shippes asia betooke lieutenant triarius tooke apamea killed many fledde apamea coast bythinia temple barbas tooke prusiade builded vnder hill nicea garrison prusias called chius mithridates fleeing lucullus tooke enimies shippes thirteene porte achaia ouertoke varius alexander dionisius lemnus lennus novv statimene monument philoctetes desert ile alter philoctetes serpent brasse bowe brestplate tyed bendes seene shewe calamitie sayled vpon wyth great hast contempte remayning still sente forth two shyppes stayd rest prouoke come comming defendyng themselues land sayled ile shippes et footemen lande whiche made take shyppes woulde come aflote fearyng lucullus army lucullus ouercometh three captaynes mithridates sayling lande folowed lande sea hurte great slaughter flighte among varius alexander dionysius eunuche taken hidde caue whiche dionysius hauyng dronke poyson thought died lucullus comaunded varius killed seemely bring romane senatour triumph alexander kepte pompe lucullus wrote victorie letter wrapped laurell romanes manerletters laurell victory wente bythinia mithridates sayled pontus two tempestes mithridates hath losse sea ed ro er barke sinope vvas vniuersit e lost ten thousande men threescore shippes rest scattered winde droue owne shippe falling leake went rouers barke freends going rouers set safe sinope fro whence went amiso trie sonne law tigranes armenian machares sonne reyguing bosphoro hee sente bothe shoulde prouide helpe scythia diocles fleeth lucullus confines hee sente golde many giftes diocles fledde lucullus hys golde giftes lucullus goyng forwarde boldely victorie ouercame euery thyng wente winnyng wealthy countrey bene long without warre slaue solde foure drammes oxea dramme vvas romane penny goates sheepe garment al thing like value lucullus reged amison eupatoria whicheeupatoria mithridates buylded next amiso named eupatoria made king palace army besieged themiscyra name one amazones themiscyra region pontus dde thermodonta lying themiscyra sette vp tower made trench wrought great ne ightyng vnder grounde themiscyrians opened aboue threw beares wilde beastes swarmes bee vpon workemen amisus went way worke amisians defendyng themselues many imies issuyng prouokyng also fight hande hande mithridates sent much vi ual armure munition cabeiris wintered gathered army cabeira tovvne higher asia fotemen fortie thousande horseman foure thousand spring come lucullus wente king mountaynes whyche hadde garded keepe lucullus make continuall happe b man king bloud named phoenix chiefe gard lucullus approched made fire mithridates yeelded himselfe power lucullus without stoppe went cabeira hauing fighte horseman kyng lucullus ouercome one fight horseman pompey generall horse brought king aunsvvered boldly princely saying king ouercome retired hilles pompeyus captayne horseman taken broughte mithridates wounded asked thanke woulde giue saued answered thou art friend lucullus giue thee great thanke thou beest enimie deliber thus aunswered pompeyus barbarian woulde haue king haue killed king sayd would hurte vertue destitute fortune preparing continually fight lucullus refusing sought way come vpon hill certaine scythian named olcabas hadde bin long fugitiue lucullus bycause hadde saued many fight horseman hee admitted lucullus table priuie counsell secretes octauius fleeth lucullus came tent midde day rest would haue gone force girded short sworde manner angry kepte backe saying hadde earnest thing tell therefore woulde haue awake aunswering thatnothing good health ruler nothing good lucullus health tooke hys horse fledde mithridates eyther meaning euill suspected hys doyng anger compting himselfe dishonored accused another scythian called sobadacus woulde flee lucullus therefore sobadacus taken whereas lucullus woulde goe playne bycause enimies horseman better could see none way foud caue hunter wilde beastes expert vnknowen wayes whome passed secret wayes came vpo head mithridates came downe auoyding fieldes horseman encamped flash water enimyes face wanting victual sente cappadocia corne skirmished enimies made flee till king came camp hast amazed made themthe romanes great feare ac turne afrayd romanes fledde vp mountaynes perceyue enimies ceassed thoughte fledde enimies well chaced greatly made afrayde mithridates sent letter euery victory great part mithridates vvrighteth victory horseman best lay awaite brought victuall lucullus cappadocia hoping bring famine themselues cyzico great argument bycause lucullus cappadocia fro might shutte king horseman meetyng first forragers streight place would tarrie till came open place made horse streight vnprofitable vnto romanes therefore quickly order helpe place came forthe fighte killed king men holpen streyghte way fotemen droue vpon fellowes made flee heapes flong downe escapinga right romane forragers king horseman streight night ranne camp affirmed onely saued nature made losse greater mithridates lucullus shoulde knowe losse thinking lucullus lacke horseman woulde hauethe king feare sette vpon determined flee feare told friend tent warning giuen sente away theyr geare hastily night cariage made great thrustingthe king army fleeth togither gate whiche armye perceyuing knowwing caried coniecturing worse feare greeued token giuen brake vp trenche fledde aboute fielde confusedly euery man well coulde without captaynes staying warning mithridates hearde hasty disorderly doings ranne tent among would haue sayd somewhat man giuing eare hym beyng thrust flyo thruste people fall getting horse hee fledde mountaines lucullus vnderstading feate forager seeing flight enimies sent many horsmen follow bringing footemen cariera reste campe commaunded spoile kylled al seeyng vessel gold siluer costly garmentsthe souldiours lvvayes gyuen spoyle forgot commaundement taken mithridates chauced cut burden one mule bare golde falling buy let king go fledde comans thence mithridates fleeth tigranes vvho vvoulde see hym tigranes tenne thousande horse woulde see hym commaunded vse like king hys townes wherefore mithridates desperation kingdome sente bacchus eunuch palace kil sister wiuesthe king sedeth kil sister vvlues daughter concubine wer dispatched sword poyson halter pitifully capitaines mithridates garnisons sawe moste parte yeelded lucullus setting thing order sayled aboute citties pontus tooke armast heraclea sinope helde iustily sea fought valiantly while besteged burned great ship fled smala dreame lucullus saueth citie sinope antolycus vvas one liued lucullus lefte citye free againe reason dreame whych say antolycus didde make warre hercules againste amazones driuen tempest sinope tooke cittie ruled sinopeans hys image greate veneration whiche fledde wrapped linnen bound fast cary lucullus knowing nothing hauing hearde hee thought sawe hym call nexte daye commaunding carried image shewe hee saide see night dreame caused sinope bee still inhabited amysios also oute whyche fledde sca vnderstanding inhabited athenienses lord sea made populare state sometime obeyed sinope restored libertie persian king restored libertie alexander subiects againe king pontus taking pittie desirous honour example alexander athenienses nation hee lefte libertie wyth speede reuoked sinopeans owne cittie thus restored taking made league machare mithridates sonne king bosphorus offring crowne golde soughte mithridates tigranes come asia whyche dydde owe fourthe parte fruit sylla putte vppon payne hee tooke taxe house seruauntes made sacrifice victorye thoughe warre hadde beene fynished sacrifice ended marched two choise lucullus vvyth small armye greate king legion fiue hundred horse tigranes woulde deliuer mithridates passing euphrates requyring anlye money barbarian wente men made warre vpon thought good intermedle betweene tigranes lucullus man durste tell tigranes lucullus commyngtelli g truth euill revvarded tolde fyrste hanged one troubled hys city hearde sente mithrobarzines wyth twoo thousande horse stoppe lucullus course hee appointed mancaeo mancaeus keepeth chiefe cittie keepe tigranocerta whiche cittie haue sayde king builded owne honor whiche called noble appointed paine whosoeuer broughte hysthe defence tigranocerta goodes thither shoulde confiscate hee made wall aboute fifty cubites hyghe bottom whyche full stable horse suburbes hee hadde builded hys pallaice garden verye faire parkes fishepondes harde bee made strong forte whiche committing mancaeo rode aboute countrey togather men lucullus first conflict ouerthrewe mithrobarzane chased sextilius shut mancaeus tigranocerta spoylyng place without wall entrenched forte cittie broughte engine vndermined wall thus sextilius occupied tigranes gathering two hundred fyfty thousand footemen fyftye thousande horseman sent sixe thousande horse afore tigranocerta passing thoroughe romanes carried away kyngs concubine taken rest armie tigranes sente agaynste lucullus mithridates commyng fyrste hys sight counselled hym fyghte romaynes range hys horseman waste countrey driue famine coulde mean hee vsed lucullus cyzico loste hys feeble armye tiranes laugheth mithridates quicke saying tigranes tigranes laughed counsell came forth order battaile seeyng little number romanes sayde bee ambassador many ennimies bee fewe lucullus hadde perceiued fytte hill beyond tigranes lucullus vvinneth hill commaunded hys horseman giue charge front tourne giue place purpose bring army oute order meane tyme ledde footman hill perceyued sawe ennimye disordered runnyng partes thoughe hadde victorie carriage vnder hill cried haue gotte victorye fellowes firste hee sette vppon carriage fleeyng confusion ranne vppon footemen footemenne vppon horsemenne fowle fleeyng oute hande gone farre pursue romaynes killed tournyng vppon disordered carriage came driuen among al afflicted none knowing ye lucullus hath victorye truth ouerthrow began exceeding slaughter without anye spoile lucullus forbidde threat therfore treading vpon bracelet chaines continued murder hundred twenty furlogs til night came vpon returne spoyled lucullus contente victorie manceus lefte tigranocerta vnarmedthe valiantnes greeke souldiors al greeke mercenarie souldiours suspected fearing taken got staues went togither wer quiet manceus came vpon barbarian armed wrapped cloakes aboute theyr armes stead tergales courage fought euer killed kepte armoure diuided thought got sufficient tooke little tent called romanes receyued thus tigranocerta taken spoyled verye riche new builded inhabited moste honorably tigranes mithridates went gathering another army whyche made mithridates generall thynkyng fytte beeyng taught owne loss hee sente also parthian requiring aide lucullus sent ambassador also requiring kyng eyther toa policie parthian king help medle either secretly promised performed none mithridates gathered armour euerye cittie manner armenian campe whyche hee chose threescore tenne thousande footemen halfe horseman lette go diuided band company italian discipline tooke trayned men pontus lucullus comming towarde mithridates helde footemen halfe horseman vpon hill reste horseman tigranes ledde meeting wyth romaine forager ouercome whiche romanes foraged safely euen place next mithridates encamped raysyng muche duste perceyued tigranes came whose purpose haue shutte lucullus middst perceyued sent best horseman encounter tigranes farre coulde compell leaue raungyng keepe campe prouoked mithridates fight encamped tigranes amd mithridates flyelli could moue tyl famme oppressed disolued al purpose tigranes went furthest parte armenia mithridates ponius rest hys owne army hauyng foure thousand many tigranes lucullus folowed driuen also want mithridates outgoing mette mithridates ouer throvveth fabrus fabio lefte lucullus ouerthrew hym killing fiue hundred fabio taking fresh seruauntes fabius ouerthrovveth mithridates vvhich sore hurt campe foughte againe whole day fighte doubtfull till mithridates hurt knee stone vnder eye darte caried away speed many dayes one refrayned fight feare king health multitude hurte agarians nation scythia cure mithridates vsing agarenes king plusitions poyson serpent medicine cause euer king fabius came triarius another captaine lucullus owne army receyued power authoritie fabio long mithridates comminga maruelous vvinde breaketh fight fight winde neuer felt tore tentes beate beastes abroade stroke downe men thus went backe told triarius hast ouerthrovve lucullus comming triarius desirous fight came set vpon former watch night fight equall king wing got better dispersed enimies driuing footemen foule mire wera romaine captaine like seruant vvoudeth king killed bycause could stirre horseman sent chased playne vsing valiauntlye brunt victorie til captaine romane band running seruant gaue great wounde thyghe bycause thought hee could strike harnesse backe next streight killed mithridates carried hinder part king frends caused retreat blowe soldiours hauing manifest victorie folowing egrely bycause straunge called wer much troubled feare leaste inconuenience badde ene timotheus king phisition stopped wound shewed king vnto aboue come thethe kyng shevved souldiours field stoode thronging aboute bodye euen alexander india macedonian afrayde shewed selfe cured shyppe mithridates came hymself blamed caused fight ende daye ledthe romaynes forsake campe great number romayne captaines flaine army romaynes campe fled fearfully whe dead spoiled found xxiiij tribune cl centurians number captain seldome hath bin found slaine romaine army mithridates went armenia romaynes call armenia lesse taking victuall coulde carried could burned lucullus whome thoughte follow hym shold haue none romane senator named attilius fled attilius killed suspition countrey bicause condemned great credite fauor mithridates taken one would betray bicause senator king would put torture killed cousell tormented cruelly free made men suffred al departe vnhurt bicause maisters comandement lucullus encamped nigh mithridates lieutenat asia sent proclamed army romaynesdi entio vvyth romaynes accused lucullus bicause made war longer oughte army shold go hym didde obey haue goodes confiscate whiche beeing tolde armye went al away saue fewe poore fearing lucullus lefte alone paine tarried stil lucullus thus war betweene lucullus mithridates surely ended finished broke vp italy rebelled molested sea full theeues famine oppressed thinke good take another great warre hande till deliuered incommodities mithridates heard went cappadocia fortified kingdome romanes winking hys doings till scoured sea whiche done pompey worker asia war mithridates began againe pompey sent general therfore bicause act pompey sea hee came againste mithridates parte pompeis feat put none proper writing shortely repeate run euer mithridates made mithridates filleth sea vvith pyrats first war againste romanes ruled asia sylla busied grecia thinking long holde asia spoyled euery place haue saide set pirats sea whiche first fewe litle boat vexed met war grew gotten great ship taking great gaine ceasse though mithridates ouercome made truce fled loste liuyngs country thorow war fallen extreame pouertie left land sought commoditie sea first brigandine foists little galley roued archpirats leader general army vnwalled citties spoiled walledthe myshappes rouers vndermined beate downe got siege destroyed best men brought sea raunsoms auoide infamy rauine called themselues hyred souldiours stead searouers hadde workemen chaines businesse carying matter woode brasse yron neuerrested prowde gaine thinking leaue piracie thought lyke king tirans gret general supposed gathered togither shold vncoquerable made ship kind armor specially aboute cilicia called hard made common receptacle vsed campe hauing cilicia full rockes mountaynes coaste cilices vvere compted rouer manye fort tower voyde ilands shipping euery place chiefe trade cilicia harde beyng without port ful great hill common name called cilices whych euill begunthere hard part cilicia brought vnto syrian cyprian pamphilians ponticans almost al nation east whiche time mithridates war rather choosing suffer vsed sea lad short space many thousads lord east sea within pillours hercules ouercome romane admiral seafight sicelie sicilia durst saile land wanted labourer bycause robbery cittie rome found inconuenience moste subiectes want great multitude grieuous famine matter seemed great harde vnto dispatch many army men shippes diuided whole circle lande sea easie flee prouision set vpon country euident place hauing house propertie al euer came hande consideration warre farre beyond rest hauing certentie suretie euidece wrought doubt fear murenas sent nothing seruilius isauricus aftermurenas serui murena nowe come coaste italy rouers bragge brunduse tosc ne taken noble woman two army ensignes therfore romanes longer suffering losse shame choose law pompey chosen admirall pyrates pompey man great fame chiefe admirall three yeares al sea within pillours hercules foure hundred furlong lad sea sent al king prince citties helpe pompey thing gaue aucthoritie gather army money sent also great army owne ordinarie many shippes sixe talent athens great difficult thing thinke ouercome many army great sea lurking many hole easily fleeing safely appearing againe sodain neuer man set power pompey army giuen cxx thousande footemen sixe thousande horseman shippes smal vessel two hundred lxx minister whiche senate call legats xxv whome pompey deuided sea gaue shippes horse footemen ensignes war euerie man absolute ruler parte committed king king went see kepte order appointed neyther woulde haue chased carried one another without profitte meete mighte serue one anothers turne shut vp within compassesthe maner appo mets pompey hauing thus ordered appointed tiberius nero spaine pillers hercules manlius torquatus marcus p cyprus phoenitia thus hee appointed captaines make course onset keepe place receiue fledde chase exceed far bethe diligence pompey caried aboute fighting mighte speedily done sayled hauing ouerseene weast fortie dayes came rome thence brunduse brunduse east long way afrayde sodayne quicke passage great preparation feare glory insomuche pirate hoped haue bin good truely haue put paine ynoughe beyng afraid left expugnations city resorted wonted holdes hole sea scowred pompey without fight rouers taken captaines euery place part wente cilicia great army many engins thinking haue hadde manye fyghtes besieging rocky tower needed none glory greate power makingthe pira gyue ouer afrayde thinking came fyght shoulde finde gentlenesse fyrst deliuered cragus cragus anticragus hilles lycia parte taurus anticragus greatest fort mountaine men cilicia order yeelded themselues also muche armour ready made readye deliuered shippes vpon stock apte sayle brasse yron gathered purpose sailes cable diuerse matter number prisoner band ransome worke stuffe pompey burned ship toke prisoner sente theyr countreys manye founde gra made bycausemany restored beyond hope thought dead pirate seemed come warre malice lacke liuing hee commaunded inhabite mall dana epipha anythe pirate appoynted inhabite hard place coast cilicia place desolate voyde men hard parte cilicia sent yma hai thus pyrats warre thought daungerous ended dayes pompey shippes tooke xij deliuered three hundred sixe city fortes strong place pirate slayne fighte thing done speedely beyonde opinion romanes highly extolling pompey yet cilicia generall warre mithridates like authoritie ruler alone would inuade make warre make friend foe r whome thought good armye italy gaue authoritiethe large commission pompey whiche neuer giuen none peraduenture called great warre mithridates ended captaynes pompey gathering hys armye asia dyd encamp confynes mithridates mithridates hadde choyce army hys owne thirtie thousande footemen three thousande horseman defended place whiche wasted lucullus want victuall wherfore many fugitiues wet threwe downe headlongs pulled eye burned therefore fewer fugitiues wet fro feare punishmet co umed want therfore sent embassador pompey knowe condition might make peace answered thouansvvere pompey mithridates deliuer fugitiues commit thy selfe v mithridates heard asked fugitiues thought whe saw afraid sware would neuer make peace romanes couetousnesse deliuered none nothing pryuye thus didde pompey laying ambushe horseman bad go front king battaile prouoke came foorth gyue place thoughe ouercome andfight horseman bryng place ambushe whyche retournyng mighte gette kynges campe fledde whyche hadde beene done deede king fearyng hadde broughte oute hys footemen retired thys ende fyrste attempt horseman betweene pompey mithridates king molested want compelled go backe suffer pompey come parte thinking wasted place shoulde suffer many inconueniences prouided victuall come behind hym going eastwarde againste mithridates made many tower trench againste compassed space fyue hundred furlong coulde nowe easilye come victualls king stoppe entrenching eyther feare ignorance euils nowe come vppon oppressed againe wyth want kylled beast cariages onelye horse spared whiche scarcelyethe king fle th seruing fyfety dayes night departed great silence harde wayes whome pompey coulde hardly ouertake day sauing tayle king counseled friend set hys men battell would fight horsmen onlye keepe backe approched night hyd himselfe thicke woodes day folowing tooke rocky place one way come kepte foure handes romanes kept contrary side shold escape next daye eyther armed men forewarders either part side hyll skirmished horsmen king commanded help fellow without horse vpon whe romanes came horsmen king ran heap cap get horse match romanes gallye aboue armed seeing come running showt knowing done thinking theya discom iture vpon errour hadde fledde another way campe taken threwe awaye armoure fled place hard one fell vpon thruste til fell rock thus army mithridates thorow lacke woulde without order take vpon helpe former selowes falling consusion loste reste matter easy p mpey killing taking vnarmed beeyng shut rockes tenne thousand slain campe treasure gold taken mithrdites guarde onely fleeing thoroughe rocky place met hyred horseman three thousande footemen conducted hym sinoregia castle laid vppe muche money giuing gyfts yeares wage companion flight carried sixe thousan e talent wente fountaines euphrates minding goe thence colchos vsing continuum l speed passed euphrates fourth day tarrying three dayes tooke came wet chotena armenia ouerthrowing cotenians iberian kepte hym sling dart wente floude apsares hiberians asia say progenitor hiberians rmenia spaine posteritie hiberians europe say onely one n maner tongue nothing like mithridates wintred dioscuride citie cholcide citie c hide vvhere sometyme occupved three h n red n ons dyuers language thinke bee monument trauaile castor argonants thought yet flee ng conceyued litle matter mynde go aboute pontus circle hians beyond pont fenne meot attemp b sphorus take kingdome machares sonne vnprofytable make open warre againste romanes begin euro e beeing asia put porus middest whiche thinke called bespheros swimming ouer made cowe andporus fled elousie iuno thus muche beyonde reason didde mithridates thinke bring passe passed seythian nation enimies otherwise eyther perswasion violence thus fleing miserye honoured seared p iochians receyuing achaean wold haue resisted hym put flight saide came fro hain troy p ntus beyng driuen tempest suffered muche barbarian bycause grecian sent countrey shippes demed hated greekes ythians sacrificed many greekes asa acri ice men came fyrste anger fairest onely laste whome fell lotte thus muche acheans ythians mith idates comming meotis many prince receiued sent glorye hys actes kingdome power yet worthy hanored bringing many gift sending others made lignage thinking straunge frat go thracia macedonia macedonia pannonia italy mountain alpes made marriage daughter mightiest confederateurs sonne machares hearde come gret way little time thorowe many fierce nation place called lock ythia man gone hee sent certaine ambassador vnto excuse hym necessitie obeyed romanes sawe anger extreame fledde ponto cherron burning shippes hys father shoulde folow llowed hym flee ng farre cholcos thinking good follow passe aboute pontus fenne meot supposing case woulde attempt great matter went cholcos see historie argonante castor p lux iourney hercules vvere arabia ar bians called nabathei areta king jesues yt olted fro king aristobulus toke hierus lem pompey take holy city rest cilicia subiect rome parte syria aboute euphrates called caele ph nice thought taken tigranes put antiochus might wel iudged people rome while aboute matter ambas adors came vnto phraates tigranes warre came tigranes desired helpe fryende came phraates desired receyued amitie romaine pompey minding make war vppon parthian without decrae senate sent arbitrers reconcile thus mithridates nowe gone pontus hauing taken pa ticup citie sphorus eris mithridates kyll th sonne p ticup chiefe cittie marchandise europ entrie pontus killed hys sonne phares p hys mother faulte whiche mithridates castle whiche hidde vnder grounde brasen vessel bounde yron muche treasure secretely stratonice one mithridates wiues woman whyche gouernement keeping castel while mithridates went pontus deliuered castle pompey reuealed treasure vnknowne onely wyth condition pompey tooke hir sonne phares saue hauing money promised saue hir sonne gaue hir leaue carie awaye hir owne thing mithridates knew done killed siph re narrowe sea threw hys b ye vnburyed hys mother yng shoare th killed childe reuenged mother sent ambassador pompey syria hearyng whither aliue dead hee might enioy father kingdom pay tribute romaine pompey bad h come speake himselfe tigranes done saide woulde neuer doe mithridates h woulde sende child friendes thus sayd withall gathered army togither free bond bringing much armour shot munition sparing man wodde labouring oxe make string ette tax vpon euery man though small substance collector whereof much spight knew sick face bile healed eunuch mithridates sick ace sen whole army gathered threescore choyce bandes sixe hundred company another great multitude shippes place captaynes got whilest sicke sent part army phanagorea whiche another mart towne mouth mighte haue entry side pompey yet syria castor phanagorea b yng iniured triphon eunuch king killed triphon asa mutenie phanagorea entred called people libertie bycause castell holden artaphernes sonnes king bring woodde burned tower whyche feare artaphernes darius xerxes ozethres eupatra mithridates child gaue themselues taken artaphernes king child taken fortie yeares olde faire yong men another daughter mithridates called cleopatra tarried still whome father louing hir noble heart sent diuers foystes toke hir away castels lately taken mithridates following b ldnesse phanagoreans reuolted mithridates xerronesus dosia city reuolte nymph fitte warre aboute pontus seeing many reuoltings hauing army suspition faithfull compelled serue necessitie great tribute infidelitie army always toward generalles miserie sent daughter eunuch married prince scythia requyring army sente speede sending fiue hundreth souldyoures farre mithridates killed eunuch bycause euer iniured ofthe king eanuchs killed eunuch might mithridates led maydes pompey mithridates spoyled many childre castle whole kingdome fitte nowe make battell loking anye helpe scythian yet conceyuing small matter one calamitie sent frenchman whome hadde made friend long intending go inuade italy thynking many italy weery romanes hearing anniball began warre spayne fearefull romanes knew late almost italy rebelled rome kepte long warre sparta swordplayer stirred vp man regard opinion marched toward france bold enterprise army disappoynted content great boldnesse long iourney ledde strange countrey men could ouercome owne countrey thinking mithridates despaire thing would labour like king end life rather rest yet abode quiet smal king contemned euen aduersitie standing thus pharnaces deere al sonnes p arnaces king sonne whome many time declared successour kingdome eyther feare kingdome army yet like obteyne pardon romanes father shoulde make warre italy like lose heritage either cause reason desire laide wayte father conspiratoures taken put racke menophanes persuaded mithridates kyll sonne sa ce much esteemed voyage sayde suche mutation happe warre whyche beeyng ceassed stayed also persuaded granted pardon sonne fearing remembrance knowing army weery iourney nighte went fugitiues rome serued next father shewed daunger shoulde wente italy whiche euidently sawe andthe army reuolteth king practise e promising many benefites woulde tarrie brought rebell father persuaded pharnaces sente next army also onsenting fugitiues firste departed morning forso ke king euer nexte made great shoute nauie aunswered beeing alike disposed peraduenture readye mutation despising aduersitie alwayes hoping forprinces calamitie better euery change ignorat done thinking corrupted alone despised part feare necessitie rather good agreed theyr purpose mithridates stirred crye sente knowe meante theyr crye dissembling sayde required sonne reigne father yong man olde ruled eunuch killed many child captaynes friend whiche mithridates hearde came forthe say somewhat euen number gard fledde fugitiues sayde would accept vnlesse notable feate withall shewed mithridates killed horse nowthe king horse killed gard crovvne paper stead golde obteyning purpose saluted pharnaces king one brought broade paper temple crowned hym stead diademe whiche mithridates see aboue sente one another pharnaces requyre safe flighte man sent returning fearing least giuen romanes praysing gar friend yet tarried sent new king armye killed without anye cause takyng hys sworde poyson e dyd carrie aboute hym tempered two hys daughter named mithridates tvvo king daughter die constantly poyson vvould vvorke king bycause vsed dayly medicine poyson vvhich hys e called rida n ssa espoused kyngs gipe cypre broughte vppe wyth hym desyred myghte take poyson fyrste verye instante woulde lette hym drynke tyll hadde taken potion soone dispatched woulde worke vppon mithridates hymselfe though hee walked fast purpose bycause hee vsed eate medicine whyche hee tooke euer agaynste violence poyson whyche medicine day cleopatra captaynes confederate followed chariote horse foote come capitoli killed none prisoner triumphes done sent countreys common expences except king aristobulus streight killed shortly tigranes triumph pharnace beseeged phanagorea borderours bosphorus pharnaces maketh vvarre till phanagoreans driuen famine came forthe foughte ouercome whome hurt none tooke pledge went way long toke sinope hill scotio father ouercame trian ouercome fledde sinope thousand horseman caesar hauing leysure follow sente domitius whome deliuered citie vppon condition peace went away horseman whose horse killed much greeued conueyed shippe fledde pontus gathering ythians sauromatians tooke theudocia panticapaea old aduersarie asandro comming againe vpon horseman wantyng horse vsed fight foote ouercome pharn ce alone fighting valiauntlye till hee wounded died pharnaces slaine priuie fiftye yeares olde x yeares king bosphorus pharnaces loste kingdome whiche c caesar gaue mithridates pergamo holpen hym well aegipt nowe free pontus bythinia president sent euery yeare coutries pompey giuen although caesar blamedspiritual office comagene taking pompey parte yet let haue sauing spiritual office comagene translated archelous nicomedes long bothe c caesar antonius gaue wer made prouinces romaynes augustus caesar hadde w e aegipt romaine taking lighte occasion againste euery man therfore dominion encreasyng thys warre mithridates pontus euxinus sandes aegipt floude euphrates hiberians pillers hercules maye wel called greate victorie pompey captaine euen haue also affrica sirene appion king
