hercules north ocean towarde weast iberia compassed sea except mou taines pyrene greatest highest hilles europe nation make nauigation compasse come pillers hercules doe go winter weast ocean passe brittayne whyche doe brittayne novve englande commoditie tydes going comming passage made sayling halfe day place ocean neyther romanes themselues none empire haue passed therefore greatnesse iberia called spayne confedered one prouince almost incredible spayne great region ight furlong maketh mile brea th terme thousand furlong length muche manye nation inhabite diuers name many nauigable flouds people inhabite first got suche matter minded shew much may apperteyne romanes saye suppose celtes passed pyrenian hilles aud dwelled among inhabitant countrey whiche manifest name celtiberians came phoenitians long sayling often thither thinke inhabite part likewise grecian sayled tartessus arganthonius king tartessus novv taressa germania arganthonius lyued hundred fifty yeares stay iberia suppose arganthonius reigned spayne tartessus whiche citie sea coast nowe named carptesse beleeue temple hercules builded iphenia place calledthere vvere diuers hercules vvhereof one vvas tirus borne leria another th be borne al umena pillers whiche day ceremony vsed manner phoeni ians borne tirus borne thebe counted god countrey leaue haue care search antiquity coast plentifull rich carthagies deuised get romanes subdued one parte vexed continuall inuasions till romanes put possessed al place townes ward came empire muche labour long time whiche reuolting diuers time againe su ued romanes diuided region three part sent many president got euery place warre kepte carthagies iberian celtiberians shew volume romanes firste made warre carthagies first vvarre carthage fo si l bycause warre made spayne must nedes shew historie whiche wright spayne cause haue comprehended booke warre sicelie doe betweene romanes carthagies islande romanes sayled sicelie subdue place first warre carthagies sicelie dominion island second spayne possession whiche tyme eyther inuaded others land wyth greate armyes nauie carthagies destroying italy romanes li ya warre beganne aboute c l olimpiad thethe olde compt yeares vvas olimpiades vvhich vvere playes made euery fiue yeares honour piter institute hercules olimpia citie lide amilchar carthagies broken truce made warre sicelie cause whereof amilchar surnamed barcha promised great reward celtes libyan sicelie whiche rewardes required amilchar come carthage cause warre affrike whiche carthagies suffered muche hurte delyuered sardinia romanes iniurie done romane merchantes warre cause amilchar barcha accused ofin first vvar vv care th gy contrary faction whome came greate detriment citie fauoure gouerned common wealthe whereof h sdruball called greate oneh sdruball whome giuen daughter marriage well beloued people pardoned also chosen captayne togither hanno called great againsthanno numidian accusation yet depending whyche amilchar muste gyue accompte doyngs warre warre numidia ended hanno called ca thage certayne complayntes amilchar remayned captayne army alone hauing wyth hym asdr hys sonne lawe wyth thys armye sayled g de novve cale bee evvo land thest part ra next stre ghte lla ar molest iberian spoyling theyr lande hadde deserued anye thing soughte occasion absente hys countrey making warre wynne fauour people deuiding pray gaue parte souldyoures parte hee sente carthage parte gaue chiefe citie fauoured hym whilest dyd thus certayne greate men others iberia conspired togither kylled hym thus sent certayne carte laden wyth wodde whyche followed wyth armoure thys carthagies laughedstratageme iberian fyrste perceyuing policie perceyued fygh e begunne iberian selte carte fyre whereby ox dryuen vpen numidian fire dispersed euery ox ra e hyther thyther muche disordered affi cane brake aray whereby iberian came vppon amilchar yne kylled amilchar barcha rest fought carthagies beeyng allured pray iberia sente another arm asdruball barchas sonne law andasdruball committed rule army ioyned anniball sonne barcha lieutenant wiues brother got great name valiant actes yong expert warre accepted souldyoures wanne manye place iberia fayre wordes verye apte persuade thing done force vse seruice yong man thys meane wente ouer spayne identall sea floud iberus made sub ect carthagies empire iberus sea c sag nt vvas cyond iberus novve nomen ro iland ioman sea floud diuiding spayne middest floweth oc n towarde north fiue dayes iourney mountaines saguntines olde inhabitance zathintians middest betweene mountaynes floud come greekes aboute place called emporio inhabited part ibe afrayd sent four embassador rome wherfore romanes willing power carthagies growe much sent embassador c thage agreed iberus end carthagies dominion spaine andthe coad tie romanes make warre vpon subiects beyoude floud carthagies g beyonde floud moue warre saguntines greeke people iberia shoulde free liue owne lawes whiche expressed league made betweene romanes carthagies done slaue killed asdruball whose maister cruelly kylled asdruball killed whilest taking order parte iberia obeyed carthage gone hunting whome ann ball tormented cruelly kylled army made anniball barcha captayne yong man welbeloued enimies amilchar barcha senate carthage agreed fearing power asdruball amilchar laughe anniball rong man beganne molest lawe friendes accusing aults accused deade vsing people fauour whiche hated loss tyme barcha asdruball required gift barcha anniball sent spople ennimies sent anniball helpe hewing also would despised father ennimies except hee hadde nowe regard might defene matter vnknowne anniball knew well ynough beginning deceyts would vppon thought good suffer suche enmity continuallye seare father grandfather done liue lyfe lightenesse carthagies v ng vnthanke fullye syde hadde doone well common wealth rumor anniball childe hys anniball vvas vv ne hys youth bee n ye romaine father commandement brought hym place hee made sacrifice made hym laye hand vppon altare sweare soone rule common wealth shoulde bee mortall ennimie romanes therfore purposed put country great continuall danger feare might preserue hys friend matter per therfore saw aff ca good state iberian vnder carthagies lyke continue obedience thoughte shoulde winne unmortall fame made warre agayne vppon romanes feare whereof carthagies shoulde occupied mighte good fortune suboue hys countrey empire worlde hee hoped romanes broughte downe none shoulde able matche wyth hym cha nced otherwise yet hys enterprise shoulde honorable beginning myght breede estimation pasied floude iber caused torboletanes whych nexte saguntines anniball pic th ua el g te come comylaine saguntines made r de vpo one hurt pers aded set theyr ambassador carthage wrote letter priuilye whiche signified romanes practised iberian carthage iurisdiction reuolte saguntines didde procure romaynes deceit left vndone wrote many letter till senate appointed saguntines shoulde profitable common wealth hee haning got occasion practised torboletans agayn come complaine againe saguntines also sent fifteene ambassadoures hym anniball wylied declare controuersies anu ered woulde make romanes judge commanded anniball go hys campe night passing ryuer inuaded lande set hys artillerie agaynst sagunt besteged citie could take compassed ditche wall trench placing many garrison continued siege fewe dayes wente came dyuerse tymes saguntines great feare sodaine euils sent ambassadours rome whome senate ioyned ambassadoures sent firste anniball putthe romaine ambassadoures forbidden ter anniballs campe remembraunce league would obey shoulde go carthage aceuse hym wyth ambassadoures went iberia came shyppes campe commanded anniball go surther wherefore went carthage wyth saguntine ambassador ed league broken side accused saguntines saide done hurte subiectes saguntines contrary side called iudgement romanes sayde iudgement vame matter muste bee tryed force whiche romaine vnderstoode thought ayde bee sente hand saguntines denyed affyrmyng saguntines comprehended league butthe romaynes helpe saguntines lefte free bothe be gers besieged muste vse lawes whiche sentence pr ua ed saguntines destitute help romanes oppressed famine continuallye assaulted annibal hearing cittie riche full golde gaue time rest commaunded golde siluer publique priuate broughte market mixed lead yron shoulde bee vnprofitable annibal bycause hadde rather dye sworde hunger mydnyght darke came assailed watch carthagies looking thing killed many while sought putte armour sight long many carthagies slaine saguntines whose decay beyng seene wals woman leapt top house hanged themselues killed first little childre themselues end sagunt great mighty city annibal vnderstoode cone mony tooke many youth left tormented annibal nameth sagunt carthage spart gena killed thinking good citie situate sea fertile soyle vnhabited made inhabitation carthage whiche nowe thinke call carthage spart gena romaine sent ambassadours carthage whiche shoulde require annibal breaker league vnlesse wold confesse done ye common consent except theythe manner romaine de ance carthage wold deliuer hym denounce war presently dyd carthagies would deliuer annibal gaue desyaunce saide done sorte carthage scorned romane ambassador hee tooke vppe irt gawne saide garment carthagies bring war peace chose wil aunswered giue v thou listest giuing war cried al one voice receiue sent hannibal ouerrun al iberia league broken wherfore raunging euerye got flattery threat force gathered many souldioures shewyng purpose didde hys meaning goe italy sende ambassador galles search way alp carry army rome leaue asdrubal spaine romaynes thinking must make war carthagies spaine affrica suspecting comming italy sente tiberius affrica one hundred threescore twoo ship two longue generalles didde labya shewen booke libyan warres sente scipio threescore shyppes ten thousande temen seauen hundred horseman whome ioyned brother c cornelius scipio one heard marchants anniball comming italy passed alpes ra shoulde haue taken italian vnp c ted deliuered army hys brother galley sayled captaynes succeeded hym thys war tyll anniball driuen italy sixteene yeares shewed v booke followeth wherein also wee shewe annibals actes therefore name booke annibals name cneus warre romanes didde nothing worthy wrytyng till brother retourned vnto hym hys tyme expired romanes sent consulls hys successor make warre againste anniball hee vnderconsull sent againe spaine twoo scipio didde make warre agaynste asdruball spaine carthagies prouoked fight syphax kyng numidia called home asdrubal wt part armye wherby scipio easily gette reste spaine mayne citties yeelded freely apte gouerne armyes also persuasion winne city obedience carthagies compounding syphax sente asdruball spaine wyth menne wyth thyrtye elephantes adioyning two captaines mago asdrubal gysgons sonnes tyme scipio sharpe warre yet superior whiche manye souldiours carthagies elephant consumed till winter beyng come carthagies went winter turditanes pub scipio stayed ca ulone cncus orsonae shewed pub scipio killed asdrubal comming went citie wyth fewe see enimies power going far vnaduisedlye circumuented contrary horseman killed al cneus scipio knowing chaunce hys brother sent hys souldiors fetche artillerie wyth killed affricanes made fraye whiche cneus vnderstanding came foorth haste light harnessed helpe hys men wherof former killed putte backe scipio driuen tower whiche sette fyre burned hym hys companye thus two scipio killed men certainly great worthinesse greatly loued lamented spaniard committed themselues sake romaine obedience knowen rome romanes tooke grieuously sent marcellus little come sicilie claudius wyth nauy ten thousande footemen two thousand horseman mony victuall sufficient make warre spaine whiche notable thing done carthagies encreased much nowe wellnigh gotten spaine romaynes beeing dryuen little streight caste pyrene hils whiche rome hearde grieued afraide least while anniball wasted region whiche side italie army shoulde inuade another way therfore thoughe woulde neuer muche coulde leaue spaine fearing warre spaine woulde stretch italy therefore appointed day determine generall war spaine whiche prouince none nowe offered hymselfe trouble feare senator still feare till cornelius scipio sonne publius carnelius scipio offereth seruice time feare slaine spaine yong man xxiiij yeres age wise accompted noble mind step forth boldly spake lamentably harde happe hys father vncle affirming alone left reuenge death thing added great eloquence vehemenete bythe diuine inflamation promised restore onely spaine also take carthage wherefore thoughte boaste muche lyke young man got fauoure people whiche stroken greate feare eare better hope promised comforted spayne decreed vnto hym foresyght would thing worthy noblenesse hys mynd antients call greatnesse minde rashnesse rather courage scipio perceyued spake people sorte spake adding youth impedunent man exhorted eldersthe modestle scipio take prouince woulde willingly gaue place whe man found take went estimation admiration men prouince whiche hee led footemen fiue hundred horseman annibal vexing italie greater number could spared mony wage furniture eighteene galleis wyth hee sayled spaine reteining footemen horseman left putte mustered purged whole army spake nobly hys fame wente shortelye ouer spaine whiche wearye carthagies rule vertue scipians stucke mindes thought house scipio sent god whiche thyng scipio vnderstanding pretended thing diuine instigation vnderstoode hys enimies lodged foure sundrye place euery campe fiue twenty thousande footemen two thousande horse al mony munition well sea land also captiues pledge spaine cittie beefore called sagunt nowe named carthage mago keep treasure x thought good make st attempt moued small number great abundance seate cittie forte receipte warre sea land spaine shorter passage liby considerationsthe diligence scipio conferring wyth man marched sunne set riding night toward carthage daye made ditche tre che carthagies amazed daye prepared giue assaulte sette engins scale scipio besiegeth nevve carthag al part one wall lowe compassed poole sea wherefore place negligently kepte souldiors made strong yt night arrowes stone scipio tooke streightes porte enimies ship escape hee trusting vertue haped take citie day commanded part souldiors mount engine throwe vpon enimies aboue run engine wall lawe sorce side mago placed r men gate taking occasion sally sword bicause streights thei could vse spear comaunded keepe wals tower engine stone dart arrow boldlye abyd nght alarm made part omitted endeuor while stone arrow cast hand engine vsed sling euerym n best kinde armoure coulde handle band scipio hardly handled carthagies kept gate issued sword made hotte fray brought engine much hurt tooke till romaynes whose courage encreaseth p ril made retire defended wall ed fought without sl ng romaynes mighte ea e sette engine wall agaynst hadde skirmished wente vppe wall againe r ne putte fighte scipio looked aboute exhorted place perceiued toward south ye place wall low ye water fall fro according course sea ye breast legge whiche thing perceyued matter diligently examined spent rest day sea encrease going aboute encouraging souldyoures doe souldyoures sayde nowe time whilest help god commeth v scale wall side sea openeth way vnto v goe saying thus toke ladder first beganne mount ga others staying souldyoures takyng matter hand romanes got vp whome perceyued vpon certayne tower badde trumpetours drummes goe vp wall encourage romanes wyth noyse thing affraying enimie fledde citie bin taken romanes fought seme ranne opened gate scipio entred army nevv carthag taken mago yeeldeth citie fledde house place mago broughte souldyoures market place whiche beeyng soone ouercome fledde castell scipio assaulted able defend men vtterly discouraged yeelded scipio greate citie beyng taken one day fourth day comming extolled infinite prayse men beleeuing thing rather councell god menan opinion scipio thing inspiration god persuaded himselfe opinion mainteyned life taking beginning time cause hee woulde many time goe alone capitoll shutte dores taught god wherefore day scipio image broughte capitoll whereas others taken common place scipio hauing taken citie whiche shoulde receptacle storehouse thing warre peace whiche greate plentie armoure shotte engine furniture name thirtie three shippes corne manye thing layde vp common market beside rie golde siluer well coyned vncoyned pledge spayne captiues rome made sacrifice god ye next day triumphed praysed souldyoures hee turned tale townesmen renuing memorie scipio deliuering bondage w e came countreys mighte winne hym thing thus done rewarded liberallyrevvards romanes firste mounted vvall grounde golde vvas giuen firste mounted wall seconde gaue halfe much third others like proportion yuorie gold siluer left pray put shippes sent rome three dayes togither holy dayes made bycause seemed citie restored auntiente dignitie manye euils spayne carthagineans astonished great acte done valiantly speedely scipio leauing strong garrison citie commaunded parte wall next fenne made higher went subdue rest hiberia going himselfe sending frieds taking force resisted carthagies captaynes asdrubals one sonne ilcare hauyng army stranger furthest part spayne sonne gisgo exhorted city remained carthagies obedience continue greate armye come shortly help sent another mago next place gather men entred countrey lersanes reu lled carthagies beseegelersan granata citie scipio comming vpon wente granata set camp citie next day easily ouercome scipio put campe got grannata mago occupyed gathering souldyourescerbona yet spayne cerbona power hee myght encounter romanes many spanyardes ioyned mago many numidian commaunded massinissa asdruball kepte campe footemen nation mago massinissa horseman camp army thus scipio diuided horseman sent one part lelio mago went agaynst massinissa fight long sharp dangerous numidian setting going backe comming againe fighte shotte scipio gaue token hys souldyoures romanes shoulde follow fyghte speares numidian destitute shotte putte flight retired tentes scipio encamped tenne furlong strong place desired whole strength carthagies lxx thousande footemen fiue thousande horse thirtie elephant scipio third part therefore doubtfull durst ioyne whole battell continued skirmishing whose victuall beeing almost spent army beginning lacke thought vnhonorable departe doe nothingthe valientnes scipio therefore making sacrifice bringing armye mighte well hearde framing countenance looke though bin inspired god said accustomed angell hadde bin exhorted fighte reason whereof shoulde rather trust power god scipio taketh occasion euery thing encourage souldyoures number men chiefly bycause attemptes brought good effect power diuine multitude souldyoures make credite wordes hee caused southsayers shew sacrifice while spake thus hee espyed certayne birdes fleeyng vnto whome turning hym selfe badde souldyoures beholde saying god dyd sende token victory also way birdes flewe turned hys bodye one rapte diuine furie wyth hys eye fixed cryed wherfore armye turned hither thither euerye man exhorted certayne victory sawe thing come passe woulde suffering courage souldyoure relent made delay one taken one diuine furie token ceremony theyr good lucke shewed sayd must obeyed battell must made whe souldyoures refreshed theselues comanded take armor comitted horseme sillano oteme l lio martio asdruball mago massinissa whe saw taken suddaine scipio tenne urlongs betweene camp blow without consusion tumult therefore battell eg romane horseman vsing old arte sup following hard enimies beating spear though fayned flee turne againe romanes continually heeles kepte shooting bycause nigh footemen ouerlayd libyan continued day although scipio ranne aboute exhorted fight would neuer giue fierce onsette til delyueringthe courage scipio horse squire toke souldioures target wente alone middest betweene army cry helpe romanes help scipio perill therefore nigh seing great perill hearing moued shame danger generall exhorted one another went enimies great vehemence affricanes able abide turned backes therfore partly weerie fight partly weake samine nighte hand vtterly ouerthrowne ende fighte cerbona whiche victorye doubtfull victory cerbona eight hundred romanes slaine tenne thousand fiue hu dred enimies time carthagies made hast gone scipio followed endamaged al wayes possible come place strong well watered full necessary matter required seege scipio left sillanus hold wente winne rest spaine carthagies beseeged sillanus remoued went cales passe sea sillanus done much hurt could returned army scipio asdruball amilchars sonne whiche gathering men north ocean called brother anniball come italy soone could whiche mighte doe asdruball passeth mountaynes vnknowen scipio passed pirenian hilles nexte north celtiberians romanes ignorant asdruball came italy great iourneys meane season liuius comming rome tolde scipio senate minded make hym captayne warre carthage thing scipio loked trusting woulde sent laelius fiue shyppes king syphax many giftes remember vnto friendship bin betweene scipio aske came africa whether would friend romanes whiche syphax promised doe receyued giftes sente scipio others carthagies vnderstoode sente embassador siphax also remember societie league scipio vnderstanding minding preuent carthagies g syphax bycause matter greate importance two gallies onely laelius wente vnto came porte carthage whiche come brought gallies vnknowen syphax scipi hauing benefite winde full sayle entred port syphax receyued courteously talking priuately giuing faith sent away commaunded carthagies layd new traynes againste stayd perill scipio escaped came coast went thence said whilest scipio syphax sate table wyth asdruball hadde asked many question heethe opinion carthage embassador scip greatly wondered sight modestie turnyng friend sayd man scared onely warre also table time erians celtiberians yet serue vnder hanno whome martius encounter kylled thousande fiue hundred rest fledde home seauen hundred horseman seauen thousand footemen hanno martius droue hyll wanting necessary sent martius composition whome hee commaunded delyuer captayne hanno sugitiues en tell message tooke hanno hearing matter deliuered fugitiues martius required also captiues whome receyued commaunded souldyoures bring certaine summe siluer playne bycause fitte aske pardon keepe highe place whiche descended martius sayde vnto well worthy deathethe victorie martius euery haue youre countreys subiect v rather make warre v oure enimies yet content giue leaue goe safe putting youre armour whiche hearde greeued denying sharp fight made halfesouldyoures vvill deliuer armoure slayne halfe escaping mago long come hannos campe wyth sixtie shippes hearyng hys calamitie returned gades beyng wante put greate feare hee rested sillanus sente citie castaces heecastaces receyued enimie sette hys campe towne made scipio knowe sending afore fytte seege followed way gotteilliturga citie illiturga whyche tyme olde scipio friende romanes hee slayne reuolted priuily pretendyng receyue romanes army friende delyuered carthagies wherfore scipio beeyng angrie ouercame foure houres tooke heere scipio hadde wounde hys necke greate scipio vvounded hee woulde departe fyghte tyll hee hadde gotte citie thys cause armye despising pray kylled woman child vtterly destroyed came castace beseeged three partes dyd assaulte hee myghte gyue castaces tyme repente bycause heard aboute suche matter hadde kylled captain garrison resisted deliuered citie scipio leauing certaynethe castaces yeelde scipio honest man citie keepe wente towarde carthage sending sillanus martius sea spoyle wast could citie called astapa whiche alwayes ofastapa carthagies deuotion sawe beseeged knewe came vnder romanes power shoulde solde slaues brought theyr goodes rich market place compassing wyth wodde badde wiues child goe vp sware fiftie chiefe citie citie taken shoulde kyll wiues chyldren sette thethe desperatio astape wodde fyre burne themselues hadde called god vnto witnesse issued vppon martius looking suche thyng whyche violence shotte horseman putte flighte footemen stayd astapeans fought valiantlye withoute hope remedye romanes number astapeans inferioure vertue slayne fiftie whyche citie kylled woman chyldren kindled fyre lepte martius maruelling vertue refrayned burning house doyngs scipio fell sicke martius ruled scipio sicke army souldyoures spente vppon pleasure thought hadde receyued worthy rewardes theyr seruice bycause hadde nothyng lefte whome scipio ascribed glory hys noble actes reuolted martius hadde campe themselues manye garrison nygh castels ioyned vntothe roman souldioures tine sente mago money persuade receyued money makyng captaynes officer themselues thyngs owne authoritie bounde oth scipio hearing thys wrote vnto authouresthe pruden scipio sayde hee coulde yet rewarde worthy bycause sicknesse hethe prudence scipio wrote appease rage wrote generally though bin reconciled woulde shortly rewarde willed soone might come carthage forage letter redde suspected euill thinking hurt thought good giue credite agreed goe carthage whither scipio vnderstoode comming commanded senatoures cache one goe one authoures sedition receyuing tentes shewe friendshippe take priuily commaunded tribune souldyoures next morning euery trusty friendes swordes shoulde goe priuily place diuers partes citie fitte place looking commaundement shoulde immediately kill made stirre spake hys oration daye called souldyoures assemblie caused borne generalles seate hearing sounde trumpet ashamed awayte vppon generall sicke thinking shoulde haue receyued rewardes came euerye place part without sword part couered little coate bycause time make ready scipio hauing garde secretely aboute firste rebuke scipio souldioures made mutinie deede said would put blame author sedition whome souldyoures helpe punish commaunded officer remoue multitude done senatoures brought authorsthe author seditio punished multitude pardoned seditio forth cry praying fellowes help tribune commanded killed durst make noyse multitude saw thus handled armed sorrie helde peace scipio commaunding bee fyrste killed cried bound pale beate roddes beheaded reste multitude signified trumpet forgaue z order army reformed indibil certaine prince beefore obeyed scipio sedition souldiours raunged dominion scipio followed would refuse battaile cowarde killed thousande two hundred romane souldioures losyng twenty thousande men compelled aske peace whome scipio punished purse receyued hym grace massinissa vnknowen asdrubal sa led spaine mademas inis romany carthagies enemy amitie scipio promised came affrica aider thus otherwise costat man cause asdrubal ledde hym espoused daughter whome syphax loued whereof carthagies thoughte needefull holde syphax agaynste romaynes gaue maide marriage vnto withoute asdrubals prinitie whiche thing done asdrubal ashamed kepte secreate massinissa whiche vnderstoode made league romanes mago admirall carthagies despayring statethis parte liguria italy spaine went gallia liguria gathered men al mighte romanes tooke gades lefte mago time beganne send yearely officer gouerne spaine little c l olympiade peace office captaine justice greate army santio broughte forme cittie whiche name italie called italica countrey adriane traiane chosen rule romaynes sant countrey adriane traiane hee returned rome wyth nauie well furnished filled captines mony spoyle al sort receyued people rome wyth ilandes especiallye north greatnesse maruellous expedition doyngs euen firste enuied noted scipio honored sortes boasting confessed thing brought glorious end indibilu scipio returne reuolted agayne wherfore lieutenaunts spaine gathering ordinarie garrison togyther indibili killed prouince killed hym condemned author rebellion confiscated goodes priuie mutinie punished money spoyled armoure tooke pledge put greater garrison town thing done streight scipio departure ende romanes first warre spaine afterthis gallia gate place alled novv der tyme romanes making war galles dwell aboute poo phillip king macedonie state spaine beganne troublesome againe sempronius tuditanus claudius minutius chosen generalls greater stirre cato sent wyth greater army young man seuere painefull notable hys wysedome eloquence insomuche people hee called another demosthenes principall emporium cato compared demosthenes courage oratour grecia come spaine place called emporium vnderstoode enimies togither place number sortie thousande kepte hys souldioures certaine dayes exercise determined fighte sent ship hym massilia admonishing souldioures feared though ennimie number seeing vertue minde muche price multitude therfore sent away shippes whereof neede kept ouercame saide thus gaue fierce onset vpon enimye afraying souldioures rather exhorting wonte doe fight begunne ranne euery part encouraged souldiors fight continued doubtfull night manye rather rebuketh chydeth ho valtantnes diligence cato falling side wyth three thousand vpon hill see al partes fight saw men compassed enimie came downe haste offring himselfe formost cry fighting brake thethe victory cato enimies aray laid first foundation victory chased enimy al night got camp killed infinite multitude returned al mette embraced congratulated authour victorie thing beyng done gaue rest armye made destribution spoyle ambassador came al people receyued pledge besides sent letter sealed citties commau ding bearer deliuer al one daye appointyng dayea people cato pulling dovvn vvals al citties coniecture considred distance place might make iorny furthest cittie comanded ruler euery citie pul wals threatned destruction made delay al obeyed mindful losse receyued seuerally durst resist thinking bin comaded afraid obey punished disobey alone obey matter greate moment respite send neighbor souldiors brought letter vrged wherfore euery citie saue themselues pulled wals might haue thanke quicke obedience great speede meane citties floud iberus cast downe theyr wall one day wisedome captaine quiet romanes space foure olympiades thefiue yeres vvas betvveene olympiades c l olympiade great parte spaine rebelled romanes bicause wer wat al necessary food wherfore matter comming light fuluius flaccus consull ouercame fuluius hath victory manye fled possession want got liuing robbing assembled al togither complega citty new made wel defenced encreasedcompolega short time fro hence many time molested thethe vvord sagum vvhich core souldiours vvere vvarre romanes set flaccus shold leaue cloake horse sword euery one killed flee spaine worse hapned vnto flaccus answered would bring many soldiors coat folowing messegers caped city doyng thing according great crake fledde dayly spoyled countreis vse certaine garment double thicke w wt buckle fastned like cloke count souldiours coate tiberius sempronius gracchus succeeded flaccus celtiberians besieged carab cittie friend romaynes wyth twentye thousande souldioures thought gette quickly wherefore gracchus comming helpe hauing mean signifie besieged certaine capitaine bande named ploy cominius tolde gracchus deuised himselfe put spaniardes coate wente among slaues campe spaniard came campe thence citie tolde gracchus hande helpe wherefore abode siege valiauntly within three dayes gracchus came c l berians left siege one daye twenty thousande came complega bringing braunches oliue lyke petitioner asking pardon whiche comming nighe romanes generall gaue violent onsette romanes put great daunger gracchus went campe purpose made thoughe fledde while aboute spoile returned sette vpon killed many got complega appointed la e neighbor neede made league inhabitant countrey certaine condition whereby receiued romaine amitie whiche bounde th condition wereconditions much desired war followed thing name gracchus greate bothe spaine rome triumphed gloriously fewe yeares great warre renewed spayne cittie border celtiberians called named seged great mighty comprehended gracchus citie enticing little townes wall compasse whereof forty ur example induced ti an celtiberians lyke whyche thing senate vnderstanding forbadde building wal required tribute appointed gracchus commanded goe warre romanes whiche also bounde league gracchus aunswered touching walles bound gracchus builde newe citties defend olde touching tribute seruice war released romanes indeede condition long shoulde seeme good senate people rome wherefore q fuluius nob sent army thirty thousande segetanes hearing comming wall notsegetanes yet finished desired araschians receiue soaraschians carus fled made chiefe captaine carus segetanes thoughte man expert war three day created generall laide ambushe twentye thousande footemen fyue thousande horse shadowy woddy place thece gaue charge vpon romanes fight doubtfull greate length carus hadde carus victorie romaine noble victorie ewe sixe thousande romaine whiche great losse citie vsed victory rashlye proudlye romaine horseman garded carriage set vppon ew carus fighting valiantly himselfe sixe thousand carus slaine hym tyll fyghte ended darkenesse night done daye romaynes kepte feaste vulcane daye none woulde come tothe feast vulcane vvas august arathon leucon fight compulsion araschians assembled night numanti strong citie chose arathon leucon captaines warre fuluius came thither thirde daye camped foure twenty furlong citie massinissa sent three hundred horsmen thirtye elephant come went straight fight fuluius vvinneth looseth placed elephant backe army fight begonne opened way elephant celtiberians sawe horse afraid fled walles romayne elephant shoulde brought wal fierce fight till one elephant hurte heade stone wall begannean elephant hurt loseth victorie rage vnruly furie turne vpon fellow thrusting treading downe euery one met difference betweene friend foe rest elephant made afrayde lyke trode thruste downe romaine souldiours whiche thing elephant feare w nte doe taking euerye man theirelephants common enimies ennimye wherefore falshoode called common enimies therfore romanes without order fled away numantines saw walles came forth chased flewe foure thousande tooke three elephant muche armour many ensignes celtiberians flight romaine two thousand killed fuluius hadde gotten slaughter besieged axenium co monaxenium market enimyes thinges sell good lose men retired night blesus killed campe wherefore hee sente blesus capitayne horsmen nation nigh friend wanted horseman bande horse way fell ambushe celtiberians whiche beyng knowne friendes fledde blesus fought killed many romanes whiche loss ouerthrowes ocile cittie ocile galacia whiche romanes treasure munition yeelded celtiberians fuluius distrusting himselfe afraid al thing kepte within campe winter defending well heethe mountain cause colde hote country coulde getting victuall yet greatly troubled lacke bitternesse colde wherfore many souldyours partly goyng wood partly sharpnesse great colde perishe yeare following claudius marcellus came fuluius claudius marcellus place bringing eighte thousande footemen v c horseman againste whome enimies likewise ha saide traines ocile taken pardoned another crafte auoyded went streight ocile camped power fortune fauouring hym tooke cittie firste assaulte whome pardoned receiuing pledge thyrtie talentes golde thys modestie hearde nergobriges sente messenger marcellus nergobriges vse crafte know might haue peace commaunded sende hundred horseman promised doe yet folowed tayle armye tooke cariage notwithstanding came brought hundred horseman saide hurte carriage done errour knewe couenauntes marcellus made hundred horsmen prisoner solde horse ranged lande gaue pray souldioures encamped cittie sawe engine broughte trench made sente oute heraulte wearing woolf skinne aske pardon whichethe vvar vvas ended brought rodde called caduceum vvherof embassadours peace called caduceatores denyed giue except aruacceans bellans titthians woulde sewe whiche nation willinglye praying reasonable payne beyng putte vppon mighte broughte league gracchus denied bicause hadde bin strife marcellus sent ambassadoures part rome dispute controuersies secretly wrote senate compounde matter desired war might ended time thinking would glory ambassadoures friendes receyued theembassadors diuersely vsed rome cittie enimies lodged without cittie manner senate would haue peace grieued brought ye romanes power nobilior would haue done generall spaine therefore senate aunswered ambassador marcellus declare plesure forthwith sent army spaine thensouldiours ta lotte first time souldiors wer take lot choice beene manye reproue consulls vsyng themselues truely sincerely choise soldiors might sed lighter enterprise cause req therfore seemed good take soldiors lotte whome l lucullus made generall cornelius scipio lucullus scipio lieutnant shortely gotte carthage numantia while lucullus comming marcellus proclaimed warre againste celtiberians whome rendred pledge requiring yet deteyned hym long wente embassadoure rome cause vncertaine suspition beleeued much thing happened persuaded people committe matter didde could marcellus procureth peace make end warre lucullus came controuersies fyue thousande aruacceans tooke nergobrigem marcellus wente numantia encamped within fyue myle citie droue enimies wherfore linteuon captain numantines cried saidlinteuon woulde deale marcellus come talke hee saide would leaue bellans titthians aruacceans marcellus accepted willingly commaunded money pledge deliuered receyued let people go free end warre bellans titthians aruaceans comming lucullus lucullus partly desire glorie partly neede poore ledde armie agaynst vacceans whiche lucullus needie vaccei people iland neather spaine people celtiberia next aruacceans notwithstading senate determined nothing euer bin enimies people rome therefore passed floude tagus came tagus floud ta lusitama citie cauc encamped towne asked came purpose molested carpetanes dvvel oud taio quiet rest answered hee came helpe carpetanes iniured returned ye city romanes wente forrage kylled many vnderstoode army brought forth mette fought caucaeans better til caucaeans slayne citie shotte fayled fledde good firme battell thrusting together gate three thousand slayne next day olde men came forth besought lucullus tell might doe keepe romanes fauour required pledge c talentes silner horseman shoulde serue graunted saide woulde put garrison citie denye put two thousand choyce souldyoures citie whome commaunded take walles whiche beeyng done brought army killed without respect age thus extreame crueltie slaine callingextreame iniurie done romanes lucullus vpon god faith oth whiche romanes sworne charging romanes infidelitie murthered twenty thousande fewe except strong rocky place lucullus spoyled citie gaue prey souldioures purchasing immortall infamie name rome countrey assembled came playnes hils strong townes carrying muche could burning rest lucullus shoulde haue profite lucullus made long iourney hard deserte way came citie called enderacia theenderacia whiche twenty thousand footemen fledde two thousand horseman lucullus suche foolishnesse inuited composition whome obiected calamitie vacceans asking woulde exhorte suche amitie lucullus angry obiection manner naught whereas rather angry themselues wasted land beseeged citie made many trench continually prouoked fight one faire armour came many time forth horsehacke prouoked romane fighte hand hand man answered laughed scorned romanes wente leaping reioyeing home doyng oft greeued scipio yong man came scipio fighteth combate killeth spaniarde forthe toke matter hande benefite fortune ouercame greate straunger small stature gaue courage romane night diuersly affrighted horseman barbarian whiche gone foraging romanes came coulde get citie ranne vpon camp great alarm citie like greate vehemence romanes made afrayde sore troubling romanes afflicted wyth watche night compelled watche armoure accustomed meates countrey hauing neyther wyne salte oyle vinegre eatevvant salte sodden wheate barlie muche fleashe dere hare without salte fell flixes whiche many dyed thus continued tyll hadde brought trench due height whiche done beat downe one part romanes perish wall entred citie valiantly repulsed retire vnawares fell fenne greate parte perished barbarian night following made vppe theyr wall length side oppressed wyth famine scipio promised fraude treatie whome faith giuen opinion hys vertue ende thys warre shoulde deliuer celtiberians c ficeme gold tenne thousande souldioures coates certayne number caitell fiftie pledge gold siluer lucullus could haue whose cause made warre thinking spayne bin full people hadde neyther doe celtiberians much esteeme suche thing wente toward pallantia whiche citie pallantia citie igh greater name power whyche many fledde therefore many counselled leaue bycause hee heard wealthy riche followe councell went forage euer pallantine horseman vpon lacke victuall fayne remoue camp ledde army square battell pallantines euer following till came floud orius orius turditanes people granata went away midnight returned turditanes land wintered end hadde warre whiche lucullus made vacceans without authoritie senate therfore shuld come iudgemet accused c p notwithstanding another part spayne called lusitania lyuing lusitania novv portugall owne lawes certayne captayne africa spoyle countreys obeyed romanes whe romanes killed ouerthrowen manilius calphurnius piso romane captaynes killed syxe thousande beside terentius varro treasourer whiche thing affrican proude runne ouer countreys ocean vettones hither spayne vvhome hearbe fetonie named captaine killed blastophenicians sea ioyning vettones vnto beseeged blastophenicians subiect romanes whyche say anniball mingle carthage generation therfore called blastophenicians thys captayne hurte head stone dyed hys placecessaro succeeded another called cessaro hee foughte wyth mummius come rome wyth another armye whome beingthe romanes ouerthrovven vnder mummius ouercome mummius chacing hym returned vppon followed disorderly kylled tenne thousande recouered hys prey hys owne campe whyche hee hadde lost besyde spoyled romanes campe tooke theyr ensignes whyche shewing throughout spayne made laughingstocke romanes mummius nowe campyng strong place exercised souldioures whyche hadde lefte whyche fiue thousande durst bryng playne tyll hadde recouered theyr courage lusitanes albeit inhabite syde floud tagus yet tooke armes wasted cuneans tributary cunistorges celtiberia romanes canchenus beeyng theyr captayne tooke cunistorges theyr greate citie passed sea pillers hercules wente affrica beseeged citie ocilis mummius followed nine thousand footemen fiue hundred horseman killed fifteene thousande wasted countreys many deliuered ocile seege meeting raunged yt countrey destroyed messenger left prey couldevictorie mummius carryed distributed souldioures rest burned honor god ruler warre thing triumphed rome returne attilius succeeded one rode killed seuen hundred lusitanes destroyed great citie called ostrace tooke countreyostrace aboute yeelding feare whiche nation bottanes soone attilius departed hys ottanes winter station reuolted beseeged certayne romanes tributary whome seruius galba successor attilius would haue put seege sodayne gone one night day fiue hundred surlongs shewed himselfe lusitanes put souldioures wearie seruius galba taketh much vvearie sould youres loseth iourney fight forthwith put enimie flighte foolishly followed souldioures weake wearie barbarian seeing scattered manye time resting faintenesse turned gaue charge vpon killed seauen thousande galba horseman recouered himselfe citie carmena gathered escaped whencarmena twenty thousand tributarie souldyoures went border cuneans wintered cunistorge cuneans lucullus made warre vacceans withoute authoritielucullus senate comming time turditania vnderstoode lusitanes made warre vppon neighboures therefore sent best captaynes killed fifteene hundred passed water others fledde hill compassed trench mountes killed great multitude entring lusitania wasted one parte galba another sente embassador confirme league made attilius broken receyued friendship compounded master wyth also fayned sory kllwel continuall wante driuen spoyle breaking league made warre know quoth copelled barennesse want countrey put plentifull soyle diuide three seuerall place full abundance allured thys hope went owne house whome diuided three partes shewed playne stay till came shew place shoulde buylde citie come firste willed leaue armour friend enclosed ditch trench sent souldyource caused kylled one escaping calling vpon god breach faith like secondeanother manifest iurie lucullus thirde one vnderstoode anothers calamitie thus reuenged fraude fraude following barbarian vse respect honor rome escaped among whome viriatus captayne lusitanes viriatus greate feates killed many romanes thing done afterwarde shewe bookes galba passed lucullus couetousnesse distributed fewe thing among souldyoures tooke rest hymselfe although riche romanes galba described man peace profite appeared would refrayne periurie lie hated men accused yet rich whereof great plenty euer quitte discharged long many remained vnfaithfulnesse lucullus galba gathering togither number tenne thousande wasted lande turditania agaynste vettilius another armye wente ioyning spayne whych tenne thousande wente agaynste wasted turditania kylled many droue castell woulde tarry must perishe hunger departed must fall romanes handes narrow place wherefore sent embassadoures vettilius humble wise desiring haue place tovettilius inhabite henceforth might tributary rome whyche accepted ready come forth viriatus escaped galbas crueltie andthe policie hardinesse viriatus put remembrance romanes falsehoode tolde oft hadde bin deceyued colour promise romanes army nowe lyke vnto deceytefulnesse galba lucullus woulde ruled hym woulde tell might escape safe beeyng moued hys wordes conceyuing good hope chose hym theyr captayne therefore hadde placed horse front battell though woulde fyghte commaunded soone tooke hys horse diuide themselues diuers pathes flee ouer hylles well could tribola andtribola tarry hym tyll came kepte wyth hym choyce horseman euery number lepte horsebacke fledde speede vettilius afrayde followe thus separate diuided many partes stayed see viriatus woulde doe abode still hys swifte horse nowe commyng vpon romanes going backe comming agayne vppon spente whole daye nexte also goyng comming playne coniecture thoughte gone come sure place midnighte wyth speede dyuers hard wayes got tribola romanes coulde ouertake hym partly weight armoure partly ignorance way partly diuersitie theyr horse thus viriatus saued hys men desperation themselues thys policie wanne hym greate fame ouer place aboute came vnto hym great number kepte warre wyth romanes three yeares togither well knowen warre muche troubled ende daungerous vnto stirre spayne cause continued longer vettilius followed came tribola viriatus layde ambushe hyll whyther knewe thattraynes romanes vettilius come fledde vettilius past ambushe turned ambushe came forthe besette romanes kylling takyng throwing headlong hygh place vettilius taken whome vettilius taken killed taker knewe sawe hym fatte olde man thought hym regarde kylled hym tenne thousande romanes scarsly sixe thousande saued themselues carpesso sea towne whyche thynke wascarpesso called grecian tartessus whyche arganthonius reigned say lyued hundred fiftie yeare arganthonius old kyng treasurer came vettilius followyng went carpesso seeing afrayde kepte citie made keepe wall gotten fiue thousande bellans titthians accordyng desired hee sente agaynste viriatus whome kylled one beeing viriatus kill spanyards sent lefte bryng tydings home treasourer remayning citie lookyng newesfrom rome durst doe nothyng viriatus meane season inuaded plentifull abundant soyle carpetanes whyche spoyled without feare tyll caius plautius came tenne thousande footemenc plautius three hundred horseman viriatus pretended flee plautius sent foure thousand follow vpon whome viriatus killed turned killed saue fewe passed oud tagus camped hill full oliues yet called name venus plautius finding heere desirous heale former wounde gaue battell wherein ouercome great losse men fledde shame kepte plautius onescome strong city men wont winter durst neuer come forthe sommer viriatus raunged countrey toke money owner saue theyr haruest whyche denyed hym wasted rome knowen sente q fabius maximus paulus q fabius maximus aemilius sonne ouercame perseus kyng macedonia gaue hym authoritie gather men hymselfe bycause late hadde gotte grecia car hage made prosperous ende thirde warre macedonia gyue respect olde souldioures come thence hee tooke vp two legion yong men vnexpert warre sente ayde hys friendes came orsona citie spayne orsona contente hys armye fifteene thousande footemen two thousande horseman whyche place myndyng beginne warre tyll hadde trayned hys souldioures wente gades sacrifice hercules viriatus meeting gone foraging kylled viriatus spoyleth romanes parte putte rest feare called agayne theyr ensigne theyr captayne ouercame spoyled greate prey maximus come ofte fielde prouoked hym fyghte maximus thoughte good auenture whole fyght continued exercising hys souldioures suffered hys souldioures skirmishe meane myghte trie hearies hys owne hys enimies maximus refuseth fight till trayned men shoulde goe victuall hee garded wyth many shotte horseman riding seene father paulus doe macedonia winter past hadde sufficiently exercised hys souldioures seconde whome viriatus ouerthrowen putte flighte doyng partes belongeth generall two city hel toke one burned another driuen strong place whiche called vecor killed many winter wente lye corduba wherefore viriatus illuding hys enimie wont induced aruacceans titthians bellans warlike people whiche warre themselues reuolte hee made warre numantines whiche long paynefull daungerous romanes haue done viriatus wil shewe briefly viriatus fought part spaine another capitaine romanes q pompeius ouercome hee fled venus hill comming vpon enimy kille romanes killed many quintus tooke diuers ensign droue rest campe caste garrison vtica wasted lande basitanes quintus helpe forbasitanes corduba cordon cowardlinesse vnskilfulnesse ut rested corduba middest autumne althoughe martius didde moue hym sending spaniarde vnto italian citie next yeare fabius maximus brother aemilianus came successor aemilianus quintus two romane legios friend eighteene footman thousand sixe hundred horseman wrote micipse king numidia soone time would serue send elephant part armiemicips wente vtica whome viriatus encountring way six thousand great escries alarm barbarian manner long vgly heare maximus withstoode without losse repulsed army come affrica ten elephant three hundred horse tooke large place encampe fortified beeganne firste ame viriatus put flight chase romanes followed hym oute order perceyuing turned vpon killed three thousanderomanes killed chased reste campe whiche hee assaulted founde fewe gate resiste hym fledde tentes feare whence generall captaines could hardly remoue fight fannius sonne lawe laelius behaued hymselfe valiauntlyefannius saued romanes comming viriatus running darkenesse night heate daye suffered moment time passe molest enimye shotte light horseman till aemilianus encamped towarde vtica viriatus victuall fayling small armye oballa captaines theeues curius apulcius troubled hym made spoile curio killed fight aemilianus recouered pray shortly tooke city iseadia semella oballa whiche garrison viriatus spoiled pardoned ten shewing benefi e romanes content make peace vvhen auntage made peace league whiche approued people say viriatus shoulde friend romanes al wer sholo lord land possessed viriatus thoughte hadde made ende great warre romanes quiet peace continued long caepto brother aemilianus allow conditionsthe peace allovved made wrote rome dishonorable senate beginning priuily agreed thinking commo wealth professe emnitie viriatus wrote many letter therof vrged matter decreed breake league viriatus renue war capio trusting vpon thys decree made open war vpo capio viriatus tooke arsa itie left power andarsa folowing viriatus went aboute wasting countryes hee ouertooke country carpetanes far exceeding number wherfore viria u minding fight fo smal number sent away great part armie certaine bypathe placed rest hill thoughe would fighte thoughte come sure place hee viriatus saueth policie tooke horse spurres reste hys companye great scorne enimie went forth speedily folowed could tell way became caepio wasted country vettones gallecians many followed viriatus spoyled portugall sextus iunius brutus sent wearye long waye inn brutus rodes spain whiche tagus l darias betis nauigeable floudes conteyne staide following lyke theeues conueyed themselues sight moment wherefore brutus thought great labour ouertake doe greate dishonor supposing finall glorie ouerthrowing went spoile campes bycause thought might chastice also get great bootie souldiors furder bande robber woulde scatter shoulde thinke daunger theyr seueral countreis wyth entent purpose spoiled whatsoeuer way woman came warre husbandesvaliant killed shewed suche constancie woulde speake worde slaine many went mountayns wyth much coulde carrye whome desiring peace hee gaue diuided land passed floude orius wasted greate regionorius required hostage yeeded came floude lethe first romane thought passage past gone forth came tonibene battarans riuer nibene ledde hys army againste battarans bycause intercepted victualls bee people goe also woman armed warre good courage abide death oldly sparing themselues neyther leeing fight lamenting dye woman taken would kil themselues child also rather shoulde bee aues manye citties helde brutus rebetled shortely subdued hym againe cause came labrica ofte made peace labrica disobedient desired pardon woulde doe thing commaundement required hostage romaine r nneawaies armour lastly leaue cittie al whiche hadde done called quietly assembly compassed army put remembraunce oft reuolted made warre made afraide cap vseth mercie might feare worse punishement ende eing satisfied rebuke refrayned urder paine tooke horse corne common money publike preparation beside hope suffered lyue country thing thus done returned rome haue declared al historie viriatus time folowing example exercised robbery viriatus might come end sente dital one andpra se kil viriatus min r caepio whiche corrupted many promise vndertooke kill viriatus matter u handled viri tus v ed little sleepe moste greate laboures moste parte slepte armed might readye nethe manner killing viriat chaun e cause lawfull hys friend come hym night whiche manner conspiratoures knowing marking firste houre hys sleepe entred hys house armed greate matter cut hys throate parte could hurte man eard noise deede facilitie cutte escaped caepio required rewarde whome orthwith gaue al possesse whatsoeuer power touching rewarde ee sente ro e viriatus friend whole army aye arried thinking rested maruelled alteration went found dead armour wherfore great sorrowe made al campe euerye man lamenting harde happe thinking danger captaine loste moste grieued coulde fynd killer therefore burned hishonor done viriatus b riall body muche honoure vppon great stacke killing many sacrifice reuerence well footemen horsmen barbarian manner wente aboute fyre extolled heauen praise laste fire funeral finished made many turneymets hand hand sepulchre great loue desire viriatus leaue men thoughe barbarian yet wasthe prayse viriatus moste skilfull gouernement warie peril aboue bolde espisyng moste iuste diuiding pray could neuer brought take whitte reste althoughe hee desired hee tooke gaue valiant ort wherby came passe harde daye hath happened captaine hys armye gathered kinde nation eighte yeares togither whiche warre continued euer obedient without mutinie endured vttermost moste ready abide daunger created tantalus captaine theytantalus went towarde gunt cittie annibal destroyed restored called carthage name country driuen e caepa alwaies backes passed floude betis beeing wearye yeelded himselfe army caepa tooke al hys armor appoynted good land lyue shoulde driuen robbe nowe oure history shall retourne warres vacceans numantines viriatus caused reuolt caecilius metellus sent rome men shortely ouercame vacceans whereby reste disco ted put feare c p remayned yet termantia numantia hyllyhere vvanteth termantia numantia place diuided two floudes compassed hylles thicke wooddes bending playne onely one waye part fortified many ditch pill ur ouerthwart numantines good eight thousand bothe horse foote small number suche manlinesse put romanes muche paine metellus ende winter deliuered army q metellus aulus successor thirtie thousad footemen two thousand horsmen wel armed practised chere vvanteth p pompeius campe numantia thence went certaine place numantines descending hil destroyed horseman ranne hee retourned broughte foorthe batayle fyghte playne enimies comming gaue charge vpon hym though bin afraide retired vnto hil till brought place ditch ouerthwart beames layde pompey perceyuing pompey looseth skirmish ouermatched inferioure hym tourned hys armie towarde termantia thinking doe better fought losse seauen hundred beside termantines put tribune flight comming victual one day giuyng three onset romaynes droue thrice sharpe rocky place threwe many footemen horseman togither horse hylles rockes reste afraide remayned al night armor day comming foorth order battaile fought doubtfullye till night ended fight pompey night made hast malia wyth horseman whiche place numantines helde garrison malian killing garrison treason malia nove malgrad deli ered pey deliuered citie pompey receyuing armoure pledge went sueditania certayne capitainesue ta ta ginus named tanginus spoyle wyth armie pompey fought ouerthrewe tooke manye hys souldyoures suche manhoode theeues none themmanhode th ues woulde lyue captiue killed themselues theyr maisters made hole hip caried sincke pompey beyng returned numantia went turne floude playne waye mighte presse citie famine townsemen droue labourer worke andthe romaine killed comming bandes without trumpet threwe dart arrowes vpon shouldnot tourne floude fought hande came aide pioners dro e campe encountring wente forage killed manye tribune leader giuing charge side romanes made ditche killed one thousand four hundred capitaine whiche discommodities certaine mencounsellours sent pompey senate came pompey helpe hym theyr counsel also young souldioures yet exercised gathered old bin nowe sixe yeares abroade wyth olde souldioures pompey hauing receyued manye displeasure remayned winter campe recouer estimation cursedly vexed colde warding watching nature countrey beganne beeflixe among romane soldiours perceyued taken wyth flyxe manye dyed anye souldiours shoulde goe oute campe victuall numantines lying awayte woulde cease hurte romanes shot dart numantine h rt romanes coulde abide woulde needes go come traines muche harme againe numidian meeting wyth brought victuall destroyed many aswell noble men pompey therfore vexed many euils counsaile senatours remoued shoulde lye reste wynter sure place spring city bycause successoure come afraid accused beganne practise secreatly numantines also losse many chiefe citizen coulde tyll ground want victuall ye continuance war longer thought sent ambassador pompey openlye spake yt yeeld themselues said knew none way howe agree dignitie romaynes pri ly tolde condition pompey practiseth peace vvith numantines woulde vse thing agreed yeelded hym pompey required pledge fugitiues whiche receiued required also thirtie talentes siluer numantines paide fifteene presently pompey looked reste successour popilius lena come numantines popilius paide pompey deliuered feare warre knowing composition made vnlawfull done wythout romanes consent successor come denyed pompey goeth fro peace made agreement numantines proued witnesse present men degree senatours tribune also capitaines hys horseman therefore popilius sent bothe partes rome pleade matter senate senate thought beste holde war still numantines meane season popilius entred lande lusones lusones neighbour numantines returned dooyng nothing c hostilius mancinus succeeded went rome mancinus came fight oft ouercome length lost many kepte within camp rumor cantabrans vacceanes would come helpcantabri scage enimie wherefore night without lighte fled abandoned campe nobilior beyng shutte neyther hauing fortifyed place otherwise able defend numantines beseeging armye hard state least hee make dishonorable peace made league amitie betweene romanes numantines equall condition bound himselfe whyche thing knowen rome sory bycause league shamefull therefore aemilius lepidus mancinus maketh peace dishonourably aemilius another consull sente spayne mancinus called iudgemente whome embassador numantines followed aemilius looking aunswere rome weerie rest generalles driuen desire false gloriegeneralles prouinces profite profite triumph went prouinces cou trey profite preteding false crime vacceans accusing holpen numantines victual inuaded land beseeged chiefe citie pallantia whiche offended league sent brutus sonne law partes spayne make partaker warre cinus caecilius came embassador rome shewing senate dote many loss receyued spayne aemilius would sowe new warres declared decree senate shoulde make warre vpon vacceans hauing begunne warre sent brutus abroade bycause thought senate knowe vacceans helpe numantines victuall money souldyoures fearing also lefte warre spayne would reuolt done feare sent embassadoures without delay wrote senate fortifyed certaine castell bestowed time gathering men victuall flaccus sent foraging falling traynes came vpon word craftily cast forthethe army saued vvorde aemilianus wonne pallantia whiche souldioures made crie manner victorie barbarian hearing beleeuing true afrayde departed meane flaccus deliuered men perill forage spoyle seege continuing long pallantia romanes wantedpallantia victuall hauing consumed cattell waxed weake dyed hunger captaynes aemilianus brutus suffered want long could legth ouercome mischiefe aemilius commaunded breake vp therefore tribune centurians went aboute campe commanded souldioures departe beforecovvardly departure romanes day forsooke euen sicke wouded souldyoures embraced recommended themselues vnto departing confusedly without order men flee pallantines ranne vpo euery much troubled following morning till night darke romanes scattered wente diuers place l ke serued pallantines lefte chasing beeing called fro purpose power god thing chanced aemilius lepidus whiche romanes vnderst de put aemilius prouince consulshippe aemilius put fro office hee returned priuate man rome punished numantines mancinus heard senate broughte forth capitulation league layde blame vpon pompey ruler prouince hym whome receyued rude cowardly army whiche oft euill handled ouercome made peace wyth numantines thereto compelled pompey hadde done whose league affirmed warre vnlucky romanes romanes angrie yet pompey acquit accused afore senate decreed mancinus made dishonorable league without consent senate giue numantines old st consull vvas deliuered samnite example gaue captayne samnite bycause agreed shameful peace comanded furius leade mancinus spayne depriued al thing naked mancinus deliuered numantines calphurnius receiued numantines whome calphurnius piso made generall entred land numantines wasted part pallantines spent rest time harborough carpentania people rome weerycarpentania long tedious warre numantines might ended chose cornelius scipio cosull againe wone carthage one could ouercome numatines could consul age yong decree senate made tribune dispense law yeare restore ye yeare following thereforea disputation make scipio consull scipio made consull made speede goe ye numantines ledde none souldioures choyce bycause wer troubled war also bycause many spaine voluntary sent king city consent senate led many seruants fro rome made one band fiue c company philoni band friend frieds called philonida band frieds felows whe appointed four souldiours cousin uteo wet afore great speede uteo army vnderstood corrupted ydlenesse riote sedition knowing could ouercome enimies except restreined kept souldiours awe temperance integritie gouernemet soone come put merchant harlot southsayers whome souldioures feare would aske many question forbad thing brought camp necessary forbad sacrifice bowel whereof thing come enquired would suffer slaues drudge co manded scipio reformed camp coke souldioures camp sell beast burthen except fewe needefull would haue souldioures haue coke forbad instrument vessells kitchen carried spit panne vessell drinke would haue eate flesh otherwise dressed sodde rost appointed measure diet forbad featherbed first yt lay vpo bed hay forbad souldiours iourneys ride ass mule saide little good hoped man warre could go afoote likewise reproued vsed minister hote house called mule yt wated hads need rub thus made souldiours obediet temperate litle little acquainted reuerece feare hard heare quarels grating thing yt iust oft yt sentence mouth easie fauourable affable captaynesfauourable captaynes profitable enimie though beloued souldyoures set little hard seuere haue souldyoures ready obediente assayes whiche though thus instructed yet durst bring fielde till exercised much labour therefore going dayly one field another made diuers campes one another whiche defaced called souldyoures worke agayne digge ditch higher fill againe make high walles pull downe againe stode morning till night ouersee pioners made iourney went square battell shoulde scattered suddaine attempte happened rode army sometime hindermost bad sicke borne horseman horse tooke burden mule much laden diuided borne footemen kepte himselfe house sommer troupe horseman sent espye commaunded returne stand without trech till another bande horseman viewed labour worke diuided among pioners make trench ditch walles pitch tentes euery certayne time appointed doe perceyued armye made fierce obediente paynefull sommer encamped nygh numantia yet choose place strong camp numantia novve called caesar august wont diuided men least anye losse happe first shoulde contemned neyghboures whiche wont laugh neither encounter enimie waying nature end warre strength numantines least would come vpon force therfore commaunded wast thing corne cutte whilest greene wasted must needes goe way went numantia playne shorter many persuaded go way whome scipio sayd considered way returnehard vvay sure enimie full shotte come sight citie backe returne safely againe said laden victual weery farre weake beside haue beastes burden carte carriage fighte shoulde hard vnequall ouercome great perill ouercome haue great gayne folly put hymselfe perill small matter euill captayne fighteth without profite valiante wise entreth danger fight constreined necessitie brought example phisitians come cut burne till haue tryed sicke place wyth medicine said comanded captaines leade way comanded goe lande vacceans numantines victuall fieldes wasted also corne gathered vse souldioures burned rest pallantines laide many awayte vnder certaine hilles adioyning playne called coplanium openly molested werecoplanium haruest therefore scipio sente rutilius ruffus hys tribune committed warre wrighting wyth four band orse stop rangings therefore ruffus began rutilus ruffus danger follow chace ppe hilles ambush whiche discouering themselues ruffus commanded neyther followe encounter enimie holde speares poylite scipio seeyng ruffus going hilles appointed began follow wich army fearing worst come place traynes diuided horseme commanded giue onset vpon enimie wayes cast dartes returne righte soft pac behinde mighte ioyne meane brought horse safe playne scipio would remoue water hard passed myrie enimie lay hidden knowen lefte way ledde hys army another longer way sure deceyts went night commanded many welles made thirst mostsalt vvater part salt water found neuerthelesse neuerthelesse army wet safe though great payne horse mule killed drought entred land cauceans whome lucullus inuaded contrary league comanded crier goe quietly euery one hys owne thence wente numantines grounde winter remained till iug rtha nephewe massinissa iugurth came xij elephant archer slinger well armed occupyed wasting spoyling countreys nigh almost entrapped uillage enuirened great fenne one side scipio like entrapped hilly place traynes layde scipio host diuided two partes entring towne leauing ensignes without went spoyle horseme rode towne beset ambush defended theselues scipio ensignes called souldioures trumpet could come horseman ranne help distresse part souldiours come towne made enimie flee yet follow fewe killed side retired camp laying two camp numati made brother maximus ruler one gouerned himselfe while sort numantines came forth offered fighttvvo campes numan scipio contemned thinking better fight desperation came famine driue yeelde made seauen trench citie presse rather sente letter confederate whiche conteyned howe many souldioures shoulde sende whyche come diuided many partes owne commaunded captaynes leader make ditch enclosure citie compasse numantia four twenty furlong enclosure muche orthree myles distributed tribune whiche let enimie signifie day redde cloth vpon speare night fire brother might aide circumuented whiche beeing done set gard sufficient resist enimie commaunded another beside made plant stake next build newe wall breadth fiue foote height tenne beside pinnacle tower distant equall space fenne nexte wall bycause coulde compasse wall made trench high wall might serue wall scipio first thinkea vvall camp dunas compassed citie beseeged wall whiche refuse fight floud dunas ranne campe commodious numantines bring victuall receiue men swimme vnder water send boates full sayle winde bigge rowe time serued bycause bridge coulde made vpon breadth vehemence scipio caused two castels made either side banke betweene haged certaine long beames rope let goe water beames laide plate sword euery side weapon pricking whiche continuall course water turned suffer enimies shippes swimmer passe thing scipio desired none go beseeged tell donepolicie scipio abroade whereby shoulde destitute councell comfort thus disposed engine placed tower instrument cast arrowes dartes stone walles ful stone shot castels kept shooter inger placed also many men trench shuld day night signifie new thing hapned rake one fro another holding vp en gne tower need tower like whe token seen first made done momet time might know happened thing must declared deede would haue brought certayne messenger deuided army confederate lx two partes set one garde sea vsed goe thing requisite occasio required twenty thousand appointed fight neede ayde xx confederate assigned euery place whiche might go without leaue euery repaired place token made enimie made thing adoe orderly wisely scipio considered euery thing numantines made many salies vpon ordinary wardes nowe heere soone made afraid dreadful sight came soone helpe also ensignes set vpo wall shew matter keeper tower trenchies sound trumpet much copasse treches furlong moment terror place scipio rode euery day see meane hauing shut enimies thought could log continue seing could holpen man neither victuall armour rit gene rit gene auen ureth countrey numatine chiefe v fellowes persuaded many seruants horse darke night passing space betweene towne camp comming ouer trench ladder made scale gote vp killed watch sending seruats back citie got away went aruacceas holding vp hads praying aru cceans help numantines kinsfolke aruacceas would receyue bad goe way citie power xxx furlong numantia called lucia youth citie much fauoured numantines moued theyr citie help numantines auntientes certified scipio therefore scipio eyght houre night tooke iourney day lucia eeged citie required head youth giuen thelucia townesmen answering fled threatned spoyle cittie vnlesse obeyed whiche citizen featingfoure hundred yong men h d cut brought foorth foure hundred young men whose handes cutte went away great speede next day betimes campe numantines oppressed famine sent fyue men numantines sue peace scipio commission know woulde yeelde would vse mercifully content moderate fine auarus chiefe man highe courage muche set valiantnes entente numantines affirming offende greatebosting r time daunger fyghting wiues child libertie theyr countrey wherefore scipio saide hee shal almost rightful thing thou noble man great vertue wilt pardon noble people appoint v paine shal able beare knowe mutation fortune safetie oure country v thee take cittie content moderate punishement thou haste v contempt thou maiste hope see perish ouerthrowne defending selfe auarus hadde saide thus scipio knowing captiues done cittie saide woulde haue freely yeelde themselues cittie armoure whiche tolde numantines thoughte inflamed anger greate desire libertie bycause neuer bin acquainted obey taken rage furie killed auarus companyethe numantines kill vvent peace bringers euill newes conspiring scipio saue themselues long victualls faylyng hauing neyther fruite cattell hearbes firste eat leather mollifiedthe necessity body beastes meate eate therfore killed hunger consumed pestilence hear beardes horrible length yeelded scipio whiche commaunded daye bring armour place appointed next day come themselues another place assigned deferred daye confessing yet many city loue libertie would end liues sword famine numantines kil themselues desired time kill themselues greate loue libertie gret vertue barbarous litle citie whiche flourished peace wer eight thousand good men whiche thinges done againste romanes euident many league made lyke equall condition coulde neuer brought doe nation captaine generall neede rehearse yet scipio fielde lx men many time prouoked numantines fight scipio better wyser general thoughte good deale wylde men force armes conquere famine whiche thing uitable whiche euill numantines coulde bee taken thing say numantines consider small number sufferaunce labour noble actes long inuincible therefore numantines determined dyu rslye killed themselues reste thirde daye came place appointed al vgly filthie horrible beholde bodiesa pitiful yelding numantines foule full heare wyth long nayles full filth stincke worne garment euill sauoures whiche thinges miserable ennimies yet feareful looke vpon therefore beholden romaine wyth admiration considering straunge affection theyr body felt ayre dolour labour whiche suffred also conscience one eaten anothers fleshe scipio choosing oute pompe hys tryumphe commaunded solde cittie vtterly destroyed generall romanes two city taken harde wonne carthage greatnesse cittie power thereof decree romaine preserued commodity lande sicilie afflicted second seruile war sent army spaine bicause war would haue lieutenats go pacifie al wel could cimbrians wer repulsed tit didius wet thither killed twenty thousand aruacceans brought termentum great cittie whichtermentum scarcely would euer obey romanes strong place scituated plaine willing dwel house dispersed wythout wals besieged city called colenda tooke ninth moneth siege therefore didius minding kyll consent x men hym told captain would ioyne land countryman bicause need offer whe perceyued accepted bad tel people mighte come wiues child diuide land came willed praying might restored syria cilicia antiochus taken hym romanes gladly tooke pretence comming good seasonambassadours ptolomie egipt sente ambassadoures antiochus shewe reconcile ptolomeus antiochus indeed espy meaning antiochus hinder muche might c eu ambassadour required antiochus ptolomeus friend romanes romanes sed ambassador antiochus might enioy kingdome father lefte citties asia philip macedonie hadde taken might free iuste antiochus would enioy place romanes take philip finally said bee doubted antiochus bring nauye armye medium asia sea inuade europe builde citties subdue thracia lay platthe ansvvere antiochus another warre answered thracia belonged ancestor lacke quietnesse reuolted nowe hauing leysure recouered restored lysimachia dwelling son seleuchus would leaue city asia free would thanke romanes ptolomie quoth kinsman shortly shal father law wil cause giue thankes doe doubt also right romanes meddle asia since doe deale italy thus breaking vppe without anye conclusion vttereda report death ptolomie manifest threatnings one againste another reported thought ptolomeus dead wherfore antiochus went speed toward egipt get kingdom voide prince ephesus annibal carthage came fleeing country hate enimies accusing romanes contentious seeking warre coulde liue rest carthaginenses agree romaynes confederate antiochus receyued annibal gloriouslye fame shippes diuerse men friend sayled seleucia syria repaired shaken nauie made mariage child antiochus laodice ioyning matr onye nowe bycause knewe euident warre woulde folowe betweene romanes allied himselfe wyth kyngs neighboures sent cleopatra called syra ptolomei antiochus maketh allyance vvith neyghbours giuyng coelosyria hir dowry whiche hee taken hym please young man hee mighte quiete war romanes antiochida hee sent ariarathes king cappadocia lefte eumenes king pergamo enimies refuse alliaunce perceyuing meante make warre vpon romanes purpose would make affinitie refuse brother attalus philetayrus dyd maruel reiected alliaunce greate king hys neyghbour seeking aunswered lyke war would beginning woulde equall side time romanes woulde ouercome good condition taking paine quoth romanes conqu rors shal hold kingdom surely antiochus ouercommeth feare al wil taken away neighboure feare haue kyngdome muste kyng vnder consideration refuse mariage antiochus straight went thence hellespont sayled helespont th streight alip cherronesus subdued ouerthrewe manye place thracia made free grecian inhabite thracia granted many thing byzantine hauing cittie verye commodious bizane novv
