ionia lose tribute deale certain asia forgo thracia euer bin hys progenitor whiche thing friendes conquerours commaunde conquered senate perceyuing comming espiall shortelye aunswered antiochus suffer greeke citties asia free refraine europe shall friende romanes ansvvere romanes thus romanes answered made none shewe cause antiochus minding firste inuade grecia begin warre againste romanes asked annibals opinion thethe opinion anniball touching vvarre matter saide grecia easy ouercome bycause long affliction war made home moste grieuous dearth followeth abroade tollerable neither ouercome romanes grecia seeing myght haue sufficient prouision helpe home therefore opinion inuade romanes italy whether went shoulde fynd romanes weaker home abroade haue saide experience italy x men take fitte place write friend carthage stir people reuolte sory angry romanes full hope hart wyll thinke againe get italy king hearing aduice well thinking accesse carthage make muche furtheraunce thys warre badde hym send letter hys friendes eute hande hee sente thoughte sure romaynes lying wayte euery war yet proclaymed many discord carthage common wealth hauing firmenesse certentie shortly destruction carthage yet sent ariston merchant tyrus vnder pretence marchandise friendes exhorting anniball sendeth ariston practice carthage vnderstoode inuaded italy stirre people carthage reuenged ariston annibals enimies perceyued aristons purpose made much adoe innouation shoulde followe diligently sought ariston friendes anniball beare blame secretely night sette vp athe deuice ariston saue annibals friend writing common house whiche anniball exhorted senate reuenge countrey vnder antiochus done sayled away daye come suspition taken annibals friend bycause matter belonged state people ful vprore angry romanes able hurte thus went matter carthage romanes sente embassador scipio scipio goeth embassadour antiochus ouercame carthagies proue king minde espie preparation founde king gone pisidia tarried returne ephesus meane pisidia countrey asia nigh ycaonia pamphilia time many time talke anniball seeing carthage league antiochus yet manifest enimie blamed would flee countrey seing romanes offended carthagies since league made make anniball suspected king deede ofte resorting anniball brought suspition vvith antiochus talking though anniball circumspect man yet foresee king heard suspected anniball ready trust beside enuie hatred grewe againste least heenuie haue prayse thing done among otherthe talke anniball scipio touching best captayne talkes say one betweene scipio anniball scholehouse many learne presente heare touching excellencie captayne whereas scipio asked whome thoughte best captayne answered alexander macedonia scipio stayed gaue place alexander asked whome hee thought second next alexander sayde pirrhus epirota putting vertue captayne boldenesse found couragious kyng hee scipio greeued againe asked whome thoughte bee thirde thinking verily woulde haue named aunswered selfe beeing yong man subdued spayne mine armie passed alpes italy firste hercules haue done inuaded none durst doe thyng ouerthrewe foure hundred townes broughte youre citie many time daunger hauing neyther money men sent carthage scipio perceyued dyd purpose aduance himselfe smyled sayde place wouldest thou haue put thy selfe anniball thou hadst bin ouercome perceyuing emulation sayde woulde haue set selfe alexander dyd anniball continue lofty talke yet secretely please scipio making hym better alexander thys talke ended anniball desired scipio hys lodging scipio sayde woulde come gladly cause suspition betweene antiachus romanes thus noble captaynes ended theyr malice warremalice endeth vvhen watter cesseth ended dyd flaminius antiochus ouercome anniball fledde sauing himselfe bithinia sente embassadour purpose prusia iniured anniball commaunded romanes feared bycause power carthage abated kylled poyson prusias consente whyche sayde hee warned oracle thys sort lande libyssa shall couer annibals bodyoracle annibals death thoughte shoulde haue dyed libya libyssus alybissus floud bithinia countrey called libyssa floud remembrance haue made noble myndes ofnoble mind anniball scipio cowardly heart flaminius antiochus comming pisidia towarde ephesus gaue audience embassadoures rhodians promised rhodians byzantine cyzioneans greeke city asia shoulde free entred league romanes aet lean ionian would grant bycause part bin vsed obey barbarous king asia romane embassadoures bringing nothing passe came doe thyng deede espie returned rome embassador aetolians came antiochus whiche thoas chiefe offering leading theyr armie wishing woulde sayle grecia sure thing tarrying hys armie come high asia settyng forthe theyr owne strength promised ayde antiochus persuaded aetolians lacedemonians philip kyng macedonie angry romanes hee woulde make hys voyage wyth speede hee moued lightely woulde stay hast although hearde asia hys sonne dead tenne thousande sayled eub ia whyche gotte yeelding feare micithion captayne setting micithio killeth romanes romanes killed delos aminander king athamanes people aetolia megalopoli one arcadia another asia counterfet philip vpon romanes delos whyche holy place apollo kylled part part toke alyue aminander kyng athamanes came league antiochus occasion one alexander maecedonia beeing brought vp megalopoli made free common wealth fayned himselfe come alexander sonne philip gyue credite hys deuice named hys child philip alexander apamea whome married amynander philip hir brother going hir marriage perceyuing amynander weake man little experience remayned wyth hys brother lawe gouerne kyngdome philip antiochus promised restore kingdome macedony owne meane athamaneans confederate also thebanes wente thebe speake people thus rashly great war put trust aetolians thebanes amynader consulted whether better inuade thessaly hand tarrie till winter past anniball consultation saying nothing king comaunded say opinion first thus spake thou mayest easilie ouercome thessalian eyther anniball shevveth opinion touching vvarre winter people hauing bin much vexed turne thee doe romanes innouation commeth come owne power giuing credite aetolians persuasion lacedemonians philip take part lacedemonians enimies heare acheans philip see great ayde vnto thee warre thy side make great power whatsoeuer part taketh mine aduise thou sendest thine army speede asia put thy trust amynader aetolians army come send italy beeing occupyed trouble home may leaue vntouched afraide themselues may vexe men manner held v spake afore must vse one halfe oure na ie wast coast italy halfe must haue flote vse occasion shall require thy selfe thy footemen must remaine part grecia next italy making shewe inuasion neede inuade indeede induce philip meanes possible agree thee shall much auayle part taketh warre bee broughte thou shalt sende thy sonne seleucus thracia molest euils home profitable thine enimies abroade thus anniball said best enuie fame wisedome well king himselfe anniball shoulde seeme passe arte warre haue prayse shoulde done hys counsell reiected sauing polyxenides sent asia polyxenides army romanes hearde entring antiochus grecia killing taking romanes delus determined warre thus antiochus romanes warrethe vvarre beginneth growing long suspition one another firste breake deede bycause antiochus rule many nation high asia inhabite sea coast sauing fewe entred europa hadde dreadfull name greate preparation otherwise hadde done many notable thing gotten name greate romanes thoughte warre would daungerous long continuance philip macedome suspition ouercome long league cartheginians great trust anniball antiochus subiects doubt least glory antiochus make seeke new attemptes therefore sen e garrison euery one gouerneconsuls proconsul officer sixe ax peaceable manner sente captaynes armyes whome call sixe axies bycause consul hadde twelue twelue roddes olde kyngs vsed bycause officer halfe authoritie hadde halfe theforesight rhodians shewe greate feare carefull italy least disturbance mighte happen eyther violence fauour antiochus sente greate bande footemen tarento bee ready assayes nauie sayled ouer coast great feare antiochus first hadde thus home giuen order thing begynning gathered theyr army againste antiochus themselues hadde twenty thousand theyr confederate twice many whyche woulde passe ionia thys preparation spente whole winter antiochus wente thessalia come vnto cynoch phalia macedonian hadde greate ouerthrowe cynochephalia place people like dogges head antiochus b e h dead romanes honorably buryed th se laye vnburyed thynkyng thereby winne macedonian withdrawe philip hadde lefte hys souldyoures vnburyed serued vnder hys standerd philip hearyng thys greate perplexitie wyth hymselfe whyche parte shoulde take yet dyd cleaue romanes streyghte sente bebius captayne romanes bebius lying farre come hym certayne place assuring hym hee woulde take romanes parte kyng whyche bebius thanking hym theappius bolde sende appius claudius macedonte thessaly two thousande footemen appius tempe perceyued antiochus lay wyth army tempe pleasant place muche praysed poet antiochus remoueth caught loue vvhen vvas aboue fiftie yeares age calcide novv negroponte made many fyres couer fewnesse hys armye antiochus thynkyng bebius philip hadde bene come togyther afrayde brake vp hys campe making winter pretence wente calcida hee caughte wyth loue mayde beeyng aboue fiftye yeares age hauyng greate warre hande hee woulde needes marry hyr make pastymes whereby hee broughte hys armye greate ydlenesse change winter spring come hee wente arnania arnania parte epir bringing foorth good horse perceyued hys armye vtterly vnprofitable ydlenesse repented hym hys marriage feasting hee hadde gotten countrey hys obedience subdued rest hearing roman passed ionia hee returned chalcide romanes wyth diligence two thousande good horseman thirtie thousande footemen elephantes acinius manius glabrie beeyng generall brunduse arriuing acinius manius glabrio appolonia novv allona appolonia wente thessalie delyuered city theyr enimies founde garrison macedonian put philippus magalopolis taken prisoner hopyng yet kingdome macedonia tooke three thousande antiochus men whyles manius philip inuaded athamania made subiect amynander fleeing ambracia whyche antiochus hearde speedy doyng thyngs hee feare bycause suddayne change alteration vnderstoode annihall gaue hym good counsell therefore hee sente one another polyxenida stirre speede hee gathered many hee coulde place thys done hee hadde owne footemen tenne thousande fyue hundred horse wyth whyche confederate tooke thermopyle hys enimies might haue harder passage hee tarrie hys armye asia thermopyle streighte long passage whyche thermopyle long ill grecia vvhere streight passage ho e vvaters tichiunta callid mu rough sea withoute porte dothe partly compasse fenne deepe without way two toppes hathe rockes hylles one called tichiunta callidromus place hathe welles h te water thereof called thermopyle antiochus made wall double placed engine wall sente aetolians toppes mountaynes man shoulde passe called atropos xerxes came agaynste leonida thexerxes leonida captayne l cedemonians man kepte hylles tolians placed one thousande eyther toppe wyth rest beseeged citie heraclea heraclea many city name manius perceyued thys preparation enimies hee gaue order fyghte nexte morning commaunded two hys tribune marcus cato lucius valerius shoulde assayle nyghte whychethe order romanes hylles woulde coulde dryue tolians toppes lucius repulsed ti hiunta tolians beeyng good hym marcus cato wente cato dothae great fea e againste callidram passed enimies asleepe last watche hadde greate conflict striuing gette high rocky place enimies keepe hym backe manius ledde hys armye face antiochus diuided small bandes coulde doe streightes kyng commaunded lighte harnessed target men fyghte mayne battell whyche hee placedthe order king battell camp righte side sette slinger archer hygh place elephantes lefte syde bande euer hym wylled stande sea side fyghte begunne shotte running hyther thyther dyd muche trouble manius hee esisting manfullyheere italian misseth doth latine gyuing backe agayne commyng hee put e flighte battell macedonian opening themselues receyued closed agayne thrust forthe theyr long pykes togyther order thys manner lacedemontans vnder alexander philip dyd troublethis vvas called phalanx macedonian legion among romanes enimies r approche pykes long many suddayne seene fleeing cry aetolians dryuen antiochus campe whyche firste knowen whyche ignorance caused trouble doubte till cato appeared followyng wyth greate shoute beeyng come kyngs campe antiochus menne hadde hearde muche romanes valiantnesse afrayde acknowledgedthe fight vvas first made betvveene romanes antiochus theyr owne ydlenesse delicatenesse wynter passed cause thys time worse doe theyr office seeyng perfitlye number cato hadde feare thinking beyng afrayde campe fledde order keepe away enimie romanes comming vppon entred campe wyth another oule fleeyng antiochus menne manius followed scarpheia killing taking comming scarpheia scarpheia king cape spoyled spoyled kyngs campe droue aetolians romanes campe taken absence presently fighte slaine romanes twoo hundred folowed chase antiochus lost tenne thousand taken king himselfe thethe king flyeth first change ranne fiue hundred horse velatia neuer staying velatia calcida ephesus eubia velatia yong vv e olde antiochus newe wyfe hir name shippes ledde admirall romanes taken came laden victual rome victorie heard seeming happily speedily obtained gaue thankes god men beyng gladde firste triall good successe warre fearful fame antiochus requite philip true confederacte sent histhe romanes gratifye phillip sonne demetrius pledge marius released phoceans calcideans followed antiochus feare tolians togither phillip inuaded ouerthrewe citties tooke damocritus damocritus generall hidden threatned flaminius would encampe tiber went calipolis hyll called coraca highest callipolis cittie e also hardest passed al verye rockye army laden spoil many fell harde way intothe romanes passe hilles laden losse stony partes tumbled downe armor burden tolians might haue troubled appeared sent ambassadours rome peace antiochus greate diligence called hys armye land ruler sea side preparing nauye whyche polixenides outlawe rhodes admiral ayled polixanides admiral king cherronesu fortified sent garrison sestus abydus whiche romanes muste passe asia made lysimachia store house warre bringing thither muche armoure victualls thinking romanes would soone great power na rom aynes appoynted l scipio brother publi publi scipio sent assa scipio ouercame carthage fyrste named affricanus successoure nius thys warre beeing consull bycause hee practised experienced warre sente hys brother wyth hym counselloure brother prepared themselues liuius hadde chardge italy sente successoure att lio nauye strayght wyth owne shyppes whiche hee scowred coaste itali certaine lent carthagies friendes hee sayled pirae receyuing nauye atilius carthagies lende shippes romanes ircu wyth fourescore one armed shyppes e menes followyng hym wyth fyftye hys owne halfe beeyng armed arryued phocida subiect antiochus feare receyued nexte daye wente foorthe fight sea polixenides admirall antiochus came foorthe wyth two hundred shyppes lighter enimy whych happy greate shyppes romaynes beeyng yet practised seeyng twoo carthagies commyng hee tookethe fight sea bothe wyth three hys emptye lybians beeing leapte sea liuius great vehemence gaue fyrste charge vppon three wyth hys admirall ship goyng far afore rest nanye earing thys one shyppe dyd caste theyr hooke yron shyps beeing grapled togither seemed fyght vpon lande romanes beeyng valyant bourded ouercame wyth one ship carrying awaye twoo returned th skirmishe fyghte whole nauyes foughte togyther romaynes beeyng better strength courage bycause heauinesse theyr vessells coulde ouertake lyghte shyppesthe romaine haue victori sea fledde whyche dydde wyth speede ephesus romanes went xio whither seuen twenty rhodian shippes theyr friend came antiochus hearde thys fyghte sea hee sente annibal sent shippes seth part annibal syria shyppes phoenitia cilicia came rhodians droue pamphilia taking parte hys shyppes lying wayte publius scipio came aetolia consull hauingcourage scipio armye manius hee disdayned make siege citties aetol small matter gaue leaue sende another ambassage rome hee would trye antiochus brother office shoulde ende passed macedonia thracia hellesp n whyche paynefull harde waye vnto hym notwithstanding phillippe macedonie guide hym making brydges preparing victual twoo scipions released philip released hym reste money hadde paye order senate founde hym faithful sente prusias kyng bythinia declaryng howe manye kyngs romaynes hadde aduaunced confederate nowe philippe macedonie whome ouercome late graunted kingdome restored sonne pledge forgaue mony oughte prusias hearde ioyned antiochus prusias ioyneth vvith romaine liuius admirall romane nauye heard scipions commyng left pausimachus rhodiane rhodian ship aeolide parte owne n uy withsc u rh ion al rest sailed hellespont receiue army sestus rhateion porte acheans yeelded byd disobeyed besieged liuius gone pausimachus made manye diuises inuentions sundry engine fastened yron vessells carrying fyre long shippe staues heaue vppe manye fyres sea caste oute owne shippes hee shoulde ioyne ennimyes while thus deuising polyxenides admirall ofa false countrey man antiochus radian also banished hys countrey certayne cause went aboute deceyue hym promising deliuer hym antiochus nauy woulde helpe restore hym hys countrey suspected crafty subtil man tooke good heede polyxenides didde write letter hys owne hande treason departed ephesus sent army forragyng fashion pausimachus seeyng hys departure thence trusting man treason woulde wryte hys owne hande whych lyke done dissembler gaue credite kept lesse guarde sent men forrage abroade also polyxenides perceyued deceyued gathered hys army sent nicander pirate wyth fewe samos come vpon pausimachus backe lande mydnyghte set forwarde mornyng watche beyng asleepe hee assayled hym taken thus sodainelye vnprepared commaunded hys souldioures leaue shippes resiste enimy lande nicander came vpon thethe rodian shippes distroyed falshode backe thinking land beset also onely hee sawe many mo beyng yet night returned agayne hys shyppes wyth muche adoe firste fought firste fell vsing himselfe valiauntlye eyther taken suncke sauing seauen carryed fyre wyth whome none durste meddle flame fledde rest polyxenides ledde awaye pry ephesus thys victorye phocea againe samos cyme reuolted cyme aeolia ochus liuius beyng nowe afraide hys shyppes hee lefte aeolide sayled thither haste eumenes hym rodians sent romanes twentye shyppes making delaye wyth good courage sayled ephesus preparing themselues fight none came lefte halfe shippes good time sea halfe spoyled coaste enimie tyl nicander romanes driuen shippes came vppon lande taking praye droue shippes came samos nowe time liuius office expired tyme seleucus antiochus sonne inuaded eumenes eumenes besieged lande besieged pergamo shutting men within cittie wherefore eumenes sayled wyth speede elaea whyche porte towne kyngdome l aemilius regulus wyth succeeded liuius matter sea came eumenes hys confederats one thousand footemen adiophanes hundred choise horseman whose generall diophanes hee perceyued souldiours seleucus play drinke passed little required pergameneans sally vpon enimy durste armed hys thousandthe valiantnesse acheans footemen hundred horseman leading wall stoode quietly enimies lookyng stil vpon yet durst set vpon dinner gaue ye onset vpo ye warder arming theseluesthe covvardi pergama taking horse fleeing folowed beeing confusion durste abide hadde noble victorie pergamenians cry oute wall yet durste come foorth hauing slaine manye coulde shorte onset carying away horse men prisoner tooke hys place next day brought acheans wal pergamenians durste yet come seleucus many horseman drewe neare prouoked hym hee stoode still wall kept charge seleucus hadde tarryed tyll middaye hee tourned seleucus king sonne wente awaye diophanes set vppon hindermost scattered hurte many whyche beeyng done hee retired wall vsyng thys manner continuallye alwaies laying wayte went forrage wood troubled made seleucus leaue pergam droue hym place eumenes betweene romanes polyxenides long myonesus lie ephesus fyght sea myones whiche polixenides hadde ten hundred armed shippes lucius romanes admirall hadde whiche fyue twenty rhodians whereof eudorus beyng capitaine left wing see polixenides much aboue romanes feared bee inclosed therefore sayled aboute lighte shippes well practised sea shippes carryed fyre set vppon polixenides flaming euery side fire durste deale wyth bicause fire circle sayled auoyding keeping seathe fight sea stroke side till one rhodian shippe fell vppon one sydonian shippes wyth suche vehemence anker fell sidonian shyppe rhodian helde faste togither fight shyppes mouing bin vpon lande commyng either side many helpe fellowe noble fyghte ane th midde battell shyppes antiochus beyng lefte naked romaynes sayled forwarde enclosed theyr vnexperte ennimyes whyche perceyued turned fledde whyche king loste nine twentye whereof thyrteene taken menne romanes loste twoo polixenides hauyng taken one rhodian went ephesus fyghte sea myonesium antiochus heard fortified cherronesus lysimachia verye stronglye thinking greate matter indeede heepe romanes passyng wyth theyr armye reste thracia shoulde haue harde painefull way except philip conuey antiochus beyng y lighte soone chaunging hearde losse myonesus hee vlterlye dysmayed thoughte god againste hym romanes hadde better sea beyonde reason whiche thought himselfe mighty anni al shutte vppe pamphilia philip conducting romaynes vnknowne wayes whome thoughte woulde rather haue remembred hurte hadde thinges beeingin calamity sense fayleth meruellously troubled god taking wi hym commonly hapneth calamity left cherronesus fondly enimies sighte regarding howe greate preparation victuall armoure money antiochus giueth ouer munition whyche hee dydde burne lefte whole ennimyes forsooke lysimachians thoughe cittie hadde bene taken whyche fledde vnto hym theyr wiues child weeping onelye hys care keepe romaynes abydus putting reste abydus asia ouer stus europe hope thys warre altogyther neyther dydde hee keepe passage god taking sense hym went midde lande ha e preuente hys ennimye leauing guarde scipions hearde thys departure went lysimachia haste tooke armoure money cherroneso quicklye passed hellespont voyde defence came sardies kyng perceyued hee confounded vtterlye deiected laying hys owne faultes vppon fortune hee sente heraclides byzance scipions make ende warre granico floud little asia offering smyrna alexandria granico lampsaco whiche warre beeganne halfe expences warre hee willed neede graunte citties ionian eoleans tooke romaynes parte thys warre whatsoeuer thyng scipions antiochus seeketh peace woulde require thys wylled heraclides speake penty ut priuatelye offer publius scipio promise much money antiochus also libertye hys sonne antiochus taken grecia sayling calcide tohere author seemeth take one another scipio yonger prisoner antiochus diametriade son scipio tooke destroyed carthage seconde time seconde man named affricanus sonne paulus ouercame perseus macedonia beyng scipio sister sonne degree hys sonne adoption scipions openly made thys aunswere heraclide antiochus haue peace muste leaue citties ionia aeolia countrey aboute taurus defraye whole charge warre whiche hath bin cause yet priuatelye publius saide thus antiochus offered condition peace hee hadde lysimachia cherronesus romanes woulde willinglye haue accepted peraduenture hadde forbidde onely passe hellespont nowe vppon landethe romaine haue bridle horse safe place hadde onely bridle say also mounted horse bridle woulde accept suche condition wordes giue kyng thankes hys great offer woulde gyue hym greater sent sonne present time would wysh take condition beefore driuen proofe greater burden publius hadde saide thus went elaea healthe leauing cneus domitius legate brother antiochus phillippe macedonie thinking coulde taken hym war propounded gathered armye plaine uf thyatira farre hys enimies sente scipio sonne elaea bee counselled elaea ile propontide tovvne e ld bringers kyng shoulde fighte tyll hee came againe campe antiochus giuing credite hym encamped hill sipyl defenced hys campe wyth strong wall put floud phryg betweene enimies domitius desirous trie fight himselfe passed floud boldly going within two myle halfe antiochus encamped foure dayes togither either set men order camp neyther beginning fight fifth day domitius set order againe came forth proudely antiochus came remoued camp nigher one day beeing past proclaymed hearing enimies hee would next day fight whether antiochus woulde hee antiochus prouoked fight troubled changed purpose might haue kept within camp manfully resist till publius come thought shame refuse fighte number wherefore toke order battell came forth last watch yet nighte eyther thus arayed themselues tenne thousand romane footemen helde left wing floud tenne thousande italian three seuerall band italian army eumenes placed target men achaia three thousand leftthe order romanes battell right horseman romanes italian eumenes three thousand mixed light armed archer domitius foure bandes horseman made thirtie thousand domitius ledde right battell middle placed consull left battell committed eumenes elephant libya thoughte toelephants libya lesse india afraide greater purpose lesse libya afrayde greater therefore sette last romanes order antiochus armye l x whiche surest macedonian battaile called phalanx conteining xvj menthe phalanx macedonia firste appointed alexander philip standeth middest diuided thousand sixe hundred ten part euery parte front fifty men middest two thirtie side eyther part two twety sight phalanx like wall elephats seemed like tower midde battel antiochus horseman eyther side men armes galatian choyce horseman macedonia called agema equally eyther side greate agema signifieth exercised battell horseman footemen vvent captayne tro mi people france inhabit asia vvent galatia bithynia battell wing beside righte wing light armed souldioures horseman siluer shieldes archer horsebacke two hundred lefte wing helde nation galatian tectosagans trocmans tolistouians certaine cappadocians whome ariarathes sente stranger mingled ioyned another company men armes hys confederate lighte armour order made antiochus seeming put trust horseman whome many placed front vnskilfully hee thrust greate battell streighte place whiche hee ought haue put trust strong also greate number inger archer darter target men phrygian lydian pamphylians pisidians crete trallians cilicians armed seleucus gouerned phalanx philip maister elephant charge foreward medis z x day cloudy darke sight taken away ofshot hindered moyst ayre preparation bowes worse aire moist thicke eumones considered passed rest feared violence armed chariot therefore gathered togither archer dariers lighte harnesse commaunding goe againste chariot shoote agaynste horse men horse chariot striuing hys yoke rest chariot made vnprofitable many time breaketh battels men afrayne sithes came passe horse stricken thicke chariot carried backe horse camel felte disorder first next carte men armes whose horse waighte armourethe chariot vvere armed vvith ythes could hardly escape danger sithes great trouble confusion diuers beganne chiefly wet whole battell ignorace needed long rowe thicke multitude men diuers crie greate feare truth perceyued next hurt person suspition made euery man thinke thing greater eumenes see firste succeede happily foreward chariot camel couer naked set owne horseman many romanes italian contrary part galatian cappadocians route stranger exhorting loude voice dispatch ignorant men destitute defence ready giuing fierce onset vpon made th turne ye men armes ioyned disordred ye chariot bicause coulde hardly flee turne reason theyr waight tooke killed done left battell macedonian right wing antiochus antiochus iside putteth romanes flight breaking battell romanes made flee followed great battell macedonian sette horseman streight place guadrate voyde horseman eyther side receyued skirmisher fought front diuiding themselues closing againe domitius horseman lighte harnesse easilie compassed thicke square neither fitte gyue onset enlarge themselues broad manfully abode much force greeued experiece could good stand receyue stripe wound enimies euery side stretched forthe pike square manner chalenged romanes trie manhoode hand hande hadde much prayse yet march forth fote heauie harnessed seing enimies horse chiefly dissolue sure aray romanes came vpon woulde fight fearing experience strength valiant men running aboute dyd shoote dart neuer missed many closed little roome neyther could auoyde dartes approch threw vpon wherefore endured long time necessitie gaue backe turned way threat orderly fearefull romanes neither durst sette vpon hurte could go till elephant brake vppon macedonian battell whiche woulde ruled bythe mayne battell difordred elephant guide orderly retiring altered domitius vpper hand passing campe antiochus forced kepte antiochus chaced domitius entreth king camp romane legion great way neither horseman light harnesse gard domitius thinking shoulde neede bycause floud till came romanes campe antiochus chacern one part romanes camp captaine charge fresh souldiours resisted violence ioyned edde bolder king returned proude haulte victorie nothing knowing yet happened side attalus brother eumenes wyth many horseman encountred king whiche passed hurte keeping course losse caring see losse field full dead people men horse elephant camp taken force fledde without ceassing came sardeis aboute midnight sardeis celaena whychecelaena call apamea whither hee vnderstoode hys sonne fledde next daye went celaena syria leauing hys captaines celaena receyue gather togither fledde sent ambassadoures consull ceasse war burying dead souldiors spoyling enimies gathering captiues romanes cittie slaine foure twentye horseman three hundred footemen chiefly whome antiochus slewe eumenes loste fifteen horseman kyngs losse hys confederate iudged fiftie thousand could well numbred multitude elephant slaine saue fifteene taken thys victorie noble beyonde reason thoughte beyng lyke fewe straunge country ouercome many especially macedonian phalanx furnished full men whiche valiauntnesse terrible thought inuincible friendes antiochus accused rashenesse falling romaine vnskilfulnesse foolishnesse beginning lefte cherronesus lysimachia oute hys handes full munition money thethe errours antiochus romanes came alande trye neglected guarding hellespont whiche romanes thoughte could easlye passe force blamed also last ouersight making chief strength vnprofitable plaeing streight putting trust mingled multitude men fresh soloures men experience time acquainted warre continuaunce endued valiauntnesse courage speech made antiochus romanes encreased incourage thought nothing harde bothe vertue fauoure god make opinion felicitie many expedition first fight straunge land ouercome one daye many nation princely power vertue hired soldioures glorie macedonian great dominion king hadde gotten surname great speeche talke king antiochus great greate word among romanes thus gloried themselues consul brother publius come recouered elaea answered antiochus ambassador required learne antiochus shoulde friend romanes publius answered thus vnto antiochus hathe bin cause bothe former troublesansvvere king ambassadours thorowe hys ambition hauing greate kyngdome romanes suffring haue tooke ptolomie hys kinsman friend romanes caelesyria inuaded europe nothing subdued thracia fortified cherronesus builded lysimachia came grecia made grecian bond romanes made free til ouercome battaile thermopylei whence though fled lefte ambition ouercome diuerse tymes v sea passed hellespont desired peace condition whereof throughe pride contemned gathered mighty army gret preparation made war againe againste v compulsion broughte trye better till ouercome hys greate losse fitte set greater punishement vpon manye tymes hathe violentlye dealte romanes wil insolet felicitie aggrauate others calamitie therefore giue condition appointed adding fewe whiche profytable v shall commodious safety tyme come refraine al europe asia side taurus condition peace limites shall appointed deliuer al elephantes hath many ship shall commaunde hereafter haue elephant ship shall appoint deliuer xx pledge president shall prescribe giue expences warre begun hym fiue hundred talent euboea presentlye senatethe least talent vvas lx shal approue league ij v c talent xij yeares xij v c talent parte whereof broughte rome euerye yeare giueth v prisoner bondman restore eumenes oughte league betweene attalus father antiochus wil faithfully performe giue peace friendship senate shal ratifie thus scipio determine ambassadoures accepted paide parte mony hande deliuered twenty pledge whereof antiochus king yonger sonne one whome scipioni antiochus son sent rome sente rome ambassadours senate agreed condition subscribed confirmation peace made scipio thynges determined made little addition two forelandes called calycadnum sarpedon shouldthese cilicia limite antiochus kingdome doe passe niake warre keepe twelue armed ship onely rule subiectes obedience warre made vpon vse harborowe romanes receiue fugitiues change pledge euery iij yeares sonne excepted written sette vppe table brasse capitoll couenants peace placed coppy sent manlio volsoni successour scipio gaue othe tomanlius volso antiochus ambassadours apamaae phrygia antiochus thermo tribune sente hym thys ende warre betwene romanes antiochus called great seemed obtained kindenesse hee shewed scipio restoring hys sonne accused scipio two tribune noted hym corruption prodition hee despysyngscipio accused contemning accusation come court daye afore ouerthrowne carthage sent make sacrifice capitoll came himselfe pallaice judgement goodly shew sad mourning like accused man euery man wondring fauouring hym worthye man greate courage cleare consciencethe courage scipio beganne speake saide nothing accusation made rehearsall life seruice al act howe manye warres finished countrey whome ouerthrowne howe ofte victorye muche pleasure earers noble declaration historie came warre carthage delated manner thereof wyth great vehemence audience people saying daye romanes conquere made carthage obey til terrible vnto day goe sacrifice capitoll many loue country accompany sacrifice made hauing saide thus went forth capitoll passing complainte people followed manye judge praysing open voice saide like while sacrificing accuser discoraged durst prosecute cause purpose blame people fauoure perceyuing life price suspition calumniation scipio seemeth wise stoute behauioure contempte accusation aristides beeing accused aristides constant scipio socrates fraude socrates thinges whereof hee charged neyther answering like discredite sauing socrates speaketh pleaseth plato yea couragious epiminondas ruler booetians pelopida thebanes hadde sente gyuing either armye helpe areadians senians warre laconian bycause thynges done entended accused called home deliuered army successoures sixe moneths whiche time expelled lacedemonian garrison placed arcadian epaminondas compelling companion doe promising doyng therof shoulde hurtefull come home accuser prosecuting matter againste euerye condemned dye lawe iudged hym die violence would rule man office escaped vsing lamentation many wordes laying al blame epaminondas willed say would affyrme condemned dye saide confesse againste lawe rule thys tyme compelled whome epaminondas ne ansvvere haue deliuered nowe desire pardoned hauing transgressed lawe beseeche seruice haue done woulde wr ie thus gote victorie l nitra brought countrey sparta selfe whiche coulde abide enimies straunger ware lacedemonian hatte condemned countrey offending lawe benefite countrey hauing saide thus came tribune offered bodye woulde take judge reproch thys speeche maruell answere reuerence person accused durste abide triall ran court euery man may iudge listeth manlius successor scipio went lande taken antiochus gaue order galathians tolestouij vvere people came spaine dvvell bithinia aided antiochus called tolestouians fleeing mysios olymp followed painefully thorough mountaines killed chase suche slaughter bloudshed could numbred multitude tooke prisoner fortie thousand burned armour solde body nexte barbarian bycause coulde carry suche company aboute warre tectosagans trocmans put daunger deceite mo ius dager whiche escaped returning againe vppon remayning staying bycause many brought shotte commaunding discharge vppon neither togither nighe enimie arrow shot vaine thickenesse enimies slewe eighte aly flond running taurus thousande chased flonde alys ariarathes kyng cappadocia confederate antiochus afraide praying peace prayer sending two hundred talentes didde ouerrunne hys lande wente hellespont greate rich infinite moneythe error muche spoile armye laden surely vnwisely sommer woulde go sea regarding waighte carriage coulde leade hys army continewe abide long iorney marching war going home spoyles went thracia streight long harde waye hote sommer neither sende philip macedonie conducte neither diuided army many part might go lighter readye purpose distributing burden seueral band might better kepte caryed al togither beape long way middest neither went behind could helpe time lenath straightnesse way wherfore thracian setting vpo fl nks euery loste greate parte pray common treasure army reste saued himselfe macedonie well perceyued howe much pleasure philip shewed scipions howe muche antiochus e ed leauing cherronesus thus manlius wente macedonia thessalie thessalie epirus epirus sayled brunduse sending hys armye euery manne home went rome rhodians eumenes king pergamus aduauncing themselues seruice antiochus eumenes went rome rhodians sent ambassadours romanes gaue rhodians lycia caria whycherevvards g rhodians long tooke bycause hadde warre wyth perseus macedonie seemed enclined hym eumenes gaue resterevvard eumenes revvardes greekes taken antiochus excepte greekes payde anye tribute attalus father commaunded pay eumenes tribute paide antiochus forgaue graunted liue free thus romanes diuided conquest antiochus antiochus great dieth greate deade seleucus hys sonne succeedyng hym hee sente brother antiochus pledge rome putte hys sonne demetrius hys place antiochus come athens seleucus killed one heli rius aboute eumenes attalus droue heli ru oute kingdome whiche hee vsurped leutus killed restored antiochus haue hys friendshippe nowe growne suspition romanes thus antiochus sonne greate antiochus kyng syria syrian called notable bicause whe antiochus noble kingdome rauished others shewed natural king making league eumenes raigned ouer syria nation aboute mightilye made tymarxus lieutenaunt babylon heraclides hys treasourer beyng brother great fauour wyth hym made warre vppon artaxes king armenia whome hee hadde taken hee antiochus second dieth dyed leauing antiochus sonne nine yeares age father vertue syrian called eupater lysias broughtantiochus eup ter vppe child romanes heard antiochus deade soone little tyme gote great fame glad demetrius sonne seleucus brother antiochus notable nephew antiochus great cousin child pledge rome three twentye yeares age requyred admytted kyngdome neare denyed hym thinking good lustye young man shoulde raigne childes place vnderstanding manye elephantes syria shyps agreede sent ambassadoures kyll elephantes burne shippes grieuous thing see thosethe ship elephant b rned beastes tame rare killed ship bee sette fyre wyth whiche fighte one l ptines l dicia offended finding cneus octauius chiefe embassage athe romaine ambassadour killed schoole house kylled hym lysias buried hym demetrius comming againe senate desired onelye released ostageship put antiochus nowe antiochus beyng dead whiche coulde obtayne fledde awaye etrius flyeth rome priuily receyued gladlye syrian hee tooke kingdome vpon killed child lysias droue awaye heraclides killed timarchus resisting euill vsing babilonians whiche babilonians gaue ou name ter beginning demetrius hauing rule sent crowne tenne thousande crownes romanes thanke tyme hee pledge also leptines killed octauius accepted crown would take leptines reseruing quarrell againste syrian demetrius droue ariarathes oute kingdome putte demetrius putteth arisrathes ol fernes accounted hys brother thousand talentes romanes thinking good bothe brother shoulde rule togither gone ariobarzanes afterward ouercome mithridates king p nt warre mithridates followedoccasion vvarre vvith brid e occasion greatest variable made manye nation continuing fortie yeres whiche time many king syria little time yet descended royall bloude many change tumult foureteene yeares lucullus romane generall follow mithridates fleing tigranes magadates wente army help tigranes antiochus sonne antiochus good broughte syria whome syrian obeyed good lucullus fauoured auntient kinges pompey seeketh cause put king syria lucullus firste made warre tigranes put land wonne enuie auntient kingdomes pomp yus followed lucullus ouercame mithridates compelled tigranes rule armenia cast antiochus kingdome syria hauing offended romanes deede bycause easie thing armye spoyle king army pretence bycause seleucidians expelled tigranes reason rule syria longer captaynes bin commaunded commaunded deed thou commaundedst contrarye would heare greater among men king godgod guideth king ruler thy thy guide citie steade v ofteded v al nation thing stande stronger generation riseth vpon v citie shall happy mighty long continuing confirme thy pardon v haue erred feare losse priuate good wiseme sayd thus seleucus glad pardoned muche haue learned seleucia seleucus discouered loue kepte secreate modest mynde whiche antiochus woulde vtter nothing hym thoughe hee vsed gentle meanes learne secretly sate obserued mutation hys bodye howe stoode came finding hys body warre carthage sente helpe rome friendes romaine onely graunted gather men italy warre also doubtfull capitulation sent pacifye matter libyan would heare woulde make city subiect romaine would accept boorde hat shold seene knowen great knowen deuying make recompence wa decreed romanes whiche gaue sardinia payne written former condition long carthaginian aded spam gote little little till saguntines slaine iberia sayled th ther putting opinion men went god name vsed diuine counsel glorious victorie therfore gret r oume hedeliuered army sent successours went rome obtayned army sentcontention senate scipio going carthage libya driue annibal italie plague carthaginias countrey ruler citie spake bicause italy troubled wt gret war annibal yet wasting mago side hyring strage souldiers ligurie france good make war vpon libya inuade another country til present hurt healed home thought carthaginian whyche without feare ouertunne italie bycause vexed home warre made vppon woulde sende annibal thus obtained sende scipio libya suffering gather men italy yet wasted annibal graunting leade would willingly goe hym vse yet sicelie gyuing leaue prepare tenne gallies make supply thethe slender setting forth scipio great vvarre take sicelie money gaue none except man friendshippe would contribute vnto slenderly began warre first redounded great honour thus scipio inflamed god carthage gathering vij thousand horse footemen sayled sicelie hauing hymthe pollicie scipio arme italian guarde three hundred chosen yong stripling hee commaunded folow without armoure appointed three hundred wealthy sicilian come day assigned furnished good armour horse coulde come graunted would giue serue place content brought forth three hundred vnarmed willed chaunge willinglye deliuered horse harnesse scipio italian many sicilian well furnished goodly horse armoure gaue great thanks continually ready seruice carthaginian hearing sent asdrubal giscanes son ligurie part italie vvhich novv longeth genowais hunt elephant sent mago made men liguria sixe thousande footemen eight hundred horse seauen elephats commaunding many could scoure tuscane sea kepe scipio fro libya mago made hast bicause could ioyne annibal farre also euer foresaw end asdrubal coming r hunting gathered carthaginian libyan six thousand footemen either horse bought slaues row gallies horseman numidian hyred stranger trayned furlong carthage prince libya seuerall dominion al syphax gretest honour al men massinissa also sonne noble king high bloud massulia nourished brought vp carthage goodly body massinissa made sure sophinisba good behauiour asdrubal g sgo inferiour none carthage dispoused daughter though carthage numidian ensured carryed syphax loue vvitin sophoniba maketh vvarre vpon carthaginian allieth vvith scipio missinissa allieth vvith scipio sophinisba giue syphax yong man spaine captaine syphax loue de ded carthaginias made league spaine inuade carthage carthagini hearing thinking great furtherance anes war haue syphax ayde gaue virgin vnknowen asdru al massinissa spain massinissa disda ning also confeder scipio spaine keping secret thoughte asdrubal vnderstanding grieued iniury made daughter yong man yet thought beste countrey dispatche massinissa go libya iberia death father sent conducte commaunding secretely coulde kil massinissa perceyuing fledde gotte hys massinissa escapeth traynes father kingdome gathered horseman continuall exercise day night vsing wt much shot horsebacke giue onset retire charge againe fight consisting flying chasing hauing gathered twentye massinissa trayneth men thousande ledde hunting prayes nation thought make endure paynethe hardnes numidian labour numidian abide hunger vse herbes steade corne drinke water altogither horse neuer tastbarley alwayes eate grasse drinke seldome carthaginian syphax thinking exercise yong man made ignoraunte wherein offended determined firste make war ouercome meete romanes syphax carthaginias many moe chariot cariage aboundaunce massinissa would himselfe beginthe manner massinissa vvarre labour hauing horseman cariage forrage might easily flie turne vpon enimies retire strong place many time circumuented diuided armie might better flee partes hiding himselfe fewe till might come night day appointed thyrde man dyd lye hidde haue enimies camping neuer stayd campe euer led army vnknown wher enimies coulde come hand kepe backe came foode euery day could get night field town citie catching spoyling euery thing diuiding hys companion wherefore many numidian came vnto wagies appointed take gayn much better thus massinissa warre carthaginian whe scipio made thing ready sicelie sacrifised iupiter neptune came toward libya long ship ship burden many pine foysts folowed led army sixteene thousand footemen thousand sixe hundred horseme caried also much armour munition much victuall sayled carthaginian syphax hearing purp sed de ue massinissa societie till ouercome ignoraunt deceites vtica vvas fayre citie aff c next carthage thirtie mile vvhich cato killed himselfe vvhen caesar folovved layde like comunicated al scipio reconciled came asdrubal horseman vpon walles within vndermined rampires caught hooke string brake force rammes casting beames breastes sallied oute againste engine fire winde bare force wherefore scipio despayring get citie determined win long ge syphax hearde came army lodged syphax cometh againe field farre asdruball dissemblyng friend delaying warre purpose till ship come arriued carthage hyred souldi r liguria would help practised also winne massinissa vnto offeringthe practise syphax confirme kingdome massilia three sister giue whiche woulde marryage hee messenger carryed golde coulde perswade hym shoulde gyue one hys seruauntes woulde promise kyll massinissa refuseda pract e massinissa offer messenger gaue golde one kyll tooke shewed massinissa bewrayed gyuer syphax thinking could longer delay openlye ayded carthaginian tooke citie vpland called tholunta hauing romanes munition victualles treason killed taketh n vvhiche vvas romaynes pro nion determination ennim e againste romanes keeper bycause woulde go awaye vppon truste sent great de numidian nowe merceanrie souldiors come shippes wel appointed agreed battel syphax set vpon ege asdrubal force scipio campe shippes shoulde fight wyth shyppes nexte daye romanes bycause fewe shoulde able resiste night massinissa vnderstanding certaine numidian tolde scipio hee massinissa saueth romanes fro greate danger doubt afrayde least armye muche diuided shoulde weake pointes called captaines night counsell sawe doubte hee saide boldenesse speede friendes fight desperationthe oration scipio touching sodaine assalting ennimye nowe beseemeth v let v go set vpon enimyes shall winne thereby learne sodayne comming vpon shal amaze strangenesse feate fewe woulde auenture vppon many shall diuide oure army manye partes vse togither wee shall set againste enimyes agaynste firste wee shall choose lodged seuerallye shal equall euerye parte et v onely preuent boldenesse good lucke god graunte v ouercome firste shall contemne reste first set vpon time manner assault shall take thinke good tel mine opinion al agreed time said matter soone go meeting beyng yet nighte whiche thyng wyll fearefull lesse prepared n e confederate able helpe darke let v preuent purpose inuading v morrowe bee three campes shyppes farre fighte wyth shy night asdrubal syphax farre asunder asdrubal heade warre syphax shall dare nothing nighte man barbarous full daintinesse feare let v go againste asdruball oure armye shall appoint ma inissa ye wayte syphax hap come foorth contrarye oure opinion let v goe foote asdrubals campe assaulte round wyth good hope lusty courage preset horseman cannot vse night wil place farre compasse camp enimies wee driuen backe maye receyue v flee oure friend ouercome may chase destroy hauing thus saide sent away captaines arme hoste sacrificed boldenesse feare sodainethis eare nonlatin alphabet cometh cause vnk ovven staied iu r put among ti feare without cause shoulde happe armye continue bolde rest thirde watche signified wyth trumpet maruellous deepe silence greate armye went till horseman compassed ennimies footemen went trench broken showte made manye soundes trumpes horne make terror droue watche place tooke trench pulled rampire boldest ranne set tent afyre libyan beyng waked offeare carthagies camp sleepe terror running order order taking armor obeying commaundements confusion neither generall himselfe certainly knowing done romanes tooke leapte oute arming themselues great turmoile set manye tent fyre killed came made afrayd crye enimie fight moste fearefull businesse nyghte ignorant euill indeede thinkyng campe hadde beene taken fearyng fyre burnyng tentes leapt themselues wente fielde sure place came partes miserably killed fell romaine horseman compassed al dispatched great misery therefore counsell thee nowe put syphax biddeth scipio bevvare sophonisba sophinisba ought sure vnto keepe sophonisba least turne massinissa wil cannot hoped wil take romanes part greatly doth loue hir citie spake eyther truly gelousie massinissa hinder much could scipio perceyuing syphax bee wise scipio vseth syphax friendlye cyrus craesus expert coutry led made priuy mind counsel iniuried secondly falsly accused hanno thus brought death carthaginian spyted death wise sente annibal breake truce make warre vppon scipio try speedy fight bicause wat brake trucethe pea broken parthos scipio c leth annibal espies led army scipio taking great citie called parthos camped neare annibal remoued sending three spy romanes whome scipio toke kil according law armes commaunded led campe see store armor munition let go tell annibal eueryething desired come talke whiche graunted sayd carthaginian grieued firsttalke betvven scipio annibal peace money might remitted romanes contented sicilia iberis iles haue peace sure scipio aunswered annibal gette greate rewarde flying italie hee myght obtayne thys scipio forbadde sende anye threatning one another departed seueral ampes cittie nygh called cilla whiche cilla annibal straightes hil fytte campe annibal perceyuing sent take vp folowed army finding taken scipio left playne field without water spent night digging water pittes army pickte heapes sande dranke little water full sande grieued without meate rest werethe order annibals battell armour night scipio perceyuing came vpon day weary way watch thyrst italie trusted bicause feared case horse men aboute wing thys annibals order scipio xxiij thousande horseman italie scipio order rome thousand fiue hundred massinissa many horseman numidia lacamas another prince sixe hundred horse set footemen three battels anniball made particion betweene bandes horsemenne might passe easily made euery bande defence front strong pertches layde ouer yron two cuvits long thicke kepe backe elephantes engine warned footemen giue place furie beastes cast dartes vpon fast coulde nigh cutte sinowes coulde thus placed scipio numidian horse placed wing acquainted fight fury elephant italian horse bicause vsed set last readye passe distance footemen bidden first violence elephant sort horsmen company shotte ioyned annoy beastes thus horseman set right wing gaue laelius left octauius middest annibal kepe glorie hauing horseman attending vpon helpe nede annibal three thousand scipio two thousande three hundred italian armed sicelie ready encouraged men scipio called god witnesse army carthaginian offended ofte brake promise scipio souldiours required hys army loke number enimies owne vertue number ouerthrowen euen lande ouercome haue anye feare doubte muche necessitie must haue haue bin ouercome thus scipio encourage stirre fewe number annibal recorded feates hadde done italie enterprise moste annibal souldiours great renoume among numidian among italian italie shewed fewe enimies exhorted worse fewe moe countrey declare vnto souldiours daunger greatnesse present fight annibal shewed carthage libya tryed thys fighte whether shoulde slaues ouercome rule hereafter ouer wonne scipio tolde hys defeated safe returne dyd ouercome great dominion shoulde fall vnto rest present paynes going home country renouine euer thus eyther encouraging went fight annibal sounded first scipio commaunded aunswere elephant beganne fight terrible manner spurred prickes rider numidian h ementhe elephant put backe vvings ranne threwe dartes thicke vppon wounded fledde troubled parte kepers led away firstthe elephant trouble romanes fotemen battel enterprise elephant wing army midde battel romaine trode downe footeme vnacquainted fight heauy harnised could hardly giue place goe forewarde tyll scipio scipio leaueth horse fight vvith b ephan broughte foorth italian horsemenne placed behynde shotte commaundyng leaue horse afrayde goe aboute shoote elephant first alighted wounded elephant came afore souldiours encouraged therby hurtyng beastes made also go battel fighte cleared beast nowe men horse right wing romaine whyche laelius ledde putte flighte numidian agaynste massinissa wounded massintha prince annibal comming massinissa vvou deth massintha quickly vnto sette againe fight left battayle whyche octauius gouerned much adoe ennimies french ligurians scipio sente thermus helpe wyth choyse men anniball hauing stayde lefte battayle roade ligurians frenchman brynging another bande libyan carthaginian whiche scipio sawe came againste scipio annibal fighte another band two moste noble captaines dyd thus contend euidente emulation care side diligence lefte eyther parte laboure sharper exhortation vehement fight beyng long doubtfull captaines hauing pittie weary souldiours coupled togither ende mighte shorter threw one another scipio hytte annibals shielde annibal stroke scipio horse horse wounde ouerthrewe scipio hee mounted agayne threw annibal missed hurt horse next massinissa vnderstanding came thyther romaynes massinissa commeth danger scipio vvas seeing theyr capitayne fighting lyke souldiour toke courage agaynst enimies putte backe chased anniball ryding aboute vaine praying staye perswading turne agayne fight annibal greate doubte broughte italian romanes skil ight came hym yet styrring place succoure fighte hoping breake romaynes araye easily bycause folowing ennimye seeing deuise called one another diligently chase put themselues againe order fighte nowe hauing horse shotte spent fought togyther blade great slaughter manye woundes grones fell shoutes dyd kyll tyll romaynes putte backe made flye also victorye euident annibal seeing annibal renevveth fight numidian horseman stande styl ranne prayed forsake hym perswaded brought chased thinking notable feate againe firste mette massulians fought massinissa annibal fighteth fighte onely betweene massinissa anniball fiercelye going massinissa stroke annibals target hitte massinissas horse foote flewe vppon anniball killed horse comming vppon hym dartes receyued vppon hys shielde drewe one stucke vppon threw annibal missing killed nexte horse drawing another wounded arme went oute battell whyle pi hearde scipio commeth reliefe massinassa afrayde massinassa came fraye found massinissa horsed going field againe hauing tyed wound fight equall agayne sore fides eyther afrayde capitaynes tyll annibal dydde see iberian frenchman ne staying vppon hill rrour battel roade bring forth againe foughte knowing cause thinkyng going bin flying lefte fighte willyngly fledde disorderedly lookyng toward annibal euery man coulde thus brake romaine fielde hadde bene fully gotte pursued order neyther vnderstanding annibals purpose returned spaniard frenchman wherefore scipio called men againe chase speede set order came hyll wherefore mighte easily resist annibal yeth annibal deceyued laste hope fledde vtterly dispayring thing manye horseman followed specially massinissa beyng grieued wounde euer hande desirous haue brought prisoner scipto night diuided annibal flyeth thonne annibal darke twentie horseman could folow fled cittie called thonne whither vnderstoode many horseman b utia iberia come field fearing iberian barbarous cruel doubting brutians italian countrey men scipio least woulde leade scipio forgiuen faulte itali priuily fled one horseman trusted best running three thousand urlongs two nightes annibal cometh hast adrume two dayes came citie sea called adrumet parte armye victuall sending aboute gathering fledde made armoure munition scipio hauing got noble victorie burned vnprofytable scipio e deth lal vvith nevves rom spoyle beyng gyrded romanes generalls went sent rome ten talent golde ij v c siluer wrought iuorie noble prisoner l lius messenger victorie reste tooke honor souldiours gaue giftes beste massinissa crowne went tooke city ende annibal scipio fighte libya first time fought togither dyed romaynes two thousand fiue hundred massinissas enimies fiue twenty thousand prisoner taken eighte thousande fiue hundred iberian three hundred yeelded scipio numidian eight hundred massinissa neyther carthaginian romanes yet hearing carthage sent mago gathering yet frenchemen inuade italie hee coulde sayle liby wyth hys hyred souldioures romanes intercepting letter sent scipio army horse footemen shyppes money scipio sent octauius carthage sedeth scipio peace lande carthage hymselfe went water carthage vnderstoode annibals ouerthrow set ambassadours pynnesse hanno magnus asdrubal haedus chiefe set vp banner peace stemme held vp hand scipio desiring pardon hee carthage ueth peace willed go campe placed vpon highe seate gaue audience teares fell grounde taken vp officer commaunded say woulde annibal spake parte romanes hanno manye wise carthage cleare oure selues faulte put vppon v embassadoures oure people driuen hunger offended saued sent home yet wee muste blame carthage desired peace firste andpeople free citties disobedent kepte firmely city soone drawne worst whiche pleasant preuayleth euer multitude whiche haue proued beyng neither able perswade stay accuse v take free speeche v iudge v romanes obedience counsell seemeth saulte slowe obey blame hunger necessitie droue v co strained act desire peace gyue much money deliuer al long ship saue fewe yeelde great parte oure dominion sweare send othe rome ambassador yet willingly offend manne may blame god chiefly storme droue corne carthage beside storme hu ger tooke cannot consider well men thing beyng neede thinges require good reason rude myserable multitude iudge v vniustlye miserye confesse pray forgiuenesse justificationiustification submission offend submission offende mercy prosperitie ought readier beholding chaunces men considering sodaine mutation crie pardon yesterday able hurte citie carthage greatest mightiest libya shippes money elephant army foote horseman many subiects haue flourished yeares ruled al libya nation ilandes great part sea comming many time contention nowe neyther shyppes elephant horse subiects whiche haue taken v haue hope helpe haue euill vsed whiche consideryng marking alteration ought vse felicitie temperately doe shall seeme worthye magnanimitie romanes fortune carthage sometime put mutation ate misfortune voide enuy may without blame afore god deserue prayse men feare nowe carthaginian wyll rebel great repentance paine former follie doth fall vppon good counsell keeper innocencie wise men offendoures repent haue suffered like constant theyr dueties neuer suche experience neither fit folow carthaginian whome accuse cruelty wickednesse misery want calamitie beginning offence prosperitie pleasure vse humanitie shall honorable profitable aucthoritie rather saue kill greate cittie bee nowe better judge youre commodity wee bring twoo thynges assurance thereof worthinesse dominion carthage somtime hath youre moderation towarde men beyng ioyned wyth armes hath brought great empire power condition gyue v peace take whiche say committing haedus saide thus muche ceased scipio willing auoid conferred officer determined called said worthy pardon ste haue broken peace scipio embassadoures carthage lastely de ied oure embassadoures manifestly wickedly offending againste v neyther purge youre selues shewe matter contrary worthy extreame punishement neede accuse confesse flee prayer woulde haue lefte name rome got victory haue done suche thyng embassadours yet rome broken league violated oure embassador citie deliuered beeyng dryuen myne armye sente vnhurte made warre v therefore ought thinke gaine whatsoeuer receiue hauing conde ned selues saye thinke good senate shall determine shal please wee giue peace agayne carthaginian gyue youre long shyppes vnto romaynes except ten elephant haue tooke pay lost iudge doubt prisoner run awayes many annibal brought thus within thirty dayes peace made threescore dayes mag shall departe g take garrison oute city whiche without p nicia deliuer pledge haue euery yeare shall bring two hundred talentes euboea fity yeares shall h frenchman ligurians shal make warre vpon mass s friend carthage war common consent shall haue citie muche lande phoenician ditche sayled libya shal friend romaynes bothe sea lande senate confirme confirme romanes shall go libya hundred fiftye dayes haue truce send rome shall giue v hand hundred fifty ostages child shall choose shall giue expences warre thousand talent victuall army peace concluded shall receiue pledge scipio said thus embassadours bare fault carthage people resorting manye dayes counsell beste sorte thought good accept condition putte al hazarde sticking somewhat corne shoulde go away people consideringpeople resiste peace present perill taking awaye resist grieued ruler take away corne romanes famme giue steade citizen truce stoode aboute euery threatned burne house spoyle ende knowing annibal hadde gathered sixe thousand footemen fiue hundred horseman staying citie named marthma called counsell matter came sober sorte afraide man warre woulde haue stirred people perswaded verye annibal persu sa deth peace grauely receiue peace people outragiously spake euill threatned till noble men fledde massimssa romanes willingly despayring citie carthaginian vnderstanding annibal hadde gathered corne plentifullye storehouse made muche adoe tyll gote diuided among meane time newes come rome newein place greeke texte vnperfect peace scipio made carthage matter debated senate house one senatoures saide thus wee shoulde agree peace iniuriousdiscorde senate house touching peace vniuste scipio whiche suspecting seemeth declared minde vnto v added wee made delay woulde make peace like hee considereth matter better seeth bycause hath al wee doe otherwise shall offende hys estimation good citizen noble capitayne prouoked v vnwilling sende affrica hauyng army v gette one himselfe hathe promoted v farre could hope therefore wondered faint beginning warre nowe earnest vehement nowe man thinketh bee well yet feareth carthaginian breake thys league nowe moste like wyll keepe peace ofte afflicted breaking henceforth keepe justice better beyng fallen knee vnrighteousnesse like counsell nowe despise carthaginian power againe feare might rebell easie v keepe shall rise destroy presently nowe wil fighte desperation might kepe vnder feare haue euils ynow without v wyth whome neighbour grieued crueltie massinissa man moste faithfull v shall euer lye wait man contemne al thinketh may succeede scipio hys owne commoditie haue like successe hee hath ende shall citie happe take shall destroy vtterly bicause spoyled ship victualls whiche content deliuer muche morecontention rome peace vvith carthage wil auoide anger god hate men shall giue massinissa thoughe friend yet made strong let contende togither common weale rome wil wee make rent country armye shall keepe therevvhat considered vvarre spende reuenne shall stand feare manye nighe nation barbarian send inhabitant middest numidian beyng strong barbarian alwaies worke oure wo get better hande shall terrible hatefull v euer hauing gret land much better whiche scipio iudge perceyuing thoughte good v heare prayer carthage therefore let v consent prayer generall thus said p cornelius cornelius lentulus kinsman consull p cornelius speaketh peace scipio offered carthaginian thoughte good succeede scipio spake agaynste thys sorte warres onely profite considered bicause hathe bin declared cittie yet power bee maintained ought take away vnfaithfulnesse togyther power might vnfaithfulnesse shall neuer take away tyme fit v deliuered feare carthage thys present bee poore weake growe strength againe yet doe swarue consideration justice thinke oure cittie shall seeme deale ute reason carthaginian weale doe iniurie despite al men wo fal prayer obtaine forsake agreement againe neyther haue regarde promise respect othe whome wee muste saue feare god enuy men thinke god themselues haue brought carthaginian point suffer wickednesse violating peace made v sicilie iberia italie libya selfe haue wrought purpose wel vsed condition euer deuises made call matter question giue themselues wee shall receiue armoure body shall v shall suppose nothing pride shall sall shall loue whatsoeuer shall receyue v preparing body fight age stregth valtantnesse massinissa next daye sente horseman receiue diuerse sonnes breake day ordered army beingixxxviij yeares age ryding yet strongly leaping vppon bare horse manner numidian good captaine fighting souldiour numidian strong among liue numidian long life long moste long life cause peraduenture haue sharpe winter euery thing destroyed sommer hotte aethiopians indian therefore region bringeth forth moste strong beastes men alwayes ayre laboure drinke little wine diet simple thinne massinissa horsebacke directed hys armye asdrubal brought people manye againste scipio beholdeth fight betvvene carthagies massinissa manye come hym countrey scipio behelde fighte hyghe place theatre wont say seene manye fieldes neuer none suche pleasure alone without care sawe hundred tenne thousande menne fighting togyther sayde two beside seene lyke id hill troade warre troy iupiter ida neptune samothracia fight continued morning till night many slayne side abyde heare departed nothing scipio returned spain elephates massinissa laye aboute hyll enimies wayting victual brought none nygh hande himselfe great way brought muchepartialitie romaine ado little carthaginian wherein haue offended haue neither ship elephant haue lefte oure tribute wee haue taken part iij king ought displease ph pp misery cause muche spea wee saide thys deliuered r armoure misery maketh men speake muche nothyng strong supplication couenaunts made wee haue thing refuge word seeyng haue deliuered oure strength former thinges romanes assuraunce present consulsmisery witnesse v required pledge brought beste sorte requyred armour haue al ken iege wil willingly deliuer haue trusted romane custome manner nate commaunded v u required pledge e shoulde free hadde added shoulde receyue reste commaundements right affyrmyng plaine speeche ure cittie shoulde bee free pledge appointe ouerthrowe carthage self thinke may desiroy giue libertie selfe say wee haue saye former league selues haue thys accepted wee gyue ouer onely lefte men miserye flee complainte prayer much prayer requisite multitude euills wee beeseeche auntient citie inhabited oracle god great glorie name spred ouer earth holy thing manye goddes haue offended whose solemnity pompes feastes spoile sepulture funeralls since none deade men haue done anye iniurie pitie saying pitie v suffer v haue dwelling place spare place publique assemblye spare countrey ceremony spare god counsell aliue fruiteful honorable neede haue anye feare carthage haue oure shippes armoure elephantes enuied touching habitation wil comfort v impossible men haue liued sea dwel maine land infinite number doth occupy sea giue choice contentation glorie suffer cittie stande hathe hurte none kill v woulde haue remoue shall seeme angry men holy thing god sepulchre cittie hathe offended romanes haue regard good fame rightwisenesse workes shewe modestie prosperitie add vse toward take remembre iupiter goddes yet haue carthage doe bring euills vppon youre child blotte good fame first vppon v deface youre glorye wyth suche acte euill done euill bee hearde begon first afore lyuing haue beene manye warres betweene gretians barbarian manye beetweene romanes others yet neuer anye defaced citye giuing handes afore fight deliuering theyr armour child hurte worlde sufer patiently bringing goddes sworne fortunereuengement belongeth god man moste fearfull goddes reuengeaunce felicitie wee beseeche dishonoure selues vpon state hath prospered neyther bring youre felicitie infamye giue v leaue suffer v haue oure cittie sende embassadoures againe senate make intercession see little distance time bringing heape long torment shorte duety thing come youre power doe either nowe shortly let pittie humanitie present said hanno consulls euidently seemed sad spake bycause could graunt nothing made end censorinus said senate hathe commaunded neede weethe romane consull carthaginian speake much hathe commaunded must obeyed neither staye haue commaunded bee doone commaunde oure ennimyes wee doe speake muste done bycause common profit talke bothe muche carthaginian refuse speake reason perswaded rather compelled sea putting insea occasion offence mynde power dominion stirreth offende fal aduersitie haue ouercomesicilie spaine sicilie done sayled spaine tooke tyme truce ye robbed merchaunts chiefly cure might knowne ye drowned till ye taken paide sardinia penaltie loste sardinia sea whiche naturally prouoketh men couet much bicause speedy commoditie athenienses seaman didde winne muche loste sea like marchauntes gaines hathe great encrease lostesea like marchauntes know whome nowe named dilating theyr dominion ionian sea ile sicilie cease coueting hadde loste power athenienses ost al couering much sea giuen porte shippes ennimies receyued garrison cittie pulled downe long wall made dwell vppon highe lande whiche saued moste parte surer life carthaginian vppon lande labouring earth quyetnessegaine vppon nd lesse sure peraduenture gaine lesse surer lesse dangerous certainly husbandry merchaundise cittiea citie sea like shippe sea seemeth rather shippe lande hauing muche tossing businesse mutabilitie inland profitte without perill vppon grounde thys auncient kingdomes moste parte middestthe great monarchy lande greatest made median assirians persian others wyll cease example kynges whyche agree wyth looke vppon youre owne libya whyche shall haue neighboures wyll choose maye take awaye sighte memorye stirre thynges nowe trouble looke sea voyde shyppes remembring number shippes haue hadde prayes haue taken porte brought plentifullye filled youre storehouse shippes treasurehouses preparation whereto serueth youre wall receipte youre army horse elephantes whereto memorie griefe stirring come agayne affection manne remembraunce former fortune hope come againe like best remedy euill fortuneforgetfulnesse remedie miserye forgetfulnesse cannot haue except take away sighte thys manifest proofe beingmany time pardoned breache promise haue broke stil yet couet rule beare v euil wil haue taken wait time haue neede citie port arsenalls wall made receiue army shoulde pardon since finde suche aduersaries wil leaue dominion deede word rather sentence content lande haue libya minde keepe without dissm lation v shew deede go dwell libya haue leaue sea haue los neyther counter te pitie holy thinges country goddes common place sepu chres whose sepulchre shall remaine vntouched make ceremony may come sacrifice youre holye goddes reste take away sacrifice arsenal ye make yeareminds vpon walles altares house palaices may builde goe shall foorthwith youre countrey carthag n con e tyrus left tyrus came libya possessed call country short learne euill sure agreement publique concordealba remember alba ennimie mothercitie euill minde willing inhabitaunce common profite wee translated rome profytable people ye saye many thatsea men worke theyr liuing sea wee haue oreseene maye haue easie traffike sea maye carrye receiue verye commodiouslye put far sea foure seore surl ng wee commaunde bee hundred surlongs wee gyue place choose selfe bee selfe thys wee saide carth ge shoulde free shee obeyed v wee thinke carthage groundmen cittie house cens inu said thys ceased carthag e astonished said nothing saide againe haue spoken thought might perswade comforte senate commaundement muste bee done oute hande therefore goe waye yet embassador thus spake remoued sergeant foreseeing might follow carthage desired leaue speake againe beeyng brought saide see commaundement must obeyed wyll carthag e speak let v sende rome hope returne shall killed carthaginian tell commaundement ch selues ready suffer thing carthage maye driuen su er calamus ie sende fledde waye pa te wente silence carthaginian loking ambassadours comming wals troubled tarriaunce ro le carth g sight ambassadours ore heare woulde tarry went te desirous learne trueth sawe heauye stroke face aske al friend acquaintaunce saluted asked none answere lamented euident distruction heard wals lamented knowing thing manifest gret aduersitie entry gate almost thrust one another death almoste torne ambassadours piece saued must first speake semors le went desir u know soone entred senate house senior commaunded au yde onely remayned people stoode without ambassadour showed commaundement consul senate cryed ut people without like amb ssadours shewing ged contrary prayer made sende ambassad ur rome senate deepe silence bydi g heare de people silence also heard might sedfury carthagies rome turned exceeding shryking people ranne fell surye like madde men without reason minister bacchus wont whichthe fe stes cch hevved tune dronken sort differ little mad folke saye place called neck diuide fro lad furlong brodethe discription carthage narrow piece ground called towne halfe furlong broade goeth weast dest poole sea simple wall among rockes towarde south lande warde olde citie byrsa neck triple wall euerye one thirtie cubites high beside batlements tower distaunt two acre asunder stayde foure planchers thirtie foote deepe pla cher higth euery wall rounde strong three hundred elephant placed belowe treasure store vpon stable four thousand horse granary wheate barley receytes men twentie thousand foote foure thousande horse greate prouision warre appointed placed walles one hooke narow part bow wall porte weake andone vveake place lowe regarded beginning sayled one porte another sea one entrye lxx foote broade shut chaynes yron firste merchauntes manye diuerse place receyt within middest ile ile poole compassed greate holowe corner full munition shippes able receiue two hundered twentie ship cellers preparation shippes gallies furniture two pitlers ionian fashion stoode euery porte shippes like gallery sight passed iland port ilethe admiral port store admiral fro whece trumpeter must giue warning crier tel time admirall see abroad iland right sayled drawn great length admirall might see sea sayled see place porte perfectly neyther could merchaunts port see store shippes double wall set gate receiue merchaunts go citie passing storehouse shippes time thus stoode citie carthage consul diuided businesse came theirthe consul carthage sea land enimies manlius lande againste necke fil ditch beate little wal approch high walles censorinus brought ladder lande shippes part bowing wall made little accompte vnarmed men tyll sounde haue new armour great courage wounder whiche gaue backe beginning fayled theyr purpose thinking get citie without fighte seconde time attempting againe reiected courage carthagies encreased consul afrayde asdruball campe backe far poole defensed campes censorinus poole vnder walles citie manlius necke way lande thus camp made strong censorinus passed poole stuffe make engine hee lost fiue hundered workemen much armoure imilco generall imileo cesorinus ioseth men horse carthage dispayred left censorinus filling trenche next narrow earth poole make passable brought two greate engine caried rammes one heaued sixe thousand footemen colonel guiding mariner conduct admiralles contention doe best capitaines souldiours piece wall throwen might see cittie carthaginian repulse repayred breach night bycause could finishe night afrayde already done shoulde throwen daye romaynes engine newe made green ranne vpon engine enimies armed naked hauing burning lampes burned notthe carthagies burn part romanes engine bycause could preuent romanes came yet made vnprofytable returned day come romanes bolonesse assault place fallen fully made vp within apeared plain fit fight fronte armed carthagies stoode behynde vnarmed stone staues placed next house entertaine approching enimie
