distaunce wal would let anye enter citie receyued driuen carthaginian saued beginning glorie appearing wise co sulin place vvant text army censorinus sicke lying fenne ful standing corrupt water receiuing winde sea bicause high wals therfore censorinus remoued sea carthaginian whe winde blew toward romanesthe carthagies burne part romanes nauy filled boates flaxe brushe within wals enimyes see shippes came forth seene layd sulphure pitch set vp sayle threw fire vessel carried winde blewe lustily romane nauye sette shippes fire almost burned long censorinus went rome election carthagies bolder vppon manlius night armed vnarmed carying bridge assaulted next trenche manlius beganne pull downe rampire souldiours within beyng troubled nighte time scipio came horseman contrarye parte enimies feared carthagies comming vpon retired citie fight souldiours disordered night scipio thought haue saued againe nobly manlius kepte campe sure making wall rampire erecting tower towarde sea shippes brought victual turning lande ten thousande footemenne two thousande horse wasted countrey gathering woode corne victuall one tribune another serue turne phameas captaine thephameas horseman yong desirous fight vsing little light horse fedde grasse none suffer hunger thirste neede keeping secret vallies wood whe saw negliget came foorth sodayn like eagle spoyled retired whe scipio comaunded ye army wold apeare scipio led people euer order horseman keepingthe circumspection scipio horsebacke raunging woulde dissolue hys order beset field would spoyle horseman armed footemen roade bandes kepte forager lefte companie went compasse therfore phameas wold come vponenuie scipio often done scipio great glorye captaynes enuying gaue friendship auncestours phamea grandfather scipio libyan fledde tower fortes scipio iust promise many ye country tribune would couenaunt depart assaile went scipio would send home therfore fame valiatnesse faith would trust except scipio gaue word honoured enimies comming foraging libyan assaulted castle nauy night cofusion great escries yt carthagies made cause ye terror malius kept within knowing matter scipio takyng two bandes horseman well spoken euerie man thought worthy sonne paulus conquered macedonie scipio whosethe progenie scipio family adopted manlius going nepheris asdrubal scipio notnepheris contente seeing al wooddes hylly place high place gotten three furlong asdrubal coming riuer must ascend asdrubal stayd counselled retire another time pollicie fitte match asdrubal tribune speaking enuy malice thinking scipio counsel ected good counsell giue place sight enimye whereby might contemne set vpon flying hee againe desired put campe hyther side riuer put might haue place resorte nowe hadde none wherevnto might flye laughed one threatned caste away sworde manlius scipio rule therefore manlius went verye skilfull warre asdruball encountred greate slaughter side asdruball ranne castle perilthe romanes ouerthroven asdruball wayted set wente repenting done retired floud order floud hard passe bycause fewe fourdes painful wer forced break order whych asdrubal saw came downe manfully killed many resiste fledde three captaines slaine brought army conflicte scipio three hundred horseman scipio saueth consul army manye coulde get togither diuided three company gaue charge vpon enimie greate vehemence portion darting retyring vppon agayne returning tolde halfe assayle enimies throw dartes circle e done libyan without staye shotte continuallye turning vppon scipio lesse trouble passe riuer scipio rode stroke verye sore foure company beginning fray put floude enimies ranne hill asdrubal besieged vnknowne romanes till stayed knewe thoughte good goe waye aduenture many fewe scipio tolde acounsell doyng marter begonne good counsell muste hadde manye menne ensignes daunger vtterme e boldenesse muste vsed chose certaine troupe horseman said would returne gladly die tooke two dayes victuall streight went forth army afraide least also shoulde perish came hill besieged great speede tooke hill oueragainste diuided little valley libyan didde giue hote charge vpon besieged thinking scipio coulde succoure long iorney seeing bottomes hill compassing valley omit occasion ranne tooke place aboue enimies beyng eset rounde aboute fled without order scipio suffering go freely bycause great deale thus scipio saued also desperation scipio saueth band vver daunger army sawe come farre beyng saued beyond hope hauing saued made great reioyce thoughteopinio god vvorking scipio god wrought grandfather seemed knowe come manlius led army cittie againe putting great faulte woulde obey scipio counselled retire army allgriefe vnburied souldioures muche grieued killed laye vnburied parte mauritania sea dominion cyrene land caused great portion cyrene novve corene conrayning prouince fyue citties inhabited many numidia liued hearbs vsed tillage left treasure mony army well practised ennimies tooke syphax prisoner hand beyng cause variance carthage left weake romanes hadde body big streng nature laste age tried fight till hys death woulde leape horse without stirrops may great coniecture hys good health hauing many child massinissa yeares age childe foure yeares olde sometime dying hadde tenne little one lefte one foure yeares age year olde thus massinissa yeares body dyed scipio gaue bastardes gift legitimate treasure reuenue haue name kyng commonthe order scipio tooke vpon massinissas child micipsa gelossa masta ab diuided thing among thoughte good micipsa oldest moste desirous peace gaue citie cyrta royall thinges gelossa souldiour second age appointed lorde peace warre mastauaba youngest giuen justice gaue authoritie iudgements deciding controuersies thus scipio diuide kingdome substaunce massinissa child presently made gelossa companion warre founde oute traynes whiche phameas many time vexed romanes stayed winter scipio phameas encamped nighe togither hauing middest valley could passed doe thing one scipio fearing traine might laide went viewe wyth three friend phameas sawe came toward one scipio thinking wold say somewhat rode towarde one also might heare one another scipio saide carthaginian gonethe talke betvvene scipio pharmeas dost thou consider thine owne health seeyng thou canste doe nothing common wealth howe quoth see safety carthaginian standing romanes oft hurte promise thee said scipio worthy trusted safetie forgiuenesse romanes haue thankes accepting bee worthy saide thinke thee possible thou canst tel departed least asdrubal come vpon went away while doubta letter scipio one gelossa army brought letter scipio deliuered sealed generall opened founde thys suche daye take suche place come thou many thou wilte bid foremoste watche receiue shall come night letter without anye name saide thus muche scipio thought touching phamea manlius afraide scipio leaste shoulde deceyued man bent deceites sawe haue good hope matter sente willing giue assuraunce phameas safety thankes determine nothing promise romanes shoulde consider neede suche premise phameas come place appointed trusted scipio safetie phameas yeeldeth scipio giuing right hande thankes let romanes consider said thus determined fighte nexte day going captain consider matter said could longer helpe country ready standing doth soresee mine horse seeing micipsa mastauaba son massinissa euer promise romanes armor money deferred looked ende encreased hart went boldely libya winning grounde speaking euill romane assembly euery citie shewing camp euery man friendes required scipio might sente consull libya election hande lawe forbad scipio consull yet bicause age desired bee anedises rule house prouision edile would haue consul beyng lawe consul bringing forth lawe grieued offended affirming lawes romul aucthoritie people tullius people lorde election mighte allowe disallowe law would ende one tribune saide consul would agree people woulde take election consulls senate perswaded people breake scipio chosen consull tyme lavve broken yeare example acedemonians pylus cittie tvvo pelope scipio appointed libya people lawe one yeare saide iudgement prouinces people whiche people chose scipio army giuen ordinarie many might supplie number deade take manye confederate coulde perswade write king citties people rome name many thoughte would send aide helpe city king went sicilie sicilie vtica calphurnius piso made war land mancinus lay carthage parte wall perceiued neglected rock could attempted thinking shoulde perceyued prepared hys ladder piso attempteth vvall get wall souldiours went boldely carthaginian seeing fewe despised set open gate goe rockes ranne vppon romanes romanes driuing backe following ranne citie gate making crie victorie mancinus leaping ioy mancinus giueth rashe attempt thing rashe light multitude leauing shippes ranne wall halfe armed naked sunne nowe ready set tooke forte wall rested mancinus wanting victuall sente piso ruler mancinus danger vtica helpe daunger bring foode speede daunger least breake daye carthaginian throwe headlong rockes scipio scipio arriuall doth seate night came vtica midnight vnderstanding mancinus written sounded battaile sent messenger call seaman italie vtica bad auntients carye victualls galleis deliuered prisoner carthage go tell scipio commyng sent piso horsmen horsmen call awaye speede laste watch come commaunded sayle stand right vppe decktes seeme ennimyes thus mancinus carthagies early morning fel vpon mancinus beaten copassed three thousad naked fiue hundred armed hurte beaten driuen rockes wall scipio shippes seen sayling al force euery ful armed souldiors carthaginian hearing prisoner thinke contrary brought romanes helpe vnlooked carthaginian giuing place little little scipio receiued scipio saueth mansinus romanes danger hys ship sent mansinus rome serranus come successor inser n nauy scipio encamped far carthage carthaginian comming fiue furlougs oute towne made trench trencho came asdrubal theasdrubal bythias captaine army abroad bythias captaine horsmen leading sixe thousand footemen thousande horsmen practised time diligence scipio perceiuing order good rule among souldiours giuen ydlenesse spoyle rauine vnder piso straunge multitude among spoile followed bolder sorte ranne wyth robbe going without warning law warlavv taketh forsaker army goeth withoute sound trumpe offence make imputed whole army desire spoile occasion euils contention among many contemning felowes luere made murder hurtes mischiefe againste lawes whiche scipio considering thinking neuer ouercome enimie except coulde rule hys owne called assemblye goyng vp highe seate thus rebukedthe exhortatio scipio souldiours vvere order souldior wyth vnder manlius gaue experience witnesse mine obedience generall require hauing power punishe disobediet vttermost haue thought good warne know speake ashamed ye rob rather make war yea scatter encampe like seeker pray egers city liue delicatelye yet warre withoute victorie whereby enimies power beyond hope little tyme haue n away growne greate thys negligence labour growne greater cause didde find woulde punishe oute hand bycause impute another forgiue haue done till tune come rob conquer get mony victorie firste beate mine enimies goe al army day souldioures except shall haue leaue tarry go wil suffer come againe till bring victuall camp good time shall appointed shal place thing price treasorer shall appoint saide superfluous bee souldiors let one comandement common al affaire maner labor follow youexample good lesson shal erre youre enterprise voide thankes nowe muste laboure perill lette luere alone till fitte time maye serue v merye thus doe commaund law obedient shal pertakers muche good disobedient shall repent thus scipio said put away al multitude vnprofitable al thing wer superfluous vaine delicate army purged reuerence readie commaundement attempted place called megara two place megara one strong place cartbage one night megara great place cittie ioyning wall whiche sending went wyth pike ax ladder bar vnseen silence whe aboue heard come neere made crie wall made countre crie firste army diuerse part made great first feare carthaginian many enimies side sodainelye come vpon coulde good wall thoughe scipio gaynerh tovver proued al wayes gote tower priuate citizen voide without wall high wall courage yong men droue away e watch wall dart laying bridge plan e space betweene gote megara breaking gate let scipio entred en carthaginian sted byrsae reste citie taken strange crie great alteratio carthog taken camy without ful harded groues fruite diuided hedge set brier riuers running diuersely fearing least army folowing shoulde finde troublesome passage without waye ignorantly going ye night might haply fal traynes blew retreate day come asdrubal angry taking megara many prisoner thethe crueltie asdrubal romaynes brought wall romaynes mighte see shoulde done pulled eye tongs sinowes priuie member hooke yron pulled skinne bodye cutte sol feete cut finger threw downe yet aliue shewing hope concorde betweene romaine carthagies thus stirre haue hope fight came otherwise tocrueltie oute time passe thoughte carthagies conscience horrible actes made fearefull steade bloud hated asdruball hadde taken awaye hope pardon specially senate exclaymed agaynst one committed cruell proude deebes country calamitie toke certaine senate killed waxen fearefull toward rather tiranne captaine safety terrible vnto therefore wared intollerable scipio burned campe enimies left whenthe carthagini n fles byrsa fled byrsa hauing gotten grounde betweene water trenched sea sea separate enimie far might caste darte resisted worke head fiue twenty furlong fayne worke fight finished thisvvorkes scipio made another ditch equall farre former drawing towarde land two whole trenche quadrate made strong pale sharpe end pale made ditch part towarde carthage fensed wall fiue twenty furlong higth twelue foote beside tower hold set distaunce wal breadth halfe much higth tower middest highest kepe woodde foure square whiche might see done cittie dyd twentie dayes nightes armye labouring working fighting turne greatly passing forthe great trech scipio mad victual brought army within trech ser ued long wall enimie woulde take reliefe brought carthage land also except part called necke water dyd beate carthage euery chiefe cause hunger destruction multitude thestraightnesse victuall carthage citie fielde neyther coulde brought thys flege stranger comming warre victuall libya little sea wynde woulde serue reste came lande whiche waye stopped sore vexed famine bythias captaine horseman sent victual long tyme neyther durst come neare passe scipio trenche seldome slowly sent foode ship albeit romanes nauy laye towne continuallye many bicause sea dangerous tempestuuos could approche cittie carthagies walkes andthe vvay victuall carthage waues great bycause rocke therefore hoyes bithyas merchant came gaine caring nothing perill obserued winde greate made full sayle gallies able folowe blowen vehemence sea whatsoeuer ship brought asdrubal distributed asdrubal feedeth souldioures vpo thirtie thousad war little regardyng people wherefore soare troubled wyth famine scipio perceyued purposed shutte mouthe porte towarde weaste farre lande hee made long trenche beginnyng streighte betweene fenne sea called longue wrought sea stopped passage making sure great thicke stone broken billow breadth trenche scipio stoppeth part carthage foure twenty feete square botte e carthaginian beginning con emned worke thingthe carthagies make nevve port nevv shippes asking long time paraduenture impossible done army applying earnestly ceassing neither daye night afrayde digged another mouth side porte midde sea trench coulde come depth vehement windes woman chyldren digged within perceyued made shippes olde stuffe great little gallies leauing want courage boldnesse kepte secrete neuer prisoner could tell scipio certainely noyse within porte day nighte ceassing vse coulde tell till al readye carthagies brake open mouthe dauning daye issewed fiftie gallies foystes brigandine many small vessel wel set foorth terrour romaine amazed sodayn opening mouth company shippes carthagies carthagies come forth vvith nevv nauy lose occasion fate vnresistable set vpon romayne nauy men occupied wall neyther mariner present defend mighte haue gotten al fame nowe come carthage must perish made shew bolde countenaunce returned thirde daye came forth fight romaine shippes thinges prepared resiste crie call made side courage shewed mariner maistersthe fight sea carthagies carthagies liues romaine full victory many hurt slaine side til midde day fight little boates carthagies ran vnder great shippes side romanes brake stemines nowe sterne oares carthagies giue place confounde themselues much hurt easily flying easily returning fighte doubtfull toward nighte carthagies thoughte good retire ouercome prepare themselues next day small vessel fledde first shutte mouth altogither great shippes put mouth fledde trenche whiche made merchaunts wall large receyue packes ye occupier little bray made warre enimies plant playne place trenche carthagies shippes fledde lacke porte sto e stemmes enimies resisted shippes trenche bray romaynes easilye gaue onset vppon bycause fought shippes stoode departing turning long shippes slow hurtful little aduauntage turned beaten carthagies fiue shippes sidents accompanied scipio gooda feate sidents renued fight wise let fal ancres aloofe sea waying longest cable fast moored charged enimie encountred shortning vp cable retyred backe haled forward backewarde alwayes fighting face vpon enimie rest nauy seeing ye deuise sidents folowed enimies much hurt night making end rest carthage shippes fled citie scipio day toke trench place fitte annoy port therfore bea ing bray rammes bringing manye engine toke part carthagies althoughe afflycted famine diuerse euils ranne vpon romanes engine night lande way shippe sea shallowe naked linckes light seene far came sea man would haue thought breastes wadedthe carthagies run vpo romanes munition vvith desperatnesse shalows swamme til came engine threw fire perceyued receyuing much hurt bycause naked much boldnesse stroke breast face dartes speares woulde giue place wilde beast offering themselues striker til set artillery fyre driue romanes away kepte confusion wasfeare romanes campe scipio forced kil ovvne solliors kepe sro flying suche feare trouble camp whole army hadde beene furie naked enimies wherefore scipio afraide came forth horsmen commaunded beate would leaue flight beare downe killed till retourned camp necessitie saue themselues watched night armes fearing desperation enimies burned artillerie swamme home againe daye carthaginian sure engine builded vppe fore parte wall againe made many tower vpon certaine distaunce romanes made engine erected trenche towersthe carthagies trenche gotten making fire worke pitche sulphure threw vpon enimie burned many tower chased carthaginian fledde ground slippery bloud myre left chase themselues scipio end miageth carthaginian lande scipio hauing got trench compassed ditch wyth wall stone verye neare farre ennimies wall vppe put foure thousand whiche much passe enimie throwing dartes weapon vpon contempt bicause like heigth sure hit thus sommer spente winter come scipio determined take carthaginian al power friend lande sente one way another himselfe went nepheris water diogenes fauoured asdrubal lay camp sent c lalius thither land whe come encamped two furlong diogenes left gelossa molestthe asiaulte pheris diogenes continually returned carthage vsed go carthage nepheris see doings two diogenes tower fel wherfore scipio went laid choice seuldiors behind ambush brought tried men againste front willed giue assault broken tower al ranckes stil following one another former putte backe hinder followed crie greate fraye hotte al libyan turned defence thousand appointed came forth seene first entred soone perceyued wherfore libyan fled seeing many wer thinking bin many mo tha celossa set vpon numidian elephats made great slaughter killed lxx wyth nepheris tak vvith grea slaughter countrey taken fied citie nepheris taken xxij dayes great difficultie winter moyst place feate chiefly cause destruction carthage army sent victual campe libyan bolder come abrode taken place libya yeelded scipio captaines without businesse victuall seeke atvictual kept carthage carthage neyther hauing libya man power sea bicause war winter season beginning spring scipio set vpon byrsa port called agatho asdrubal night burned parte agatho agatho one port carthage quadrate thinking scipio would haue come vpon ready resist carthagies laelius side set part round laelius assault shoute made victorie afrayde romanes without dreade clymed vp set beames engine bridge vpon broke place warder weake bodyes hunger hart wall yt cat taken market place nigh scipio also toke bycause could passe night hee remayned armes till day come called fresh men went apollo teple stale picture roufe couered leaues gold waying alents cutting sword captain bidding til diuided went businesse scipio earnestly bent take byrsa ye strogest place ofthree streete byrsa citie part got wher three way fro market place many house hyghe euery side romanes shot toke first defeded theselues fro next whe gotten layde plan kes boardes betweene streygthes went vpon bridge battellthe miserable murder vpon chamber vpon streightes mette filled sighes cry lamentes diuerse passion killed hande throwen downe loftes grounde receiued vpon speares held vp swordes pykes nothing burned solares till scipto came byrsa attempt byrsa three narrow place burned burned hidden go next army might haue easie way sight ful griefe ther wasgrieuous fight flaming fire consuming men house falling little little heapes violentlye ouerthrowen great noyse followed men deade aliue specially olde men woman child fell stone hid secrete place full woundes halfe burned making pitifull crie driuen fro solares fell fire tymber broken torne horiblye diuerse way behold yet end euils ye mason e ramers pointes forkes rake deade liuing also holowe place earth turning tossing like stone tymber hole filled men turned vpside downe set heades legges shaking aboue ground feete downewarde stoode head aboue ground horse treading vpon brake face theyr braynes put purpose maker way thing purpose vehemence fight glorie victorie hande forwardenesse army trumpet crier making noyse euery tribune capitaines going wyth men encouraging made men furious passe see great desire continued broyle sixe dayes nightes euer freshe men beyng sette shoulde ouerladen watche labour slaughter grieuous fighte scipio continued without ceassing encouragyng without sleepe scipio pain abstinence taking meate wente aboute businesse tyll beyng tyred stayed stoode aboue see done manye yet slaine euill like continue longer seauenth day fledde garlandes suche vsed aesculapius temple castle moste rich goodly aesculapius temple carthagies aske pardon thousand goe byrsa desiring pardon prayed scipio yt wold go castle mighte haue liues onely graunted fugitiues except came forth fifty thousande men woman thrust togither maruellous streightnesse commaunded kepte runnawayesrenavvayes rome rome nine hundred without al hope fled aesculapius temple asdrubal wife two male child fro whence fought fiercely althoughe fewe high rockye place temple whiche time peace men went vp three score payre stayres hunger watche feare payne euil hand beset left low parte temple fledde toppe time asdrubal asdrubal flyeth scipio fled secretly scipio braunches oliue scipio put feete shewed runnawayes whiche saw desired silence giuen done reuiled asdrubal many diuerse wayes burned temple themselues say thatthe fugitiues set themselues fire wife asdruball fire tooke ouer againste scipio good behauiour time would suffer shewing hir child sayde hearing scipio romayne reuenge god thou doest accordyng order war asdrubal husbande betrayer country temple child ye god carthage shal punishe thou god turning asdrubal saide thou wicked vnfaithfull moste cowarde al men child fire shall burye thou shalt honor triumphe arte great captaine carthage paine shalt thou suffer whome thou kneelest whe thus vpbraided killed hir child threw fire hir selfe thusthe death asdrubals vvife say asdrubals wife spake died rather haue bin fit asdrubal himselfe haue done scipio seeing citie hadde continued seauen hundreth yeares ruling ouer many nation aboute power lande also shippes sea ilands full armor nauie elephant mony equall greatest kingdom boldnesse courage surpassing whiche spoyled ship al armor yet abode warre three whole yeares wyth greate famine seeing vtterly destroyed extreame siege saye hee wept openly pitiedthem ouercome calling scipio vvrepeth sight carthage ouerchrovvne mutation state vvorlde remembrance perceyuing al lotte prouinces spaine syria spaine fell topro nces lotte pompey syria cr ssus lot fell acceptable vnto bothe people woulde haue pompey cittie pompey pompey vxorius louing wife desirous farrye moste crassus shewed openly glad lot fallen thinking crassus proude prouince greater felicitie could hap vnto prouince insomuchas could bee quiet made great auauntes brag among friendes otherwise al life verye smal boaster setter forth hymselfe beyng puffed exalted onely hope get parthia syria andthe parthian vvere decree lucullus tigranes pompey vp make boundes dominion making play lucullus dydde agaynste tigranes pompey agaynste mithridates also winne bactria indus beyonde sea yet decree warre parthian contained euery man feare crassus would meddle caesar wrote letter praysing hys purpose prouoking hym warre atteius tribune didde stop voyage wyth threat manye consented grieued anye man shoulde make warre vpon men offended nothing also league crassus afraide prayed pompey caesar stirreth crassus vvarre paribians helpe set forwarde great people opinion notwythstanding sawe manye readye resist exclame gentle looke countenance appeased quiet suffred passe yet atteius stopped first voice forbidding protesting go commanded officer lay hand vpon body deteine tribune would suffer lette goe crassus atteius ran gate set burning harth asexecrations ste crassus crassus came insense sacrifice pronounced sharpe execration horrible calling naming cruell strangecurses vsed god therwith romanes thinke curse secret auntient haue power man auoide made naughte vse therfore vsed vnaduisedly manye case atteius bla ed many blamed atteius cursing crass brought cittie misfortune crassus wente br se sea yet vnnauigable winter woulde tarry tyme tooke sea loste many shyppes receyuing power footemen ledde alongest galatia finding king olde manne galatia asia lesse building cittie iested saying king beginne builde twelue clocke king laughing saide gen see goe againste parthian iest betvveen deiotarus crassus age crassus early crassus threescore year age went older see indeede marching forth matter firste tell te according hope easilye hee made bridge ouer euphrates conueyed ouer armye safely got many citties mesopotamia yeelding vnto hym one appollonius tyranne slaine one hundred souldiors brought power thither wanne tooke money solde men greekes call cittie zenodotium taking zenodotium tie osr ne woulde needes called imperator souldioures caused muche discredite vnto lesse esteemed one distrusted greate victorie taking occasion little matter sette garrison citties taken number whereof seauen thousande footemenne one thousande horse hee went syria winter hys son crassus sonne caesar came caesar oute fraunce rewarded wyth greate honoures souldioure bringing one thousande picked horseman firste great error crassus greate offence leading armye oughteerrour crassus haue gone babilon seleucia citties euer ennimies parthian hee gaue ennimies time prepare themselues babilon chie citie chaldea tarrying syria blamed beeyng rather lyke receyuer rente captayne souldioures searche number souldiors vse exercise gathered reuenues city venus iun name irthe godde h e apolis n nature beginning seede al thing ministring cause moisture going onte temple firste yong crassus fell doores olde man fell vppon hym nowe gathering power place embassador came arsaces brrefe speach thusthe parthian message crassus arsaces king parth vvhose good rule parth an call king arsaces sele cia one syria antiochena e phra e third belu saide army sent romanes warre made contrary league neuer woulde ende without authoritie hys countrey hys owne gaine hearde come armes againste parthian take lande arsaces woulde temper hymself pitie crassus age let romanes go rather like garrison army crassus swelling ayde woulde make answere seleucide auntient embassadours vagise wing bare palme hollowe hand said sooner shall hairsthe italian text varieth grow thou shalt see seleucia thus bold lye spake signifying orodes must first ouercome f romane garrison city mesopotamia escaping muche danger tell fearefull matter theya sharp ansvver sawe multitude enimies exercise howe hadde fortified citties purpose tell ng thing vttermost v r su table caine gh vnrecouerable fledreport encrea eng feare arrowes te woulde preuent sight coulde see shooter woulde hande strike thorowo men armes beate downe afore coulde resisted army hearde began meni betvveene ru capa region pontus called leucosyri faint thinking parthian differed nothing arn nians cappodocians whome lucu lu ouercame without resistaunce therefore thought paine shoulde long iorney shoulde come blowes enimies woulde abide whereas nowe otherwise supposed great trauaile daunger hande insomuche officer camp thought good staye crassus take newe aduise matter secreatlye maisters sacrifice shewed manye euill harde token appeared crassus sacrificessacrifices shevve euill token hee neither woulde heare exhorted hym goe forwarde among whych artabases king armenia didde let prouoke art base king armenia nd dued vvith le ng vvhom antony took treason caried triuniphe alexandria please cleopatra crassus refuseth good counsell come campe sixe thousande horsememe called guarde defence king promisyng tenne thousande menne armes three thousande footemenne charge hee perswaded crassus inuade parthia armenia whereby shoulde leade armye onely safely ministring thynges also thorowe mountaynes continuall hill place combersome parthian horsemenne wherein consistes theyr strength cr ssus praised good wyll hym goodly preparation yet hee sayde hee woulde enter mesepotan ia lefte many good romane souldiours armenian went way crassus dde armye ouer bridge manye terrible token crassus thunder brake oute greate lightning flashed face souldiours winde mixed cloudy perry arose brake consumed muche matter made brydge place appointed campe twice stricken lightnyng borse generalls verye fayre cladde carrying waye rider violence owned theyr sight saye chiefe standerd beyng firste taken bearer turne backe selfe beside chaunced iorney meate shoulde giuen souldiours firste hadde l ntilles soppes whyche romaynes thinke vsed burialls crassus made hys oration hys voyce failed hym whyche armye tooke heauily sayd cut bridge man returne ouer word vncomely spoken whera folish vvorde pa eth crassus shoulde haue repeated declared made afrayde would frowardnesse last hadde killed sacrifice make sol mne viewe armye minister giuen bowel fell handes whiche present grieued smiled saying e incommodities age weapon shall neuer fal hads crassus excuseth vveakenes ledde army floude hauing seauen legiens little lesse foure thousande horse number shotte equal skoutes went see way returned brought worde countrey voyde men print horse feete gone backe whereat crassus tooke good hope souldiours beganne crassus vaine hope seleucia plentifull place despise parthian afrayde come handes yet cassi others spake crassus perswading staye menne cittie garrison till better instructed enimies force would go seleucia floude shoulde haue aboundaunce ofthe counsel cassius folovved victual souldiours solde also defence safegarde armye enuironed floude beeyng euer equall fyghte wyth enimye face crassus considering pondering thing acbar vseth craft vvith crassus came president arabi acbaros name subtile dissembling manne greatest prouoker euyll fortune ente theyr destruction hadde serued vnder pompey knewe receyuiug humanitie hys hande shewing friende romaine sente crassus consent king counsel turne coulde floude foote hils playn field might compassed deuised thing rather come fight yth romanes hande acbarus came crassus sayde probablye firste prayse pompey benefactoure crassas blaming hauing greate power acbarus deceyneth crassus lost time delay preparation though need armour rather handes ooif e f te alreadye seeke gather moste precious rich carrie ythia hircania sayde wyll ythia asia hir ania play region aboundant fighte must quicklye whole power gathered king taking harte againe nowe suren sillaces commeth make warre king seene al lye king went streight power inuade armenia fa bian king inuadeth armenia se deth surenas romanes punish artabaze sent surenas againste romaynes contempt saye like would contemne crassus sent hym one chiefe romaynes go artabazes destroye townes armenia thinke afrayde daunger laye wayte see ende appoynted surena beyng otherwyse expert acquainted wyth war surenas none common sorte rich surena sen crassus glorye bloude nexte king chiefe parthia strength youth beautye goodlynesse bodye inferiour none carried alwayes thousand laden camel two hundred chariot concubine thousand men armes light horseman tenaunts seruantes lesse ten thousand horse touching bloud giuen beginningthe nobility surenas set crowne vpon king head new king made called orodes exile hys kingdome orodes brought exile suren toke great citie seleucia first aled walles owne hande repulsed resisted yet thyrty yeares age yet greatest glory wisedome experience litle beguile crassus first thorough pride boldnesse afterthe text varieth hys feare aduersitie easily entrapped acbarus hadde brought crassus floud playne fieldes wythout woodde water wythout ende reste appeared trauelled wyth thirst dificultie also vncomfortable prospect eye seeing neyther tree riuer apparaunce hyl growing grasse shape like sea fearful desarts besette armye cra te beganne espied furthermore came messenger artabazes artabazes signifieth inuaded king armenia shewing deteyned greate warre orodes hauing inuaded coulde sende helpe crassus yet wished hym anye wise turne make waye armenia togither mighte goe orodes king part orodes alwayes marche encampe hee might auoyde horseman go hylles crassus writing nothing againe anger straungenesse aunswered crassus maketh frovvard aunsvvere nowe leysure deale armenia returned would punish artabazes treason cassius agayne grieued leauing crassus woulde heare good counsel playnely rebuked acbarus crassus mi iketh iourney naughty wight wicked brought thee v passion witchcraftes hast thou made crassus leade army desarts vglye wildernesse fitter archtheefe numidia chiefe generall romaine arbarus crafty man dyd speake fayre comforted arbarus deceiueth rest exhorted endure whyle riding among souldiours sted thinke goyng campania fountaines riuers shadowes brooke brayes ostanes wayes doe remember go confines arabia arabia tvvo part b r nne assiria furthest part sy assiria thus acbarus playe holer among romaine craft perceyued road vnknowen crassus agreeing though woulde prouide defeate enimies sayde crassus thatmore token uil daye came abroade purple manner romaine general blacke garmente changed againe perceyued ensignebearers could without great laboure pull vppe ensignes stucke fast crassus laughing went faster bad legion follow horseman came espyes bin abroad haste shewing felowes killed enimies escaped ennimies came great power speed troubled crassus set men order orderlye cassius moued legion thinne could fill playne fear compassing diuide horseman wing altered made serue wayes square battayle euerye de going twelue bandes troupe horseman part shoulde voyde helpe horseman eueryside like defended fight appointed one wing cassius yong crassus went middest thus marching came riuer call balissus great full water acceptable thebalissus souldiours hote dry iourney greate payne p rie water manye captaines thoughte good staye til certaine knowledge come enimies force purpose daye come goe againste crassus commaunded sonne horseman wyth hym go ready fight badde eate drinke kept order well done hee led leysure pausing fight much speede haste tyl sawe enimies great shewe neyther appearing many fearefull romaynes sir putte multitude behinde hydden bryghtnesse arne lo skinnes come nygh token giuen captaines firste filled allthe parthian manner going fight playne wyth barbarous noyse fearefull shoutes parthian go battell wyth horne trumpet drummes many place made leather hollow stretched yron barres beate vpon continually maketh noyse holow deepe like roaring wilde beastes intermedled sharpnesse thunder nothing could harde sence hearing bringeth trouble minde soonest moued troubleth vnderstanding romanes astonished noyse parthia threw away couers harnesse sodainely appeared shyning armoure made beste steele bright horseman barded caparison likewise goodliest greatest wassurenas surenas finesse w mannish aray like glorie valiauntnesse rather decked median fashion trymming person diuisio haire parthian vgly purpose terrour sh dding heare first gaue onset spear diuide breake fore warde sawe firmnesse battel stable abiding men went backe though would haue scattered diuided order compassed battell circle wet crassus commaunded light h r sse giue charge vppon went farre ouerlaide shotte turned againe thruste among thethe beginning disorder romanes campe legion gaue beginning disorder feare saw might shot continuall course breaking harnesse bearing alike vnarmed well armed parthian distant little beganne shoote ntures directing shotte romanes battayle thicke coulde mysse thoughe woulde gyuing continuall hurte woundes strong great bowes violence drawing driuing arrow stronger vndoing romanes continuing order stroken trying go vpon ennimy keepe close againe suffered alike parthian shotte fledde thinkethe parthian manner vva e beste eate according scythian moste wise parte hurte saue themselues hid shame fleeing pretence long romanes hopedthe parthian e shotte shot done would haue come hads abode saw number camells come laden newe shotte whiche firste spente arrowes wente receiue crassus himselfe thought woulde haue ende wherefore sente messenger sonne shoulde set vppon ennimie beefore inclosed moste busy vpon hym rode come vpon backe yong man tooke xiij c horse whereof thousand caesar ight band next footemen badde set vpon r enimies parthian foremoste either bicause myrie grounde saye bycause woulde drawe crassus pollicie farre coulde turned fledde young crassus rying thoughe theyyong crassus vvith censorinus gaba u would haue turned againe gaue chase censorinus gaba u passed valiantnes strength censorinus order senatoure eloquent friend yong crassus like age horseman going footman folowed courage fearefulnesse hope thoughte haue victorie chase gone farre perceyued deceit seemed ee turned againe many comming stayed thinking woulde haue come handes bicause fewe set men armes vpon romanes horse confusedlye rode vppon troubling playne raysing heapes sande making full duste romanes coulde neither see speake driuen thrustethe romane killed togyther ouerthrowen dyed easily shorte death shriking sorowfull manner laboring breake arowes woundes prouing violence pul forked heades enited vaines stnowes fore lamented themselues many thus dead aliue vnprofytable helpe andromanes vnable helpe publius exhorted set vppon men armes shewed handes nayled shieldes theyr feete fastened grounde coulde neyther flye fight brought horseman fiercely vpon weake stryking defendyng weake little speares vpon strong armour steele galatian stryken long speares vpon vnarmed body trusted muche maruellous feates toke speares bare men horse could moued waightthe valiantnes galatian harnesse many left horse stroke enimies horse belly payne threwe theyr ryders trode vpon enimies tyll dyed also heate thirst troubled galathians accustomed neyther many hauing lefte horse staues fought contrary therfore could haue gotten legion hauing publius crassus sore vvounded publius among euill bestadde wound seeing hyll sande farre went thyther putting horse middest defending outwarde partes target thoughte mighte easilye put backe barbarian came otherwise passe beeing playne former kepte hindermost hurte went mounting ground daunger came behinde moste none escaped al shotte indifferently lamenting deathes voyde reuenge glorie publius carria great asis irna two men grecian dwelling carria ieronimus nichomacus moued goe flye irna towne helde romaynes answered wasa noble ansvver yong man deathe grieuous feare whiche publius woulde leaue dyed therfore prayed saue themselues gently sent away coulde vse hande hurte arrowe therfore commanded page take sword runne therowe sydethe death p crassus tvvo friendes censorinus died sort magabactus killed himselfe dyed noble rest parthian killed speares fighting themselues onelye fiue hundred taken aliue hadde cutte heades publius crassus hope company tourned toward crassus stoode sorte hadde sente sonne encounter parthian one hadde tolde hym greate fleeing sore chase ennimies sawe came vppon went also part beganne take comforte leading army rising place thinking son would haue come straight chase firste sent publius tell daunger taken enimies slaine hardely escaping shewed publius vndone crassus perplexed except speedy great helpe sent nowe crassus dynersly troubled could see reason howe vse matter one side feare whole desire saue sonne doubting might helpe helpe yet ende went forward power nowe enimies come terrible shewt declaryng victorie striking many armenian feared romanes looking battell brought head publius vpon spearsthe parthian shevve spight point approching nighe despight asking parent kinred could thinke sonne crassus cowardly lewd man young man noble renowmed vertue fight al grieuous romanes directing breaking hart anger reuenge oughte vtterly feare dreade crassus shew selfe noble case say went aboute hoste cried crassus shevveth himselfe noble romanes proper losse greate glorye fortune rome keepe vnbroken aud vntouched haue pitie haue loste good sonne shewe youre anger vppon ennimies take away ioy reuengethe vvordes crassus comforte souldioures crueltie dismaide done great feat must sometime suffer lucullus ouercame tigranes without bloudeshed scipio antiochus auncestors loste thousande shippes sicilie italy manye capitames army woulde lette losse get victorie againe romanes haue come great dominion fortune sufferaunce manhoode calamitie crassus saide encourage didde seea declaration romanes faintnesse many willingly heare hym therefore badde make noise whiche bewrayed faintnesse army made seeble weake crie whiche answered barbartans wyth chearefull bolde sounde comming togither shotte enimies troubled romanes side comming vppon speares face droue litle roomth yet fleeyng death shotte came oute fight hande little purpose dispatched greatethe fight mortall woundes many time sharpe long speares passing thorowe horse man thus night brake battaile saying wouldethe parthian reste arsaces gratifie crassus one night bury sonne consider hymselfe whither better go arsaces led thus going place nigh hande greate hope romanes hadde heauy night neither burying deade healing hurte dying lamenting themselues thing appeared wythoute helpe remembred day woulde bring care shoulde goe awaye night huge playnes carry hurte souldioures would lette vnto lefte behinde woulde crie disclose theyr going away althoughe thoughte crassus authour al euill yet desired see hym heare hym speake hee himselfe face couered darke example comon sort fortune wise want wisedom crassus exemple fortune mutabilitie ambition contente one chiefe gretest among many thousand suche bicause iudged inferior onely two men thought hymselfe least octauius legate cassius raised badde good cheere sawe vtter desperation called officer captaines shewing tarrying departe withoute sounde trumpe secreately whiche done hurte men perceyuing forsaken great lamentation sorrowfull crie made camp staide trouble feare thoughe enimie come vpon resting take wounded men bestow cary lette vnto sauing three hundredegnatius carras coponius whiche egnatius led carras midnight speaking latin watch willed tel coponius captain garrison great fielde sought betweene crassus egnatius euill thoughte thought hee saued bande parthian saide asked went bridge saued bande yet euill thought bicause forsoke generall notwithstanding worde spoken copenio good crassus thinking well bicause sodaine straunge speech gathered men togither went meete crassus way receiue souldiors cittie parthian hearing going awaye night folow daye come killed lefteromanes killed whiche lesse foure thousande playne ouertooke manye horseman killed foure bandes vergunteius led night losing waye vargunteius hys bandes slaine slaine without resistance except twentie breaking thorowe naked swordes ennimiestvventie souldioures suffred passe enimies maruelling manhoode suffred passe souldiors marche carras false tale tolde surena crassus wyth chiefe fledde common sorte receyued carras hee thinking victorie yet gotten standing doubt coueting learne truthe eyther might besiege suren vseth crassus cittie followe crassus let hym goe sent one men could speake tongue wall commaunding speake latine call crassus cassius tell surenas woulde speake tolde crassus message receiued shortly came certaine arabian knewe crassus cassius hauing bin camp fight seeing cassius vpon wall saide surenas would make friendes king saue woulde departe mesopotamia better trie vttermost casius accepting requiring time place crassus deceipt surena meete togither answering doe departed surenas hearde messenger glad place besieged willed parthian next daye goe greate crie require romanes woulde haue peace parthian sende crassus cassius bounde king grieued deceiued counselled crassus leaue long vaine hope armenia saue himselfe let none carrenans knowe made knowne andromachus false fellowe whome trusted crassus deceiued andromachus made guide way nothing kepte parthian tolde andromachus custome fight night sure thing crassus went night shoulde farre folowing fleeing capitaines andromachus ledde romanes way waye laste putte fenny marrish place hard footme folow thought wel andromachus turning compassing followed therefore cassius went againe carras cassius retourneth guids arabian willed make hast moone paste scorpion saide feare sagittarie went syria fiue hundred horse hauing gote good guide went hilly place whiche called synacha safe daye hadde sy cha ouertaken aboute fiue thousande octauius good man leader daye come crassus weary iorney fenne strange way ledde andromachus foure bandes legatemen fewe horse fiue sergeant whome hauing weary iorney scarcely staying rest ennimies hand hadde myle halfe ioyne octauius therefore little hyll able kepe horse backe otherwise sure ioyning synaces stretching long space thorowe octauius cometh helpe crassus large field nighe octauius might see daunger firste octauius went fewe saue hym reprouing themselues folowed kept ennimies hyll compassed crassus middest defended tergats shot parthian shoulde hurte generall fighting slaine surenas sawe parthian slowly feate night came romanes goingnevve vvyle surenas hilly place ouertaken wroughte wile wyth crassus caused talke campe romane captaines might heare king would crassus continually deceiued make war continually romanes would bee gladde friendeship vse crassus gently wente tolde barbarian ceassed fight surenas chiefe went quietly hill vnbent bowe offred righte hande called crassus truce saying agaynste king proued force power nowe hee shoulde willingly feele clemencie mildenesse beeing confedered suffer goe safe surena saide gladde woulde haue followed crassus credite thoughte sodaine change taken therefore thoughte good take aduice yet souldiours cried angry obiecting woulde caste villainously slaine ennimies durst go talke vnarmed beganthe souldiours compell crassus take vvorst vvay desire abide rest day night passe hilles safe wayes shewed waye prayed caste away hope health whiche hand reuiling bending weapon compelled afraide went turning said thus octau petrons captaines romanes crassus army presente see necessitie going tell sowle violence suffer therefore tell al men escape crassus deceyued enimies died forsaken citizen octauius souldioures tarry came hill macebearer crassus put away firste came hym barbarian two halfe greekes alighting horse honored saluting hym greeke wished hym sende whome surenas mighte shewe without armor weapon crassus answered hadde anye little hope life woulde go yet sente riscous two brothren learne howe many shoulde come whome surenas deteined chiefe hee came horsebacke meaneth saide hee romane generall af te mounted commaunded horse broughte forum surenas crassus crassus answered neyther offend came talke maner country surena saide henceforth good peace shoulde betweene surenas vvithout saith romanes king condition must written floude whither woulde goe romanes aunt romanes said mindfull youre couenaunts holde forthe right hand crassus called horse shall neede quoth surenas king giueth thee horse brought crassus trapped gold setting vppe went stroke horse go away crassus sed led avvaye octauius first tooke bridle petronius tribune rest stood one striuing make horse goe keepe backe stay horse whiche tumulte fray began octauius drew sword killed one barbarian horsekeepers octauius slaine killed octauius thrusting thorow behinde petronius weapon stroke curet escaped vnhurte maxarthes parthian killed crassus saye maxarthes crassus killed killed cutte heade right hande rather coniectured knowne present fought aboute crassus killed fledde againe hyll parthian went awaye sayingmiserable ende crassus romanes crassus worthy punishment al surenas badde come downe boldely yeelded fledde night whiche fewe saued chased arabian killed say twenty thousand slaine tenne thousandethe number romanes slaine taken surenas sent crassus head hand orodes armenia spreading rumor seleucia broughte crassus aliue sente messenger prepare mocking sporte iest calling triumphe one caius among captines like caius spight done crassus h death crassus cladde queenes robe commanded whensoeuer called crassus generall shoulde aunswere ledde horsebacke certaine trumpeter macebearer riding camelles purse tyed roddes heades romaynes cutte ax folowed greate company harlottes baudes seleucia speaking many opprobrious laughing matter againste effeminate cowardise crassus al followed calling auntients seleucia togither shewed theballades founde red spite aristides milesi rescius wanton writing aristides milesia therein lie founde carriage rescius ministred great matter reproue blame romanes euen warres doe refraine suche fonde manner writing seleucians aesopus seemeth wise man seeing surenas blame bag blessed happy hunting al repeate came aboute agayne quyre shoulde syng mine mine rewarde maxarthes leapte forth set table tooke head saying appertained hadde king glad giuen rewardthe killer crassus antonie hearing prepared toantonie go parthian called home letter wife fuluia sent weeping turned italie accorde caesar pompey ruled sic lie sent againe asia ventidius represse parthian co mingventidius forewarde fauour made holy minister former caesar thing como friendly antonie made minister diuine caesar ciuil moste greate matter prophete aegipt cunning men natiuities eyther gratifye cleopatra tell truth spake antonie southsaye freely saying thy fortune noble great ouerlayde caesar counselled farre coulde yong man thine angel sayd wise feareth angell appeared antonie gaue credite antony angel afraide octa u angel thought better aegiptian committyng thing caesar sayled grecia whylest athene first newes came ventidius good proceeding ventidius hath good lucke parthia ouercome parthian slaine labinius phraartes chiefe captaynes king orodes feasted grecian made ruler athenian schole went warre ware garlande holy oliue according oracle carried hym vessel ful ye foutain clepsidra tolde ventidius ouerthrown pacorus clepsidra vvas vvel castle athens king sonne great armie parthian inuading syria agayne cyristica many slain among pacorus slaine whiche pacorus one firste acte one noblest romanes reuenged misfortune crassus droue parthian againe medium mesopotamia ouercome three battells togither ventidius ventidius leaueth furder againste parthian feare antony enuy samosata bringeth forth earth setteth vvater afire parte syria called comagene refrayned followe parthian fearing enuy antonie reuolted recouered againe besieged antiochus comagenus cittie samosatis offring thousand talent doe antonie command ventidius badde sende antonie hand ventidius wold haue antiochus make peace acte mighte redounde honoure leaste shoulde seeme done vetidius siege continuing longer inhabitance desperatio peace turning courage antonius deceyued hope returneth doyng nothing ventidius triumpheth parthian octauius antonie fortunate lieutenaunts themselues sosius canidius phraartes killeth father orodes heartes antonie content let antiochus go three hundred talent tarryed syria returned athens rewarding ventidius worthie sent triumphe day triumphe parthian man base byrth comming great estimation waighty matter antony friendship vsing wisely made saying caesar antonie found true fortunate captaines themselues sosius antony lieutenaunt syria dydde many thing canidius lefte armenia ouercame hiberian albanian king droue farre iberia nighe hyll caucasus full veni e vvhence came novv inhabite spaine antonie vvoulde giue revvarde comparable king persia larissa many name one asia nighe tralus arethusa one syria another lubaa hierapolis mesopotamia caucasus whereby antony name renoumed among barbarian phraartes killed father orodes taken kingdome many parthian fledde away monesius noble mighty man fledde antonie waying man fortune themistocles comparing power king persia gaue three city larissa arethusa hierapolis called bambyce monesius called home againe king let goe meaning deceiue king hope peace desirous recouer ensignes crassus captiues aliue sent cleopatra aegipt went arabia armenia gather power confederate king many greatest artabazes armenia giuing sixe thousande horse seauenforces antonie bactrians people scythia assia thousand footman mustred men lx footemen romanes ordinarie horseman iberian frenchman ten thousand nation thirty thousand horsmen shotte great preparation power made bactrians indian afrayde asia shake saye cleopatra made come cleopatra cause decay greate preparation little profite making haste winter hir tooke due time warre vsing al thing confusedly one wittes abused sorcery witchcraft antonie abused cleopatra hir thought make haste hir get victorie ennimies oughte haue wintredeight furlong maketh myle armenia rested weary army gone viij furlong parthian come winterings inuade medium beginning ye spring would tarry time led army armenia lefte hande came atropatea wasted region atropatea part parte medium hauing engine necessarie ouerthrowe city followed campe three hundred chariot whiche one called ramme length foureramme engine beate vvalles cittie antony leaueth hys artillerie behinde phraata besieged score foote broken coulde made againe bicause ledde armye countrey plaine barren wood length hardnesse left behind impediment haste appointing captain kepe besieged phraata greate cittie whiche wife child king medium antony error feeling want engine knewe erred leauing behind therefore would winne citie mountes whiche great labour slowe diuise nowe came king phraartes great army hearing thethe artillerie taken keeper killed leauing cariage engine sent many horsme statianus chiefe romanes killed ten thousande statianus polemon killed barbarian tooke engine destroyed manye people whiche polemon king made antony army afraide might receiue losse beginning artabasses armenian king dyspayring romaine returned artabazes forsaketh romanes home army albeit ye cause war besieged trusted vpon parthian muche vsed spitefull language antonie thinking good souldiours courage shoulde abated lying ydly loke tenne legion three bandes guarde hys horseman wente forage thinking prouoke hys enimies fighte deale orderly gone one onely dayes iourney sawe parthian fetching compasse seeking stoppe waye hee commaunded token fight giuen campe leauied though woulde fight marche passed barbarian sette like crescent commaunding horseman footemen nigh mighte fight horseman turne vpon parthian parthian maruel good order romanes iudge romaine order better reason behelde marching wyth equall distaunce quietlye silence shaking weapon token giuen went shoute horseman turned vppon enimie receyued defence although within shotte footemen came crye clashing armour horseman parthian gaue placethe romanes haue victorie smal accompt disorder fledde came handes antonie followed chase hauing greate hope make ende eyther whole warre great part folowed chase footemen sixe mile horsemenne thrice muche found taken thirtie slayne foure scoure euerye manne thinking harde case hauing victorye shoulde kyll fewe loosyng theyr engine manye ouercome fell greate discourage doubte themselues next daye passed phraartes campe waye founde first fewe enimies last inuincibly hurte prouoked euerye set vpon hardly muche adoe romanes went campe citie haddethe romaine hardly gette campe mace sallie put romanes trenche antony angry punished euery tenth deaththe romaynes punished lod according deserte taking euery tenth lotte hadde forsaken place insteade wheate hee gaue barley warre painefull bothe continuance fearefull antonie perceyuing hunger would folowe coulde get forage without death hurte souldiors phraates knowing parthian rather doe thing lie fielde land winter afraide thatautumne craftie practise romanes hold tarry woulde leaue hym ayre begynning chaunge time equall day night hande deuised crafte best parthian vsed romanes gently foraging encounter suffering carry away thing praysing vertue men moste valiaunt warre great estimation king wel worthy meane comming nearer togither suffring horsemenne passe spake euill antonie bicause phraates woulde gladly haue peace spare good many menne giuen none occasion would tarry abide two gret harde enimies winter hunger whichevvinter hunger tvvogreat enimies coulde hardely escape thoughe parthian would suffer many declaring antonie deceiued hope antony deceyued deferred sende heraulte parthian king till knewe wel willing barbarian spake muche king consent affirming promising ought doubt dreade sent one friendes againe requiring receiue ensign captiues might thought altogither saue himselfe escape parthian aunswering shoulde passe departe shoulde haue peace safete wherefore wythin fewe dayes brake vppe went way whereas eloquent perswading wente people armye hys oration shame heauinesse omitted antonie committeth speeche souldiours another contrary vvonte speake multitude commaunded domitius aenobarbus angry though despised parte content perceyued matter therefore thought rather graunt obey generall beeing aboute leade playne barren waye mardi people hyrcania mardus taketh vppon leade armye best vvay man kinde called mardus acquainted parthian fashion faithfull romanes fielde engins came antonie willed flee right hand hill caste armye laden harnesse weary iourneys suche mighte horse shorte phraates vnder shewe beneuolence went aboute ent woulde leade hym shorter way whiche shoulde haue sufficiencie thing antonie heard tooke counsel said would seeme distruste parthian touching peace shortnesse way plentifull townes inhabited hee mardus bounde praysed mardus requyred saith offred till brought armenia bound ledde ij day quietlie done antony looking parthian come vppon antonie sodaine parthian going negligently bycause boldenesse marde sawe banke floud newe broken much water enterunning place shoulde passe knewe parthian worke make way harder set floude impdeiment vnto willed antonie ennimie farre while set hys men order commaunded shotte encounter beholde parthian appeared came woulde haue compassed dissolued army shotte comming vppon hurte done side retyred afterfrench horsmen came againe french horsmen encountred putte backe day attempte antonie learning shoulde placed manye shotte onely taile one side leadyng armye square commaunding horseman putte backe ennimies followe farre parthian foure dayes hauyng done hurte receiued waxed flowe entended goe waye making wynterflauius gallus pretence fifth daye flauius gallus good souldioure forwarde feates warre required antonie giue shotte hys rerewarde horsmen hys fore warde woulde good seruice gaue kept backe ennimies nowe returning footemen following fighting courage whenthe hencite gallus sobernesse titius leader aile saw go far called hym backe would say titius take ensigne turne backe rebuke gallus woulde lose manye good men rebuked agayne badde medle owne matter titius went way gallus setting vppon face compassed backe besette rounde aboute sente helpe bringing footemen among whiche canidius canidius committeth greate errour man great fauour antonie seemed committe greate erroure oughte haue broughte forthe whole battaile haue sent forth band one ready help another whiche weake haue supplied perceyued wanted little whole army putte worste flight antonie hadde brought legion set face third legion passed among fledde stayed enimie chase slaine lesse thana slaughter romanes three thousande came tentes wounded fyue thousande gallus among shotte thorowe four arrowes coulde healed woundes antonie went comforted wyth teares bad good antonie comforteth menne cheare chearfully taking hande prayed hym comfort himselfe diseased calling chiefe generall saying well whole generally antonie verye good captaine captain led noble armi neither stregth patience boldnesse dayes reuerence obedience beneuolence indifferen lye noble vnnoble ruler priuate men euer giuen captaine antonie preferring hym owne liues health might compare aunt ent romanes diuers cause haue saide gentlenessecauses souldiours loue tovvarde eioquen e plainenesse liberalitie magnificence courtesie myrth speeche woulde pitie comforte sicke giue needed made sicke hurte assured enimies victorie suche pride thoughe weary almost refusing fight contemning romanes night encamped hard thinking straight haue spoiled voide tent sacked money fled day come many saye lesse fortie thousande horsemenne king sending still vnto sure certaine victorie whither wonne lost antonie shoulde speake souldioures woulde antony discoura ed haue blacke garment might pitied friend suffering came captaines purple robe spake vnto praysing done well dispraysing fledde whiche prayed good comforte con essed faulte offered punyshed euery tenth man waye chastice onely antony prayer prayed cease sorrowe grie e holding vppe hand prayed goddes ther reuenge towarde hys former felicitie mighte lighte hym reste armye mighte haue healthe victorye nexte day marched better guarded parthian followed much dec iued purpose thought come spoile pray fight beyng resisted great cheerefulnesse souldieures wearie againe romanes went certaine hillsthe manner romanes againste par came vpon made sharpe shotte target men turned vpon couered shotte shiel target hid easily kneeling knee stoode behind defended armor manner forme bowing alike euery way made figure theatre surest waye auoyde shotte arrowes sliding away parthian thinkingthe parthian deceyued fight stouping romanes vpon knee bin hea e thirst vnbent owes spear came nig romanes rising odai ly crie set vpon wringing weapon handes killed foremost made runne away like done dayes giuing little way famine falling army little mea e bi ause oftenthe miserie romanes fight wanting milles grinde corne loste wyth engine lefte behinde bicause many beast killed sicke wounded men borne say athens bushel wheate worth fiftie dram chani atti co taineth sextarij sextarij sixte part corg dragm vvas muche romane penny hearbs hurtefu vvl che soldioures eat hearbe making men mad barley worth waighte siluer driuen hearbs rootes ound vsuall sorte compelled proue vnknowne first lighted vpon hearbe brought death maddenesse eate remembred nothing knew nothing one thing moue turne stone thing great waighte done fielde full stowped grounde digged remoued stone length vomiting choller dyed wine whiche remedy spent many deade parthian ceassing say antonie many time cried ten thousande grecian passed field loste captaine vvithout hurte tenne thousande praising xenophon go farre longer way babilon fighting many battells saued themselues r thians could draw asunder breake order diuers time put worse ed waxing quiet againe gotte among went forage shewyng string bowes loose said would retire make ende chase ewe median folowed et daye two hurte onely guarding town medium wordes gaue salutation went gentlenesse much romanes cheerefull agayne antonie soone led hope whiche antonie hearde hee sayde would go playne rather hylles lacke water mindyng thus doe one named mi hrid y came enimies beyng cousine moneso bene antonie three citties gyuen hym desired mighte come hym coulde speake par hi n median tongue alexander antiochia cred antonie beyng sente hym hee sayde come yeelde thankes mithrida e sent mon gi eth antonie vvarning monesus asked alexander ee sawe highe long hylles hym sayde vnder sayde hee parthian lie wayte army greate fielde stretcheth hilles thinke beyng deceyued leaue way hilles bycause thirst labour antonie go way lette knowe fall crassus calamitie antonie beyng troubled harde conferred antonie gri ued friendes mardus guyde way thought lesse knewe though none enimies iourney playnesse waylesse vncertaine harde strange finde way hilles none difficultie wante water one day beyng turned commaunded goe night carie water wasthe parthian come night wante vesselles therefore caried water headpeeces skinnes goyng beyng knowen parthian came vpon night contrary maner rysing sunne molested tayle weary watchyng labour gone night twoo hundreth fortie furlong thinking enimies woulde haue come soone discouraged neyther drinke muste fight went former chaunced meete floudde whose watervvater tful colde cleare salte venemous whiche eing dronke dyd wring belly torment inflamed drouthe though mardus gaue warnyng notwithstandyng eate woulde haue stayed dronke antonie came among prayed content whyle floud e good water farre residueof way sharpe horseman whiche enimies would leaue blowing retreate commaunded pitche tentes least soldiours might repose shadowe tentes beyng tte parthian goyng wa wante mi hr e came agayne wil eda nevv vva ni g alexander came see armie shoulde take little reste goe make haste floudde bycause parthian woulde goe yther woulde folow beyng tolde antonie alexander brought hym cuppes vessel golde alexander taking many hee coulde carie vnder ke wente waye remoued w nt reste day without trouble enimies night made theselues moste vn ot fearefull killed anydisorder romanes cape amog theselues golde siluer spoyled money caried ende nfacked antony cariage tooke awaye vessell table golde diuided amongst great feare confusion whole armie thought enemy turned spoyled people antonie called one hys g rde whise name ram n antonie dispay e made hym hee commaunded hym hee shoulde hys rde thorough cut head mighte neyther ee taken aliue enimie knowne wh hee dead friendes weepyng mar omforted antonie oudde neere hande moist breath felt colde ayre came vnto thata colde aire declareth floude hande made breathing sweete time quoth iorney doth agree ye measure little night left came said tumult rise iniurie spoile among themselues therfore bringing multitude confusion feare order commanded encamp day began shewe army beginning take little reste archer parthian fel vpon hindermoste wherefore token fight giuen shotte armed men couering themselues againe shield staied ou e enimy fore warde going little floud appeared horseman keeping enimies caryed ouer sicke men first while fighting leisure quiet drinke parthian saw floud vnbended bow badde romanes go boldely commending much theyr vertue passed quiet gathered togyther againe great truste parthian went sixte day last fighte came floude araxes cometh hyll euphrates dothe araxes diuiding medium armenia appeared deepe swift saide enimies came set vpon passage quietly passed come armenia thoughe seene land sea kneeled downe teares embracing one another ioye ranne togither nowe going plentifull country al vsing superfluitiethe reioicing romanes come armenia want fell drop e chollycke disease antonie made muster founde xx footementhys vvarre vvas accop ed lacke armenian horseman horseman slaine enimies ore halfe disease going h sea twentie day ouercame parthian eighteene battells victory substaunce suretie made ofte small chase well perceyued artabazes armenian cause antonie coulde bring war end sixteene thousande horse hee led medium might haue done best seruice parthian armed like accustomed fight wyth ed romanes fight haue chased ouercome could haue bin bold set vpon againe oft army anger moued antonie reuenged king vsing discretion neyther blame defection change wonted humanitie honor army yet weake needy afterwarde come againe armenia fayre word promise persuading come handes toke carried bounde triumph alexandria grieued romanes goodly antonie taketh king maketh triumph alexandria vvhiche grieueth romanes comely thing country translated alexandria cleopatra sake thus betweene king medium parthia fell variaunce begonne say romanes spoyle median king da ger thereby loose kingdome sent antonie promising make war power therefore antonie broughte greatehope supposed wanted nothing ouercome parthian horsmen archer saw offred gratify without asking prepared go armenia ioyne median floud araxes moue warre called backe intercession octauia cleopatra deferred median til next sommer although parthian diuisio yet going made league maryed one daughter sonne cleopatra returned againe ciuil warre end romanes vvar vvith parthian p romanes war illyria appian alexandria grecian thinke illyrian illyria novv slau chaonia part mou taines thesprotia next chaonia paeonia parte macedonia breadth length illyria haue dwelling beyond macedonia thraecia chaonia thesprotia floud hister greatnesse reacheth macedonia mountaines thracia paeonia alpes three day iourney length muche greater three partes grecian thinke romaynes measuring ground thinke sixe thousand furlong length thousand two hundereth breadth affirme countrey haue name beginning illyria sonne polyphemus polyphemus illyrius sonne polyphemus celte part fraunce lion taulantij antient beginning great countrey illyria whiche scordiscians triballians greate possession fought long togither till triballians lefte fled celtes beyond hister nation thought mightye tyll time philippe alexander destroyed hath man left scordiscians become noughtescordiscians paeonians also ouercome romaine came legth dwel ilands hister continuaunce tyme went abroade inuaded vttermost part nation illyria robbing ionium ilandes swifte shippes wherefore romaynes call shippes speede liburnians saying autarias came vtter destruction wrath apollo celtians wyth cymbrians encampe delphos cymbri came fro north saxon n onne fraunce vvhere marius ouercame punishment god dispearsed fledde many fight stroken raine tempest lightning wer left came home foud corruptio made frog water perished vapor whiche infected countrey illyria autarians plagued fled bycause man durst receyue went xxij dayes togither comming fennie grounde vnhabited buylded citty next basternia asturn e floud b risthenes scythia saye also apollo dyd destroy celtians theyr city ende plague fled left theyr house came illyria offered ke sickenesse soone ouercame handling irene hill diuideth fraunce spaine thing toke infection fledde pirene moued toward east romanes afraid foughte exceeding battayle sente consul least shoulde passe alpes come italy romaine hauing syllenus lius c p consul ouerthrovven
